column2: Blindfolded and dressed somewhere between princess drag and locker-room sweats, the four-man Austrian art collective Gelitin began a weeklong residency at Greene Naftali Gallery in Chelsea last night, working in a makeshift plywood arena before a dense crowd of oglers. Assisted by up to seven guest artists each day, with a performance by the art band XXX Macarena scheduled for Saturday at 7:30 p.m., Gelitin is building a completely mad, totemic sculpture made of fabric, rubber, glue, spools of thread, Styrofoam and whatnot, which they will be the last to see.

Quindel Francis, a 21-year-old Bronx man who spent the last five years in jail on charges of murdering a classmate, was convicted of manslaughter on Friday, bringing an end to a legal saga that had stretched through two mistrials.

Karmically speaking, we have to guess that the Sundance Film Festival is in pretty good shape. The Dalai Lama sent a "message of peace," which was broadcast during the Music 4 Peace Initiative press conference, an event attended by Dr. Arun Gandhi, the Def Jam founder Russell Simmons and the civil rights leader Dr. Benjamin Chavis, Jr. (Music 4 Peace also sponsored an appearance by Pras, the Haitian former member of the Fugees, who performed for Haitian Relief.) Less divinely, but only slightly, Robert Redford came down from the mountain last night to sit in on a panel with the author Naomi Klein and the director Michael Winterbottom, who together made "The Shock Doctrine," a documentary about Milton Friedman, the Chicago School of Economics, third-world corporate oppression and how countries like Haiti get that way. Great stuff. And if the connections with American independent cinema seem a bit, shall we say, loose, well that's all part of the Great Wheel of Life in Park City, Utah.But it's hardly a big mystery. When people whisper about the "dirty little secret" of Sundance (the jaded will say, "Uh, which one?"), they're usually talking about something else: that the documentaries are better than the features? (Yawn.) That the festival is as much about stars as anywhere else? (No kidding.) That when a film is introduced by someone who says, "It went through the Sundance lab ... but that's not why it's here," you know that's exactly why it's here? Old news. How about the fact that the festival's Volunteer Appreciation Day was celebrated Wednesday with the same enthusiasm that prison inmates would celebrate Corrections Officer Day? Tell us something we don't know.

Maplewood resident Jeanmarie Hargrave came to Words bookstore in Maplewood last night to say thanks. As a family member of a 9/11 victim, Ms. Hargrave was full of praise for the work of former New Jersey Gov. Thomas H. Kean.
News from the Weinstein Company that is not doom or gloom!

Updated, 4:30 p.m. BALTIMORE -- President Obama and the Congressional Republicans who have opposed him engaged in a lively and robust public debate this afternoon over health care, the economy and who was more to blame for the toxic atmosphere clouding the nation's politics.
From Glenn Collins at Diner's Journal:

The artist Andrew Kuo charts every track on "Diplo Presents: Free Gucci (Best of the Cold War Mixtapes)" a compilation of mixtape series tracks by the Atlanta rapper Gucci Mane, remixed by the likes of Flying Lotus, Salem, Zomby and Diplo himself. Gucci Mane's latest studio album, "The State vs. Radric Davis," came out late last year.

The state's planned seizure of property in Brooklyn to make way for the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project was delayed on Friday when a judge declined to rule immediately on the state's request for final approval.

Just when it appeared life couldn't get any worse for Toyota, the influential Consumer Reports magazine says it is withdrawing its "Recommended" label from eight Toyota models being recalled because the accelerator may stick.

Not yet 30 years old, Muhammed Basem Muheisen of The Associated Press is among the more prolific photojournalists out there. He was a member of the team that won the Pulitzer Prize in 2005 for breaking news photography, for a "stunning series of photographs of bloody yearlong combat inside Iraqi cities." In recent months, his work has been featured 18 times in Pictures of the Day; second only to his A.P. colleague, Altaf Qadri, in appearances by non-Times photographers. (Mr. Muheisen's latest, Slide 10, shows a family very much on the move in Rawalpindi, Pakistan.)

The global carbon market is expected to total $170 billion this year, a 33 percent jump from 2009, driven mostly by higher prices in Europe and a growth in the nascent carbon market in the United States, according to a new report from Point Carbon, a market analysis firm.

The I.P.O. pipeline in the United States is filling up as companies once afraid of braving the capital markets are now lining up to for initial public offerings. A fair number of these companies, especially in the financial industry, are looking to spin off businesses at lucrative prices.
This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America's up-and-coming talent.

Tell a seasoned trucker who drives a heavy-duty rig day in and day out that the Bose Corporation has made a product especially for him, and he'd probably guess that it's a new sound system or perhaps a fancy pair of noise canceling headphones to wipe out road noise.

In his extraordinary question-and-answer exchange with House Republicans, President Obama fielded a query from Representative Jason Chaffetz, a freshman from Utah, who asserted that Mr. Obama and Democrats had shut Republicans out of the health care debate and that the president had broken a campaign promise to let C-Span show health care negotiations on live television.

We talk about helicopter parenting as though this generation invented it whole cloth. True, we've perfected it - spurred by a changing world where being a parent is harder and is layered with more guilt. But overly involved parents (and those who wondered where the lines were) have been with us for generations.
What do the programs on Spike and Lifetime tell us about the sexes?
Reacting to a wave of interest in President Obama's televised dialogue with Congressional Republicans, C-Span said it would replay the session in prime time tonight.

It's T-4 days until the Oscar nominations are announced; the Bagger will be there to deliver some bleary-eyed analysis in person. In the meantime, awards watchers are weighing in on their predictions.

Frenzied bargain hunters who descended on the Tavern on the Green tag sale on Friday hardly entertained hopes of landing the $180,000 leaded-glass ceiling, as it was long gone. And they knew the $75,000 stained-glass peacock was but a memory.

In my latest Your Money column, I discuss the Obama administration's push to get more people to put some of their retirement money into simple annuities or other products that can provide a regular income stream for the rest of their lives.
All the fashion news of the week that's fit to reprint.
If you are happier than your wife, you may be at greater risk of divorce.

Jeff Bridges has deservedly earned some of the best reviews of his career for his role as Bad Blake, a washed-up country singer, in the movie "Crazy Heart." In interviews, Mr. Bridges has said he based the look and feel of the character on his friend Kris Kristofferson, among other musicians.
Reacting to a wave of interest in President Obama's televised dialogue with Congressional Republicans, C-Span said it would replay the session in prime time tonight.

Here's a look at another idea from the spring couture: garments with exceptional three-dimensional texture. Jean Paul Gaultier, right, used feathers, crisp fan pleating and basketweave details. Among his most dynamic looks were a cream day suit with a lattice jacket, and a stiff, semi-transparent skirt scattered with feathers and shown with a corseted white shirt/jacket.

This week: the music legend Patti Smith discusses her memoir, "Just Kids"; Rebecca Newberger Goldstein talks about her new novel, "36 Arguments for the Existence of God"; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)
The maker of Budweiser beer is having second thoughts about a decision to run commercials during Super Bowl XLIV that would not feature the brand's familiar Clydesdales.
The artist Steve McQueen discusses a scene from “Giardini,” a 30-minute film about the Venice Biennale's festival grounds in winter.
Cameron Lester and Mike Kwatinetz of Azure Capital Partners examine why start-up companies need to be time-efficient as well as capital-efficient.

N.H.L. Vice President Colin Campbell is not especially pleased with two prominent Canadian politicians, federal Finance Minister Jim Flaherty and Member of Parliament Ken Dryden, two men with hockey backgrounds who, as noted here yesterday, called for the league to take more of a leading role on the matter of checks to the head.
Update | 3:50 p.m. Part two of this post is here.

The Seattle Symphony's musicians and management have agreed on a contract after contentious negotiations that included a strike authorization. The agreement, which was announced on Thursday and still has to be ratified by both sides, includes a 5 percent pay cut through August with a complete restoration of the cut by early 2011 and a 1.5 percent raise at the beginning of the 2011-2012 season. The players also agreed to donate $2,010 each, or $168,840, back to the orchestra. The symphony's minimum wage is $78,750, not including the reduction, although most musicians earn more than that. The concessions by the players are in line with moves at many orchestras around the country during the recession.

Glistening fabrics gave the spring couture collections in Paris an extra quality of mystery. What were some of those glassy, textured, iridescent fabrics at Giorgio Armani? They were certainly otherworldly and made for an absorbing, different Armani Privé show. In addition to gorgeous silk satins, Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel used stockings with shimmer, embroidery that looked like melted nuggets of silver, and custom-made rocker boots in silver leather with rococo heals.

Laura Robson, who played on Britain's Hopman Cup team with Andy Murray to start the 2010 season, has replicated his success at the Australian Open by reaching Saturday's girls singles championship final. The Australian-born left-hander, a finalist in Melbourne last year, may not be seeded, but she is the favorite when she takes the court against No. 6-seeded Karolina Pliskova of the Czech Republic.
Ariel Kaminer visits a popular New York restaurant to get the lowdown on how chefs really cook with salt.

The Obama administration finally weighed in on Friday at the World Economic Forum, as Lawrence H. Summers, director of the National Economic Council, criticized banks that are resisting regulation even as they dispense lucrative bonuses to their executives.
Two University of Utah Web sites won Science's first award for online education materials.
1.) Tweets per minute from different cities around the world.
POTUS delivered his SOTU, with SCOTUS sitting right there in front of him.

Yielding to pressure from animal rights groups, Johnny Weir, the three-time national figure skating champion, said he would tweak the costume he had planned to wear in his long program at the Olympics, replacing the outfit's white fox fur with white faux fur.

Unlike their fashion brethren, young American furniture and product designers get little respect or attention in their native land, let alone in the sophisticated capitals of Europe. But now, in a surprising turn of events, they are being celebrated in Paris, the apogee of chic.On Jan. 21, Triode, a Left Bank gallery, opened "Americans in Paris," a show that features the work of over a dozen budding United States-based talents including Harry Allen, Mathilde Alessandra, Chris Ferebee, KleinReid, Paul Loebach, Jason Miller, Jeff Miller, Moorhead & Moorhead, John Pomp, Josh Owen, Jonah Takagi and Ali Tayar.
The blog "Classics Rock!" has reposted its list of songs referring to the works of J. D. Salinger.

"Saving Lives on the U.S.N.S. Comfort" (06:40)Brent and Craig Renaud have produced a remarkably intimate and detailed look at the challenges faced by rescuers in Haiti, from the vantage of the U.S. Naval Ship Comfort, a hospital ship anchored off Port-au-Prince. The video takes us inside the ship, where the crew works around the clock to save the lives of those injured in the quake. But we also learn about the difficulties of logistics on the ground, when it becomes clear that the lawn of the ideally situated National Palace cannot be used as a military heliport - to airlift the injured and dying to the ship - because the symbolism is so politically fraught. The scenes aboard the ship are heart-rending. We meet Corpsman Christopher Brossard, a Haitian-American who comforts a severely injured woman whose foot almost certainly has to be amputated. Scenes are expertly composed and moments that might otherwise be gruesome are infused with a tragic tenderness. These moments can be hard to watch, but they are a necessary part of telling a story like this one. (E.O.)

It's not only mayors and inveterate gamblers who place bets on the Super Bowl -- art museums do, too. The Times-Picayune reported that the New Orleans Museum of Art and the Indianapolis Museum of Art have placed a friendly wager on the outcome of the big game on Feb. 7: if the New Orleans Saints win, the Indianapolis museum will send "The Fifth Plague of Egypt" -- that is, the landscape from its collection painted by J.M.W. Turner in 1800 -- to the New Orleans museum, which gets to show it for three months. If the Indianapolis Colts prevail, the New Orleans institution will send the painting "Ideal View of Tivoli," a 1644 work by Claude Lorrain, to Indianapolis for three months. The Times-Picayune said the bet was instigated by Tyler Green, who writes the Modern Art Notes blog for artsjournal.com, and who helped egg on some tongue-in-cheek trash talk between the museums' directors. When E. John Bullard, the New Orleans museum director, offered to wager a valuable Renoir, his Indianapolis counterpart, Maxwell Anderson, dismissed it as a "sentimental blancmange". Mr. Bullard replied: "I am amused that Renoir is too sweet for Indianapolis. Does this mean that those Indiana corn farmers have simpler tastes?"
Manhola Dargis delivers an almost final word on Sundance, slicing through the hype and history to find that it's all still pretty worthwhile.
Village Voice columnist Michael Musto makes his nightly rounds with shoe leather, not Twitter.
Two Web sites created at the University of Utah's Genetic Science Learning Center were honored with the Science Prize for Online Resources in Education. (Science/AAAS)

This is not to diminish the seriousness of the fact that a man was recently murdered in a jewelry store holdup, but the sketch that the police released Wednesday got us wondering: how is this going to help anyone catch the killer?
In her column, We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman writes about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.

For the first time in its history, the University of California is expected to institute waiting lists for incoming applicants, possibly starting this spring. More than 1,000 applicants may be affected.

In case you missed it earlier in the week: this report on nj.com, about the arrest of four women, including two West Orange students, over extreme pledge practices at a Rutgers University sorority, is a reminder that we need to keep our dialogue going with our teens, college students and schools about hazing practices. For parents and teachers who are seeking a jumping-off point, College Corner took on the topic in October. -- Maureen P. Tillman

Most people seeing the J.D. Salinger obituary on Friday are probably remembering when they read "Catcher in the Rye." Richard A. Behrendt, a lawyer and estate planner at Robert W. Baird & Company, is a self-confessed tax geek, with a different perspective. He sends along the following:

BAGHDAD -- Laura al-Asadi has found her heaven in a cold and dusty apartment in Baghdad's Red Zone. Mrs. Asadi, a 49-year-old from Lincoln, Neb., has married an Iraqi and moved to Iraq's violence-ridden capital.

Frozen blueberries are one of the foods I wrote about in "The 11 Best Foods You Aren't Eating." These nutrient-rich fruits are available year-round and don't spoil, and blueberries have been associated with better memory in animal studies.
Monologue | Thursday night on "The Jay Leno Show" on NBC: How many of you watched President Obama's State of the Ruin, uh, State of the Union address?

It's a new year, and a new New York State budget proposal, but it's the same old deficit. So once again, Gov. David A. Paterson has proposed allowing New York groceries to sell wine as a means of raising revenue through license fees. Eric Asimov reviews this year's proposal on The Pour. Read the Post ».

Reggie Miller did not hit every big shot of his 18-year N.BA. career against the Knicks, but sometimes it felt that way. Miller, who is remembered as one of the great clutch performers of his generation, is the star of an ESPN documentary, "Winning Time: Reggie Miller vs. the New York Knicks." The film, which will be broadcast on March 14, highlights the Knicks-Pacers rivalry and focuses on Miller's legendary performance in the 1995 playoffs. In Game 1 of that series, Miller scored 8 points in 18.7 seconds to break the Knicks' hearts and give Indiana a come-from-behind victory at Madison Square Garden. Whether it was feuding courtside with Spike Lee or butting heads with Knicks like John Starks, Miller was at the center of the rivalry.

It's been the dream of many a producer -- and perhaps the nightmare of many a faithful reader -- that J. D. Salinger's novel "The Catcher in the Rye" might someday be translated to another medium. In a report for The Associated Press, Hillel Italie writes that Mr. Salinger considered a stage version of the novel in which he himself would play its teenage protagonist, Holden Caulfield. That (mercifully) never happened; nor did offers for film adaptations from Billy Wilder, Elia Kazan, Steven Spielberg and Harvey Weinstein, all of which the author summarily turned down.

Over on our sister blog, Wheels, Cheryl Jensen writes that laws banning cellphone use while driving have not resulted in a reduction in car crashes. The study was conducted by the Highway Loss Data Institute.

It's a new year, and a new New York State budget proposal, but it's the same old deficit. So once again, Gov. David A. Paterson has proposed allowing New York groceries to sell wine as a means of raising revenue through license fees.
I taught "The Scarlet Letter" eight times in my classroom career, and got to the point where I could reel off whole passages by memory.

The death of J. D. Salinger, whose life remained private in a way few celebrities could imagine possible for today (Tiger Woods en tête), left many blogging in the blanks of his life or else reliving those few moments, literary or otherwise, they spent with the man.

Our colleagues over at the Motherlode blog note that the British government has just approved a paid paternity leave system that allows men to stay home for up to three months, under certain circumstances, to take care of a newly arrived child.

Sheila Bair, the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said on Friday that proposed proprietary trading limits are "very positive," but said they would not have necessarily reined in risk-taking at the institutions that required huge bailouts.

BlackRock said Friday that it had hired a former Goldman Sachs banker, Kendrick R. Wilson, to be a vice chairman and help support the firm's client relations as the firm solidifies its position as one of the world's largest asset managers. Mr. Wilson's large Rolodex could help BlackRock's win new clients as well as help it gain a louder voice in Washington.
The Frugal Traveler, Matt Gross, gives a quick course on the Ramen Mania culture in Tokyo. There is an art to ordering well and eating well.
Representative Steve Buyer, a veteran Indiana Republican, announced today that he would not seek re-election this year.

We can't stress this enough: Washington is the dominant topic at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this year. Between the panels and at the parties, political and business leaders from around the world keep asking whether or not the Obama administration can pull off its ambitious initiatives.
If you've lost your job, or suffered a big drop in income, you may have a significantly different tax situation from previous years.
Kai Eide, the U.N. representative, spoke with members of the Taliban leadership this month to discuss the possibility of peace talks, officials said.
Canada’s Supreme Court criticized the interrogation of Omar Khadr, the country’s only citizen held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, but did not order the government to demand his repatriation.
California officials have indicated they are not inclined to regulate electric car infrastructure companies that plan to sell electricity to drivers through networks of charging stations.
After scores of states applied for a competitive education grant known as Race to the Top last week, the vast majority of states posted their applications online for all to see.

While watching my daughter's volleyball practice from the sidelines recently, I struck up a conversation with another mom who looked, quite frankly, awful. "Migraine,'' she explained, wincing as she spoke.
Honda said it was recalling about 141,000 2007-8 Honda Fits in the United States because of a fire hazard involving the power-window switch.
This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: America's up-and-coming talent.

Sly Stone has filed a lawsuit against his longtime manager, Jerry Goldstein, saying that Mr. Goldstein defrauded him of "tens of millions of dollars" in royalties for more than 20 years, and that he registered a trademark for the name Sly and the Family Stone without permission. In the suit, filed on Thursday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Sly Stone (whose real name is Sylvester Stewart) and another former manager, Ken Roberts, request an accounting of royalties and unspecified financial damages that their lawyers estimate at $20 million to $30 million. (The musician previously told his side of the story in this 2008 profile in Vanity Fair.)

For some of us, the feeling we get from helping our kids with their math homework ranks right up there with that awful brain-freezing headache that happens when you eat an ice cream too fast : face-scrunching pain.

Over at The Lede blog, our colleague Rogene Fisher is covering the grilling of Tony Blair by the Iraq Inquiry. (You can see live video of the proceedings on the Web site of The Guardian.) John F. Burns also reports from inside the Queen Elizabeth II conference center in London, saying the inquiry has given Mr. Blair "an unusually prominent platform to map out his own version of a history that has brought much vilification in his own land."
Several hotels and tour companies are offering sweetheart deals, some lasting the entire month of February.

Shipments of California wine fell last year for the first time in 16 years, The Los Angeles Times reports. "Consumption of wine is up 2.1% nationally, but industry analyst Jon Fredrikson told the audience at the annual Unified Wine & Grape Symposium on Wednesday that the American public was snubbing tonier bottles from the Golden State and instead opting for cheaper bulk wine imports from overseas winemakers." And in Australia, imports are up and the value of Australian wine sales are down.

When Andrew Castrucci moved into a tenement on East 3rd Street in 1986, he arrived not with a real estate agent and a new set of keys but with two accomplices who stood watch as he used a 10-pound sledgehammer to smash through cinder blocks filling a rear door to the derelict building.

Pen and Brush, a nonprofit space in Greenwich Village for public exhibitions and performances and earlier a private club where women gathered for teas and dinner, has found a buyer for its historic town house on East 10th Street, its executive director, Janice Sands, confirmed on Friday.
Q.

Back in 1993, when I was a sophomore in college, I came across a movie that changed my life: "Tampopo," the charming tale of a truck driver who comes to the aid of a young, beleaguered widow who's struggling to raise a child-and run a ramen shop. The movie, directed by the late Juzo Itami, is all about food-about the intricacies of making ramen and eating ramen, about slurping noodles, about the ways that what we eat and how we eat make us who we are.

In the catalog for the artist Mark Dion's project "Travels of William Bartram - Reconsidered," now on view at the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery, Dion is quoted as saying, "I like things - not pictures or facsimiles of things." This is a little like Michael Bloomberg saying he likes being mayor: inarguably true, and more than a bit of an understatement.

This morning, as President Obama visits a small business in Baltimore to unveil a temporary tax credit to encourage the hiring of new employees, The Agenda would like to fill you in on the details. The initiative, which would require Congress's assent, is more generous than earlier versions that have floated around Washington, and it's tailored more specifically for small businesses.

Pete Confalone, an old friend and a faithful correspondent who lives in Miami, sends this hilarious clip from the Huffington Post. Italy has arranged with McDonald's to use local produce and traditional flavors on a couple of burgers. This is along the lines of making a Mickey D's burger with (sugary sweet) barbecue sauce to somehow regionalize it -- but is it better (i.e., artichoke puree is good stuff) or worse (i.e. it puts a friendlier face on fast food)? More amusing than monstrous, I suppose, but your comments?
BALTIMORE -- It's the rumble in Baltimore as House Republicans take on President Obama today.

The financial markets are returning to measurable health and consequently private equity firms are now doing deals more frequently, even those particularly hurt. Apollo Management, scarred by the Huntsman/Hexion acquisition, has a pending acquisition of Cedar Fair, and TPG, which posted a $1.35 billion loss after its investment in Washington Mutual, is acquiring IMS Health. About a week ago, Lone Star Funds agreed to acquire Lodgian in a deal valued at $270 million.
This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit malapropisms - either those they have overheard or those of which they are guilty.
Update | 1:09 p.m. No Regrets.

Like an alien's scarred cranium, an orange Mars rose slowly above the stage of Carnegie Hall. Later, Venus hung suspended, an alabaster orb in the darkness. Strips of Jupiter's surface of swirling colors looked like canvases of abstract art. Moons made guest appearances.

Entertainment personalities are continuing their efforts to raise awareness and money for the earthquake relief effort in Haiti. On Thursday, BET Networks said that it would hold a benefit concert and celebrity telethon for Haitian charity organizations, to be presented on several cable channels on the night of Feb. 5. The event, to be called "SOS Saving Ourselves - Help For Haiti," will take place at the AmericanAirlines Arena in Miami and will be hosted by Queen Latifah;, Sean Combs, known as Diddy; and Pharrell Williams. It is to be shown from 8 to 10 p.m. Eastern time on BET, MTV, VH1 and the Centric channel, with proceeds going to charity organizations like Yéle Haiti, CARE, Project Medishare and Children's Safe Drinking Water. A full lineup of artists for the concert has not been announced, but Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-born musician and founder of Yéle Haiti, is expected to perform at the event.

A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Overview | What threats exist to Internet freedom, and how can people and democratic governments combat them? In this lesson, students imagine how they might communicate, and evade censors, if they were antigovernment activists. They then look more closely at the issues involved in the dispute between Google and China and develop ideas for how Google or the United States government should respond. Finally, they do independent research to learn more about the types of information that the Chinese government has sought to block online.
He strolled into the mostly empty room on Wednesday, jolly as can be. He looked the part of a public figure, with his black suit, navy blue tie stamped with small ducks, and tortoiseshell glasses.

With a stalled peace process, Israeli soldiers and Palestinian protesters clash violently each Friday. 
The skirmishes are a combination of desperate activism and staged theater.

Even with the lower celebrity wattage of this year's World Economic Forum, there are still important political and business leaders wandering around the ski resort that is Davos, Switzerland this week.

Bain Capital said Friday that it has invested $12 million in Edgar Online, a publicly traded data services company that helps businesses prepare regulatory filings in a new format that will be mandatory by 2012.
Michael Pagano, a finance professor at Villanova, argues that the Volcker Rule resembles another attempt to turn back progress -- namely, the Luddite movement of nearly 200 years ago.
This Mark Schmitt piece on the tug-of-war within liberalism dovetails with some of the themes I've been exploring lately. He writes:

Are comic books the new lease on life for television series that have ended their runs? There certainly seem to be more adventures in store for characters created by Joss Whedon. He's already been involved in the comic-book version of Season 8 of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," which is published by Dark Horse. (There are even plans to reunite her with - spoiler alert! - Angel). This week, another of Mr. Whedon's television creations enters our softcover list at No. 3. "Serenity: Better Days" continues the journey of the space-faring crew from the 2002 television series "Firefly." The show was canceled early in its first season, but its characters returned in the 2005 film "Serenity" and as a comic book, "Serenity: Those Left Behind."

The women's and men's finals of the Australian Open will be shown live this weekend when many people in the United States will be asleep. But each match will then be shown on tape several times.
This week's Complaint Box features two views on dogs in public, from Barbara Rosenblatt and Erica Manfred.
With strong interest from corporations eyeing the clean energy sector, 2010 could turn out to be a good time for private equity and venture capital firms to pursue investments.

The annual lunch hosted by Ukrainian powerbroker and philanthropist Viktor Pinchuk in Davos has often been a bellwether for the tangled politics of the huge country of 46 million sandwiched between Russia and Europe.
As expected, a big GDP number (pdf), signifying nothing much. It's an inventory blip: topline growth at 5.7 percent, but only 2.2 of that is final demand.

Danica Patrick said Thursday that she planned to compete this year in at least 12 races on the Nascar Nationwide Series, the second highest level in the sport. Officials at the racetracks where she expects to compete promptly stomped on their marketing accelerators to sell tickets.

The momentary disappearance of Conan O'Brien from the airwaves brought peace to the late-night landscape for, oh, about four days. On Thursday night, the surviving combatants were reapplying their war paint as the ABC host Jimmy Kimmel used his monologue to rebut Jay Leno, who said that Mr. Kimmel had "sucker-punched" him in an earlier interview on Mr. Leno's show. And by rebut, we mean pound him mercilessly.
As Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo readies his candidacy for governor, one industry is helping him amass a huge fund-raising advantage: real estate.

The London-based shoe wizard Chrissie Morris had a lot on her mind when she designed this multifunctional stiletto of rock python, stingray and suede. Inspired by the cagelike structure inside a Gothic church cupola, the shoe has a detachable suede ankle strap (not shown) so you can wear it --- get this -- three different ways. It's not exactly cheap ($1,390 at kirnazabete.com), but this kind of ingenuity is oh so New Economy.
Two days after calling for more cooperation between Democrats and Republicans, President Obama heads to Baltimore for a discussion with House Republicans at their retreat.

Good morning from Davos, where the topic of the day isn't anything that happened during the official panels of the World Economic Forum.

The idea of integrating solar power with building materials has been an attractive concept for decades, but one of the biggest challenges, according to Anna Dyson, director of the Center for Architecture Science and Ecology, or CASE, has been aesthetics.

Right-thinking ArtsBeat readers can agree that J.D. Salinger was no phony. The Times's chief book critic, Michiko Kakutani, writes in an appraisal that the author, who died Wednesday at 91, had "unerring radar for the feelings of teenage angst and vulnerability and anger," and that "The Catcher in the Rye," published in 1951, "remains one of the books that adolescents first fall in love with - a book that intimately articulates what it is to be young and sensitive and precociously existential."

Steven D. Black, the executive chairman of JPMorgan Chase's investment bank, was named a vice chairman of the firm on Thursday, as part of a plan to give more responsibility to the investment banking head, James E. Staley.

After The Wall Street Journal reported that banks were doling out other financial perks to their employees to ease the toll taken by the slimmer bonuses, Gawker got busy investigating Goldman Sachs's lending practices.

BART to Avoid Fare Increases, for Now | On Thursday, BART directors said they would not raise fares or cut service to help close a $25.2 million shortfall in the current budget. Although the transportation agency said it would cut 74 positions, 55 of those are vacant, 12 employees can transfer to another job and the number to be laid off can be reduced further if there is more turnover. BART will also rely on $19.2 million in stimulus and other funds to help close the gap. Proposals, like imposing a surcharge of 10 or 25 cents for rides through the Transbay Tube, were bypassed for now. "We believe those charges would have a negative impact on our already soft ridership," said Carter Mau, BART's executive manager for planning and budgets. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

There are a few similarities between Wednesday's Apple announcement and the blockbuster movie "Avatar." They both cost many millions of dollars and took many years to produce. They both required vast amounts of technology to build, and of course they will both make hundreds of millions of dollars for their respective companies. But they will also share another category: too much hype before their launch, and a result that comes across as intriguing and entertaining, yet sadly anticlimactic.

Real estate securitization was one of the great innovations in finance in the last quarter-century. In an unprecedented way, it allowed vast sums of money to go into the real estate market from people who traditionally did not take part in it. But the people making the loans did not need to worry if they would be repaid, and in the end the entire edifice collapsed.

Hull, a former United States ambassador to Yemen, first traveled to that country’s more dangerous areas in an earlier American effort to foster aid projects. It was 2002, not 2003.

Roasted winter squash and carrot bisque from “21” Club or Jean-Claude’s lobster bisque from Chez Josephine: Could there be more perfect meals for a cold winter day? You can choose either one — or both — at the NYC Restaurant Week Truck, which will be parked on Broadway between 50th and 51st today. In honor of restaurant week, the city is offering soups from 24 of the city’s restaurants, including Le Cirque, Blue Water Grill, Tribeca Grill, Delmonico’s Steakhouse and many more. The soups cost $6 and come with bread from Tom Cat Bakery. Even better, $1 from every NYC Restaurant Week Truck purchase will go to The Haiti Relief Fund at the Mayor’s Fund to Advance New York City. The truck is on the move through Feb. 5, so check the Web site for times and locations.

Despite many attempts to revive Coney Island, for most New Yorkers the former resort still conjures images that are more likely to resemble a Diane Arbus photograph than a charming Victorian postcard. But Save Coney Island, the volunteer nonprofit organization, hopes to change that. This Saturday, the group, which is working to restore Coney Island to an amusement destination, is hosting “Gone Country for Coney,” a Country Jamboree at Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo. The all-day benefit event, which begins at 3 p.m. and runs through 9:30 p.m., features performances by rock, country and blue-grass groups, including Citigrass, Piñataland, the 2009 fiddle champion Rob Hecht, Central Valley Wildfire and Animal Pharm. The program will also feature dance performances by the Prospect Cowgirls and plenty of BBQ and raffle prizes, not to mention an after-concert burlesque.

Rain Machine is a side project of Kyp Malone from TV on the Radio, and it “leaves no question as to exactly where Mr. Malone’s main band gets its churn and melancholy,” writes Jon Caramanica. Mr. Malone will be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday, with Anti-Pop Consortium, for Sounds Like Brooklyn. The music festival, in its fourth year, features an eclectic mix from the neighborhood — one that seems to have a knack for churning out really great bands. Head to BAM tonight for a totally different pairing when Les Savy Fav headlines a show that also includes the Vivian Girls, “whose wistfully melodic no-fi dream-pop will probably be the haziest sound ever featured in the Academy’s Howard Gilman Opera House.” The festival continues next weekend, Feb. 4-6, with shows all around the borough, featuring Dred Scott Trio, The Sweet Divines, The Antlers, Rose Parade and more.

BAKER--C. Edwin (Ed). A public Memorial Service honoring the life of C. Edwin (Ed) Baker will be held Sunday, January 31 in the Moot Court Room at Cardozo School of Law, 55 Fifth Avenue (5th Ave. at 12th St.), New York City at 2pm. Professor Baker, age 62, died unexpectedly on December 8, 2009. At the time of his death he was the Nicholas F. Gallicchio Professor of Law and Professor of Communication at the University of Pennsylvania. He also held a joint appointment at Penn's Annenberg School of Communications. Ed Baker was one of the nation's leading constitutional law and media policy scholars. He published four books, Media Concentration and Democracy: Why Ownership Matters (Cambridge, 2007), Media, Markets, and Democracy (Cambridge, 2002), Advertising and a Democratic Press (Princeton, 1994), and Human Liberty and Freedom of Speech (Oxford, 1989). He also authored over 70 articles and book chapters, as well as numerous op-ed pieces, including two in the New York Times. Yale Professor Jack Balkin describes Ed Baker as "the finest media law scholar of his generation." Professor Monroe Price, the director of the Annenberg Center for Global Communication Studies states: "There was no scholar so committed, passionate, disciplined and wise in thinking through the relationship between the media and the political system." Professor Robert McChesney of SavetheNews.org writes that: "It is impossible to gauge the immensity of the loss with Ed Baker's passing. His commitment to a strong free press and a vibrant democracy guided all of his work." Baker's most recent work focused on equality and on the threats to democracy posed by the concentration of media ownership, the subject of his recent testimony before Congress. Raised in Madisonville, Kentucky, Ed Baker was a graduate of Stanford University and Yale College of Law. He was a fellow at Harvard three times, most recently at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study. He was a resident of Greenwich Village for over 20 years. Ed was predeceased by his parents, Falcon O. and Ernestine Magagna Baker. He is survived by his sister, Dr. Nancy Lynn Baker of El Granada, CA, a professor at Fielding Graduate University, her spouse Cathy Hauer, seven first cousins, a number of close longtime friends, and his girlfriend Jennifer Mathews. His cremated remains will be interred in April in Madisonville, KY. Memorial Contributions in his honor should be made to the ACLU, the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, Oxfam, or another charity honoring Ed's commitment to human rights and free speech.

HUNNEWELL--Francis Oakes, 71, died of a pulmonary embolism on January 24th while on a business trip in Tbilisi, Georgia. St. Paul's '56, Harvard College '60, Harvard Business School '65. Officer in U.S Navy on U.S.S. Kitty Hawk, '63-'65. Investment banker with focus on emerging markets, including North Africa, South America, Asia, and Eastern Europe. Deals included the financing of the modern telecom system in Saudi Arabia and the development of the Charleston Navy Yard in Boston. Chairman of From The Top, the NPR radio show which features classical musicians between the ages of eight and eighteen. Former Chairman of the Boston Philharmonic, board member of Walnut Hill School for the Performing Arts. Former trustee of the New England Conservatory and Earthwatch. Former co-Chairman of the Arts in Education Committee, Harvard School of Education. "Butch," as he was known to his friends, was an eclectic collector of art and artifacts, including an Indian elephant saddle and a Chinese opium bed. He never met a museum or a castle ruin he didn't like. His pronounced sartorial tastes veered from Borselino hats and pin-stripe suits to Stetsons. But his greatest love, apart from his family, was his land in Wellesley where he could be found in boots and goggles, covered in wood chips, clearing brush and riding a cherry-picker. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth, his three children, Susannah Hunnewell Weiss of New York, Francis Oakes Hunnewell Jr. of Wellesley and Lee Hunnewell Alphen of Paris, his brother H. Hollis Hunnewell of Nahant and his sister Lisa Hunnewell von Clemm of London, and six grandchildren. Memorial service on February 5 at 3pm at Harvard's Memorial Church in Cambridge, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to From The Top and Walnut Hill School.

For years, every morning, the sight has been the same at Marcy and Division Avenues in Williamsburg, Brooklyn: a crowd of women gathered on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway overpass in the din of traffic. They are day laborers, looking for work cleaning houses of nearby residents. There were originally maybe 40 or 50, according to veterans of the hiring corner. And like many traditions that grow up out of necessity around New York City, this gathering of cleaning women had certain unwritten codes, accepted patterns that all the women acknowledged.

DALY--Carolyn K.,83, recently of Nazareth, PA (formerly of Easton, PA), passed away peacefully at St. Luke's Hospice Center in Bethlehem, PA, on August 28, 2009, following a sudden but short respiratory illness. Carolyn was surrounded by her loving husband, John H. Daly; their five children; two grandchildren, and a daughter-in-law and son-in-law. Carolyn was born on March 1, 1926 in Brooklyn, NY. She was the youngest child (with her twin brother Ralph) of the late Ralph and Carolyn (Kirwin) Keating of Scarsdale, NY. Carolyn was raised in Scarsdale, NY, and graduated from Scarsdale High School. Carolyn then attended and graduated from Trinity College, a women's college in Washington, DC, where she majored in English. Following college, Carolyn was employed by Look Magazine in New York City prior to her marriage on June 23, 1951. Following her marriage, Carolyn was employed at Lafayette College in Easton, PA, until the birth of her first child, John M. Daly. Following her last child's graduation from college, Carolyn worked for many years as Administrative Assistant to the Pastor at the Palmer Moravian Church in Palmer Township, PA. Carolyn was very active in her community, serving as a Trustee of the YWCA of Easton, PA, and as a member of the Board of Managers for The Easton Home. In 1991, Carolyn was honored for her many years of service to the American Association of University Women with an AAUW national graduate grant awarded in her name by the Eleanor Roosevelt Fund. Carolyn served as the President of the URW Club of Easton, where she organized at least two bus trips per year for many years to cultural and historic venues up and down the East Coast. Carolyn was an avid bridge player, belonging to numerous weekly bridge clubs. Carolyn loved literature, symphony, theater, opera, and ballet, as well as LaFayette basketball which she followed closely. Carolyn enjoyed sports, including bowling and golf, and for several seasons coached a girl's softball team in Palmer Township, PA. Carolyn's greatest joy came from spending time with her beloved husband, children, and grandchildren, at family gatherings on holidays and summer vacations each year. Carolyn was truly the center of her family, around whom all activities revolved. She enjoyed a wide circle of friends throughout her life, all of whom will remember her for her kindness, great sense of humor, commitment to her Catholic faith, dignity, and strength of character. Her memory will live on in the hearts of all who knew her. Carolyn is survived by her husband, John H. Daly, recently of Nazareth, PA (formerly of Easton, PA); three sons, John M. Daly, of Union City, NJ; David M. Daly, of Keyport, NJ; and James C. Daly, of Indianapolis, IN; two daughters, Mary Einkauf, of Acton, MA; and Ann P. Daly, of Topsfield, MA. Carolyn has sixteen grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Her twin brother, Dr. Ralph Keating, lives in Centerville, OH. A wake for family members and friends was held at Finegan Funeral Home, 1837 Washington Boulevard, Wilson Borough, PA on Wednesday, September 2, 2009, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at the Holy Family Church in Nazareth, PA on Thursday, September 3, 2009. Interment was at Holy Savior Cemetery, Bethlehem, PA.

8 P.M. (ABC) SUPER-MANNY SPECIAL: GRISWOLD FAMILY Climb back into your London taxi cab, Jo Frost. Mike Ruggles, above, a native Chicagoan and ''manny'' with more than 17 years of experience as a teacher and developmental therapist for children, goes up against a family of six from Colorado in this hourlong spinoff of ''Supernanny.'' And at times it seems that he has met his match. Allan Griswold, a working father with a short fuse, terrifies his brood by yelling and making threats. Roberta, a stay-at-home mother, feels like a failure and lets her four children run all over her. About those kids: Joe, 7, curses, makes obscene gestures and brutalizes his sister Lauren, 11. Brianna, 16, berates her mother and already drinks enough to have wound up in the hospital for alcohol poisoning. Even Alex, 2, hasn't escaped his brother's and father's wrath unscathed. 8 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER Detectives Lupo (Jeremy Sisto) and Bernard (Anthony Anderson) investigate the murder of a rich young woman found dead in her apartment. But why were suitcases filled with money and drugs left behind?

Emergency snow stockpiles at the resort hosting freestyle skiing and snowboarding for the Winter Olympics in Vancouver are more than ample to cover any further thaw, the organizing committee said Thursday. An exceptional warm spell brought rain to the lower portions of Cypress Mountain in suburban Vancouver earlier this month and forced the organizing committee to close the resort to the public two and a half weeks sooner than scheduled. News photos showing muddy ground in some areas that are not being used for the Games raised concerns last week about the ability to stage events.

My Sunday column is the first of several from eastern Congo, site of the most lethal conflict since World War II -- and perhaps the most under-covered. There are of course many problems in the world, many demands on our conscience. But the Congo war seems to me particularly important because of the death toll (already 5.4 million as of April 2007); the savagery or rape and mutilation directed at civilians; and the prospect that some pressure and heavy diplomacy could resolve it. Moreover, without that pressure and diplomacy, it will continue unabated for years to come. I do think that the news media have dropped the ball on this one, but that may reflect the new media realities in which television reporting in particular from abroad just falls off the map.

The Times just published an article about small businesses, desperate for credit, who turn to purchase-order financing to keep their operations running. The reporter, Andrew Martin, talked to business owners who pay interest rates as high as 40 percent on an annualized basis to borrow money from a purchase-order lender, Hartsko Financial Services, whose New York City offices are in Queens, right above an acupuncture clinic that used to be a massage parlor. Richard Eitelberg, Hartsko's founder and president, says his business was up 80 percent in 2009.

Since there's probably not a whole lot of jumping for joy at Toyota these days, this week's classic ad looks back to happier times for the company: namely the 1980s, when its reputation for quality and dependability -- and its loyal customer base -- was still being built. An essay on Tuesday about caring for a terminally ill parent gave an incorrect side effect for lithium, a drug given for bipolar disorder. Lithium was not responsible for the liver damage found in the writer’s father because the drug is filtered and excreted by the kidneys.

The Reuters Breakingviews column on Thursday, about the lessons to carmakers in Toyota’s recent problems, misstated Toyota’s market status relative to that of General Motors. Pen and Brush, a nonprofit space in Greenwich Village for public exhibitions and performances, has found a buyer for its historic town house on East 10th Street, its executive director, Janice Sands, said on Friday. The sale has yet to be completed, Ms. Sands said. The buyer, Heirloom Trust, offered $13 million; the asking price was $13.5 million. On Wednesday, members of Pen and Brush voted to approve the sale. The organization determined that the 1848 building, its home of more than 80 years, was no longer suited to its mission and that repairs would be too costly. It has found new space on East 22nd Street, between Broadway and Park Avenue South. Ms. Sands said the new site, on which Pen and Brush is still in negotiations, offers about three times the current exhibition space.

The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture will mark Black History Month with two major new exhibitions: one features photographs of President Obama’s first year in the White House; the other showcases watercolors by Jerry Pinkney that depict people and events in African-American history from colonial times to the Voting Rights Act of 1965. On view together under the theme of “365 Days: 390 Years in the Making,” the two exhibitions will be on display Feb. 5 through April 18. “President Barack Obama: The First Year,” features 77 photographs by Pete Souza, the chief White House photographer for Mr. Obama. “African-American Journey to Freedom,” brings together 35 watercolors by Mr. Pinkney, an award-winning artist and illustrator.

It’s not only mayors and inveterate gamblers who place bets on the Super Bowl — art museums do, too. The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported that the New Orleans Museum of Art and the Indianapolis Museum of Art have placed a friendly wager on the outcome of the big game on Feb. 7: if the New Orleans Saints win, the Indianapolis museum will send “The Fifth Plague of Egypt” — that is, the landscape from its collection painted by J.M.W. Turner in 1800 — to the New Orleans museum, which gets to hang it for three months. If the Indianapolis Colts prevail, the New Orleans institution will send the painting “Ideal View of Tivoli,” a 1644 work by Claude Lorrain, to Indianapolis for three months. The Times-Picayune said the bet was instigated by Tyler Green, who writes the Modern Art Notes blog for artsjournal.com, and who helped egg on some tongue-in-cheek trash talk between the museums’ directors. When E. John Bullard, the New Orleans museum director, offered to wager a valuable Renoir, his Indianapolis counterpart, Maxwell Anderson, dismissed it as a “sentimental blancmange.” Mr. Bullard replied: “I am amused that Renoir is too sweet for Indianapolis. Does this mean that those Indiana corn farmers have simpler tastes?”.

Sly Stone, below, has filed a lawsuit against his longtime manager, Jerry Goldstein, saying that Mr. Goldstein defrauded him of “tens of millions of dollars” in royalties for more than 20 years and that he registered a trademark for the name Sly and the Family Stone without permission. In the suit, filed on Thursday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Sly Stone (whose real name is Sylvester Stewart) and another former manager, Ken Roberts, request an accounting of royalties and unspecified financial damages that their lawyers estimate at $20 million to $30 million. On Thursday, Jay M. Coggan, Mr. Goldstein’s lawyer, said that the case was without merit, and that the accusations had been made before. He said Sly Stone and his bandmates had given written approval for the trademark, and added: “Mr. Stewart would like to rewrite history. He would like to get everything back even though he owes money.”.

BERNSTEIN--Alan D.,age 52, passed away on January 27, 2010. Born and raised in New York, Alan was a loving son of Marvin and Trudy, devoted husband to Janet and father to Eric and Kate, and adored brother of Steven and Gail. We will forever remember and will sorely miss Alan's unselfish love and devotion to his family, his unique intellectual gifts, and his indomitable spirit in the face of life's many challenges. Alan left us way too soon. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, on Sunday January 31, 2010, at 11:30am.

Lawmakers in the lower house of Haiti's Parliament plan to ask President René Préval to postpone coming elections and instead extend their terms of office by two years, United Nations officials said on Friday. The elections are set for Feb. 28 in most of the nation and for March 3 in the center of the country. Haiti, still unable to provide basic services more than two weeks after a crippling earthquake, is in no position to hold nationwide parliamentary elections, according to a United Nations spokesman. The government's central elections office was devastated, and some United Nations workers who had been enlisted to help Haiti carry out the vote were killed in the quake. Voting machines have been crushed and voter records destroyed, and hundreds of thousands of voters have scattered to the Haitian interior or are camped out in tent cities throughout Port-au-Prince.

An article on Jan. 1 about a court decision to dismiss the indictment of former Blackwater security guards over a shooting in Baghdad in 2007 that left 17 Iraqis dead misstated, in some copies, the number of guards affected. It was five, not four. (The error was repeated in an article on Jan. 8 about the arrest of two other former guards for the company on murder charges from a shooting in Afghanistan last May.) And because of an editing error, the Jan. 1 article misstated, in some copies, the circumstances under which the company, now called Xe Services, was operating in Iraq after the 2007 shooting. It was working without a formal operating license while trying to get one; it was not trying to keep an existing license. (The same error appeared in an article on April 4, 2009, about job prospects for former guards in Iraq after the company lost its contract to protect American diplomats there.)
People are dying in Haiti because they can't get out. DR. BARTH GREEN, on the suspension of medical evacuations of critically injured Haitian earthquake victims to the United States. [A15]

ROTH--Fred. Died peacefully at home in Boynton Beach, FL on January 29 at age 93. Mr. Roth is survived by his beloved wife of fifty five years Virginia (Von der Linden) Roth, devoted sons and daughters-in-law Steven and Daryl, David and Karen, Richard and Andrea, Jeffrey and Debbie, and Delfina Faria Da Silva who has been in the family for 38 years, his adoring grandchildren Amanda, Jordan, Benjamin, Brennen, Brielle, Chelsea and Jamon, and loving great-grandchildren Rebecca, Abigail, Emily and Jackson. The son of Sam and Lena Roth, Mr. Roth was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Erasmus Hall High School. He lived in Riverdale, NY, Tenafly, NJ and finally Boynton Beach, FL. Predeceased by siblings Sigismund, Doris, Jules and Millie. Mr. Roth and his wife Virginia met as students at Arthur Murray's dance studio in New York City and married in 1954. He built his own children's clothing manufacturing company, Wonderland Fashions, his life-long business, from which he retired in 1994. A lifelong lover of golf, Mr. Roth was a member of Briar Hall Country Club, Alpine Country Club and Hunter's Run Country Club and Community. A Memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 2 at 11am at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, New York City.

Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 12 about the effects of Europe's prolonged cold weather misstated the initials of France's state-owned rail operator, and a correction in this space on Jan. 20 misstated the operator's full name. The operator is known as S.N.C.F., not S.C.N.F. And the initials stand for Société Nationale des Chemins de Fer Français -- not for Société national chemins de fer France.

We extend sincere condolences to his family. Alan Levine, Chairperson Blaine (Fin) Fogg, President Steven Banks, Attorney-in-Chief

GARNER--Paul J.,81, died January 19 of a cerebral hemorrhage in his native St. Catharines, Ontario. Trained as pianist and actor, he worked in Decca Records Artists and Repertoire division in London before becoming personal secretary to soprano Joan Sutherland and her husband, conductor Richard Bonynge, but he was best known in the opera world for his 26 years service as personal secretary to Placido Domingo. His gentlemanly demeanor, acerbic sense of humor and vast store of backstage lore helped satisfy Mr. Domingo's many professional suitors even when they were being kept at bay. Paul won the affection not only of the Domingo family but of all who knew him. He is survived by 13 nieces and nephews. There will be a memorial service January 30 at 10am at Lookout Ridge Retirement Residence in Fonthill, Ontario. Donations in his name may be made to the Ontario Heart and Stroke Foundation (www.heartandstroke.on.ca).

We benefited enormously from his counsel and have been enriched by his leadership and humanity. We are thankful for the time he shared with us and will miss him greatly. James R. KEATES--Richard H.,M.D. Rest in peace dear friend. Susan and Sol Liebowitz

MON TOY--Mary, 93, died on December 7, 2009 in her beloved New York City. A triple threat: Latin Quarter showgirl; original Broadway cast member in The World of Suzy Wong and House of Flowers; on television on Kojak, Ryan's Hope, Teahouse of the August Moon, I Spy and Drs. Hospital; in movies in Airplane II and Bob Fosse's All That Jazz. She was the first Asian runway model in Paris. Born in Hawaii, her family moved to Seattle in the 1920's only to be uprooted and sent to the Minidoka Japanese American Internment Camp after Pearl Harbor. She left the camp in 1944 on a scholarship to Juilliard procured by Eleanor Roosevelt. The rest of her life was spent in New York City where she was an active member of Screen Actors Guild, AFTRA and Actors' Equity, and generous supporter of The Actors Fund, animal rights and The Japanese American National Museum. A celebration of her life will take place on Sunday, January 31 at 1pm. Call 212-580-0052 for information.

SCHAFFNER--Dr. Bertram H. Schaffner, 97, renowned as a psychiatrist and widely known as a collector of Indian art, died in his sleep on January 29, 2010. The son of Milton and Gerta Herzon and raised in Erie, PA, Bert began his university studies at Harvard at the very young age of 15, transferred to the Honors Program at Swarthmore College, graduating in 1932 and completed his medical education at Johns Hopkins in 1937. Following a residency at New York's Mount Sinai Hospital and further training at Bellevue Hospital and the New York State Psychiatric Hospital, Bert served with the U.S. Army, first evaluating the mental fitness of draftees and then with the 10th Armored Division as a neuropsychiatrist (seeing active combat during the Battle of the Bulge); at war's end, he was called to serve at the Nuremberg trials and then served on the denazification process for the American Military Government, service which lead to the publication of his seminal work Father Land (1948) widely used in University courses and by those setting up anti-nazi democratic systems in Germany. After the war, Bert took further training with the William Alanson White Institute in New York City, with which he was associated for most of his career as a psychiatrist, teaching, advising and leading. During these years he was active in promoting mental health initiatives in the Caribbean, serving on the Expert Committee for Mental Health of the United Nations, advising the British, French and Dutch island governments in the West Indies on their mental health programs, and assisting numerous other international organizations. Never abandoning his private psychiatric practice, he was a leader in the study of the problems of homosexual practitioners in the medical world; he was proud of being one of the very first doctors to treat AIDS patients, writing articles seeking more humane attitudes and treatment for them, and from the 1980's forward, he dedicated much of his professional efforts to helping HIV/AIDS patients and the health care providers who ministered to them, continuing to receive patients at his home office until shortly before his death. Also well known as a collector of Indian art, an interest spurred by his participation in a Brooklyn Museum trip to India in 1966, Dr. Schaffner travelled often to the subcontinent and became a beloved member of the arts community in New York, serving on the Collections Committee of The Brooklyn Museum, to which he was both devoted and one of its major donors. Author, prizewinner, compassionate psychiatrist and a model of what it means to be a friend, Bert is survived by his sister-in-law, Mrs. Robert Edward Schaffner, two nieces, and many cousins in all parts of the country, as well as a host of professional colleagues and close friends from all walks of life. A memorial service will be held at a time subsequently to be announced.

If Democrats break down their major health care legislation into components that could be approved separately, the first bill up for consideration could be a proposal to end the exemption from federal antitrust laws that insurers have enjoyed since 1945. The House Judiciary Committee, led by Representative John Conyers Jr., right, Democrat of Michigan, has approved such a bill, and the full House may take action on it early next month, aides to Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday.

COHEN--Harold. The Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of Harold Cohen. Mr. Cohen served on various boards of Metropolitan since 1969, and served with distinction as Chairman of Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center and the Metropolitan Jewish Health System Foundation. He is survived by wife, Elsa and son, Richard and daughter, Ellen, as well as five cherished grandchildren. A tireless advocate for access to quality health care for all New Yorkers, Mr. Cohen was an inspirational leader and generous supporter for over four decades. He will be greatly missed. May his memory be for a blessing. Ronald Milch, ChairmanMetropolitan Jewish Health System Eli S. Feldman, President and CEO Metropolitan Jewish Health System

OSTERMAN--Marjorie Korn, novelist and playwright, wife of three time Tony award-winning Broadway producer, Lester Osterman, died age 92 at the Jewish Home for the Elderly, Fairfield, Connecticut. Born August 23, 1917, she attended Smith College and Barnard College, Columbia. Her novel, "Damned If You Do, Damned If You Don't" (1962) and was a National Library Selection. The New York Times' reviewer commented: "Without sentimentality, prejudice or treacle, she gives the lives and loves of a Jewish merchant dynasty from the civil war to World War II... Fiction either imitates life or captures it... Marjorie Osterman captures it." Her full length play, "A Scent of Almonds", about the stain a Nazi governess lays on a New York Jewish girl, was produced in 1986. "There are moments of gnawing pain, and guilt surges up around five of the six characters like the waters of an engulfing flood," said the Times review. "Merely raising the kinds of questions Ms. Osterman does is an extraordinary and even courageous act. One is not likely to forget it soon." Her short stories and poetry appeared in New Voices, the American Vanguard, Sports Illustrated, McCalls's and Mademoiselle. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law Patricia and John Thackray of Manhattan, her son and daughter-in-law Tom and Phyllis Osterman of Stamford CT, and by seven grandchildren, Sunshine Osterman-Ball, Heather Osterman-Davis, Sam Osterman, Charlie Osterman; Shelia Bagdade and Natasha Gray; and three great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, January 31, 2010 at 11am at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT. Burial will follow at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to PEN American Center or Doctors Without Borders.

GIM--Benjamin. The accomplished and remarkable life of noted immigration lawyer and human rights advocate, Benjamin Gim, ended serenely on January 16th, 2010. He was 87. A memorial service will be held at Museum of Chinese in America, 215 Centre St., New York, on February 1, at 2pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The MoCA Museum in New York.

JANOVSKY--Adele, died January 27, 2010 at the age of 94. Adele lived a remarkable life as an inspiration for generations of summer campers, dance students and just about anyone she met. She poured her rich and compassionate heart into everything she did, whether it was running her beloved Camp Red Wing on Schroon Lake, or being a guiding spirit of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester. She lived a 67-year love story with her late husband Joe, and delighted in their family -- sons Andy and Peter, their wives, Helaine and Fran, and granddaughters, Rebecca and Barbara, Geena and Isabel, as well as Rebecca's husband Rohndi and his family. We all miss Adele terribly, but know that she lived as marvelous a life as anyone can live. Contributions may be made to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation or The Neighborhood Playhouse Junior School Tuition Assistance Fund.
D'AVANZO--Gerald. 8/18/43 - 1/30/07. 3 years today, never to be forgotten. Always in our hearts. Judy, Laura, Joanna, Ben, Vanessa and Papa's 3 boys.

Members of the Taliban leadership met with a United Nations official this month to discuss the possibility of face-to-face peace talks with the Afghan government, American and United Nations officials said Friday. The official, Kai Eide, the United Nations' special representative in Afghanistan, met with a group of Taliban leaders in the days before this week's international conference in London, where President Hamid Karzai invited the Taliban to take part in peace talks.

BAKER--C. Edwin (Ed). A public Memorial Service honoring the life of C. Edwin (Ed) Baker will be held Sunday, January 31 in the Moot Court Room at Cardozo School of Law, 55 Fifth Avenue (5th Ave. at 12th St.), New York City at 2pm. Professor Baker, age 62, died unexpectedly on December 8, 2009. At the time of his death he was the Nicholas F. Gallicchio Professor of Law and Professor of Communication at the University of Pennsylvania. He also held a joint appointment at Penn's Annenberg School of Communications. Ed Baker was one of the nation's leading constitutional law and media policy scholars. He published four books, Media Concentration and Democracy: Why Ownership Matters (Cambridge, 2007), Media, Markets, and Democracy (Cambridge, 2002), Advertising and a Democratic Press (Princeton, 1994), and Human Liberty and Freedom of Speech (Oxford, 1989). He also authored over 70 articles and book chapters, as well as numerous op-ed pieces, including two in the New York Times. Yale Professor Jack Balkin describes Ed Baker as "the finest media law scholar of his generation." Professor Monroe Price, the director of the Annenberg Center for Global Communication Studies states: "There was no scholar so committed, passionate, disciplined and wise in thinking through the relationship between the media and the political system." Professor Robert McChesney of SavetheNews.org writes that: "It is impossible to gauge the immensity of the loss with Ed Baker's passing. His commitment to a strong free press and a vibrant democracy guided all of his work." Baker's most recent work focused on equality and on the threats to democracy posed by the concentration of media ownership, the subject of his recent testimony before Congress. Raised in Madisonville, Kentucky, Ed Baker was a graduate of Stanford University and Yale College of Law. He was a fellow at Harvard three times, most recently at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study. He was a resident of Greenwich Village for over 20 years. Ed was predeceased by his parents, Falcon O. and Ernestine Magagna Baker. He is survived by his sister, Dr. Nancy Lynn Baker of El Granada, CA, a professor at Fielding Graduate University, her spouse Cathy Hauer, seven first cousins, a number of close longtime friends, and his girlfriend Jennifer Mathews. His cremated remains will be interred in April in Madisonville, KY. Memorial Contributions in his honor should be made to the ACLU, the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, Oxfam, or another charity honoring Ed's commitment to human rights and free speech.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, an engineering major in college, has never been shy about proclaiming an unerring faith in statistics. He created 311 as a way to collate data, and improve the lives of New Yorkers. He has whipped out education data to justify extending mayoral control, reward star employees and close laggard schools. Rarely does a month go by without Mr. Bloomberg citing data analysis as the marrow not just of his administration, but also of his private sector career and his philanthropic foundation.

He was 92. The cause was apparently a heart attack, said his daughter, Cissie Bragan Walden.

Endorsing vaccines as the world's most cost-effective public health measure, Bill and Melinda Gates said Friday that their foundation would more than double its spending on them over the next decade, to at least $10 billion. The change could save the lives of as many as eight million children by 2020, Mr. Gates calculated. He said he hoped his gift would inspire other charities and donor nations to do the same.

Even before Senator-elect Scott Brown's stunning victory last week in the Massachusetts special election, there was no shortage of advice on simpler approaches to health care legislation. Earlier this month in The Wall Street Journal, the editorial columnist Peggy Noonan suggested one fix. ''The public in 2009 would have been happy to see a simple bill that mandated insurance companies offer coverage without respect to previous medical conditions,'' Ms. Noonan wrote. ''The administration could have had that -- and the victory of it -- last winter.''

So much for all the pretournament talk about how Roger Federer was distracted, aging and vulnerable at the Australian Open, and how 8 to 10 players were ready to knock him from his throne. After Federer filleted Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France in straight sets, now there is only one: Andy Murray, the scrambling Scotsman. It took Federer, the world's top player, less than 90 minutes to showcase his touch shots, mastery of angles and all-around court command and reach his 22nd Grand Slam final, a record, and eighth in a row. He broke Tsonga's serve in the fourth game of the first set, then toyed with him, 6-2, 6-3, 6-2.
JONES--David Gareth. 8/25/51-1/30/04. We miss you, especially B and J. We know that you are close by.

When Andrew Castrucci moved into a tenement on East Third Street in 1986, he arrived not with a real estate agent and a new set of keys but with two accomplices who stood watch as he used a 10-pound sledgehammer to smash through cinder blocks filling a rear door to the derelict building. Property records said that the abandoned structure, between Avenues C and D, belonged to the City of New York. But a handful of squatters, including Mr. Castrucci, assumed practical ownership. They cleared out thousands of pounds of rubble, repaired the roof, replaced broken water pipes and lighted the rooms with pirated electricity. They called the place Bullet Space, after the name stamped on bags of heroin sold on the block.

8 P.M. (NBC) TRUTH IN MOTION: THE U.S. SKI TEAM'S ROAD TO VANCOUVER From summer ski camps in Portillo, Chile, and Saas-Fee, Switzerland, to the days leading up to the World Cup competition in Sölden, Austria, this documentary -- commissioned by Audi and directed by Brett Morgen (''On the Ropes'') -- chronicles the journey of some elite American skiers on a quest to qualify for the 2010 Olympics. The fast and furious include Scott Macartney, who in January 2008 crashed on a slope in Kitzbühel, Austria, and slid across the finish line, unconscious and without his skis and helmet, at nearly 90 miles per hour; Ted Ligety, who won a gold medal in the combined at the 2006 Olympics; Sarah Schleper, who had been sidelined with injuries and the birth of her son; the veterans Jake Zamansky, Lindsey Vonn (above), Julia Mancuso and Bode Miller; and the newcomer Tommy Ford. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton reports on the efforts of religious and humanitarian groups to meet the needs of survivors in Haiti; Saul Gonzalez travels to Fresno, Calif., where a Mennonite church has founded Circles of Support and Accountability, a program created to help paroled sex offenders re-enter the community.

The Supreme Court of Canada ruled Friday that Canadian agents violated the rights of the only Canadian citizen held at the Guantánamo Bay detention center when they interrogated him there. But the ruling, the second concerning the inmate's politically delicate case, does not order the government to demand his return to Canada, as he has long requested. The man, Omar Khadr, was 15 years old and severely wounded when he was captured by American forces in Afghanistan in 2002. Mr. Khadr still faces proceedings before an American military commission on charges that he killed a member of the United States military with a hand grenade during a battle.

Burial directly following at Mount Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Heart Association or Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center's efforts in melanoma research.

JOFFE--Robert D. Time Warner Inc. mourns the passing of our longtime trusted advisor, confidant and friend Bob Joffe. Saying that Bob was a brilliant lawyer doesn't do justice to the magnitude of his gift or depth of his influence on our company. He was a problem-solver of the highest order. Over Bob's more than 35 years as our outside counsel, a succession of Time Warner leaders relied on his impeccable judgment in the most complex and sensitive situations. He was not only widely respected for his wisdom and conviction, but also revered for his decency and humanity. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to Bob's wife, Dinny, and his entire family. Jeff Bewkes and the Time Warner family
