Mao Asada, the former world champion figure skater who struggled last season, has gotten her groove back -- just in time for the Vancouver Olympics. At the Four Continents event Friday, Asada, the four-time Japanese national champion, hit two triple axels, challenging jumps that require a forward take-off and three and a half revolutions in the air. Only a handful of women have landed the jump in competition.

JOFFE--Robert D. All the lawyers and staff of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP mourn the loss of their partner Bob Joffe, a friend and mentor who was a preeminent litigator and boardroom adviser. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife and family to whom he was so devoted. Mr. Joffe was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in August 2009 and died in New York, NY on January 28. He was 66 years old. Over the course of his extraordinary career, Mr. Joffe was well- known nationally and internationally, both for his tenacity in handling landmark litigation and for his ability to provide highly sensitive counsel in the boardrooms of corporate America. Since 1978, Mr. Joffe was the primary outside lawyer for Time Warner. One of the many significant matters he handled was the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. He was the principal litigator for Time Inc. in successfully rebutting Paramount's 1989 attempted takeover in a case considered to be a milestone in M&A litigation. Mr. Joffe represented the Boards of Directors of some of the world's most prominent companies in connection with their most pressing challenges, especially during the recent financial crisis. He was a longtime advisor to the non-management directors of Fannie Mae and was also counsel to the independent directors of Merrill Lynch, Citigroup, General Electric and General Motors, among many others. Mr. Joffe was passionate about human rights even as a student at Harvard Law School. From 1967 to 1969, after just a few months as a Cravath associate, Mr. Joffe left New York to serve in the Ministry of Justice of the Government of Malawi on an Africa Asia Public Service Fellowship funded by the Ford Foundation. It was in this position that he assisted the Commissioner for Law Revision in rewriting the country's laws and instituting a framework for supervision of the local courts for this African country. He continued his interest in civil rights and, in 1989, he argued Martin v. Wilks, a pro bono civil rights case in the United States Supreme Court in which he represented black and women municipal employees in Birmingham, Alabama, in an effort to secure equal opportunity in employment. In later years, as Cravath's Presiding Partner, Mr. Joffe was a strong promoter of the need for lawyers to treat pro bono clients with equal regard and concern as they would any paying client. Mr. Joffe became a partner at Cravath in 1975. He was elected Deputy Presiding Partner in 1997 and became Cravath's Presiding Partner in 1999. Mr. Joffe served as the Firm's leader until December 31, 2006. Mr. Joffe was a beloved and devoted husband, father and son. He is survived by his wife Virginia (Dinny), two children, Katherine Joffe (New York, NY) and David Joffe (New York, NY) and two stepchildren, Dr. Ryan DeHaas (Concord, NC) and Elizabeth DeHass (New York, NY). He is also survived by his mother, Bertha Joffe, and two brothers, Paul Joffe (Washington, DC) and Richard Joffe (New York, NY). A memorial service will be held to celebrate his life on Wednesday, February 10th at 11am at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Human Rights First, 333 Seventh Ave., 13th Floor, New York, NY 10001 or to The After-School Corporation, 1440 Broadway, 14th Floor, New York, NY 10018.
LYNN--Elaine. Our heartfelt condolences to the Lynn Family who have lost a very special and caring woman. She will be missed by all who knew her. Our prayers are with you. The Kremer Family

The Tea Party movement may be fringe no more. After a career spanning nearly a half-century as a solo artist and a member of groups like Buffalo Springfield and Crosby Stills Nash and Young, Neil Young won his first Grammy Award in a pre-telecast ceremony in Los Angeles on Sunday afternoon. The award, for best art direction on a boxed or special limited edition package, was shared among Mr. Young and his art directors Gary Burden and Jenice Heo for the boxed set "Neil Young Archives Vol. 1 (1963-1972)." Upon his win, Mr. Young (who did not receive his first Grammy nomination until 1989, for the video for "This Note's For You") told the crowd: "Thanks a lot, everybody." Mr. Young was also nominated for a Grammy in the best solo rock vocal category, but lost to Bruce Springsteen.

In Brad Gilbert's book "Winning Ugly" he writes that Ivan Lendl liked to start his matches carefully, playing at about 65 percent of his shotmaking ability in order to get his rhythm, probe his opponent and figure out the conditions on court. Once he'd gotten a feel for things, he gradually opened his game up, going for his shots and thwarting whatever tactics his opponent was playing. The first set of the Australian Open men's final on Sunday night was played this way for the first seven games, with Andy Murray and Roger Federer testing one another, trying to figure out the other's early game plan.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. - The Pro Bowl will be played Sunday night, which will finally stop the flow of players dropping out of the game. At last count, ESPN, which will broadcast the game, said 30 players won't be on the field because they are members of the two Super Bowl teams or because they are injured.
Karen Schmeer, a film editor whose work includes "The Fog of War," died Friday in Manhattan, after she was run down by a car when crossing a street, the police said. She was 39.

Broadway likes safe bets, which is why there has always been a steady stream of British plays making the journey from London to New York. Even American plays occasionally have to prove their box office worth in Britain before opening on Broadway. "Red," a new drama by the playwright and screenwriter John Logan about the Abstract Expressionist painter Mark Rothko that received sterling reviews at the Donmar Warehouse in London, will start previews for a 15-week limited run at the Golden Theater in March, according to a publicist for the show. This two-character play, directed by Michael Grandage, stars Alfred Molina as Rothko and Eddie Redmayne as the painter's ambitious assistant. The setting is 1958 New York, after Rothko has been hired to paint a series of murals for the Four Seasons restaurant in the new Seagram Building on Park Avenue.

The Pasadena Playhouse, the state theater of California, is scheduled to close its doors on Feb. 7, after the final performance of "Camelot," because of deep debt. The entire staff of 37 was laid off on Thursday. "We firmly believe it would be irresponsible to continue to operate in the same financial patterns of the past," Stephen Eich, the executive director of the playhouse, said in a statement, adding that the theater will explore bankruptcy as well as financial reorganization. The playhouse, which was founded in 1917 and has closed and filed for bankruptcy before because of financial troubles, has been the staging ground for many hits, including "Looped," starring Valerie Harper as Tallulah Bankhead, which is scheduled to start previews at the Lyceum on Broadway this month.

Because of an editing error, the Phys Ed column on Page 17 this weekend, about the ability of exercise to slow some aspects of aging, misidentifies the German city that is home to Saarland University Clinic, which has conducted studies on the life spans of human cells. It is Homburg, not Hamburg.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the University of Connecticut’s 88-74 victory over Texas in men’s basketball on Saturday, Jan. 23, misstated, in some copies, the given name of the Huskies’ senior guard who scored 32 points. He is Jerome Dyson, not Eric. The article also quoted incorrectly from comments by George Blaney, UConn’s associate head coach. Blaney said, “Jerome moves in straight lines, no matter where he is on the court. ” He did not refer to the player as Eric.

An article last Sunday about new rental units coming online this year in New York City misstated the role Rose Associates has with two buildings in Brooklyn, 184 Kent Street and 34 Berry Street. It is marketing the buildings, not managing them. The article also misstated the title Robert Scaglion holds at the company. The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about a building on West 56th Street in Manhattan that was passed over for landmark designation, described incorrectly the electrical treatment used by Dr. William J. Morton, the first resident of the building, to treat a patient for scarlet fever in 1893. The doctor sat the patient on a chair insulated from the ground by glass balls and applied thousands of volts to the chair and then modified the electric fields by waving a grounded rod around her head and body. He did not pass “thousands of volts of electrical current around her body.”.

An article last Sunday that contrasted the careers of the composers Frédéric Chopin and Robert Schumann misidentified the key in which Chopin wrote a ballade that he eventually dedicated to Schumann. It was his Ballade in F major — not Ballade in F minor, a piece he wrote years later.

An article last Sunday about the actress Laura Linney misidentified the state where she attended boarding school. She attended Northfield Mount Hermon in western Massachusetts, not in upstate New York. The article also misidentified the school that Ms. Linney attended with the actress Jeanne Tripplehorn. They attended Juilliard together, not Brown. (Ms. Linney attended Brown.).

The DVD column on Jan. 17, about the transition from silent movies to talkies, misidentified the composers who wrote songs for the 1927 Broadway musical “Rio Rita,” which Warner Brothers released as a movie in 1929. The songs were written by Harry Tierney and Joseph McCarthy — not by E. Y. Harburg and Harold Arlen, who wrote some of the music for the 1942 version of the film.

As airlines continue to raise fees for checked luggage, more travelers are coming up with creative ways to dodge them.

The 36 Hours column on Jan. 3 about Tucson misstated the location of a shopping center, the Plaza Palomino. It is north of downtown, not in downtown.
“Game Change,” John Heilemann and Mark Halperin’s dishy account of the 2008 presidential campaign, enters the list at No. 1.

The issue of stopping head shots in hockey may have reached a critical mass as a result of Patrice Cormier's elbow to the head of Mikael Tam in a Quebec Major Junior Hockey League game this month. That blow left Tam with broken teeth, convulsing on the ice. Cormier, a Devils second-round draft choice in 2008 and Canada's captain at the recent world junior championship, has been suspended for the balance of the season and playoffs. Now the sport's governing body in Canada, Hockey Canada, has announced it will convene a summit in August to discuss player safety, with a focus on hits to the head.

STILLMAN--John S.,of Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY and Seal Harbor, Maine, on January 19, 2010. Age 91. Lawyer, government official in Kennedy and Johnson administrations, loyal Democrat. A warm, kind, gracious gentleman. Beloved husband of Amelia, father of Nathaniel, John J., Linda, Whit, and Mark; six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Maine in July. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Cornwall Hospital.

FIANCE--Seymour, age 88, was born December 23, 1921 in Brooklyn, New York. He died peacefully with his family's love surrounding him. He was a graduate of Pratt Institute and a member of The Explorers Club. He served his country with honor in WWII as a U.S. Navy Fire Controlman Third Class, where he bared witness to the raising of the flag at Iwo Jima. He was a member of the Legal Aid Society and founder of the Waldemar Cancer Research Center with famed jazz musician Count Basie, in memory of his beloved son, Jeffrey Lee. He was a legendary entrepreneur with wonderful employees from coast to coast. He leaves behind the love of his life, his wife, Libby, his beloved eight children and spouses, 22 grandchildren, four great-grandchildren and many dear friends. He lived life to the fullest with elegance and class and will live on in the hearts of his family and friends forever.

The touchy subject of how airlines should or should not treat obese passengers came up again this month when Air France issued a new policy to refund larger passengers the cost of a second seat but instead found itself having to clarify the move. Several media outlets including The Daily Mail in Britain reported that passengers unable to squeeze into a single economy seat would be charged double to fly with Air France.

ATWATER--Phyllis Yvonne. She was born on November 4, 1947. She died peacefully in her home in New York City on December 12, 2009. Phyllis is survived: by her husband, John R. Ernst; her mother, Thelda E. Phillips Atwater; and her sister Bertha L. Atwater. Phyllis was born and raised in Memphis, TN. Precocious and brilliant, she entered Vassar College at age 16 and graduated with honors with a degree in Mathematics in 1968. She then went on to obtain her Master's degree in Mathematics from Boston University. Post graduation, Phyllis helped create Roxbury Community College. It was also at this time that she met and then married John on December 28, 1972. As Phyllis continued her academic career she won a fellowship from the Ford Foundation. She then became a Danforth Foundation Dissertation Fellow at the New School, where she worked on her doctoral dissertation, "The Difference between Depreciation Charges and Replacement Costs." In the 1980s Phyllis was President of R2B2 (Resource Recovery of the Borough of the Bronx). Subsequent to this position she then held a number of high-level state and city government positions, both in New York and Massachusetts. Most recently Phyllis served as the Director of the Certification Unit for the Minority and Women-Owned Business Enterprise program. Phyllis was also very active in the community. She was on the board of directors of the Girls and Boys Project and the Scenic Hudson Foundation. Most recently, Phyllis was a founding member of the Psi Lambda Omega Brooklyn chapter of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority. Phyllis was a woman of great intellect, warmth, humor, wit, insight, and commitment. She touched everyone she knew and will be missed by her immediate family, her uncles, aunts, cousins and friends. Thank you Phyllis, for sharing your life with us! In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Atwater Foundation (located at 64 Fulton Street Suite 404, New York, NY 10038-2755). The foundation is a non-profit organization started in her honor, and will support scholarship in the areas of education, economics and the environment. Please be sure to join Phyllis's family and friends at 6pm on March 17, 2010 for a celebration of her life at Trinity Church in New York City. For more information please contact the toll free number, 1-866-271-4900 or email celebration@pipeline.com.

MATTHAEI--Gay Humphrey, Russian scholar, award winning author, independent film producer and interior designer, beloved wife of Konrad, twin sister of Jewel, mother of Marcella, Leslie and Konrad, grandmother of Konrad, Spencer and Sophie, passed away in her sleep on January 1, 2010. A Phi Beta Kappa, magna cum laude graduate of Mt. Holyoke College; she received her Masters Degree from Columbia University School of International Affairs, Russian Institute. Gay was one of the first four American students invited to visit the Soviet Union in 1954 by the undersecretary to Stalin, Nikita Kruschev. CBS and NBC equipped her with camera and film for this first peek behind the iron curtain. Her film was shown on NBC prime time and she lectured extensively throughout the country on her experiences in Russia. Gay co-authored, with her sister Jewel, three books about the coming of age of young Lakota Sioux in the 19th Century including the prize winning Ledgerbook of Thomas Blue Eagle and its accompanying award winning CD-ROM. Gay also produced and directed the educational film Where Time is a River, which won First Prize at the first Women's Film Festival and was subsequently acquired by the Museum of Modern Art Archive of Films. As President of Gay Matthaei Interiors, she specialized in residential and commercial interiors and historic restorations. She was a member of the Governor's Commission to Restore the State Capitol in Hartford. She also served as a Trustee of Mount Holyoke College for ten years, as a founder of the Addie Mae Collins Storefront School and as a Director of Young Audiences, Inc. Her literary awards include the International Reading Association Award, and Christopher Medal; her CD-ROM won the Emma Award, Best Visuals Educational Europe 1995; Intermedia Asia Best CD-ROM Title, 1995; Best CD-ROM Elementary School, Edinburgh Festival and the FNAC Prix. A celebration of Gay's life will be held at First Church of Round Hill, Greenwich, CT on Saturday, February 6th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Annual Fund of Mt. Holyoke College in memory of Gay Humphrey Matthaei, Class of '52. Mail to: The Annual Fund, Mount Holyoke College, Mary Wooley Hall, South Hadley, MA 01075 or to St. Joseph's Indian School, Chamberlain, SD 57326.

Grouper has been a fixture of South Carolina eating for what seems like centuries, but right now it's harder to source than Iranian caviar. When I had the locally caught grouper at McCrady's in Charleston in December, I knew that it was relatively rare: much of the ''local'' fish served in the port city is frozen or trucked in from the Gulf of Mexico, even Mexico. But I didn't know I'd be eating one of the last groupers to be caught in Southeastern waters for some time.

As the candidate of hope and change, President Obama has doubtless spent some private time around his first anniversary in office wondering whether he shouldn't have been more specific about the kind of change he'd hoped for. If a single year has so transformed his political fortunes, imagine what cannot be imagined in the next three ahead. If it's any comfort, the phenomenon isn't new to the American presidency. To quote the favorite political philosopher of the president I served, it's déjà vu all over again. Travel back to January 1990, as President George Bush -- no ''H. W.'' needed back then -- prepared for his first State of the Union address. The invasion of Panama, which returned democracy to that nation by way of the barrel speakers of a boom-box, had officially ended after 23 days. The Revolutions of 1989 across Europe -- in the speech, the president told of a Czech Everyman reciting in accented English the words of the Declaration of Independence -- served to underscore the president's claim that the State of our Union was strong.

HALPER DICKSON--Sari. Sept 9, 1969-Jan 30, 2009 One year. An extraordinary person who is most sorely missed and deeply loved by her husband John, children Zachary 2, Aleksander 4 and Diana 6, mother Barbara Kaplan Halper and sister Shauna Prudenti. We sincerly appreciate all that has, and continues to be, done in her honor. She will always be our song.

KLEIN--Philip E. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of our dear friend Philip Klein of Baltimore, MD. His more than 40 years of unyielding service to and staunch support of our organization, the Technion and the Baltimore Jewish Community have been sources of great inspiration. Mr. Klein, affectionately known in Baltimore and Israel as "Mr. Technion," was past president and honorary chairman of the ATS Baltimore Chapter Board. He was also a life trustee of the ATS National Board of Regents, served on the Technion Board of Governors, and was a regular participant on ATS missions to Israel and the Technion. His strong belief that Israel's success was dependent upon the strength of the Technion was characterized by his major support of every Baltimore Chapter project, including the Baltimore Center for Research Engineering, the Baltimore Double Module Dormitory, the Baltimore "Utilization of Dry Desert Air" Project, the Dusty Klein Memorial Scholarship Fund (named in honor of his late granddaughter), the Louis and Bessie Stein Biotechnology and Food Engineering Complex, and most recently, the Philip E. Klein Perpetual Fellowship Fund for Biotechnology & Food Engineering. Mr. Klein was known throughout the ATS/Technion community as a role model of volunteer leadership and fundraising for two generations. The Technion recognized Mr. Klein for his longtime support with an honorary fellowship and honorary doctorate. The university also named the prestigious "Philip E. Klein Awards to Students on the President's List" in his honor. Together with his late wife Harriet, Mr. Klein was a Technion Guardian, having achieved the highest level of commitment. His son, Michael, is a graduate of the ATS 21st Century Leadership Development Program and serves on the Baltimore and National Boards of Directors. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his sister Frances Copeland; his sons Michael, Jeffrey and David; his grandchildren Daniel, Jennifer, Maria, Stephanie, Rachel, Rick and Linda; and his great-grandchildren. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

GAYNOR--Peter Thorpe, previously of Modesto, CA died January 20, 2010 in Cincinnati, OH. Preceded in death by his parents, Primrose Whitfield and Dr. William C. T. Gaynor of Southampton, NY, sister Pamela Lewis and brother Kim. Survived by his children, Mary, Andrew, and Bruce (Kimberly); grandchildren, Matthew, Emily, Daffani and Steffani; brothers, Vere (Susie), and Michael (Constance); and sister, Katherine (Matthew) Marine. Peter was a graduate of The Choate School in 1953 and Harvard College in 1957, where he was president of The Fox Club and on the varsity wrestling team. A champion doubles squash player, Peter was a lifetime member of the United States Squash Racquets Association, 30 year member of The Jesters Club, Past President of the Northern California Squash Racquets Association and a 40 year member of the University Club. A celebration of his life will be held at The University Club of San Francisco in April. Memorials may be made to U.S. Squash, 555 8th Ave, Suite 1102, New York, NY 10018.

COHEN--Harold. The Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of Harold Cohen. Mr. Cohen served on various boards of Metropolitan since 1969, and served with distinction as Chairman of Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center and the Metropolitan Jewish Health System Foundation. He is survived by wife, Elsa and son, Richard and daughter, Ellen, as well as five cherished grandchildren. A tireless advocate for access to quality health care for all New Yorkers, Mr. Cohen was an inspirational leader and generous supporter for over four decades. He will be greatly missed. May his memory be for a blessing. Ronald Milch, ChairmanMetropolitan Jewish Health System Eli S. Feldman, President and CEO Metropolitan Jewish Health System

POWERS--James A.,on January 28, 2010. Formerly of Sunnyside and Grandview, NY. Graduate of Columbia Business School. Retired Senior Executive, Lonestar Industries. Beloved husband of the late Joan F. (nee Ogilvie), loving father of Katherine P. Brackett, Elizabeth Powers-Trupp and James A. Powers. Cherished grandfather of William, Johanna, Elizabeth, Sarah and Madison. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd, Sunnyside, NY, Sunday 2-5pm. Funeral Mass Queen of Angels R.C. Church Monday 10:30am. Interment Calvary Cemetery. He will always be remembered for his quiet strength, humility and the love of his family.

The five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for Jan. 23 to 29. 1. STUDIES LINK RARE AILMENT TO PAIN PUMPS Chondrolysis, an ailment in which joint cartilage dies, has been linked to a postsurgical device that delivers local anesthetics to a specific area.

GIM--Benjamin. The accomplished and remarkable life of noted immigration lawyer and human rights advocate, Benjamin Gim, ended serenely on January 16th, 2010. He was 87. A memorial service will be held at Museum of Chinese in America, 215 Centre St., New York, on February 1, at 2pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The MoCA Museum in New York.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Figure Skaters of Asian Descent Have Risen to Prominence,'' Jan. 24: Jeré Longman reported that ''Asian skaters are often small and willowy, which can be an asset when jumping.'' And Frank Carroll, a former coach for Michelle Kwan and currently the coach for Mirai Nagasu, said, ''They have bodies that are quick and light; they're able to do things very fast.''

IN the collaboration-crazed world of men's wear, it was perhaps inevitable that Steven Alan and Michael Williams would team up. Mr. Williams, who has been the cheerleader of American men's wear with his blog, A Continuous Lean, crossed paths with Mr. Alan, the vintage-inspired designer, as each headed for work. ''I would walk north, and he would walk south,'' Mr. Williams said. ''The more that I saw him, the more we talked.'' The result: two locally made shirts, with Mr. Alan's signature truncated fit and Mr. Williams's fetish for a practical flap pocket. Each shirt is $168 and available at Mr. Williams's new online store at acontinuouslean.com. TYLER THORESON

WEEMS--John Theodore, died Friday, January 15 in Brewster, MA. A Williams College graduate he was an actor and theatrical producer. Ted co-founded Weems Buccolo and Matthews off Broadway producers and Cross Right Stage at the Highfield Theatre in Falmouth, MA.

BODGER--Lowell, November 8, 1944--January 26, 2010, of Alzheimer's disease; teacher, writer, typographer, letterpress printer, filmmaker, planetary cartographer, book lover, ardent observer, dear friend. Memorial to be announced.

BAIRD--Charles F.,former chairman of INCO Limited, the Canadian metals and mining company, died December 26th at his Skillman, New Jersey home. He was 87 years old. Mr. Baird graduated from Middlebury College in 1944 and served in the Marine Corps during World War II and the Korean War. Prior to his time with INCO, he served as Assistant Secretary and then Under Secretary of the Navy and in executive positions with Exxon. He was the chairman of the board of both Bucknell University and the Center for Naval Analysis and served on the boards of Aetna, the Bank of Montreal, the Logistics Management Institute and the Marine Corps University Foundation. A devoted racquets enthusiast and competitor, he won 23 national senior titles in platform tennis. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, the former Norma White, four children, Susan Creyke, Stephen Baird, Charles Baird Jr. and Nancy Harwood and eight grandchildren. A celebration of his life will be held next July in Bridgehampton, New York. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to Bucknell University for the Baird Family Scholarship, c/o the Development Office, Lewisburg, PA 17837.

President Obama has blamed many factors for the stalling of his health care overhaul, from the recent special election in Massachusetts that deprived Democrats of their supermajority in the Senate to his own failure to better explain the legislation to the American people. He has also prominently blamed lobbyists, taking them to task in his State of the Union address last week as he cited ''special interests and armies of lobbyists and partisan politics.''

IN 1971, John Baldessari designed a print -- ''I will not make any more boring art'' -- that became legend. Mr. Baldessari, the pioneering California conceptualist, has been as good as his word. His videos, paintings, photographs and assemblages -- which he appropriates from existing imagery -- provoke laughter, puzzlement and admiration, often all at once. He layers his photographic works, juxtaposing multiple images from television, advertising or film. A new book, ''John Baldessari: A Catalogue Raisonné of Prints and Multiples, 1971-2007'' (Hudson Hills Press), compiled by the art consultant Sharon Coplan Hurowitz, indexes the artist's extensive prints, which have appeared as etchings, lithographs, album and book covers, posters and billboards. ''Inexpensive art should be available to all,'' Mr. Baldessari writes in a foreword that should sound sweet to recession-weary ears. ''And printmaking is an excellent answer.'' LINDA YABLONSKY

IN the art and fashion worlds, many a project begins with a fabulous party. In the case of ''Supermodels of the '70s and '80s,'' a new exhibition by the photographer Timothy Greenfield-Sanders, the party was given last year by the hairstylist Harry King. ''The room was full of all these fabulous women,'' Mr. Greenfield-Sanders said, ''and it seemed an obvious opportunity.'' The resulting limited-edition prints of Dayle Haddon, Beverly Johnson and Cheryl Tiegs (above, left to right) and others are largely unretouched -- only dirt and film specks were cleaned up, he said. The photographs are sold as a portfolio of 10, in a handmade Tramontano leather envelope. ''Supermodels'' runs through Feb. 27 at Steven Kasher Gallery, 521 West 23rd Street, (212) 966-3978. SANDRA BALLENTINE

Pop The hungrily cross-disciplinary tangle of electronic music called the UNSOUND FESTIVAL has been going on in Krakow, Poland, since 2003. This week, starting on Thursday and running for the next 10 days, we'll see the first American edition of Unsound, held in multiple spaces in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The festival is nearly as broad as the idea of ''electronic music,'' and in some cases, broader.

Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

AUCHINCLOSS--Louis. The partners of Hawkins Delafield & Wood LLP mourn the passing of their beloved friend and esteemed retired partner, Louis Auchincloss. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family of whom he was so very proud. A legendary man of letters and civic leader, Louis Auchincloss was all that and more to his admiring law partners. He was, of course, not only a superb draftsman but a very highly skilled practitioner, wise counselor, member of the Management Committee, and highly principled inspiration to the Firm for over 32 years. The exceptional ethical values embodied in some of his heroic fictional characters were the values he actually lived. Louis filled the unforgiving minute with sixty seconds' worth of distance run. We are enormously proud of and grateful for our time spent with this magnificent writer, lawyer and friend.

8 P.M. (CBS) THE 52ND ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS ''Music's Biggest Night'' pulls out the stops with performances by Jamie Foxx and T-Pain with Slash and Doug E. PEALE--Barrows, son of the late William Barrows Peale and Lorna Stevens, was born in New York, New York on May 26th, 1937. He grew up in Summit, New Jersey and Darien, Connecticut, and spent childhood summers in Quogue, New York. He graduated from Harvard College in 1959 where he was coxswain of the undefeated varsity heavyweight rowing crew. His love of sailing led him to a long career as an owner of Milford Boat Works, in Milford, Connecticut and eventually to work in restoration at the Mystic Seaport Museum. His long and very happy marriage to Mary Ellen Gates began on June 18, 1960 and ended when she passed away in November 2007. He is survived by his son, William Barrows Peale; his daughter, Barbara Farnum Peale, and four loving grandchildren; Charlotte, William, Wesley and George. Barry, as he was known by most, passed away on January 25th, 2010. His family plans to hold a memorial service for him in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mystic Seaport Museum in Mystic, Connecticut. www.mysticseaport.org

ROTH--Fred. Died peacefully at home in Boynton Beach, FL on January 29 at age 93. Mr. Roth is survived by his beloved wife of fifty five years Virginia (Von der Linden) Roth, devoted sons and daughters-in-law Steven and Daryl, David and Karen, Richard and Andrea, Jeffrey and Debbie, and Delfina Faria Da Silva who has been in the family for 38 years, his adoring grandchildren Amanda, Jordan, Benjamin, Brennen, Brielle, Chelsea and Jamon, and loving great-grandchildren Rebecca, Abigail, Emily and Jackson. The son of Sam and Lena Roth, Mr. Roth was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Erasmus Hall High School. He lived in Riverdale, NY, Tenafly, NJ and finally Boynton Beach, FL. Predeceased by siblings Sigismund, Doris, Jules and Millie. Mr. Roth and his wife Virginia met as students at Arthur Murray's dance studio in New York City and married in 1954. He built his own children's clothing manufacturing company, Wonderland Fashions, his life-long business, from which he retired in 1994. A lifelong lover of golf, Mr. Roth was a member of Briar Hall Country Club, Alpine Country Club and Hunter's Run Country Club and Community. A Memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 2 at 11am at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, New York City.

In the fashion world, there are optimists and there are pessimists (who prefer to be called realists). This winter the optimists are holding their own with their bright, freshly colored lumberjack looks, although the traditional Paul Bunyan checks are still a force to be reckoned with. But what catches the eye are the cheerful Day-Glo versions worn by young people, for whom ''log'' is computer talk. The bold squares of their inexpensive ear-flap caps and shirt-style jackets, with their distant and romantic connection to the forest, enliven a city where basic black is the rule.

Barack Obama, reeling from the Democratic defeat in the Massachusetts Senate race, isn't the first president to get an unwelcome anniversary gift a year after taking office. On Jan. 20, 1994, Attorney General Janet Reno announced that, at President Bill Clinton's request, she had appointed Robert Fiske as special counsel to investigate the Whitewater case. What we didn't know then was that seven months later, Mr. Fiske would be replaced by Ken Starr, whose investigation would ultimately lead to the president's impeachment. But what those of us on the Clinton staff were learning fast after 12 tumultuous months on the job was how little control we had over our own unfolding drama. The cockiness of the campaign was giving way to a humility imposed by history. Events large and small -- and so often out of our hands -- could unfurl without warning, or sometimes over time, to upend our day, alter our political fortunes and change the world. In that first year, they often did.

ANGELL--Frank. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Professor Frank Angell. Professor Angell was a Renaissance man in every sense of the word. He wrote six books starting with The Treatise "Insurance: Principles and Practices" in 1959 (at about 894 pages) in the slightly briefer "Health Insurance" in 1963 (at about 600 pages). He touched so many people's lives/shaped them fundamentally. Professor Angell was a one man NYU Alumni networking service. If you needed financing, he hooked you up with a wealthy NYU Grad. If you needed credit or banking, he would set you up with an NYU Alumnus who went into banking. For over 40 years Professor Angell was NYU's most popular Professor. His class was by far the most sought after in NYU's history. He was generous with his time and wisdom. He taught about life, the real world and family values. He continued his friendship with his students long after they graduated and for that we will be forever grateful. NYU Alumni

TIMOTHY EGAN I live in Seattle, a place recently touted, again, as America's most literate city. Seattle is also home to Amazon.com, the nation's biggest online retailer. Last Christmas Day, Amazon sold more e-books for its Kindle reader than regular books. A first. This happened just days after Laredo, Tex., a city of nearly a quarter-million people, shuttered its last standing bookstore, becoming the first metropolis of that size to be barren of books sold the old-fashioned way. Amazon's triumph and Laredo's loss are linked, many would say -- the Web robo-seller crushing the quirky corner bookstore. And it can only get worse, the pessimists have it, with Apple moving aggressively into e-reading with an iBooks reader as part of its sexy and slender tablet.

THE NEWS Toyota said it would temporarily stop making or selling eight of its most popular models, including Camrys and Corollas, in North America as it tries to resolve a problem with gas pedals that may become stuck. Expanded recalls during the week brought Toyota's total since November to more than 9 million worldwide. BEHIND THE NEWS The episode is the worst in a series of black eyes to Toyota's reputation for quality as the company grew rapidly in recent years, surpassing General Motors as the world's top automaker. A House panel said it would hold a hearing on the matter.

IN April 1969, three months after his inauguration, President Richard Nixon hosted a party at the White House to celebrate Duke Ellington's 70th birthday and award the Duke the Medal of Honor. Great American jazz figures were there. Musicians played Ellington songs arranged by Gerry Mulligan. Joe Williams and Mary Mayo sang. Ellington danced with Rose Mary Woods. After dinner, the president had a nightcap with the pianist Earl Hines. It was in many other ways a very good year for President Nixon. He called to congratulate the Apollo 11 astronauts on their moon landing. He initiated a huge expansion of the National Endowment for the Arts and began the processes that led to the desegregation of public schools in the South and a historic reform of the government's policy toward American Indians. He announced the ''Nixon doctrine,'' providing aid -- but not military forces -- to our anticommunist Asian allies. He signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

THINGS were tough as Jimmy Carter prepared for his 1978 State of the Union address, one year into his term. But they seemed, strangely, hopeful. The president's big domestic initiative that year was a national energy policy. The gas-station lines and first-ever spike in fuel prices in the mid-1970s made this a genuine emergency. He hadn't yet gotten the whole plan through, but the previous summer he had signed legislation creating the Department of Energy and begun imposing standards that, even after he was gone, kept improving the fuel efficiency of American cars, buildings and factories. His big foreign policy initiative was the Panama Canal treaty, to restore Panama's sovereignty over the Canal Zone with safeguards for the canal's operation. Although the opponents were fierce, employing what we would now call ''tea party'' tactics, they were a minority. Mr. Carter had John Wayne and other tough guys to speak on the treaty's behalf -- not to mention 61 Democratic votes in the Senate and a more than 2-to-1 Democratic majority under Tip O'Neill in the House.

Political platforms are usually written for election campaign purposes, then quickly scrapped after a presidential election. But the 1980 Republican platform bore a simple five-word title: ''Family, Neighborhood, Work, Peace, Freedom,'' and was planned and written with the purpose of creating an agenda for a Reagan administration on Day One, Jan. 20, 1981. My signal memory of Reagan's first year in office is that we were actually able to stick to the plan that he insisted we put in place. Coupled with the basic policy framework, Reagan's was one of the most carefully planned presidential transitions in modern political history, replete with teams of ''Reaganauts'' dispatched to each department and agency in the days following the election. Staffing lists were compiled, and presidential and subcabinet appointments were made swiftly, background and vetting checks completed and requisite Senate hearings scheduled.

The skiing great Annemarie Moser-Pröll can rest easier after Saturday's women's downhill, in which Lindsey Vonn's winning streak came to a decisive end. There were even some cautious notes of optimism from the rest of the women's field, which has been hammered by Vonn in the speed events for months. But then again, this final downhill before the Olympics was just one race, and even though Vonn finished fifth, her body of work so far this season amounts to an Alpine magnum opus.

I was very touched when I saw Mickey Rourke talk to a television interviewer about his role in ''The Wrestler'' while holding his Chihuahua, Loki. And a few weeks later, when he won best actor at the 2009 Golden Globes and thanked Loki and his other dogs for getting him through the years when he had no one, I teared up. I feel the same about my dog, Shadow, even though Shadow and I don't get the same welcome reception wherever we go. Shadow is a black 11-pound cross between a Chihuahua and a Jack Russell terrier. He's got floppy ears, a winsome way of cocking his head to listen when you talk to him and an ability to effortlessly jump three feet in the air on command. Not only is he the size of a baby, but he also acts like one, following me around the house and insisting on all my attention all the time.

THEY served pineapple upside-down cake for dessert that snowy evening at Camp David, the last weekend of President George W. Bush's first year in office. I remember thinking it seemed fitting. ''What a year,'' President Bush said during dinner. ''Sometimes it seems like seven,'' replied Condoleezza Rice, his national security advisor. But no one else said much. The emotions had been too raw, too intense. The sudden horror of Sept. 11 had changed the course of the presidency, making America's national security the president's relentless focus. ''Continued vigilance'' were the watchwords, as we fully expected additional attacks. We had seen the president's strong leadership as he rallied the country, Congress and each of us to confront the threat. ''Let me tell you how to do your job today,'' I remember him saying to me early one morning, directing me to plan an announcement. We had watched Mr. Bush make the most profound decision a commander in chief can make, committing American lives to battle in Afghanistan. We had witnessed the fall of the Taliban and worked to calm the panic of anthrax attacks.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Reaching First Super Bowl, Saints Set Off a Celebration,'' Jan. 25: The N.F.L. should take a page from other sports like basketball, baseball or even college football, and let the teams play a whole quarter to break a tie, so overtime actually means something. If the score is still tied, then go with the ''golden score.'' But don't let sudden death in the N.F.L. playoffs be a matter of luck over fairness and quality. Sean Wood

THE classic car auctions have ended in Phoenix. For me, that means taking a few moments to dream about which of the more than 2,000 collector cars I saw I would most want to drive home. And that car this year was the 1926 Hudson Speedster ''Grapes of Wrath'' that was auctioned at Barrett-Jackson. This is a car with a story. The 1926 Hudson Super Six was modified and used to carry the Joad family in the 1940 movie adaptation of John Steinbeck's novel ''The Grapes of Wrath.'' According to Barrett-Jackson, the car was put into storage after the filming.

Forget the Segway. Leave that jet pack behind. NASA is working on a personal flying suit. Conceptual designs for the experimental vehicle, called Puffin, were introduced by Mark D. Moore, an aerospace engineer at NASA's Langley Research Center, at a meeting of the American Helicopter Society on Jan. 20 in San Francisco. The Puffin is designed to be 12 feet in length, with a total wingspan of 14 1/2 feet; it would weigh in at 300 pounds (without a pilot).

OSTERMAN--Marjorie Korn, novelist and playwright, wife of three time Tony award-winning Broadway producer, Lester Osterman, died age 92 at the Jewish Home for the Elderly, Fairfield, Connecticut. Born August 23, 1917, she attended Smith College and Barnard College, Columbia. Her novel, "Damned If You Do, Damned If You Don't" (1962) and was a National Library Selection. The New York Times' reviewer commented: "Without sentimentality, prejudice or treacle, she gives the lives and loves of a Jewish merchant dynasty from the civil war to World War II... Fiction either imitates life or captures it... Marjorie Osterman captures it." Her full length play, "A Scent of Almonds", about the stain a Nazi governess lays on a New York Jewish girl, was produced in 1986. "There are moments of gnawing pain, and guilt surges up around five of the six characters like the waters of an engulfing flood," said the Times review. "Merely raising the kinds of questions Ms. Osterman does is an extraordinary and even courageous act. One is not likely to forget it soon." Her short stories and poetry appeared in New Voices, the American Vanguard, Sports Illustrated, McCalls's and Mademoiselle. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law Patricia and John Thackray of Manhattan, her son and daughter-in-law Tom and Phyllis Osterman of Stamford CT, and by seven grandchildren, Sunshine Osterman-Ball, Heather Osterman-Davis, Sam Osterman, Charlie Osterman; Shelia Bagdade and Natasha Gray; and three great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, January 31, 2010 at 11am at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT. Burial will follow at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to PEN American Center or Doctors Without Borders.

CAHILL--Sarah du Pont, "Sally", age 80, died peacefully Sunday, January 24, 2010 after a lengthy illness, surrounded by her loving family, at RiverMead, in Peterborough, NH. Born in 1929 and raised in Wilmington, DE, she was the daughter of Emile F. du Pont and Sarah Dure Townsend du Pont. Sally attended the Tower Hill School in Wilmington followed by Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, where she served as President of the School her senior year in 1947. She graduated from Bennett Junior College in Millbrook, NY. Sally lived a life of service and leadership. For more than 50 years she was very involved with Miss Porter's School, where she received the school's highest honor for distinguished service. She was a Trustee from 1993 to 1999, and until recently, served on various alumnae, class and development committees. She was part of a strong family tradition, her mother, aunt, daughter and granddaughter all having attended Miss Porter's. Other roles of leadership and service included Deacon, Member of the Finance Committee and Sunday School Teacher at the Wellesley Congregational Church, Wellesley MA; Hospice Worker for over a decade at Norwood Hospital in Norwood, MA; Trustee, Member of the Corporation and Chair of Planned Giving at the Joslin Diabetes Foundation; Trustee of the Stoddard Congregational Church; Secretary of the Stoddard Historical Society; and numerous volunteer positions in area hospitals, schools and in her local community. Sally was a devoted wife and mother. She met her husband of 60 years, Dr. George F. Cahill, Jr., during college week in Bermuda in 1947, and they married two years later. She was very supportive of her husband who has had a distinguished career in medicine. She accompanied him around the world as he shared his medical expertise, and he credits his professional success to her unwavering support, grace, and ease in any situation. They lived in New York City in the early 1950s, followed by Wellesley and Needham MA, raising six children, four girls and two boys. Love of nature and the outdoors brought them to Stoddard, New Hampshire in the 1980's where they built a home on property they had owned since the mid- 1960's and had used as a weekend and vacation retreat. Sally had a deep love and commitment to the natural world and to all living creatures. She created an extensive catalogue of wildflower photographs, accompanied by her observations and research, which was recently printed. In addition to her husband George, of Stoddard and Peterborough, NH, Sally is survived by her children, Colly Remley, Green Bay, WI, Peter Cahill, Los Gatos, CA, George (Chip) Cahill, Bellevue, WA, Rhett Cahill, Acton, MA, Eva Cahill, Calais, VT, Beth Tiedemann, NYC, their spouses and 15 grandchildren. She is also survived by her brothers, Francis I. du Pont, Chadds Ford, PA and Peter R. du Pont and wife Jeanie, NYC. A memorial service is being held on February 1st at 1:00pm at the Union Congregational Church, 33 Concord Rd. Peterborough, NH. An interment service will take place later this spring at the Stoddard Congregational Church. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Sally's memory to Home Health Care Hospice and Community Service, PO Box 496, Peterborough, NH 03458 or Miss Porter's School, Alumnae Office, 60 Main Street, Farmington, CT 06032.

With the State of the Union address, President Obama marked the symbolic end to his first year in office. From the outside, it seemed like a pretty rough roller-coaster ride. But did other administrations have it any easier? The Op-Ed editors asked veterans of the previous seven administrations to reflect on their initial 12 months in office -- and to provide some perspective for the current team in the White House.

AUCHINCLOSS--Louis S. The Board and staff of the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation extend our heartfelt sympathies to Louis' family. Mr. Auchincloss gave the Foundation 42 years of wise and insightful service. We will miss his sharp intellect, his ever presence of sense of humor and quick wit.Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman Clarence F. Michalis, Chairman EmeritusGeorge E. Thibault, M.D.,President

JOFFE--Robert D. All the lawyers and staff of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP mourn the loss of their partner Bob Joffe, a friend and mentor who was a preeminent litigator and boardroom adviser. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife and family to whom he was so devoted. Mr. Joffe was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in August 2009 and died in New York, NY on January 28. He was 66 years old. Over the course of his extraordinary career, Mr. Joffe was well- known nationally and internationally, both for his tenacity in handling landmark litigation and for his ability to provide highly sensitive counsel in the boardrooms of corporate America. Since 1978, Mr. Joffe was the primary outside lawyer for Time Warner. One of the many significant matters he handled was the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. He was the principal litigator for Time Inc. in successfully rebutting Paramount's 1989 attempted takeover in a case considered to be a milestone in M&A litigation. Mr. Joffe represented the Boards of Directors of some of the world's most prominent companies in connection with their most pressing challenges, especially during the recent financial crisis. He was a longtime advisor to the non-management directors of Fannie Mae and was also counsel to the independent directors of Merrill Lynch, Citigroup, General Electric and General Motors, among many others. Mr. Joffe was passionate about human rights even as a student at Harvard Law School. From 1967 to 1969, after just a few months as a Cravath associate, Mr. Joffe left New York to serve in the Ministry of Justice of the Government of Malawi on an Africa Asia Public Service Fellowship funded by the Ford Foundation. It was in this position that he assisted the Commissioner for Law Revision in rewriting the country's laws and instituting a framework for supervision of the local courts for this African country. He continued his interest in civil rights and, in 1989, he argued Martin v. Wilks, a pro bono civil rights case in the United States Supreme Court in which he represented black and women municipal employees in Birmingham, Alabama, in an effort to secure equal opportunity in employment. In later years, as Cravath's Presiding Partner, Mr. Joffe was a strong promoter of the need for lawyers to treat pro bono clients with equal regard and concern as they would any paying client. Mr. Joffe became a partner at Cravath in 1975. He was elected Deputy Presiding Partner in 1997 and became Cravath's Presiding Partner in 1999. Mr. Joffe served as the Firm's leader until December 31, 2006. Mr. Joffe was a beloved and devoted husband, father and son. He is survived by his wife Virginia (Dinny), two children, Katherine Joffe (New York, NY) and David Joffe (New York, NY) and two stepchildren, Dr. Ryan DeHaas (Concord, NC) and Elizabeth DeHass (New York, NY), and two grandchildren. He is also survived by his mother, Bertha Joffe, and two brothers, Paul Joffe (Washington, DC) and Richard Joffe (New York, NY). A memorial service will be held to celebrate his life on Wednesday, February 10th at 11am at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Human Rights First, 333 Seventh Ave., 13th Floor, New York, NY 10001 or to The After-School Corporation, 1440 Broadway, 14th Floor, New York, NY 10018.

IT started the day I tripped on a dog's tail while leaving the dressing room at the Banana Republic at 86th and Broadway. The tail, an ordinary brown one, was sticking out of the dressing room next door. I never did see the dog's body or the master of the animal, who was, presumably, deciding whether to buy just the black T-shirt, or the red one as well. Animals are joining the ranks of small, bored children who must accompany their grown-ups just about everyplace. Can't tie up my kid on a leash outside, so why should I do it to my dog?

For the big Broadway musical, surviving the recession often means that the sets are rarely stars anymore. You don't hear many audible gasps these days when the curtain rises, or when scenery transforms to reveal a theatrical vision.

Indiana's Reggie Miller, remembered as one of the great clutch performers of his generation, is the star of an ESPN documentary, ''Winning Time: Reggie Miller vs. the New York Knicks.'' The film, which will be shown March 14, highlights the Knicks-Pacers rivalry and focuses on Miller's performance in the 1995 playoffs. In Game 1 of a series against the Knicks, Miller scored 8 points in 18.7 seconds to give Indiana a come-from-behind victory at Madison Square Garden. Whether it was feuding courtside with Spike Lee or butting heads with John Starks, Miller was at the center of the rivalry. The entire interview is at nytimes.com/offthedribble. FRED BIERMAN Q.What was most surprising about the film?

Dance The DANCE ON CAMERA festival, which runs through Tuesday at the Walter Reade Theater, doesn't divide its offerings (47 this year) into categories, as some dance-film festivals do. Instead it presents serendipitous discoveries in its groupings of short films and pairings of longer works.

The N.H.L. has gained huge attendance the last few seasons with its annual outdoor Winter Classic, played at places like Wrigley Field and Fenway Park. Never an organization to pass up a good idea, the Harlem Globetrotters decided to play a game outdoors as well. Not wanting to mess with success, they decided they too would play their game on ice. Believed to be the first professional basketball game on ice, the game will be a matchup of the Globetrotters and the team's familiar foe, the Washington Generals, at Lasker Rink in Central Park on Feb. 9 to kick off a series of six games in the New York area.

MON TOY--Mary, 93, died on December 7, 2009 in her beloved New York City. A triple threat: Latin Quarter showgirl; original Broadway cast member in The World of Suzy Wong and House of Flowers; on television on Kojak, Ryan's Hope, Teahouse of the August Moon, I Spy and Drs. Hospital; in movies in Airplane II and Bob Fosse's All That Jazz. She was the first Asian runway model in Paris. Born in Hawaii, her family moved to Seattle in the 1920's only to be uprooted and sent to the Minidoka Japanese American Internment Camp after Pearl Harbor. She left the camp in 1944 on a scholarship to Juilliard procured by Eleanor Roosevelt. The rest of her life was spent in New York City where she was an active member of Screen Actors Guild, AFTRA and Actors' Equity, and generous supporter of The Actors Fund, animal rights and The Japanese American National Museum. A celebration of her life will take place on Sunday, January 31 at 1pm. Call 212-580-0052 for information.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Special Town, Special Teams,'' Jan. 24: Although I admired the article regarding the influence of the Saints on New Orleans, I find it disheartening that it referred to Hurricane Katrina as destroying New Orleans.
DEAMANT--Marjorie (Midge) E.,92, daughter of Fan and Is Engel, widow of Fred, Fieldston grad. Loved by Edith S. Engel, Ginger E. Benlifer and extended family. Donations to: Alzheimer's Association.

JOFFE--Robert D. Harvard Law School mourns with great sadness the passing of Robert D. Joffe, brilliant lawyer, and great friend and adviser to the School. A man of uncommon wisdom and integrity, Bob contributed his extraordinary experience, expertise, and enthusiasm to his many efforts on behalf of his law alma mater, including his leadership as Chair of the Annual Fund, service on the Dean's Advisory Board, and membership on the Advisory Board of the Center on Lawyers and the Professional Services Industry. We are especially grateful for his profound support of the Cravath Fellows Program at HLS. Our deepest sympathy is with Bob's wife, Dinny, and their family. Martha Minow Dean and Jeremiah Smith Jr. Professor Harvard Law School

In the fashion world, there are optimists and there are pessimists (who prefer to be called realists). This winter the optimists are holding their own with their bright, freshly colored lumberjack looks, although the traditional Paul Bunyan checks are still a force to be reckoned with. But what catches the eye are the cheerful Day-Glo versions worn by young people, for whom ''log'' is computer talk. The bold squares of their inexpensive ear-flap caps and shirt-style jackets, with their distant and romantic connection to the forest, enliven a city where basic black is the rule.

JOFFE--Robert. Bud Shulman and Amy Newman express their great sadness at the passing of Bob Joffe. Bob was an important mentor to Bud and a great friend to both of us. Bud worked closely with Bob for many years as partners at Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP. Bob taught him what it means to be an effective advocate and a trustworthy counselor. He was unselfish in giving Bud opportunities that made a huge difference in his career. Bud and Amy will dearly miss him. Our deepest sympathies go to Dinny and Bob's entire family.

FRIEDMAN--Lawrence S.,formerly of Briarcliff Manor, NY, died peacefully at his home in Greenfield, MA on January 19, 2010 at the age of 59 after a long illness. Larry had a passionate commitment to his students, to the schools where he taught and to the English language itself. This passion, combined with Larry's irresistible yet somewhat unique and twisted sense of humor, made the world of literature an accessible place of wonder for the countless students he taught in his 30 years as a teacher. Larry taught English at Northfield Mount Hermon from 1979 until 1995. He then worked briefly for the State of Massachusetts giving high school students the opportunity to experience work situations. Larry then went back to teaching English at Eaglebrook, a boarding and day school for boys in grades six to nine, where he continued to inspire his students until his illness made it too difficult for him to get to his classroom. Larry demanded and brought out the best in his students. He shared with them his wide range of interests from James Joyce and William Butler Yeats to Groucho Marx and W.C. Fields, from Richard Wagner to early jazz and Klesmer music. Larry is survived by his mother Blanche Friedman, his sister and her husband, Ellen Friedman and Jeffrey Cowan, nieces Rachel Friedman and her husband, Christopher Wallwork, Celia and Molly Friedman Cowan and nephew Sam Friedman Cowan and his aunt Marie Alpert. Memorial services for Larry are planned for May in Briarcliff Manor, NY with the exact date to be announced. Contributions may be made to the Larry Friedman English Department Fund at Eaglebrook School, 271 Pine Nook Road, Deerfield, MA.

GOLDBERG--Phillip, of Congers, NY, age 54, died in his home Saturday morning, January 30, 2010. The cause of death was a brain tumor. A partner at Nextlevel Consulting, he was a resident of Rockland County, NY for over 13 years. Brother of Arnold Goldberg, Lutz, FL, survived by his wife of 13 years, Doris Goldberg; the uncle of Alex Goldberg, Marissa Goldberg and Emma Goldberg. Funeral services Sunday, January 31, 12:30pm at Eden Memorial Chapels, 327 Main St, Fort Lee, NJ. Burial January 31, in Garden of Memories Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

Barbara, Peter, Leslie, Hillary, George, Ross, Donald, MaryEllen, Paul, Jean, Richard, Suzy, Neil, Michael, Leah, Brad, Mikal, Jenna, Max, Noah and Natasha.

ZOMBIELANDWoody Harrelson and Jesse Eisenberg play a couple of drifters making their way across a post-apocalyptic roadside America in Ruben Fleischer's horror comedy. The film, which also features Emma Stone and Abigail Breslin, is ''a minor diversion dripping in splatter and groaning with self-amusement,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times in October. (Sony, Blu-ray $39.95, standard definition $28.96, R) AMELIAHilary Swank is the pioneering aviator Amelia Earhart in this biographical film directed by Mira Nair (''Monsoon Wedding''), who ''keeps a tidy screen,'' Ms. Dargis wrote in The Times in October. ''It's all very neat and carefully scrubbed. I don't recall a single dented automobile or a fissure of real feeling etched into a face.'' With Richard Gere, Ewan McGregor and Virginia Madsen. (Fox, Blu-ray $39.99, standard definition $29.98, PG)

Art Even with the extensive attention paid to Asian art by Western museums in recent years, Vietnam has remained outside the loop. The exhibition ''ARTS OF ANCIENT VIET NAM: FROM RIVER PLAIN TO OPEN SEA,'' opening Tuesday at the Asia Society and Museum in Manhattan, begins to make up for the neglect. The show, which appeared at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, last fall, consists almost entirely of loans from Vietnamese museums.

DICK--Marion Pokoik, age 83, on January 28, 2010 at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Florida, after an acute infection. Wife of the late Manuel Pokoik and the late Frederick Dick. Survived by son Leon Pokoik of Longboat Key, Florida; twins Gary Pokoik of Brentwood, California and Gail Pokoik of New York, New York; grandchildren, Davin (Sheriann), Mathew (Aynsley), Alicia (James), Jonathan, Justine, Charlotte, and Manny. Burial directly following at Mount Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Heart Association or Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center's efforts in melanoma research.

TISCHLER--Rita, of Elizabeth, New Jersey passed away Friday, January 29, 2010 at her home. She was born on February 14, 1916, the daughter of the late Gussie Levy and Louis E. Levy, of New York City. Survivors include her brother Paul Levy and his wife Elizabeth of Cooks Falls, NY: Her nieces, Susan Wright of Queensbury, NY, Ellen Caputo of Merrick, NY, Jane Walker of Ronkonkoma, NY, and their respective spouses and nephew Nicholas Levy of New York City; two grand-nieces, four grand-nephews and two great-grand-nephews. She was predeceased by her husband William Tischler in l986. Rita was a source of fun to all who knew her, and loved by all who were so privileged to be close. Her presence in our lives is gone but we were so fortunate to have had her for so long. A small funeral service is being held on Sunday, January 31 at B'nai Abraham in Union, New Jersey.

Thank you for Peggy Orenstein's truly sad but wonderfully written piece on the death of California's educational dream. This state seems to have been working long and hard to destroy its schools, first with the irrational Proposition 13 capping property taxes and thus stripping the elementary and secondary schools of their most logical source of funding and now moving on to damage the centers of higher education with a perpetually deadlocked Legislature that can no longer manage to put Band-Aids on the wounds it keeps producing. They often say that trends begin in California and spread to the rest of the country. Let's not forget, it was California that foisted Ronald Reagan on the country, propelling the ideology that now prevails: every man for himself. JAMES FOREMAN Los Angeles

Classical SEQUENTIA, the extraordinarily inventive early-music group directed by Benjamin Bagby, has made a specialty of bringing medieval epics to life. Mr. Bagby's version of ''Beowulf,'' heard several times in New York, was a powerful setting of sections from the 11th-century Anglo-Saxon manuscript, sung as it might have been by a bard of the time. That was a solo show, with Mr. Bagby's quirky but evocative singing to his own lyre and harp accompaniment. Now he and Sequentia are back with ''The Rheingold Curse: A Germanic Saga of Greed and Revenge From the Medieval Icelandic Edda,'' a work based on the Norse legends that also inspired Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle.

FINNELL--Maurice. Teacher of sight singing and musicianship, singer, conductor, composer and vocal coach, in New York City, on January 5, 2010 at age 93. Beloved father, grandfather, uncle, and maestro, survived by his children Jan and Ian, daughter-in-law Janice and grandsons Gabriel and Daniel. He loved his work and felt privileged to have been able to teach over 9,000 students in 52 years. This rare gentleman of wit and charm is deeply missed, and a memorial gathering celebrating his long life and achievements will be held in Manhattan this spring. Friends are encouraged to contact his family for details.

SCHAFFNER--Dr. Bertram H. Schaffner, 97, renowned as a psychiatrist and widely known as a collector of Indian art, died in his sleep on January 29, 2010. The son of Milton and Gerta Herzon and raised in Erie, PA, Bert began his university studies at Harvard at the very young age of 15, transferred to the Honors Program at Swarthmore College, graduating in 1932 and completed his medical education at Johns Hopkins in 1937. Following a residency at New York's Mount Sinai Hospital and further training at Bellevue Hospital and the New York State Psychiatric Hospital, Bert served with the U.S. Army, first evaluating the mental fitness of draftees and then with the 10th Armored Division as a neuropsychiatrist (seeing active combat during the Battle of the Bulge); at war's end, he was called to serve at the Nuremberg trials and then served on the denazification process for the American Military Government, service which lead to the publication of his seminal work Father Land (1948) widely used in University courses and by those setting up anti-nazi democratic systems in Germany. After the war, Bert took further training with the William Alanson White Institute in New York City, with which he was associated for most of his career as a psychiatrist, teaching, advising and leading. During these years he was active in promoting mental health initiatives in the Caribbean, serving on the Expert Committee for Mental Health of the United Nations, advising the British, French and Dutch island governments in the West Indies on their mental health programs, and assisting numerous other international organizations. Never abandoning his private psychiatric practice, he was a leader in the study of the problems of homosexual practitioners in the medical world; he was proud of being one of the very first doctors to treat AIDS patients, writing articles seeking more humane attitudes and treatment for them, and from the 1980's forward, he dedicated much of his professional efforts to helping HIV/AIDS patients and the health care providers who ministered to them, continuing to receive patients at his home office until shortly before his death. Also well known as a collector of Indian art, an interest spurred by his participation in a Brooklyn Museum trip to India in 1966, Dr. Schaffner travelled often to the subcontinent and became a beloved member of the arts community in New York, serving on the Collections Committee of The Brooklyn Museum, to which he was both devoted and one of its major donors. Author, prizewinner, compassionate psychiatrist and a model of what it means to be a friend, Bert is survived by his sister-in-law, Mrs. Robert Edward Schaffner, two nieces, and many cousins in all parts of the country, as well as a host of professional colleagues and close friends from all walks of life. A memorial service will be held at a time subsequently to be announced.

KIRSCH--Millicent. Devoted wife of Albert, sister of Annette Weiner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mark Block. We'll miss your wit, kindness and unique perspective on life. Service Sunday, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Your loving cousin, Charlie

Television The efforts of the satellite television service DirecTV to position itself as a provider of sophisticated (and exclusive) content have included original seasons of ''Friday Night Lights'' and unseen episodes of canceled series like ''Wonderland'' and ''The Nine.'' Now it's looking farther afield: beginning Wednesday at 10 p.m., its in-house 101 channel will begin carrying ''UNDERBELLY,'' a fact-based drama about the Australian drug trade that is in its third season on the Nine Network in Australia. That series, winner of both Logie (low-brow) and Australian Film Institute (high-brow) awards for best television drama, has told stories of dealers, police officers and politicians covering the late 1970s to about 2004; DirecTV is beginning with the show's second season, ''A Tale of Two Cities,'' which comes first chronologically. The show has been compared to ''The Sopranos,'' but based on the first few episodes of ''A Tale of Two Cities'' it's more like ''Traffic'' with copious nudity.

WEINGARDEN--Esther. Widow of Harry Weingarden, passed away peacefully at 102 years. Devoted mother to son Marshall and late daughter Ann Linda; beloved grandmother to Alison and loving mother-in-law to Barbara. Donations to: Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation.

THE CTS Corporation, the Indiana-based automotive supplier that makes the gas-pedal assembly involved in Toyota's ''stop sale'' order and recall announcements last week, also produces assemblies for other manufacturers, including Honda and Ford. According to Christina Ra, a Honda spokeswoman, ''We use the same supplier for a small number of vehicles sold in the U.S. We do not use the same components as are involved in our competitor's recall.''

WEINBERGER--Phyllis, died too soon and too young on January 28, 2010, in Delray Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of Donald, Phyllis is also survived by her mother Belle and sister Toby; three loving children Ron, Dineen and Paul; and grandchildren Drew and Alec. Born in Forest Hills, New York, where she was also raised, Phyllis was a brilliant award winning artist who loved life, people, family and good food. Her interests were vast but most of her passion was dedicated to her abundance of close friends, many whom considered her family. She was a unique, loving and generous spirit whose goodness and generosity was beyond measure. Phyllis was a member at both Engineers CC in Roslyn Harbor, New York and Glen Eagles CC in Delray Beach, Florida. In lieu of gifts or flowers, please direct any generosity to ST. Jude's Children's Hospital in her memory. Services will be held Sunday, January 31 at 1pm at the Gardens in Boca Raton, Florida.

JANOVSKY--Adele, died January 27, 2010 at the age of 94. Adele lived a remarkable life as an inspiration for generations of summer campers, dance students and just about anyone she met. She poured her rich and compassionate heart into everything she did, whether it was running her beloved Camp Red Wing on Schroon Lake, or being a guiding spirit of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester. She lived a 67-year love story with her late husband Joe, and delighted in their family -- sons Andy and Peter, their wives, Helaine and Fran, and granddaughters, Rebecca and Barbara, Geena and Isabel, as well as Rebecca's husband Rohndi and his family. We all miss Adele terribly, but know that she lived as marvelous a life as anyone can live. Contributions may be made to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation or The Neighborhood Playhouse Junior School Tuition Assistance Fund.

Influential artists sometimes click in the public consciousness only after the rise of the movements they have influenced. A school of creative work emerges -- seemingly spontaneously, its origins obscure at first. Then, with attention to the artists in that school comes recognition of their influences, their antecedents and their mentors. After Pollock, de Kooning and their peers in postwar American art established Abstract Expressionism, the precursory importance of prewar iconoclasts like Kandinsky became clear. After the Ramones, the Sex Pistols and the Clash blurted forth punk rock in the 1970s, a rude vision became apparent in the noise of '60s garage bands like the Seeds. A new movement in jazz has surfaced over the past few years -- a wave of highly expressive music more concerned with emotion than with craft or virtuosity; a genre-blind music that casually mingles strains of pop, classical and folk musics from many cultures; an informal, elastic music unyielding to rigid conceptions of what jazz is supposed to be. It's fair to call it ''post-Marsalis,'' in that it leaves behind the defensive, canon-oriented musical conservatism of '90s jazz (as both Branford and Wynton Marsalis themselves have done in their best work of the past decade). Among this music's most celebrated and duly admired practitioners are the pianists Brad Mehldau, Ethan Iverson (of the trio the Bad Plus), Jason Moran and Vijay Iyer. And singular among the trailblazers of their art, a largely unsung innovator of this borderless, individualistic jazz -- a jazz for the 21st century -- is the pianist and composer Fred Hersch.

Recently, scientists in Germany gathered several groups of men and women to look at their cells' life spans. Some of them were young and sedentary, others middle-aged and sedentary. Two other groups were, to put it mildly, active. The first of these consisted of professional runners in their 20s, most of them on the national track-and-field team, training about 45 miles per week. The last were serious, middle-aged longtime runners, with an average age of 51 and a typical training regimen of 50 miles per week, putting those young 45-mile-per-week sluggards to shame. From the first, the scientists noted one aspect of their older runners. It ''was striking,'' recalls Dr. Christian Werner, an internal-medicine resident at Saarland University Clinic in Hamburg, ''to see in our study that many of the middle-aged athletes looked much younger than sedentary control subjects of the same age.''

The family will be receiving friends on Monday and Tuesday in New York. Send donations to: Alexander Lebenstein Fund for Tolerance and Human Rights at the Richmond Jewish Foundation, 5403 Monument Avenue, Richmond, VA 23226 or The Virginia Holocaust Museum/In Memory of Alex Lebenstein, 2000 Cary Street, Richmond, VA 23223.

"Eye of the Tiger" was blaring from the speakers as I walked into the photo studio. It seemed an appropriate entrance for my meeting with Joan Collins, a woman known for draping herself in animal prints, and who has in recent years come to be heralded as the "original cougar." Try as she might, she cannot escape the association with Alexis Carrington, the perfectly bitchy character she portrayed for almost a decade on the prime time soap opera "Dynasty." And on this day, Alexis - oh, sorry - Joan was being photographed for the jewelry designer Alexis Bittar's spring ad campaign. Alexis the legend, donning bold, '80s-inspired costume jewelry designed by another Alexis who, hard to believe, had never seen the show.But I had, and I was about to meet the woman who, as Alexis, devoured anyone who stood between her what she wanted, and did so sporting big hair, red lips and shoulders galore - whether bare or padded. She did it so well that today people have trouble distinguishing her character from the real person who was now seated in front of me, wrapped in her own Michael Kors leopard-print trench coat and clutching a decidedly unglamorous white Styrofoam cup of coffee. "I would never go out to lunch in a tracksuit," she said about her insistence on keeping up appearances. "But I might pop out to the supermarket in one - but only in L.A."

As families of this year's high school seniors set about tackling the form in earnest, Mark Kantrowitz of finaid.org, spent a week last month dutifully answering a laundry list of questions from readers on our blog. For further assistance, we direct you to the new February Resource Center on the Web site of Sallie Mae, where there are instructional videos, links and information on a coming Q&A. Our sib-blog, Bucks, has more details here.

There is growing concern in Congress that the shaky $6.7 trillion commercial real estate market could implode, delivering a major blow to the economic recovery. A bipartisan group of 79 House members led by Representative Paul E. Kanjorski, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and Representative Ken Calvert, Republican of California, sent a letter to the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve on Monday urging them to take a more active role in keeping the commercial real estate market from turning into a disaster.

Got something you want to express to Rocco Landesman and the National Endowment for the Arts -- in a constructive, artistic way? Now's your chance: on Monday, the N.E.A. and Mr. Landesman, its chairman, announced that they were seeking proposals for a new logo to represent the phrase "Art Works," which Mr. Landesman has previously described as the agency's "guiding mission." In a statement Mr. Landesman said the logo, which will be used in print and online promotions, should represent the three meanings of the phrase: the creation of artists; the effect of art on audiences; and the contribution of artists to the economy. Proposals for the design must be submitted by email to the agency by 5 p.m. Eastern time on Feb. 26, and the selected proposal will receive a government grant of approximately $25,000. A complete list of instructions and requirements for submitting a proposal can be found here at the arts.gov Web site.

The British artist Michael Landy will be destroying hundreds of works of art this year, even though he's gotten in trouble for it before. In his 2001 performance, "Break Down," Landy shredded everything he owned - 7,227 items in total. Members of the public were most affected by the disposal of his car, his love letters, family heirlooms and the entire archive of his own art. However, he received most criticism from within the art world for destroying his art collection: works by fellow Young British Artists, including Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin, most of which he had received as gifts.
