Iris Murdoch, Patrick O'Brian and J. G. Farrell may no longer be with us, but they -- along with 19 other writers -- are among the authors eligible for an unusual new British literary award. The organizers of the Man Booker Prize, the prestigious honor given each year to an English-language novel, have announced a new award intended for writers who may have been shut out by a change of rules early in the prize's history. When the award was first handed out in 1969 and 1970, it was given to a novel published in the previous year; starting in 1971, the prize was given to a novel published that same year -- meaning that several works published in 1970 were ineligible. The new award, called the Lost Man Booker Prize, will be awarded in May to one of 22 works on a long list that includes Murdoch's "A Fairly Honorable Defeat"; O'Brian's "Master and Commander" and Farrell's "Troubles," as well as Shirley Hazzard's "The Bay of Noon" and Brian Aldiss's "The Hand-Reared Boy." Peter Straus, the honorary archivist of the Booker Prize Foundation, told The Guardian: "I am delighted that, even in a Darwinian way, this year, with so many extraordinary novels, can now be covered by the Man Booker prize."

Generally speaking, chuck is too tough to eat without braising. (There is an exception: the blade, or flatiron steak, is delicious.) Braise it, however, and it becomes one of the most tender of meats, as in this version of Malaysian rendang, in which browned beef chunks are simmered in coconut milk until tender. At that point the traditional approach is to cook the meat dry, stirring all the while, so it develops a thick, brown crust. I prefer to leave it a little moist, the meat sitting in its gorgeous caramel-colored sauce.

Snøhetta is coming to New York. These rock stars of Scandinavian architecture will be featured in "Snøhetta: architecture-landscapes-interiors," opening Feb. 4 at Scandinavia House: the Nordic Center in America. The exhibition will feature 11 projects by the Oslo firm, which places equal emphasis on architecture, landscape and interiors, and which is known for its innovative, environmentally conscious designs. Founded in 1989, Snøhetta won raves for its Bibliotheca Alexandrina in Alexandria, Egypt, which was completed in 2001, and since then has amassed a project list that includes the iceberg-like New Norwegian National Opera and Ballet in Oslo (completed in 2008); the Ras Al-Khaimah Gateway Project, an undulating composition of buildings planned for the United Arab Emirates; and the National September 11 Memorial Museum Pavilion in New York. Until April 3 at 58 Park Avenue.

By now you've all seen "Avatar", unless the box-office numbers have been inflated by people who've seen it a hundred times. For me, James Cameron's blockbuster poignantly reinforced a philosophical dilemma that I had first experienced many years ago while reading a science fiction story by the great Isaac Asimov, "That Thou Art Mindful of Him." We'll discuss the dilemma later, but in this Asimov story, a robot named George directs the "robotization of the earth's ecology," creating little 'positronic' robot creatures that fill environmental roles. Today's protagonists might have come out of these sci-fi worlds. They are the antomatons seen in the picture.

A portrait of the cloistered author J. D. Salinger now hangs in the National Portrait Gallery. Devoted readers of "The Catcher in the Rye" can see the illustration of Mr. Salinger that was installed on Monday at the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery in Washington. The portrait of Mr. Salinger, who died on Wednesday at 91, was created by Robert Vickrey for the cover of Time magazine published on Sept. 15, 1961, and is meant to depict the author against a (metaphorical) amber wave of grain. (In that cover story, which was timed to the publication of Mr. Salinger's story collection "Franny & Zooey," the Time reporter writes that when Mr. Salinger moved to Cornish, N.H., in the early 1950s, "he was friendly and talkative; now when he jeeps to town, he speaks only the few words necessary to buy food or newspapers.") A press representative for the National Portrait Gallery said the painting was given to the gallery by Time magazine in 1978 and was last on display there through 1979. Before Mr. Salinger's death, the gallery was planning to install the portrait in its permanent collection exhibition in May.

Sewage in the Bay | During last week's storms, 630,000 gallons of raw sewage entered the San Francisco Bay at 47 spots, according to San Francisco Baykeeper, an environmental watchdog group. In addition, 170 million gallons of under treated sewage were discharged into the Bay, the group reported. Outdated sewer pipes and processing plants contribute to spills happening when big storms overwhelm the draining systems. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

Whether you're a master at step ball change or a first-time hoofer ready to strut your stuff, head over to The Kitchen tonight where the tap dancer, poet and "Bring in 'Da Noise Bring in 'Da Funk" alum Joseph Webb will be hosting "Shim Sham," a free and open jam tap session. What does it mean to be American? Hundreds of years have passed, and the question remains as charged as ever. But instead of watching the talking heads on cable news squawk over the answer, listen instead tonight to the authors Jamaica Kincaid, Gary Shteyngart, and others when they read excerpts from the new anthology "Becoming Americans: Four Centuries of Immigrant Writing" at the 92nd Street Y. The anthology includes letters, stories, and diaries documenting the immigrant experience in this country. The contributors will also share their personal experiences in a conversation moderated by the editor Ilan Stavans.

Times Square may not be a regular destination for art lovers, but starting today fans of the filmmaker Bruce Conner should brave the neon and swarms of tourists to watch a mini-retrospective of his work on MTV's outdoor screen. Presented by Creative Time at 44 ½, the showcase will feature three films by the artist, who died in 2008 and whose "ecstatic films — fabricated from bits of old documentaries and educational reels, from mass-cultural snips and snails and recycled movie tales — were at once salvage projects and assertions of individuality in an increasingly anonymous age," wrote Manohla Dargis in an appraisal. See for yourself when "Ten Second Film" (1965), "Crossroads" (1976) and "Easter Morning" (2008) are shown through Feb. 28.

TUNICK--Elinore Jacoff. August 4, 1921-January 30, 2010. Elly died at home, of multiple myeloma. Daughter of Frieda (1894-1986) and Morris (1892-1984) Jacoff. Wife for 53 years of Frederick L. Tunick, MD (1919-1994). Barnard graduate. Survived by adored children Alice and Paul (Susan Mauss Tunick), grandchildren Anna Tunick Tabachnik (Serge), Asher, Tamar and Zak Anolic; sister-in-law and brother-in-law Mimi and Arthur Iger; cousins Marilyn Abrams (Susan Tunick's aunt), Judi Marrus, George Steinberg and Steve Jacoff; nieces and nephews Nancy (Geoff), Susan (Bill), Carolyn (Eli), Bob (Willow); and nieces' and nephews' children Todd, Jenny (Matt and sons Bobby and Jack), Jessica, Jordan, Katie (Jarrod and daughter Hayden), Amanda, Max, William. Life-long artist and lover of art. Studied at Brooklyn Museum Art School with Ruben Tam and William Kienbusch; early member of Pleiades Gallery in SOHO. Extensive travels including a 1961 trip to the Matisse Chapel, the Leger Museum, and Picasso's Vallauris. Took loving care of Fred through his long illness. Cared for with devotion by Susan and by Renee Bizzeth, Phyllis Alexander, and Karen Hinds. Much gratitude to her superb doctors. Donations may be made to Barnard College. Burial will be private.

Sweden upset host Russia with a goal in the 20th minute of overtime to win the final of the world championship of bandy, 6-5, in Moscow on Sunday. Daniel Mossberg scored the goal that gave the Swedes their 10th world title, second only to Russia's 23 in the hockey-like sport played with 11 skaters a side on an ice sheet the size of a soccer field. On Saturday, the United States defeated Canada, 9-6, to remain in the A pool for next year's world championship. John Arundel scored three goals to pace the Americans, who broke open a 3-1 game with five straight goals just after halftime. The United States finished 1-5; Darren Richardson was the Americans' top scorer with eight goals and seven assists.

GROSS--Margery (nee Levy), died peacefully in her home in Stamford, CT on January 31, 2010, age 85. Wife of the late Alfred E. Gross. Survived by her children Jean (Donald Miller) and Robert (Barbara Wacholder). Formerly of Guilford, CT; Roslyn Heights, and NYC, NY. A dignified and elegant woman who cared more for others than herself. An activist who dedicated her life to political and social causes. Registered voters in Mississippi in 1964; founded Coalition for Safety and Justice in Nassau County, NY; appointed by gov. to NY State Probation Commission; co-chair of ACLU-CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the ACLU-CT or New Israel Fund. Visitors will be welcomed Tuesday, February 2 and Wednesday, February 3 from 1pm until 8pm at 155 Wildwood Road, Stamford, CT.

THE SOFT PACK ''The Soft Pack'' (Kemado) Everything is smarter up close than from a distance on the full-length debut of the Soft Pack, Southern California punk minimalists with a whiny streak. The singer Matt Lamkin operates at a single emotional register, sounding disdainful and disaffected at once. And the rest of the band -- the guitarist Matty McLoughlin, the bassist David Lantzman and the drummer Brian Hill -- are churners, jumping into songs at full speed, burning through them with aggressive nods to surf, to garage, to any subgenre that sums up as ''succinct mess.''

8 P.M. (IFC) HEATHERS (1989) Winona Ryder (above, with Christian Slater) stars in this cult classic satire of high school mean girls. Suicide becomes cool after the queen bee, Heather Chandler (Kim Walker), seems to off herself. The rest of the movie follows the characters' desperate struggles to be cool, with lethal results. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Guests include Andrew Young, Ashton Kutcher and Henry Paulson, former treasury secretary.

BETTY--Elio Jr.,72, of Old Saybrook, CT, formerly of Darien, CT died on Friday at home with his family. ORRIN EVANS ''Faith in Action'' (Posi-Tone) When the jazz pianist Orrin Evans leads a band, there's usually a moment in the middle of a tune when it goes off the rails and into the dirt, and things get interesting. Maybe the drummer breaks away from the song's governing rhythm and does something on the toms; the bassist starts playing agitated repetitions; and Mr. Evans commences some percussive banging or a little sly, perverse repetition or an improvised idea extended beyond the breaking point. He finds a node of tension and makes something bloom from it.

Back in the old days, a sign that a corporation had hit the big time was when it got a single-letter stock symbol on the New York Stock Exchange. For example, Ford has ''F,'' AT&T has ''T'' (for telephone) and United States Steel has ''X.'' On the Web, there's another way a single letter can enhance a company's prestige. Go to Google's home page or browser toolbar and type a single letter into the search box. The search engine will then drop down a list of suggestions, based on overall search activity. There are 26 sites that have the distinction of being Google's first suggestion for each letter of the alphabet.

Long after the Los Angeles Kings swarmed defenseman Drew Doughty, celebrating his last-minute goal and an improbable comeback Sunday, Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur was asked to recount what he saw on the play. He said softly that he did not see much of anything. Brodeur said he was screened on both of the Kings' goals in the final 1 minute 46 seconds as the Devils stumbled and lost to Los Angeles, 3-2, before a capacity crowd of 17,625 at Prudential Center that was set to salute them for a hard-earned victory.

Buyers of the iPad will grapple with the question of whether spending the extra cash for a model outfitted for wireless data over AT&T's overtaxed network will be worth it. But it's not just tablet computers, which some analysts estimate could sell in the low millions this year, that AT&T has to worry about. In its most recent earnings release, the company said it activated an additional 3.1 million iPhones on its network during the fourth quarter. And at the Consumer Electronics Show in January, AT&T announced plans to begin supporting two Palm smartphones, as well as several Android-powered smartphones, this year -- all of which have the potential to gobble down as much bandwidth as the iPhone.

Rex Ryan's team did not make it to the Super Bowl, but he certainly made a splash in Miami anyway. While attending a mixed martial arts event in Miami on Saturday night, Ryan, the Jets' coach, made an obscene gesture to a group of Dolphins fans, who captured the moment with a camera phone. It is unclear whether the fans did or said anything to provoke him. Ryan is smiling in the photograph, which was sent to several South Florida news media outlets Sunday. By Sunday afternoon, though, Ryan was apologizing in his typically blunt manner in a statement released by the team.

ROTH--Fred. Died peacefully at home in Boynton Beach, FL on January 29 at age 93. Mr. Roth is survived by his beloved wife of fifty five years Virginia (Von der Linden) Roth, devoted sons and daughters-in-law Steven and Daryl, David and Karen, Richard and Andrea, Jeffrey and Debbie, and Delfina Faria Da Silva who has been in the family for 38 years, his adoring grandchildren Amanda, Jordan, Benjamin, Brennen, Brielle, Chelsea and Jamon, and loving great-grandchildren Rebecca, Abigail, Emily and Jackson. The son of Sam and Lena Roth, Mr. Roth was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Erasmus Hall High School. He lived in Riverdale, NY, Tenafly, NJ and finally Boynton Beach, FL. Predeceased by siblings Sigismund, Doris, Jules and Millie. Mr. Roth and his wife Virginia met as students at Arthur Murray's dance studio in New York City and married in 1954. He built his own children's clothing manufacturing company, Wonderland Fashions, his life-long business, from which he retired in 1994. A lifelong lover of golf, Mr. Roth was a member of Briar Hall Country Club, Alpine Country Club and Hunter's Run Country Club and Community. A Memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 2 at 11am at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, New York City.

MIDLAKE ''The Courage of Others'' (Bella Union/Sony) The most striking chorus on ''The Courage of Others,'' the third full-length album by the indie soft-rock band Midlake, arrives stealthily, in a haze of petulance. ''I only want to be left to my own ways,'' declares Tim Smith, the band's lead singer and songwriter, like a precocious child from behind a closed door. The song is ''Rulers, Ruling All Things,'' and its harmonious purr, aflutter with flute and finger-picked guitars, creates a damp and cloistered feeling. You come away with the sense Mr. Smith says this a lot, and often gets his wish.

Oracle expects that through its acquisition of Sun Microsystems, it has a way to sell a full spectrum of hardware and software to business customers. That's the big picture. Digging in more deeply, it looks as if some of Sun's more quixotic projects will live on at Oracle.

JOFFE--Robert D. All the lawyers and staff of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP mourn the loss of their partner Bob Joffe, a friend and mentor who was a preeminent litigator and boardroom adviser. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife and family to whom he was so devoted. Mr. Joffe was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in August 2009 and died in New York, NY on January 28. He was 66 years old. Over the course of his extraordinary career, Mr. Joffe was well- known nationally and internationally, both for his tenacity in handling landmark litigation and for his ability to provide highly sensitive counsel in the boardrooms of corporate America. Since 1978, Mr. Joffe was the primary outside lawyer for Time Warner. One of the many significant matters he handled was the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. He was the principal litigator for Time Inc. in successfully rebutting Paramount's 1989 attempted takeover in a case considered to be a milestone in M&A litigation. Mr. Joffe represented the Boards of Directors of some of the world's most prominent companies in connection with their most pressing challenges, especially during the recent financial crisis. He was a longtime advisor to the non-management directors of Fannie Mae and was also counsel to the independent directors of Merrill Lynch, Citigroup, General Electric and General Motors, among many others. Mr. Joffe was passionate about human rights even as a student at Harvard Law School. From 1967 to 1969, after just a few months as a Cravath associate, Mr. Joffe left New York to serve in the Ministry of Justice of the Government of Malawi on an Africa Asia Public Service Fellowship funded by the Ford Foundation. It was in this position that he assisted the Commissioner for Law Revision in rewriting the country's laws and instituting a framework for supervision of the local courts for this African country. He continued his interest in civil rights and, in 1989, he argued Martin v. Wilks, a pro bono civil rights case in the United States Supreme Court in which he represented black and women municipal employees in Birmingham, Alabama, in an effort to secure equal opportunity in employment. In later years, as Cravath's Presiding Partner, Mr. Joffe was a strong promoter of the need for lawyers to treat pro bono clients with equal regard and concern as they would any paying client. Mr. Joffe became a partner at Cravath in 1975. He was elected Deputy Presiding Partner in 1997 and became Cravath's Presiding Partner in 1999. Mr. Joffe served as the Firm's leader until December 31, 2006. Mr. Joffe was a beloved and devoted husband, father and son. He is survived by his wife Virginia (Dinny), two children, Katherine Joffe (New York, NY) and David Joffe (New York, NY) and two stepchildren, Dr. Ryan DeHaas (Concord, NC) and Elizabeth DeHass (New York, NY), and two grandchildren. He is also survived by his mother, Bertha Joffe, and two brothers, Paul Joffe (Washington, DC) and Richard Joffe (New York, NY). A memorial service will be held to celebrate his life on Wednesday, February 10th at 11am at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Human Rights First, 333 Seventh Ave., 13th Floor, New York, NY 10001 or to The After-School Corporation, 1440 Broadway, 14th Floor, New York, NY 10018.

PAASWELL BAILINSON--Jean, passed away on January 31, at home in New York after a brief illness. Born May 7, 1924 in Brooklyn, to Benjamin and Lucille Paaswell, Jean was a lifelong and loyal New Yorker, lover of the Brooklyn Dodgers, New York Mets and the Metropolitan Opera. She studied at the Pratt Institute and Traphagen School of Fashion and began her career at Lord & Taylor's, then worked briefly at the New York Times where she met her former husband, Frank Bailinson, a long-time editor. Her advertising career focused on the fashion industry through the creation of Jean Paaswell Associates. In 1973 she founded Jean Grayson's Brownstone Studio, a successful mail order women's apparel company, serving as its President and chief creative force for almost thirty years. Jean will be remembered as a dynamic self-taught business-person with a wonderful fashion sense and an ability to treat everyone with compassion and dignity. Jean's first priority was her family for whom she was a devoted and self-less mother, grandmother and recently great-grandmother. She is survived by daughter Ann Kleinman of New York, son Frank Bailinson (Jann Dickerson) of San Francisco, son James Bailinson (Nancy Gibson) of Cumberland, Maine, and grandchildren Jill Kleinman Halberg (Kenneth) of New York, Emily, Charlotte, Peter and Julia Bailinson and great grandchild Zoe Lucille Halberg. Jean will be remembered with love by all who knew her for her warmth, generosity and style. A celebration of Jean's life will be held in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, 1-800-381-0075.

Paul A. Though she may look petite, and may glide unnoticed among the many bearded and fashionable patrons of Henry Public, a new cocktail-and-hamburger joint in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Cobble Hill, Ms. Tam, a 34-year-old marketing consultant, has outsize status there. She is the mayor of Henry Public.

The last official "American Idol" audition show of season nine was a warm, wet kiss with an unusually high percentage of treacle. Maybe it's the law of averages, but after several straight dud-thick shows this was "Idol" easing into its comfort zone, nudging viewer support in its preferred directions.

No. 22 Pittsburgh (16-5, 6-3 Big East) at No 6 West Virginia (17-3, 6-2)The Panthers are falling; they were 5-0 in the Big East but have lost three of their last four and are struggling to score. They averaged 74 points in their first five games, but that dropped to 62.7 in the past four. Not surprisingly, guard Ashton Gibbs is struggling, too. Gibbs averaged 20 points in the 5-0 start, shooting 51 percent. He's down to 14 points and 30 percent in the slump. He's still getting his shots (28 for 55 in the 5-0 start, 16 for 55 in the slump); he's just not making them.

The veteran Silicon Valley executive Dan Rosensweig is leaving his job as president and chief executive of Activision Blizzard's Guitar Hero franchise to take the same title at Chegg.com, a well-financed start-up that is applying the online rental model pioneered by Netflix to college textbooks. Previously, Mr. Rosensweig served as chief operating officer of Yahoo under Terry Semel, then the chief executive.

Taking a major step toward allowing openly gay men and women to serve in uniform, Defense Secretary Robert Gates and Adm. This change, Admiral Mullen said, "would be the right thing to do."

MetLife on Tuesday confirmed that it was in talks with the American International Group to buy a major life insurance unit, commonly known as Alico.

The theater producer who holds the rights to mount "A Streetcar Named Desire" on Broadway has decided not to try to transfer the Sydney Theater Company production starring Cate Blanchett, which was a critical and audience favorite in late 2009 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

After almost a year of exhibitions, performances, panels and screenings, the X Initiative, a nonprofit art consortium that took over the old Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea, will cease and desist on Friday, as planned. But it is going out with a bang and, in contrast to its rather austere exhibition program, with a stark lack of curatorial oversight. The farewell event is a 24-hour marathon titled "Bring Your Own Art (BYOA)" that starts Wednesday at 11 a.m. and ends 24 hours later, at 11 a.m. on Thursday.

In an opinion released on Tuesday, a federal judge in Manhattan dismissed all of the Securities and Exchange Commission's civil fraud complaints against Cohmad Securities, a small brokerage firm that the S.E.C. said had played a role in Bernard L. Madoff's long-running Ponzi scheme.

It is routine, of course, for start-ups to participate in business plan competitions and related events. It is virtually unheard of, however, that a start-up would hold its own competition to foster start-ups -- especially one offering a first-place prize of $100,000. From Milan and Paris, here are the sets that will have you singing "Let's do the time warp again!"

When "The Hurt Locker" was nominated as one of the 10 best movies on Tuesday morning, there were no names attached to receive the kudos officially. Greg Shapiro, one of four producers of the film, told the Bagger that his team was appealing the Academy's rule that only three people may take proper credit. The other producers are Kathryn Bigelow, the director and a nominee; Mark Boal, the screenwriter and a nominee; and Nicolas Chartier, the financier.

Last week was a tumultuous one at Harper's Magazine. On Monday morning, as the editor, Roger Hodge, finished a croissant, he was fired by the publisher, John R. MacArthur. On Tuesday, Mr. MacArthur, who goes by Rick, told Media Decoder that Mr. Hodge had chosen to resign: "It's his choice, and it's personal," he said. By that afternoon, Mr. MacArthur acknowledged he "misspoke," after Harper's editors said that was untrue.

She checks her pulse to be sure it stays in the target range of 80 to 95 beats per minute.

Leslie Day, author of "Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City" and resident of a houseboat docked at the 79th Street Boat Basin, had a rather distinguished guest Saturday morning: a mandarin duck, Aix galericulata, paddling with the usual gang of mallards outside her boat. "I have no idea where he came from or where he was going, but what a gift on a freezing NYC morning," Ms. Day wrote.

I remain skeptical of the Academy Awards' decision to expand the Best Picture pool to 10, but this year's list makes the decision look like a qualified success. Without the expansion, it's probably safe to assume that the roster of nominees would have consisted of "Avatar," "Up in the Air," "Inglourious Basterds," "The Hurt Locker" and "Precious." That means the additions are "An Education," "District 9," "Up," "A Serious Man," and "The Blind Side." The first four are solid or even inspired choices, and if - as people seem to think - the alternative to "The Blind Side" was "Invictus," then I'm glad the Academy went with Sandra Bullock's hit instead.

On Sunday, Amazon appeared to surrender to Macmillan in a dispute over the pricing of e-books. Macmillan, like other publishers, wanted more control over prices for their digital books. At first, Amazon responded by removing Macmillan titles, both digital and paper, from its site, except when bought through third-party vendors. Then, Amazon seemed to back down. But the talks are continuing, and Macmillan titles are still mostly absent from the Amazon site. Read the full story here.

It seemed a fairly straightforward request: a principal asked teachers to outline their goals for students as part of a school plan. But for the United Federation of Teachers, the request for written student goals amounted to an increase in the workday. So last April, the union filed an official grievance, claiming that the Education Department had "refused and/or failed to provide sufficient time during the workday for U.F.T.-represented teachers to perform the goal setting."

Carving out a niche in the crowded investment banking world is tough, with boutiques focusing on nearly every sector of the economy from autos to green technology. But the partners at Galileo Capital Management may have done just that with the start-up of LGBT Capital, a specialist corporate advisory and investment management unit that will focus exclusively on the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender consumer market.

Barry Estabrook says the Atlantic albacore may be going the way of the Atlantic bluefin. "Catches have dropped from 60,000 tons to 20,000, since the 1980s, but ICCAT'' -- the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna -- "still sets an annual limit that, at 32,000 tons, is more than 50 percent higher than the annual take.''

The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture will mark Black History Month with two major new exhibitions: one features photographs of President Barack Obama's first year in the White House; the other showcases watercolors by Jerry Pinkney that depict people and events in African-American history from colonial times to the Voting Rights Act of 1965. On view together under the theme of "365 Days: 390 Years in the Making," the two exhibitions will be on display Feb. 5 through April 18, 2010. "Barack Obama: The First Year," features 77 photographs by Pete Souza, the chief official White House photographer. Collected for public display for the first time, the photographs with commentary by Mr. Souza showcase such images as the inaugural ball last January and Mr. Obama playing with his children. "African-American Journey to Freedom," brings together 35 watercolors by Mr. Pinkney, an award-winning artist and illustrator. The exhibition includes depictions of events like the Great Migration of blacks from the South to the North, and famous figures like Sojourner Truth, as well as ordinary men, women and children.
Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.
Kraft Foods declared victory on Tuesday in its pursuit of Cadbury, announcing that it had won widespread support from the British confectioner's shareholders.

When Dr. Andrew Wakefield - the British doctor who linked vaccines to autism - was found to be "dishonest," "irresponsible" and acting "contrary to the clinical interests" of a child by a medical-misconduct panel last week, and when the respected medical journal The Lancet officially retracted its publication of Wakefield's 1998 study earlier today, those were but the most recent controversial moments in the medical mystery that is autism.
Update | 8:44 p.m. Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, apologized for using the word "retarded" to describe liberals at a closed-door meeting last year.

On the eve of moving into its new home, the Paul Taylor Dance Company said on Tuesday that it had eliminated an executive position to save money and was expecting to finish with a balanced budget this season, as it celebrates Mr. Taylor's 80th birthday. The Paul Taylor Dance Foundation, which runs the company, said its executive director, Martin I. Kagan, resigned on Friday. He was effectively replaced by the company's general manager, John Tomlinson, who was given the title of managing director of the foundation. Mr. Tomlinson said that construction work was complete on the company's new studios and offices on the Lower East Side and that it was just waiting for permits to move in. He said he hoped that would happen before the start of the company's season at City Center on Feb. 24. The company lost the lease on its old home in SoHo in late 2008.

Meanwhile, some big Olympic names made an impact -- including Teemu Selanne, who suffered a broken jaw on Jan. 13 and was feared lost to Finland for the Winter Games. Home teams listed first:

On Wednesday, Jan. 27, Maplewood police arrested four teenagers that detectives said broke into Seth Boyden Elementary School on Boyden Avenue in Maplewood over the weekend of Dec. 19. The police said the teenagers scanned the Internet on school computers, took "several items" from two classrooms (including two Palm Pilot PDAs, which were recovered) and munched on some food they found in a classroom.

In his typical style, Elon Musk, Tesla Motors' chief executive, laid out grand ambitions in a government filing Friday: He wants to make all-electric sport utility vehicles, vans and coupes once he is done with Tesla's sports car and sedan.

Pinot gris is a most unusual grape. Unlike, say, sauvignon blanc, which is pretty much identifiable as sauvignon blanc wherever it comes from regardless of varying expressions of terroir, pinot gris offers completely different guises depending on whether it hails from Alsace, Italy (as pinot grigio) or Oregon, which is the subject of my column.

If you're going to spend several weeks crashing at Norman Mailer's place, it's probably for the best that the master of the house is no longer around. The British edition of GQ magazine is offering young writers an opportunity to stay for a month at the disheveled if singularly productive author's former home in Provincetown, Mass., where Mailer lived from the 1990s until his death in 2007, and which has since been turned into a writers' retreat. The Guardian reported that Dylan Jones, the magazine's editor, announced on Tuesday the start of an annual nonfiction writing competition, open to undergraduates and post-graduates at British universities who are over the age of 18. The contest will be judged by a panel that includes GQ editors and the pop singer Lily Allen; its winner may be published in GQ, and will for certain receive a prize of about $1,600 and a July stay at the Norman Mailer Writers Colony, whose activities include writing workshops, seminars and not getting beaten with a hammer by Rip Torn.

President Obama's Jobs for Small Business 2010 United States Tour continues. Tuesday's stop: Nashua, N.H., where he is to flesh out his State of the Union proposal to facilitate lending by community banks to the tune of at least $30 billion.

(The latter two were nominated in categories like costumes and art direction.)

The Italian Olympic Committee isn't fooling around with its intent to take a drug-free team to the Vancouver Games. The organization announced Tuesday that it would fine any Italian athlete $140,000 if he or she was caught doping at the Winter Games.

There comes a time when musicians heed a certain call and come together as one, and that time came on Monday evening as more than 70 performers joined up to record a new version of "We Are the World" to benefit Haitian earthquake relief organizations, Reuters reported. The all-star session took place in the same Hollywood studio where the original song, written by Lionel Richie and Michael Jackson and produced by Quincy Jones to raise money for African famine victims, was recorded, and was overseen by Mr. Richie and Mr. Jones. Among the artists who can be heard on the new single are Barbra Streisand, Celine Dion, Tony Bennett, Snoop Dogg, Lil Wayne, Drake, LL Cool J, and will.i.am of Black Eyed Peas, as well as Justin Bieber, who sings the song's opening line, and Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-American performer who has largely served as the celebrity face of the earthquake relief effort. None of the performers on the original "We Are the World" recording are involved in the new single, nor was Lady Gaga, who was widely rumored to be on the producers' wish list. Randy Phillips, the AEG Live executive, told Reuters that a video for the song would have its debut on Feb. 12 during the Winter Olympics, and that proceeds will go to a newly established charity foundation.

There was a wave of cheering in the press room when "The Blind Side" was announced as a best picture contender on Tuesday morning. In a year tailor-made for surprises, the Oscars delivered some, with the box-office hit nabbing a lead spot and a nomination for its star, Sandra Bullock. When he announced in December that he was entering rehab, the Aerosmith front man Steven Tyler said that he was "eager to be back" with his band mates as soon as possible. Perhaps to illustrate that point, his lawyer has sent a cease-and-desist letter to the band's management, saying that its efforts to seek a replacement singer "could destroy" the group, Billboard reported. In a letter to the band's manager, Howard Kaufman, Mr. Tyler's lawyer, Skip Miller, wrote that the strategy was "playing band members off against one another" and "engaging in acts and conduct to the harm and detriment" of the singer and the band. "Aerosmith without Steven Tyler is like the Rolling Stones without Mick Jagger, or U2 without Bono," Mr. Miller wrote. "While this management strategy may get the band on the road a few months sooner, it ultimately could destroy Aerosmith."

"As President Obama and his aides unveiled the administration's fiscal 2011 budget with lots of talk about reining in discretionary spending,'' the Web site Inside Higher Ed wrote Tuesday morning, "they largely exempted programs important to higher education from the budget restraint they urged.''

"C'etait un Rendez-Vous," the nine-minute film of a car speeding through Paris at dawn, with only the car's revving engine as soundtrack, is a cult classic. Produced in 1976 by the French director Claude Lelouch, the film has inspired numerous remakes and spoofs, including Nissan's promo for the 350Z several years ago.

A special master ruled Monday that N.F.L. owners may not dismantle its supplemental revenue program, as it had planned to do at the start of the 2010 league year, a victory for the players union on the eve of the uncapped year. The pool is worth about $200 million and is divided among 8 to 12 lower-revenue teams. Owners had contended that the pool was only required during years with a salary cap and that with the disappearance of the cap, the pool was no longer necessary.Stephen Burbank, the special master, ruled that the owners could not unilaterally dismantle the program, and that the collective bargaining agreement demanded that the union approve of any changes to supplemental revenue sharing.

The N.F.L. players' union last week requested a meeting with the owners' labor committee before the Super Bowl with the start of an uncapped year looming. The owners agreed, so the sides will meet early Saturday, before a previously scheduled meeting of team owners. The meeting is unusual because it will involve the full labor committee of owners and players on the union's executive committee, and is not a meeting of the regular negotiating teams for both sides.

The Oscar nominations were announced at dawn on Tuesday. The full story and the complete list of nominees are on the Carpetbagger blog. Bottom line: Lots of love for James Cameron, Quentin Tarantino and "The Hurt Locker" -- not so much for Clint Eastwood. Check in with Carpetbagger throughout the day for Oscar updates.

No details yet from the Recording Academy about what led to the, shall we say, aggressively dissonant duet between Taylor Swift and Stevie Nicks during the Grammy Awards on Sunday night. But CBS, which showed the awards ceremony, has provided a brief explanation of why it censored a rap performance that featured Eminem, Lil Wayne and Drake. The audio from the performance, which combined the rap songs "Forever" and "Drop the World," was frequently cut from the live telecast, leading many viewers to wonder if their television sets simply weren't working. In an interview with The Associated Press, Chris Ender, a spokesman for CBS, said: "It was a rousing musical performance, but words were edited from the live telecast that didn't meet our broadcast standards. We have great respect for artists' creative freedom, but there are certain things you can't say, or sing, on television."

Accusations of Bullying | Steve Poizner, the state's insurance commissioner and a candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, accused his rival in the primary, Meg Whitman, of criminally trying to bully him out of the race. In a complaint with federal and state authorities, Mr. Poizner said that Mike Murphy, an official in the Whitman campaign, sent him an e-mail message urging him to leave the race and run for the Senate in 2012. Mr. Murphy, in a statement, did not deny claim. "After reading the ridiculous charges made by Steve Poizner during today's strange press conference," Mr. Murphy's statement said, "all I can say is that I'm starting to worry about the commissioner's mental condition." [The New York Times]

An article on Sunday, about the first year of the Nixon administration, misstated the medal President Nixon bestowed on Duke Ellington. It was the Presidential Medal of Freedom, not the Medal of Honor.

An obituary on Jan. 24 about Bob Noorda, a graphic designer who helped modernize the signs in the New York City subway system, misidentified the agency that commissioned his work in 1966. It was the New York City Transit Authority, not the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. If you’ve ever indulged in a marathon of MTV’s “The Hills” or “The City,” then you know who Kelly Cutrone is. The fashion publicist and founder of the P.R. company People’s Revolution, “is a backstage figure propelled by the synergy of the celebrity industry into her own version of stardom,” writes Alessandra Stanley. She has succeeded with the arrival of “Kell on Earth,” which began on Monday, and “is the latest addition to the Bravo universe, a reality show that follows Ms. Cutrone, as she bullies and cajoles her way through the underbelly of the New York fashion world.” Though she is more of “an earth mother” — no make up, sloppy dress — than a glitzy, size zero Rachel Zoe type, she still makes assistants quake in their Louboutins. Spot her minions tonight at Barnes & Noble where she’ll be reading from the book she co-authored, “If You Have to Cry, Go Outside: And Other Things Your Mother Never Told You.”

Compared to, say, JVC Jazz or CMJ, the New York Guitar Festival doesn't get much attention from the city's music community, but that doesn't it mean it should be overlooked. The series, which runs through Feb. 4 has been "examining virtually every aspect of the guitar's musical personality" since 1999. Tonight, head to Le Poisson Rouge to listen to Marc Ribot's contribution. "Mr. Ribot is a fount of pithy commentary," writes Nate Chinen. "In Ceramic Dog, his punkish band with the bass guitarist Shahzad Ismaily and the drummer Ches Smith, he pursues a more messily ecstatic agenda; the name of the group's most recent album, 'Party Intellectuals,' captures it perfectly." Mr. Ribot will be performing songs off that album as part of the festival with Skeleton$.

The goal of the European artist Tino Sehgal is to create “something (a situation) from virtually nothing (actions, words) and then let that something disappear, leaving no potentially marketable physical trace,” writes Holland Cotter. “His rule may be unenforceable in this day and age. Still, it turns the museum into a zone of sort-of secrecy. It piques both the voyeur and the skeptic in us.” Mr. Sehgal, who lives in Berlin and studied political economy and dance, has cleared out the Guggenheim for his self-titled exhibition, which runs through March 10. “Yet the space isn’t empty. On the rotunda’s ground floor, a man and woman entwine in a changing, slow-motion amorous embrace” and “on the ramps above, people walk and talk in pairs or clusters at a leisurely pace, with new participants periodically joining conversations as others drop away.” Mr. Sehgal’s art is made up almost entirely of such balletic tableaus and social encounters; it’s bare-bones but “addictive” and makes you want to return for more.

Following Oprah Winfrey (“The Color Purple”), Jay-Z and Will and Jada Pinkett Smith (“Fela!”) in lending their names to Broadway shows, Elton John and his partner, David Furnish, have signed on to the producing team of the forthcoming Broadway transfer “Next Fall,” a new play about the happiness, strains and religious differences between two gay men during their five-year romantic relationship. As producers Mr. John and Mr. Furnish have put money into the show — on Monday no one involved in the production would say how much — and will lend their names to publicity and other material in hopes of drawing attention to the play. Written by Geoffrey Nauffts and directed by Sheryl Kaller, the Naked Angels production of “Next Fall” — which drew critical acclaim during an Off Broadway run at Playwrights Horizons last summer — is moving to the Helen Hayes Theater without a star performer, director or playwright, a risky proposition on Broadway today. It is scheduled to begin previews on Feb. 16 and to open on March 11.

Got something you want to express to Rocco Landesman, right, and the National Endowment for the Arts — in a constructive, artistic way? Now’s your chance. On Monday the N.E.A. and Mr. Landesman, its chairman, announced that proposals are being sought for a new logo to represent the phrase “Art Works,” which Mr. Landesman has previously described as the agency’s “guiding mission.” In a statement Mr. Landesman said the logo, which will be used in print and online promotions, should represent the three meanings of the phrase: the creations of artists, the effect of art on audiences and the contribution of artists to the economy. Proposals for the design must be submitted by e-mail to the endowment by 5 p.m. Eastern time on Feb. 26. The author of the proposal selected will receive a government grant of about $25,000. Instructions and requirements for submissions are at arts.gov.

Devoted readers of “The Catcher in the Rye” will be able to see a portrait of its author, J. D. Salinger, that was installed on Monday at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington. The painting of Mr. Salinger, above, who died on Wednesday at 91, was created by Robert Vickrey for the cover of Time magazine published on Sept. 15, 1961, and is meant to depict the reclusive Mr. Salinger against a (metaphorical) amber wave of grain. (In that cover story, timed to the publication of Mr. Salinger’s story collection “Franny & Zooey,” the Time reporter writes that when Mr. Salinger moved to Cornish, N.H., in the early 1950s, “he was friendly and talkative; now when he jeeps to town, he speaks only the few words necessary to buy food or newspapers.”) A press representative for the National Portrait Gallery said Time gave the painting to the gallery in 1978, and the work was last on display there through 1979.

HIRSH--Selma. We deeply mourn the death of our dear friend, colleague, and advisor, Selma Hirsh, who was a founder and Steering Committee member of the Jacob Blaustein Institute. Selma's insights and her wise and worldly advice will remain among our most treasured gifts. Selma's imprint on the Institute's work is indelible. With a firm commitment to human rights, and a sense of impatience in wanting to see rights protected globally, she held us to the highest professional standards and encouraged a unique collaborative style of operation. She was a remarkable woman who was never at a loss for the right word, the right policy and the right judgments, and we shall miss her dearly. Jacob Blaustein Institute for the Advancement of Human Rights, The American Jewish Committee E. Robert Goodkind, Chair Felice Gaer, Director

SHUREN--Irving, died on January 31, 2010. Beloved husband of Rochelle, loving and generous stepfather of Robin (Robert), Barry, Jennifer (David), empathic and involved grandfather to Ariana and Marlaina. Irv was a brilliant, engaged, down to earth, talented and insightful psychoanalyst, supervisor, teacher and writer. Known for his love of music, cigars, travel, and restaurants. His verve and capacity for joy were striking throughout his life. Irv touched a multitude of people who will never know his name. By those fortunate enough to have known him, he will be remembered and missed.

It's not quite as impressive as scoring, say, the last known interview with J. D. Salinger, but The Cleveland Plain Dealer has landed what is believed to be the first interview in nearly 20 years with Bill Watterson, the privacy-loving creator of the comic strip ''Calvin and Hobbes.'' Mr. Watterson's newspaper cartoons about a headstrong boy named Calvin and his stuffed tiger, Hobbes, ran in syndication from 1985 to 1995, until Mr. Watterson stepped away from the strip at the peak of its popularity, and he has rarely spoken about it since. Asked 15 years later why ''Calvin and Hobbes'' was such a popular work, Mr. Watterson told The Plain Dealer: ''I just tried to write honestly, and I tried to make this little world fun to look at, so people would take the time to read it. That was the full extent of my concern.'' Mr. Watterson added that he still experienced ''occasional flare-ups of weirdness'' from die-hard fans and was flattered that people still read his work, but, he said, ''I wrote 'Calvin and Hobbes' in my 30s, and I'm many miles from there.''

The Tony-winning director Anna D. Shapiro (''August: Osage County'') has signed on to a Broadway revival of ''You Can't Take It With You'' next fall, according to the producers of the show, Elizabeth I. McCann and Joey Parnes. The producers said on Monday that they had scheduled preview performances to begin on Nov. 5, with an opening night of Nov. 14, at a Broadway theater to be determined. The ensemble casting for the colorful Sycamore family and the prim Kirby family, who blend humorously when two of their children decide to wed, will be announced later. Pending conclusion of negotiations, the Huntington Theater Company in Boston is expected to present the production in a pre-Broadway run from Sept. 24 to Oct. 24. George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart won a Pulitzer Prize in 1937 for that three-act play, which was last revived on Broadway in 1983, starring Colleen Dewhurst, Jason Robards and Elizabeth Wilson.

LAX--Ruth. NYFS mourns the loss of Ruth Lax, a longtime member, teacher, supervisor, and friend. Her scholarship, social activism, and love of psychoanalysis will be greatly missed.

LEEDS--Charles, died January 31, 2010. Cherished and loving husband of the late Sylvia S. Leeds, father of Theodore Feldman and last surviving child of Isidor and Annie Levy of the Bronx. Served in the US Army and was in active duty in Europe from June 1943 until January 1946. He owned and operated Haril Textiles. Charlie served on the board of trustees of YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities. He was a passionate advocate for the establishment and high standards of services for individuals with developmental disabilities. In his leisure he was an avid reader and devoted to theater, travel, good conversation and intense friendships. He enriched the lives of his friends and family. There will be a service for Charlie on Wednesday, February 3rd, at 4pm at Vernon C. Wagner Funeral Home, Hicksville, NY. 516-935-7100.

ROSEN--Benjamin, of Fort Lee, NJ, 90 years old, passed away on January 31, surrounded by his loving family. Ben was an innovative and successful real estate developer, dedicated philanthropist, and family man. He was known for his exuberant personality, fun loving spirit and desire to help others. He was unique and unforgettable. He is survived by his wife Yetta, the love of his life for 68 years, their children Stephen and Penny Rosen, Myrna and Yale Block, Dr. Beth Rosen and Pamela Cobey, and grandchildren Douglas and Adam Rosen, Lisa Bergman, Barry and Julianne Osherow, Linda and Geoffrey Stern, and Brian Block. He was also blessed with six great-grandchildren. He will be greatly missed!

A forecast of rain has forced the N.F.L. to move Tuesday's Super Bowl media day inside for the first time in memory. The event, which is usually on the playing field at the host stadium, will instead be staged on an indoor concourse, a more compact environment for the annual theater of the media absurd.

STITT--Nancy Kendall. With great sadness, the friends of Nancy Kendall Stitt announce her passing on January 28, 2010 at the age of 85. Born to Homer and Eileen Kendall of Alliance, Ohio, Nancy arrived in New York to pursue a career in vocal music in the early 1950s. Shortly thereafter, she married the late Rev. Jesse Stitt, Minister of The Village Presbyterian Church. Throughout her career as an ensemble singer, Nancy performed with most of New York City's major concert organizations and was instrumental in the creation of the Village Light Opera Company serving as an early director. Nancy was an active soloist in many houses of worship and was director of music of the Woodstock Jesuit Community at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, organizing the liturgical music for the annual ordinations of Jesuit priests at Fordham University. In addition to her performance career, Nancy was a faithful member of AGMA, serving many years as a member of its governing board. She was also a President of Church Women United. Her talent, dedication and joy in watching her beloved New York Mets will be sorely missed.

A day after masked gunmen killed 16 people in Ciudad Juárez, the authorities have not determined a motive for the attack, Mayor José Reyes Ferriz said Monday. Most of the dead were teenagers celebrating at a birthday party whom Mr. Reyes described as ''innocent civilians.'' Ciudad Juárez has become one of the most violent cities in the world since the Mexican government began its crackdown on drug cartels three years ago. Mexican newspapers reported Monday that January was the bloodiest month since the crackdown began, with more than 900 people killed in violence related to organized crime.

ROTH--Fred. Died peacefully at home in Boynton Beach, FL on January 29 at age 93. Mr. Roth is survived by his beloved wife of fifty five years Virginia (Von der Linden) Roth, devoted sons and daughters-in-law Steven and Daryl, David and Karen, Richard and Andrea, Jeffrey and Debbie, and Delfina Faria Da Silva who has been in the family for 38 years, his adoring grandchildren Amanda, Jordan, Benjamin, Brennen, Brielle, Chelsea and Jamon, and loving great-grandchildren Rebecca, Abigail, Emily and Jackson. The son of Sam and Lena Roth, Mr. Roth was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Erasmus Hall High School. He lived in Riverdale, NY, Tenafly, NJ and finally Boynton Beach, FL. Predeceased by siblings Sigismund, Doris, Jules and Millie. Mr. Roth and his wife Virginia met as students at Arthur Murray's dance studio in New York City and married in 1954. He built his own children's clothing manufacturing company, Wonderland Fashions, his life-long business, from which he retired in 1994. A lifelong lover of golf, Mr. Roth was a member of Briar Hall Country Club, Alpine Country Club and Hunter's Run Country Club and Community. A Memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 2 at 11am at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, New York City.
A two-bedroom two-bath loft apartment in Central Amsterdam is on the market for 995,000 euros (about $1.4 million).

Chinese officials have rejected demands by the Dalai Lama that Tibetan areas of China receive greater autonomy and be governed as a single region, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported Monday. The report came after days of meetings in China between Chinese officials and envoys of the Dalai Lama, left, the Tibetan spiritual leader. A senior Chinese official, Du Qinglin, told the envoys that the concept of a ''Greater Tibet'' and ''high-level autonomy'' violated the Constitution, Xinhua reported.

Near the end of my surgical training, I spent three months as chief resident of a hospital trauma team. Two other doctors-in-training and I formed the first-line emergency room response, resuscitating patients who had been mangled, burned or otherwise injured. It was my first experience as a leader, but each of us was already fairly proficient and we all got along. I was confident that we would work well together. I was wrong.

10 P.M. (BET) THE MICHAEL VICK PROJECT This new documentary series chronicles the return of Michael Vick (above, second from left, with family members) to football as a backup quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles. A former first-stringer for the Atlanta Falcons, Mr. Vick lost his contract after pleading guilty to bankrolling a dog-fighting operation in 2007. After 18 months in prison, he was released to find his relationship with the N.F.L. and his family strained. This series investigates his life before prison as well as his experiences after. 4 P.M. Barzee, who in November pleaded guilty to federal charges of kidnapping and unlawful transportation of a minor in exchange for a 15-year prison term in the case of Elizabeth Smart. It has been more than six months since President Obama held a prime-time news conference at the White House. A new study finds that places him on a par with Herbert Hoover for the number of times he has held formal news conferences with reporters. The White House says this statistic does not reflect today's reality of how Americans receive their news and information. So in the search for creative ways to convey the president's message, the White House turned to YouTube, where more than 11,000 questions had been submitted since last week's State of the Union speech.

Nearly 10 years after a Concorde jet crashed on takeoff from Charles de Gaulle Airport outside Paris, Continental Airlines and five people are scheduled to stand trial on Tuesday in a French criminal court, accused of manslaughter in 113 deaths. A 2002 report by French air accident investigators concluded that a small strip of metal had fallen off a Continental DC-10 that took off minutes earlier, and that the piece punctured a tire of the Air France Concorde as it accelerated down the runway on July 25, 2000. The tire disintegrated in seconds, investigators said, sending shards of rubber into the fuel tanks and causing a catastrophic fire. All 109 passengers and crew members were killed, along with 4 people on the ground.

DEWAR--Nick. Twinkling eyes, wry smile, bespectacled Scotsman of extraordinary talent and enormous wit has left us way, way too soon. Our loss will be felt deeply, far and wide. Amazing husband of Sri, treasured friend to so many. Contributions in Nick's memory can be made to WFMU, New Jersey.

CORPUEL--Peter, died on January 30, 2010 surrounded by his family. Loved by his wife Kathy, children, Josh, Ali, Narcis and Jenn, his brothers Michael, Noel, and Jeffrey, his sisters-in-law Randy, Georgeanne and Carol, and his granddaughter Sarah -- she brought him so much joy. All who knew him loved him. Funeral will be at Gutterman's 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY Wednesday at noon.

SCHAFFNER--Bertram H.,M.D., brilliant psychiatrist, psychoanalyst, mentor, colleague, and friend. Pioneer in understanding different cultures, people with AIDS, rights of gays and lesbians, and Indian art. A gentle giant. Mark J. Blechner, Ph.D.

HIRSH--Selma. AJC mourns the passing of Selma Hirsh, who served the global advocacy organization for five decades, beginning in 1945, in our New York headquarters. A dynamic woman of grace, elegance and wisdom, Selma fulfilled a series of key roles at AJC during a critical time in American Jewish history, culminating as AJC Associate Executive Director from 1972-1982. After retiring, she continued her involvement with the agency as a co-founder of AJC's Institute on American Jewish Israeli Relations, and also in her association with AJC's Jacob Blaustein Institute for the Advancement of Human Rights. The strength of AJC today is due in large measure to her dedication and leadership. We extend our condolences to her daughters and to all members of the mourning family. Richard Sideman, President David Harris, Executive Director American Jewish Committee

DICK--Marion Pokoik. It is with great sadness we learned of the passing of our friend and business partner, Marion Pokoik Dick. The members and employees of Steinberg & Pokoik and the respective Steinberg families wish to extend sincere and heartfelt condolences to Marion's children, grandchildren and extended family. Marion was a vibrant, active, kind and caring woman and will be sorely missed by all.

ISAACSON--Daniel L.,on February 1, 2010. He lived a rewarding and active long life, mostly with his devoted and beloved wife, Thelma. Daniel was a self-made successful businessman who, in his later years, became a painter and a photographer par excellence. He was a caring father to his children Jane, Matt and Larry and their respective spouses Warren, Lainie, and Michele. He doted on his grandchildren Joshua, Nina, Alex, Sarah, Anna, Jess, Mollie, Cora, and his great-grandchild Asher. He was a wonderful uncle and good friend to all who knew him. We will miss his sense of humor, generosity and his beautiful photographs. Funeral services will be held February 2nd, at noon, at Sherman's Funeral Home, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. The family will be sitting shiva at 40 Dover St., Brooklyn.

Ten Americans arrested in Haiti for trying to take 33 children across the border without proper documentation were expected to learn Monday whether they would face criminal charges of child trafficking and kidnapping. Members of the group, who are Baptists from the United States, said they had been falsely accused of child abduction and insisted they had only been trying to rescue orphans in the wake of the earthquake that devastated the Haitian capital on Jan. 12.
CORPUEL--Peter. Our hearts and appetites will truly miss our "delicious chef". You were loved by all. Ilene Katz, Ross, Ian, Erica, Liza, Ryan and Jean Shapiro

Planners of the National Tea Party Convention announced late Sunday that main parts of the convention, including the keynote address on Saturday night by Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, would be broadcast live on cable television and the Internet. The organizers suggested that they saw the broadcast as a solution to some of the criticism leveled at the convention, which is billed as a coming together of the conservative grass-roots groups that sprang up last year to protest the federal stimulus package.

LAX--Ruth F.,Ph.D., passed away in her home the morning of January 31, 2010. She was a training and supervisory analyst as well as a member of the faculties of both IPTAR and the NY Freudian Society. In addition, she belonged to 17 other professional organizations. She recently retired from her practice in New York City. The author of Being and Becoming a Woman, Dr. Lax also published numerous articles in psychoanalytic journals. She chaired a study group investigating the psychoanalytic causes of socially sanctioned violence against women. She was predeceased by her first husband, Lewis L. Salton and her second husband, Leon Ari Falik, M.D. She is survived by her son, William Lax Salton, Ph.D., his wife Angela Matthews, Psy.D. and her grandson Javier Salton; her stepdaughter Imy Wax and her husband Howard Wax and their children Deborah and Gregory Goodman; her stepson Shelley Falik, M.D. and his wife Kathleen MacNeil. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, 11:15am on Tuesday, February 2nd.

The bulldozers came at night, flanked by armor-clad riot police officers, to clear the houses of a small neighborhood here at the behest of Moscow's mayor, forcing residents out into subzero temperatures. The mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov, said they were living on the land illegally. But as more and more homes -- some stately, some mere shacks -- have come tumbling down over the last week and a half, an uncharacteristically fierce backlash has broken out, challenging one of Russia's most powerful politicians. Politicians, human rights activists, media organizations and even nationalist and anarchist groups have come to the defense of the neighborhood, called Rechnik. Legal or not, these critics say, the demolition operation has crossed the line.

ROSEN--Benjamin. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and benefactor, Benjamin Rosen, whose powerful and imposing frame cradled a soft and generous heart. His many decades of support for our Division, the 68 years of mutual devotion between him and his wife, Yetta, and his boundless affection for their three children, their son- and daughters-in-law, and their grandchildren and great-grandchildren remain a timeless example and inspiration to us all. Lloyd Mayer, M.D., David B. Sachar, M.D., GI Division, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

CORPUEL--Peter. The Wayne County Camp Association ("WCCA") mourns with sadness the passing of our outstanding camp director, Peter Corpuel. In addition to leading Camp Wayne for Boys, one of America's premier boys camp, Peter spent eight years as the president of the WCCA. In this role, Peter used his brilliant business mind to promote the summer camp experience for the 30 camps in our region. We are thankful for having had Peter in our lives and will greatly miss his leadership, friendship and camaraderie. Our deepest sympathy goes out to his wife, Kathy, children, Josh, Ali, Narcis and Jenn, brothers Michael, Noel, and Jeffrey, sisters-in-law Randy, Georgeanne and Carol, granddaughter Sarah and the entire Camp Wayne Family.

ZOBEL--Margot. The Parkinson's Disease Foundation mourns the loss of Margot's vigorous voice and her magnanimous leadership on behalf of people with Parkinson's. We wish every comfort at this time to her daughter, Vida, and her many friends. Lewis Rowland, M.D., President Robin Elliott, Exec. Director

My Thursday column is about the war in eastern Congo, looking at the work of Lisa Shannon and her Run for Congo Women. Readers sometimes ask why I often write about outsiders, like Lisa, rather than about the innumerable local people who are doing extraordinary work -- often at greater risk. It's certainly true that Congo, for example, has a vibrant and admirable civil society, full of Congolese women themselves organizing against rape and war.

The Obama administration, even as it tried to restrain other domestic spending in its 2011 budget request, has called for expanding the Pell Grants, the main federal college aid program for low-income families. If adopted by Congress, the president's formula would raise the top grant to $5,710 in 2011, compared with $5,550 this year, according to The Chronicle of Higher Education, and make the program available to an additional one million students.

It sounded like the makings of a wild scene: For 24 hours, anyone and everyone could show their art, at a major exhibition space in Chelsea (Dia's former home, no less). To participate in "Bring Your Own Art (B.Y.O.A.)," the closing event of the yearlong, not-for-profit X Initiative program, all you had to do was bring your work in anytime after 11 a.m. Wednesday, grab a spot in the galleries, install it, and remove it by 2 p.m. the following day. The description on the X Initiative Web site conjured images of American Idol auditions, or at least of half of Bushwick pitching tents along West 22nd Street.

Monster Worldwide said Wednesday afternoon that it was buying HotJobs, a rival employment Web site, from Yahoo for $225 million in cash. The deal's price represents a significant discount from the $439 million that Yahoo paid for HotJobs in 2002.

Michael Mann, the climatologist from Pennsylvania State University who has been under attack by foes of restrictions on greenhouse gases and critics of the dominant view that human-driven warming is occurring and dangerous, has been cleared on three points of inquiry by a faculty review panel at the university, John Broder of The Times reports. A fourth question will be investigated further.

Ben S. Bernanke stepped into the imposing two-story marble atrium at the Federal Reserve's headquarters and took the oath of office from his deputy. The president lauded him as "an economist's economist" who had "earned the respect of the global financial community." A cabinet secretary, members of Congress and two former Fed chairmen looked on.

Update | 6:29 p.m. One of Alberto Giacometti's best-loved bronzes, "Walking Man I," broke the world record price for a work of art at auction, selling to an unidentified telephone bidder for $92.5 million, or $104.3 million with fees at Sotheby's in London on Wednesday night. The previous record was $104.1 million, paid for Picasso's 1905 ''Boy With a Pipe (The Young Apprentice)'' at Sotheby's in New York in 2004.

Children, unfortunately, are all too often the perfect subject for photojournalists, since they embody - in their innocence - the grievous damage of wars, disasters and civil strife. Today, their faces run through the show. To fathom the trauma of the school bombing in Pakistan, take a moment to study Slide 2, by Ali Shah of Reuters. As your eyes accustom themselves to the strong contrast of light and shadow, you will begin to see more of the human toll. In visiting the children at the makeshift clinic in a soccer stadium in Port-au-Prince (Slides 3 and 4), Ruth Fremson of The Times finds contrasting emotions. Slide 10 by Dar Yasin of The Associated Press seems at first to be a more benign view of curious boyhood - until you read the caption.

Few McDonald's franchisees have ever been as prominent or daring as Irwin S. Kruger. In the 37 years since he opened the company's first outlet in Midtown Manhattan, Mr. Kruger has spoken out about changes in the McDonald's menu and has even done a little tinkering of his own.

Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said Wednesday that the American International Group's contracts to pay hundreds of millions of dollars in bonuses were "outrageous" and appealed to Congress to help recoup the payments. He said Congress could help recover the "deeply irresponsible" bonuses by passing an Obama administration proposal to levy fees on large financial firms.

Lincoln Center on Wednesday announced its "Great Performers" programming for next season and the big news included no news: programmers will mount two festivals, but officials declined to release the themes, subject matter, performers or even all the genres being presented. A spokeswoman said in an e-mail that the festivals, one in the fall and one in the spring, would be announced when "all of the information is confirmed/finalized." A news release from Lincoln Center did say that the festivals "will incorporate productions of genre-crossing works, innovative collaborations and premieres, and diverse music presentations." Lincoln Center also said that two groups, the chorus Accademia Chigiana Siena, and the Belgian wind ensemble I Solisti del Vento, would be making their New York debuts during the season.

In 1983, Norma Millay of Austerlitz, N.Y., wrote a letter to The New York Times Book Review that is certainly one of the more romantic tributes to St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village. Addressing what some more realistically minded souls assumed must be the apocryphal story that her sister, Edna St. Vincent Millay, the famous poet, got her middle name from the hospital, Norma Millay assured the book review: "The reason why the story that my sister was named for New York's St. Vincent Hospital has been bandied about is that it is true."

Dr. Jane Aronson is back from visiting orphanages in Haiti. She was still there last Friday when 10 Americans were detained at the border of the Dominican Republic, trying to leave with 33 children who may or may not be orphaned. And she was there during the resulting debate in the United States about whether adoption by Americans is the best way to help Haiti's children.

Overview | What is embodied cognition, and how does research in the field describe the way our bodies and minds process language and metaphors? How might this research provide insight for teaching and learning? In this lesson, students act out common metaphors that convey abstract ideas. They consider embodied cognition research on how we process information and abstract ideas, then design and conduct their own cognition experiments. Finally, they present their findings and reflect on how their research might be applied.

A medical examiner said that cocaine and alcohol contributed to the death of Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., the punk rock musician better known as Jay Reatard, The Commercial Appeal of Memphis reported. After an autopsy, Dr. Karen E. Chancellor, the medical examiner of Shelby County, Tenn., told The Commercial Appeal that Mr. Lindsey died from "cocaine toxicity, and that alcohol was a contributing factor in his death." Mr. Lindsey, a prolific musician whose recent albums included "Watch Me Fall" and "Blood Visions," was found dead in his home in the Cooper-Young section of Memphis on Jan. 13. He was 29.

Across the first thirteen months of the Obama era, Wisconsin's Paul Ryan, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, has been one of the few conservative politicians offering detailed alternatives to the Democratic agenda. When Obama released his initial budget, Ryan responded by issuing a sweeping fiscal roadmap that envisioned bringing the U.S. budget back into balance across the next three decades. While many of his fellow Republicans were greeting Obama's health care push with Medicare demagoguery, Ryan was busy co-sponsoring (with Tom Coburn, among others) the "Patients' Choice Act," an imperfect but impressive alternative to the Democrats' approach. And now, with the release of Obama's second budget, which projects deficits as far as the eye can see, Ryan has updated his fiscal roadmap as well - and suddenly, people are paying attention to him.

You can't in any way discern this from the 2-D picture above, but "Clash of the Titans" will soon be coming at you in temple-rumbling, Medusa-decapitating, Kraken-battling 3-D. Capitalizing on audiences' renewed interest in the 3-D format that has helped boost ticket sales and revenue for "Avatar," the James Cameron sci-fi film released by 20th Century Fox, Warner Brothers announced that several of its coming films will be shown in 3-D screens. In a news release, the studio said that its coming remake of "Clash of the Titans," starring the "Avatar" veteran Sam Worthington as the Greek hero Perseus and directed by Louis Leterrier ("The Incredible Hulk"), will be its first film to get the 3-D treatment. Its release will be delayed by one week, to April 2 from March 26 as a result. The first part of "Harry Potter and Deathly Hallows," the two-film finale of that boy wizard franchise, will also be shown in 3-D in November, Warner Brothers said. Both movies will also receive traditional 2-D releases.

As I moderated comments Tuesday on a post about President Obama's proposal to increase Pell Grant awards, one dispatch stopped my cursor cold. It read: "This is absolutely the right direction and in keeping with my grandfather's original vision for the program." It was signed, "Clay Pell."

Now that everyone has had a day to suck in the Oscar news, and process the snubs and surprises, the Bagger would like to weigh in with her own analysis. Well, we'd like to, but it's a lot easier to link to this generic analysis, written a la Steven Soderbergh's "Schizopolis" ("generic greeting").

Oceanic Flight 815 didn't crash in the "Lost" episodes that opened the show's final season on Tuesday night, and ratings for this ABC serial stayed aloft as well. The Live Feed blog of The Hollywood Reporter said that the two-hour "Lost" premiere drew 12.1 million viewers, up from the 11.4 million viewers who tuned in for the debut of the show's fifth season in 2009. The Hollywood Reporter said that the "Lost" premiere also beat a new episode of NBC's reality show "The Biggest Loser," which was rescheduled at the last minute to go head-to-head with "Lost."

President Obama urged Democrats not to be defeatist about the loss of their supermajority in the Senate, declaring: "If anyone is searching for a lesson from Massachusetts, I promise you, the answer is not to do nothing."

When the founders of 25CPW took a former supermarket near Columbus Circle and turned it into an alternative space for exhibits and lectures, they knew they would have to move out one day when the landlord found a commercial tenant.

Monologue | Tuesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Well, the Oscar nominations were announced today, you guys. Best-actor nominees included George Clooney for "Up in the Air," Jeremy Renner for "The Hurt Locker," and President Obama for the "State of the Union."

The Dutch photographer Erwin Olaf's latest photo and video series, "Hotel" and "Dawn & Dusk," opened last week at New York's Hasted Hunt Kraeutler. The somewhat surreal exhibit reminds us of the artist's gift for highly detailed but ambiguous storytelling. "I want to trigger something in your head, so that you're going to make up your own story," he says. While the images of "Dawn & Dusk" are series of mirror images rendered alternately in black and white and then in color, the photographs that make up "Hotel" provide plenty of room for interpretation.

Monologue | Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Today, by the way, is Groundhog Day. And this morning, the groundhog known to humans as Punxsutawney Phil was ripped from his hole by men dressed like the mayor in Monopoly. The animal rights group PETA has asked the organizers of this ridiculous event to replace Punxsutawney Phil with a robot groundhog. You create one robot groundhog, and before you know it, they take over the planet, you have to send people back in time to exterminate them and then we have no governor anymore. It's not a good idea.

Nine games on Tuesday, and so many of them involved streaks: Washington's 10-game winning streak was on the line, as was Vancouver's seven-game streak, Los Angeles's six-game streak and Antero Niittymaki's personal 15-game streak vs. Atlanta. Then there was the chance that the Capitals might overtake the Sharks as the N.H.L.'s overall leader.

In its continuing unofficial mission to prove that a poetry career need not condemn an author to a life of destitution, Claremont Graduate University has announced the winners of its highly lucrative Kingsley and Kate Tufts Poetry Awards. The Kingsley Tufts Award, which comes with a prize of $100,000, will go to D. A. Powell for his collection "Chronic" (Graywolf Press), the university said in a news release. Mr. Powell, a poet from the San Francisco Bay Area, is a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle's poetry award, also for "Chronic"; his previous collection "Cocktails," was also a finalist for that same honor. The Kate Tufts Discovery Award, a $10,000 prize that is given to a first book by a poet, was won by Beth Bachmann for her collection "Temper" (University of Pittsburgh Press). The awards will be officially handed out at a ceremony on April 22 at Pasadena Museum of California Art.

A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Since life in Haiti was not a common subject in international news reports until the country was devastated by a 7.0 magnitude earthquake three weeks ago, it is something of a shock to view the short video embedded below, which was shot just over a month ago by a Haitian photographer named Frederic Dupoux to document New Year's Eve in the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince.

After my last post, some readers suggested that I was exaggerating the potential cost of paying unemployment insurance when you hire the wrong person. Fred from Florida wrote, "Payroll tax rates that fund unemployment insurance are affected by the company's history, but it's not a dollar for dollar payout." Actually, in Illinois, it's even worse.

Sarah Ryhanen and Nicolette Owen discovered each other the way everyone does these days: online. Ryhanen owns Saipua, a flower shop in Red Hook, Brooklyn, where she also sells beautifully packaged soap made by her mother. ("Saipua" is Finnish for "soap.") Owen runs her own Williamsburg-based flower biz focusing on private events. They are kindred spirits, who make stunning flower arrangements in the style of "Oh, these wild things I just cut out back?" Of course, the flowers are particularly chosen and arranged - and not cheap.

More bad news for high-end California winemakers, even Robert M. Parker tells them to get real as sales have plummeted. "Sadly, far too many proprietors of high-end Napa wines are in denial, and have failed to recognize the dramatically changing parameters in the wine world of the consumer," he says.
