Hikers' Mothers Want to Go to Iran | In an interview, Nora Shourd, the mother of one of the three graduates of the University of California, Berkeley, who are detained in Iran, said she and the two other mothers have applied for visas to travel to Iran to plead the case of their jailed children. On Tuesday, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad told state television that the three Americans may be exchanged with Iranians jailed in the United States. "We're still at ground zero here, and nothing has happened," said Ms. Shourd, of Oakland, whose daughter, Sarah, has been imprisoned in Iran since she and two friends crossed the Iranian border from Iraq. "I can't even begin to tell you what this feels like to us." [The Oakland Tribune, Reuters]

The menu at Northern Spy Food Company "reads like a roster of favorite snacks and midnight feasts, albeit executed with a precision honed in high-end kitchens," writes Ligaya Mishan. The East Village restaurant, which opened in November, is run by the chef Nathan Foot, who "has done time in fine dining, but seems to have a soft spot for down-home cooking." Look for comfy dishes like pickled eggs and corned beef hash. Polenta "engorged with crème fraîche substitutes for grits, its country cousin, as a bed for baked eggs. It's a voluptuary's dish." There is also exotic risotto, sandwiches stuffed with salty country ham and a kale salad with cubes of roasted squash for all the non-meat eaters. "The dining room is charming, referencing a country store without the glaze of irony."

In keeping with the golden statue theme, "Ajami," an Israeli film, one of five Oscar nominees for best foreign-language film, opens today in New York. The movie, takes its name from a rough neighborhood in Jaffa, a mostly Arab city just south of Tel Aviv. "This particular urban conflict zone may be unfamiliar to most American viewers, but it bears a definite kinship to mean streets we know very well, at least from movies and television," writes A.O. Scott. "We could almost be in the Los Angeles of 'Colors' or 'Boyz N the Hood,' the Baltimore of 'The Wire' or the Rio de Janeiro of 'City of God.' " The movie, written and directed by Scandar Copti, an Israeli Arab, and Yaron Shani, who is Jewish, "is acutely insightful about the social divisions within Israel, but it examines them without scolding or sentimentality. There is no finger-pointing here, and no group hugging either. Instead there is an acute sense of just how deep and wide the schisms are, not just between Jews and Arabs, but also between Christians and Muslims, rich and poor, farmers and city dwellers, men and women, young and old and so on."

For a long time it seemed like films made about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan just weren't clicking with critics or audiences. But with "The Hurt Locker" tied at the top of the pack of Oscar nominations with "Avatar" and a win at Sundance for the Afghanistan documentary "Restrepo," movies are finally catching up to the stage, which has fared better in tackling the past eight years of conflict. There was "Stuff Happens," "Black Watch" and now "Time Stands Still," which stars Laura Linney as a photojournalist recuperating from severe injuries suffered while she was covering the war in Iraq and Brian d'Arcy James as her partner who suffered a breakdown there. The "thoughtful drama by Donald Margulies," writes Charles Isherwood, which also stars Alicia Silverstone and Eric Bogosian, "explores the relationship between two couples at a crucial juncture in their lives, when the desire to move forward clashes with the instinct to stay comfortably — or even uncomfortably — in place." The "flawless Manhattan Theater Club production" is directed by Daniel Sullivan, "with the leads giving performances of "complementary sensitivity and richness."

Peter Olenick, a 25-year-old freestyle skier and gold medalist in the Big Air skiing competition at last weekend's 2010 Winter X Games, vividly recalls the first time he tried the Whiskey Flip, his self-invented marquee trick, a twisty, somersaulting double flip executed 20 feet or so above the halfpipe's lip. ''It was terrifying,'' he says. ''I didn't even know if it could be done. But I'd been doing it over and over in my head, so I figured I could make it go right.'' Some deep breaths, some mental finger-crossing and ''I just kind of hucked it,'' he says, landing cleanly, exhilarated. A second attempt was even ''scarier. Now my body knew what was happening. But I did it. Fear kind of keeps all of us going.''

The nation's top two defense officials called Tuesday for an end to the 16-year-old ''don't ask, don't tell'' law, a major step toward allowing openly gay men and women to serve in the United States military for the first time. ''No matter how I look at the issue, I cannot escape being troubled by the fact that we have in place a policy which forces young men and women to lie about who they are in order to defend their fellow citizens,'' Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Senate Armed Services Committee.

Countries, like individuals and corporations, have credit ratings. Th ese ratings off er forward-looking opinions about risk -- will a country be able to pay back its debts in full on and on time? Lenders pay close attention to nations' credit scores. Indeed, some banks and investment organizations are prohibited from lending to countries with all but the best ratings. Th e creditworthiness of entire countries has become increasingly thorny as governments around the world face tough choices about how much money to borrow (or print) to secure their economies. For example, it is currently considered less risky to lend to McDonald's than to Brazil. Credit ratings are off ered by various agencies, each of which employs diff erent methods to calculate and defi ne risk, usually using an alphabetical scale. He is survived by his beloved wife of 55 years, Judy, devoted daughters and sons-in-law, Debra and Henry Sutton, Robin and David Seyburn, his adoring grandchildren, Paulette, Leah, Emily, Stephanie and Andrew. On the right-angled grid of New York City streets, curves can be downright subversive. Spiraling, meandering, almost serpentine at times, they defy their rectilinear surroundings with abandon. They evoke nature, whether they are in fact as natural as a tree root -- or as manufactured as a Veterans Day street-fair sausage. In either case, attention must be paid. Earlier pictures in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

PAASWELL BAILINSON--Jean, passed away on January 31, at home in New York after a brief illness. Born May 7, 1924 in Brooklyn, to Benjamin and Lucille Paaswell, Jean was a lifelong and loyal New Yorker, lover of the Brooklyn Dodgers, New York Mets and the Metropolitan Opera. She studied at the Pratt Institute and Traphagen School of Fashion and began her career at Lord & Taylor's, then worked briefly at the New York Times where she met her former husband, Frank Bailinson, a long-time editor. Her advertising career focused on the fashion industry through the creation of Jean Paaswell Associates. In 1973 she founded Jean Grayson's Brownstone Studio, a successful mail order women's apparel company, serving as its President and chief creative force for almost thirty years. Jean will be remembered as a dynamic self-taught business-person with a wonderful fashion sense and an ability to treat everyone with compassion and dignity. Jean's first priority was her family for whom she was a devoted and self-less mother, grandmother and recently great-grandmother. She is survived by daughter Ann Kleinman of New York, son Frank Bailinson (Jann Dickerson) of San Francisco, son James Bailinson (Nancy Gibson) of Cumberland, Maine, and grandchildren Jill Kleinman Halberg (Kenneth) of New York, Emily, Charlotte, Peter and Julia Bailinson and great grandchild Zoe Lucille Halberg. Jean will be remembered with love by all who knew her for her warmth, generosity and style. A celebration of Jean's life will be held in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, 1-800-381-0075.

ROBERTS--Vera Mowry, 96, noted theatre historian and author. Founder of the Theatre Department, Hunter College, co-founder, Theatre Ph.D. Program CUNY Graduate Center, founding editor of the Journal of American Drama and Theatre, first woman Moderator of the Presbytery of New York City. She gave selflessly to her colleagues, friends and many students. Cherished aunt of Patricia and Mark James of Arlington, TX, great-aunt of Michael James and Lisa Kibler. Devoted mother of Christopher Roberts (deceased) and sister of the late, Ellen Mowry Nath and Laverne Mowry. She will be missed. Memorial service Sunday, February 14th, 5pm at Rutgers Memorial Church, 236 W. 73rd St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Christopher Roberts Homeless Shelter at the church.

BROWN--David, 93, acclaimed movie producer, author and journalist, passed away on Monday, February 1, 2010, at his home in Manhattan. Brown's legendary career as a movie producer and executive spanned six decades, included four Academy Award nominations and produced smash box office hits like Oscar winners The Sting and Jaws, along with popular classics like Cocoon and Driving Miss Daisy. He was married for more than 50 years to Cosmopolitan magazine editor and author Helen Gurley Brown. Brown and his wife have been celebrated as anchors of both the Hollywood film and New York publishing communities. A public funeral will be held on Thursday, February 4 at 3:30pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel (1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.) in New York City.

The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, ended a three-day visit to Cyprus on Tuesday with no indication of a breakthrough in his effort to energize settlement talks under way since 2008. There were reports of a diplomatic gaffe: two Greek Cypriot newspapers reported Tuesday that Mr. Ban had visited the Turkish Cypriot leader, Mehmet Ali Talat, at his presidential office in northern Cyprus. The reports set off protests among Greek Cypriots, angry that the visit could be taken as tacit recognition of the Turkish Cypriot enclave.

NEWMAN--Frances S. 2/3/1925 - 8/10/2009. Lived a wonderful life, was cherished by all, the sweetest person in the world. I miss you more than words can say, and think about you every day. Happy 85th Birthday, Mom. Your loving daughter, Louise

BECKER--David V.,M.D. We are saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. David V. Becker. Founding director of the Division of Nuclear Medicine at New York - Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center and professor of radiology and medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College, Dr. Becker was a much beloved member of our Medical Center for more than 50 years. A pioneer in his field, he conducted research leading to the development of national and international policies for treating people exposed to radiation from reactor accidents. He headed the National Cancer Institute's team investigating the effects of the 1986 Chernobyl reactor accident and helped create health monitoring and treatment plans for those affected. He also advanced the treatment of hyperthyroidism, thyroid cancer and other endocrine diseases. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lois Lunin; his children, Susan and Daniel Becker; and his four grandchildren. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College

At a time when so many people could not spare a dime for a movie ticket, hundreds of thousands of youngsters hovered around big, boxy Depression-era radios in their living rooms, entranced by scripted voices and sound effects that conjured images of adventurous heroes in faraway places. There were the likes of Tarzan, Jack Armstrong and Dick Tracy, and there was the spunky, curly-haired Little Orphan Annie, who in her high-pitched voice exclaimed, ''Leapin' lizards!'' at scintillating twists in the serial plot.

Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, apologized for using the word ''retarded'' to describe liberals at a closed-door meeting last year. Mr. Emanuel, below, expressed his regret last week to Tim Shriver, the chief executive of the Special Olympics, after the remark was reported in a Wall Street Journal article about growing liberal angst toward the chief of staff.

A judge ruled Tuesday that the estate of Nina Wang, once Asia's richest woman, will not go to her feng shui master. The judge, Johnson Lam, ruled that Mrs. Wang meant to leave her estate to her charity, the Chinachem Charitable Foundation. He ruled that the signature on a will that would have given an estimated $4 billion to $13 billion to her onetime spiritual adviser, Tony Chan, was forged.

Wednesday is when the movers will show up, ready to pack box after box and load everything onto the truck and leave Mario J. Pulice's landlocked apartment looking less like a ship. A very special ship, to be sure: the luxury liner Normandie, the seagoing Art Deco tour de force of the 1930s.

Mir Hussein Moussavi, the Iranian opposition leader, made some of his harshest remarks to date against Iran's rulers on Tuesday in an interview on his Web site, calling their behavior dictatorial and terrifying. The remarks by Mr. Moussavi, whom supporters regard as the real winner of Iran's contested presidential election last June, appeared to be part of a broader opposition effort to counter an intensified crackdown by the government ahead of the Feb. 11 anniversary of the 1979 Islamic Revolution, when many expect new street protests to erupt.

Jimmy Lafont was at work in the bayou town of Cut Off, La., where he manages a business that operates boats and barges that run up and down the Mississippi, when he looked up and saw himself on television. It has been that way for a few days, ever since Lafont received a phone call from the N.F.L., looking to invite him to the Super Bowl. Lafont had been featured in a USA Today column last week about three New Orleans Saints fans. Lafont said that he had not missed a game in 25 years and that, with the help of a cousin who drove the getaway truck, he had gone AWOL from a spiritual retreat to watch the National Football Conference title game.

Some readers have asked, in the context of my recent Congo columns, why I have named rape victims, including the name of a 9-year-old girl. To help our fashion peeps battle the winter blues and make those days at the beach seem a bit closer, I've decided to highlight a couple of summery lines. Orlebar Browne is a young company based in Britain that makes a very focused range of quick-dry nylon swim "shorts" based on traditional surf jams. Its tailored shapes come in a few different lengths and flatter even the skinniest shanks. The Bulldog is a midlength trunk with metal side tabs and angled pockets that help it pass as normal shorts post-swim; the Beagle is a more traditional surf short with a drawstring waist. These leaner, cleaner, "Gidget"-era togs are far more flattering than those oversize, below-the-knee psychedelic printed things that you see in Cancún.

Veryl Witmer, an amateur photographer who lives on the Upper West Side, was walking past the pond in Central Park on Tuesday afternoon when he noticed something unusual: a coyote. "The animal came out of the Hallett Nature Sanctuary and walked across the frozen pond several times," Mr. Witmer writes. "It seemed timid and skittish and kept retreating back to the sanctuary -- avoiding humans? It kept a watchful eye on me." The coyote did, however, find a moment to pose for a more formal portrait.

Medical marijuana's support among voters in New York State is so solid that even a substantial majority of Republicans favor its legalization, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released Thursday. The poll found that 71 percent of voters supported medical marijuana, including 55 percent of registered Republicans. The poll numbers seem to confirm others cited by sponsors of the current medical marijuana bill in the Assembly. The poll, on a range of issues before the State Legislature, also found that 75 percent of New York voters support a wage freeze for state workers to help balance the budget, while 78 percent oppose cutting state aid to schools to do so. Gov. David A. Paterson's proposed tax on sugary sodas, meanwhile, was opposed by 57 percent of voters.

As a New Yorker born in the middle of the 20th century, I come from a place and time where lasagna was without fail made of dried pasta layered with red meat sauce and ricotta, along with the inevitable mozzarella and parmesan. It wasn't until I first visited Italy, in my 20s, that I encountered lasagne (note the shift from "lasagna" in the singular, describing the whole dish in Little Italy fashion, to "lasagne" in the plural, referring to the sheets of pasta that are its defining ingredient) based on egg pasta, ragù bolognese and béchamel sauce. It seemed very sissified at the time, but somehow it came to be my standard, perhaps simply because it is a more satisfactory dish. I still occasionally make ricotta/red sauce lasagna, but most of the time the lasagne that come out of our oven are more in a Bolognese than a Calabrian vein.

For many years, Pascal Petiteau was the chef at Jubilee, a popular bistro near Sutton Place that is known for mussel dishes. His wife, Virginie, was a manager there. For an anti-establishment guy, David Mamet is certainly getting comfortable with Broadway. Revivals of his plays "Speed-the-Plow," "Oleanna" and "American Buffalo" have recently been presented there (some lasting longer than others), his latest work, "Race," continues to run there, and now a revival of his early play "A Life in the Theater" is headed to the Great White Way. On Thursday, the producers Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and Steve Traxler (who were also behind "Race") said that a new staging of "A Life in the Theater" would come to Broadway this fall. Neil Pepe, the artistic director of the Atlantic Theater Company, is to direct; Mr. Mamet is a founder of the company. The play, about the evolving relationship between a young actor and his older mentor, was first performed in 1977 at the Goodman Theater in Chicago in a production that starred Mike Nussbaum and Joe Mantegna and was directed by Gregory Mosher. That same year it played off Broadway at the Lucille Lortel Theater, where it starred Peter Evans and Ellis Rabb and was directed by Gerald Gutierrez. Cast members and a theater for the Broadway revival have not been announced.

When Chicago-born Harry Gordon Selfridge opened Selfridge's department store in London in 1909, he wasn't thinking small - the original architect drawings show the Oxford Street shop topped with a dome that rivals that of St. Paul's. (It was nixed before construction began, but a colonnade of impressive looking Doric columns adorns the building's facade). A pioneer of the shopping-as-entertainment school of retailing, Selfridge was all in favor of using culture to get shoppers through his doors. So while the latest exhibit to go up in the store's gallery space, the Museum of Small Things (MOST), may sound like, well, small potatoes, he would no doubt have approved. Conceived of in collaboration with the artist and designer Kit Grover and POCKO, MOST celebrates the tiny and the trifling. "We left the definition of small up to the artists," Grover says. "So it can mean something minuscule or something that's generally ignored or thought of as insignificant." The exhibit is arranged in the form of a labyrinth, with a rotating eight-foot head created by the Japanese artist Kin Pro at the center. "Kind of like a Macy's float, but not from this planet," Grover says. "We wanted to play with scale. You can't see all of it as you approach it, so you feel like you're being peered in on by someone very large - and you're miniature." Also included in MOST are a bag by Grayson Perry (limited-edition replicas are available at the exhibit pop-up shop), a Richard Wentworth dictionary ("of small, of course") and several films, including "I Met the Walrus," which features a soundtrack of an interview a teenage fan did with John Lennon in the 1960s paired with animation by James Braithwaite.

Conrad Murray, the personal doctor who was with Michael Jackson when he died, may soon surrender to the authorities in Los Angeles to face charges related to the singer's death. Dr. Murray injected Jackson with the anesthetic propofol and the anti-anxiety drug lorazepam, causing his death, according to the Los Angeles County Coroner's office, which has ruled it a homicide. Although prosecutors have not announced any charges against Dr. Murray, his lawyer, Ed Chernoff, said in a statement on Thursday that he is "negotiating with the District Attorneys' office the surrender of Dr. Murray." Details have not yet been agreed on, the statement said. Randal C. Archibold has more here.

Gerard Schwarz will bow out after 26 years as music director of the Seattle Symphony with a bang. The program also includes Gerard Schwarz's own arrangement of a suite from "Der Rosenkavalier" by Strauss. And the 2010-11 season will close with a performance of Mahler's Symphony No. 2, "The Resurrection."

What is the value of art? Yesterday's record-breaking sale of "Walking Man I," a bronze by Alberto Giacometti for $104.3 million with fees, has revived the age-old question and our readers had plenty to say about it. Most, like snesich from Seattle, were outraged that during a recession an individual would pay such a huge sum for a sculpture. "Am I the only one who finds it morally and ethically repugnant that an 'unidentified telephone bidder' has the disposable income to pay $92 million for a 'work of art' in a world where almost half of the human race lacks decent drinking water and sanitation?" A few, like John from Westport, Conn., countered, "It's worth what someone is willing to pay." And others, like suzing from Baltimore, tried, with a little humor, to put the price in context: "A steal at half the price of 'Avatar.' What's that tell you?" Below, please read Anna's thoughts on a book by Greg Craven, best known for his series of popular videos deconstructing the climate challenge.

The not-so-surprising surprise addition to the best actress Oscar list, Sandra Bullock, has won a bunch of awards this season for playing a sassy Southerner with a heart of gold and hair of platinum in "The Blind Side." As Leigh Anne Tuohy, a real-life Memphis matriarch who takes in a near-homeless black teenager and helps him be all he can be, Ms. Bullock sports a lot of jewelry and a bit of twang. The Academy, of course, loves physical transformation. But not all sassy Southerners were enamored with Ms. Bullock. "Just for the record, those of us here in Memphis are not necessarily impressed with Ms. Bullock's accent," Susanne Nan Bayes Koenig wrote to the Bagger recently to register a complaint. "She sounds like she is from Georgia, where the film was shot. Lovely woman, great work, two states off."

The China Investment Corporation, the sovereign wealth fund that is investing some of the country's huge foreign currency reserves, has won approval from a British regulator to buy a stake in the private equity firm Apax Partners, an Apax spokesman said Thursday.

Break out the carrot raisin salad and feel free to plant a big wet kiss on the oldest child of your polygamist husband's first wife: HBO has renewed "Big Love." The Hollywood Reporter said that the cable channel has officially ordered a fifth season of "Big Love," its hit drama about the familial entanglements of a Mormon patriarch (Bill Paxton) and his three wives (Jeanne Tripplehorn, Chloë Sevigny and Ginnifer Goodwin). Now in its fourth season, the show saw ratings for its premiere episode rise 49 percent over that of Season 3 and has maintained its viewership despite competition from the National Football League playoffs and the Grammy Awards. The show's creators, Mark V. Olsen and Will Scheffer, told The Hollywood Reporter that the current season will get "deeper and darker," while Season 5 will settle "into the storytelling" and "take the temperature of the marriages." Does that mean we'll get the old opening credit sequence back too?

Updated, 5:34 p.m. | Lean budget times have hit the New York Public Library in a big way. On Wednesday, the library announced it would reduce hours at two-thirds of its 87 locations in Manhattan and the Bronx and on Staten Island after having its financing from the city chopped by $5.9 million in the mayor's latest round of budget cuts. Such a drastic move has not occurred since 2001.

Buyer's remorse is the pits. These days especially, there's nothing worse than seeing that rash purchase collect dust in your closet. So if you're going to fork over some serious fashion dollars, you want a sure thing. For pre-fall, a lot of designers are revisiting '70s classics, which, far from feeling dated, strike me as timeless. 24:7, Tamara Mellon's new collection of iconic styles for Jimmy Choo, delivers "the perfect wedge" - and in cherry red, it feels plucked from the world of Slim Aarons. Salvatore Ferragamo's simple frame bag in brown croc manages to be both minimal and luxe - the very definition of understatement. And scarves, an accessory usually reserved for ladies of a certain age, turned up at Lanvin and other pre-fall shows. I love the American folk feel of the pheasants and peacocks on this one from Hermès.

Kraft Foods is planning to sell a minimum of $4 billion in bonds in four parts on Thursday to help finance its $18.7 billion acquisition of the British chocolatier Cadbury, IFR said on Wednesday.

Faced with rising inflation and evidence that the country has finally emerged from recession, the Bank of England announced Thursday that it would not extend its massive buying spree of government bonds that was intended as an economic stimulus, Matthew Saltmarsh and Jack Ewing report in The New York Times.

The Death of a Bay Area Philanthropist | Evelyn Haas, whose philanthropy touched many aspects of life in the Bay Area, died Wednesday in San Francisco. She was 92. The widow of Walter A. Haas Jr., Mrs. Haas led the family foundation, the Evelyn and Walter Haas Jr. Fund. It has contributed more than $364 million to a range of community and cultural organizations, including the San Francisco Symphony, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the restoration of Crissy Field. Mrs. Haas wanted to make a tangible difference to people's lives, said Ira Hirschfield, president of the foundation. "It was about leveling the playing field so that all families could live and raise their families with equality and dignity, to make sure all families had an equal chance to enjoy their lives," he said. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

The opening event of the Unsound Music Festival indicates the expansive terrain the series covers, writes Steve Smith: "The Finnish electronica musician Vladislav Delay collaborates with Lillevan, a German video artist; and Sebastian Meissner, a German electronic musician also known as Klimek, joins the exciting Polish new-music quartet Kwartludium in a project inspired by the seminal American punk-rock record label SST." Sound hip enough for you? The experimental-music festival, founded in 2003 and based in Krakow, Poland, presents its first New York incursion Thursday night with the help of several local partner organizations, including Wordless Music, the Bunker, Issue Project Room and the Goethe-Institut New York. It starts at 8:30 p.m. at the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center and it's free.

The farewell event for the X Initiative, a nonprofit art consortium that took over the old Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea, is a 24-hour marathon titled “Bring Your Own Art (BYOA)” that started Wednesday at 11 a.m. and ends 24 hours later, at 11 a.m. Thursday. Tell your boss you have a dentist appointment and stop by to see the hodgepodge of an installation or even contribute a creation of your own. As Roberta Smith writes, “the rules are easy enough, despite sounding like a recipe for bedlam. Any artwork that anyone brings to 548 West 22nd Street, X Initiative’s temporary home, will be displayed in 'BYOA.' A few conditions apply. Small artworks can be carried up the stairs. Bulkier ones must be able to fit — whole or in parts — into X’s passenger elevator. X will provide two ladders; otherwise participants should bring their own tools. One imagines lots of running with hammers.” X will be open for the entire run, with bands, musicians and D.J.'s playing in 30-minute segments throughout.

"If your devotion to the shoe resembles a form of worship ... this will be your temple," writes Llorraine Neithardt on her Web site, "and you, a disciple of the art of shoe making." There's no doubt many women in New York would find divine inspiration in these words. Ms. Neithardt is a full-time psychic — a Jungian-inspired clairvoyant, to be more precise — and a part-time shoe guru. "Since learning the craft," Penelope Green writes, "she has had a shoe art show at Art Basel Miami Beach, inspired the shoe-making subplot of a movie, 'P.S. I Love You,' starring Hilary Swank, and, for the last five months, directed workshops." In her classes, students learn the intricate craft of hand-making footwear, unleashing, as Ms. Neithardt put it, "the shoe within." The results "are fantastical creations of fig bark and rooster feathers, spotted python and blood-red kid leather." A beginners course on mules starts tonight and runs through Feb. 7. Give it a go before moving on to intermediate pumps and the master class in boots. You must bring your own heel, shank and leathers. Basic soles, of the material sort, are provided.

WHELAN--Charles M.,S.J. Fordham Law School is deeply saddened by the loss of Father Charles Whelan. Throughout his 44-year teaching career at Fordham Law, Father Whelan was the personal embodiment of the School's motto, "In the service of others," through his dedication to education, to advocacy, and to service to a broader community. He enjoyed a national reputation as a Constitutional scholar, and his expertise in First Amendment issues, most especially matters of church-state relations, was as deep as it was broad. His interest in religious issues led Father Whelan into yet another facet of his great career: Associate Editor of America magazine. His scholarship and legal arguments will continue to influence how the courts consider the relationship between church and state in the United States for many years to come. His lessons will be passed on daily and forever as his students and their students teach the law in class or mentor less experienced lawyers in practice. His was a career shaped by his Ignatian ideals, and he left an extraordinary legacy. William Michael Treanor, Dean, Fordham Law School

For President Obama and Congressional Democrats groping for a new strategy on their stalled health care legislation, a crucial question is whether the way forward is to the right, to the left -- or would it be better to just stand still? Some Democratic advocacy groups, including the Progressive Change Campaign Committee and Democracy for America, insist that a main problem with the legislation is that it is not progressive enough.

Greece won a reprieve Wednesday in its battle to stave off financial ruin after the European Commission endorsed plans to bring its public finances under control. But the commission also warned that the country's progress was subject to close monitoring. The statement from the commission appeared to calm some of the anxiety in the financial markets, though analysts said the risk was that domestic opposition in Greece could derail the austerity package.

TRUSSELL--Elizabeth Davis, professionally known as Elizabeth B. Davis, MD died on February 1, 2010 at the age of 89. She was professor emerita of Clinical Psychiatry at Columbia University and was the founder of the Department of Psychiatry at Harlem Hospital Center which she directed for 17 years. She was the daughter and granddaughter of two rectors of St. Philip's Episcopal Church in New York City. She became the widow of Ray E. Trussell, MD of New York City after 32 years of marriage. She is survived by a brother Shelton Hale Bishop, Jr., a daughter Liberty M. Rashad, three grandsons, six great-grandchildren, one nephew, two stepdaughters Margaret Hardy and Susan Stedman, their families and a host of other relatives and friends. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, February 10th at St. Philip's Church, 204 West 134th Street, NYC. Viewing at 10am, service at 11am. In lieu of flowers, we are requesting that donations be made to the NAACP Legal Defense Fund in her name.

The organizers of the Vancouver Games withdrew an official video for their Olympic torch relay after the Canadian Jewish Congress and others questioned its use of footage from ''Olympia,'' Leni Riefenstahl's film of the 1936 Olympics in Berlin. The four-minute video, ''Lights Will Guide You Home,'' was shown to relay participants after they boarded shuttle buses to their positions along its route. The video was also posted on the Vancouver organizing committee's Web site.

The N.F.L. announced the officiating crew for the Super Bowl, and one member will revive bad memories for Giants fans. Scott Green, who is finishing his 19th season as an N.F.L. official, will be the referee. He was the back judge in the January 2003 wild-card game between the Giants and the 49ers. Giants guard Rich Seubert lined up as an eligible receiver on what was supposed to be a game-winning field goal, but Green apparently did not know that and did not call a penalty when Seubert was blatantly interfered with downfield when the field goal was botched. After that game, the former commissioner Paul Tagliabue expressed unhappiness with how officials had handled the play.

BASSOLA-HEALY--Sarah Jean, 26 years old, of Jupiter, FL, passed away unexpectedly, on Monday, February 1, 2010. Born in Australia, Sarah grew up on Long Island, NY, moved into New York City and later to Santa Monica, CA. Sarah is a graduate of Our Lady of Mercy Academy, Syosset, NY and also holds an Associates Degree from Santa Monica City College. She was also preparing for her Florida State Real Estate License. Sarah recently purchased a home with her sisters in Jupiter, FL, that she was renovating. Her legacy includes helping her family to live each day with happiness and illuminating the room like the brightest shinning star. A devoted daughter and sister, She was the daughter of Kathryn Healy, stepdaughter of Daniel Healy, Sr. and daughter of Barry Bassola, and sister to Angela, Camilla, Mary, Daniel, Jr., Matthew, and Christine Healy. Friends may visit with the family between the hours of 6 to 8pm on Friday, February 5, 2010 at Quattlebaum Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. A Funeral Mass will be held at 9:30am on Saturday, February 6, 2010, at St. Patrick's Church, 13591 Prosperity Farms Road, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Cremation will follow. To express condolences and share memories, please visit Sarah's Memorial Website at: www.quattlebaum.org. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Sarah Jean Ectopic Pregnancy Foundation. Mr. Daniel Healy, Sr., Premier American Bank, N.A., 5301 Blue Lagoon Drive, Miami, FL 33126.

FORGET the bulky snowshoes of yesteryear: The newest models have aluminum frames, titanium crampons and even modular components that can be mixed and matched. While they are still based on the same design -- a latticework frame that rides atop snow -- modern snowshoes are designed for people who want to move fast and work up a sweat. There are 2.4 million Americans who snowshoe, according to SnowSports Industries America, a trade group in McLean, Va. And fortunately for them, the latest gear not only floats over powder but also handles the occasional stretch of pavement.

Campbell Funeral Chapel (1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.) in New York City.

Most Americans think health care legislation is doomed, according to a survey released Wednesday by the Pew Research Center. But a growing, if still small, percentage of people are becoming more optimistic that it may pass. In the survey, conducted from Jan. 29 to Feb. 1, 60 percent of those polled said they thought health care legislation would not pass this year. That is fewer than the 67 percent who said just after a special Senate election last month in Massachusetts that health care would not pass.

After pondering his college future all day Tuesday, Seantrel Henderson, an offensive lineman who is considered by most analysts to be the nation's top high school football recruit this year, lay in the bed of his hotel room in Midtown Manhattan, reflecting on his options. Dozing off after 9 p.m., he was Southern California dreaming after deciding he would play for the Trojans. ''I just felt the most comfortable there,'' Henderson said. ''I felt like it was the greatest spot for me with L.A. and everything.''

DIRKS--John, of Mystic, CT, died on January 26, 2010. He was born on November 2, 1917, in New York, NY, the son of Rudolph and Helen Dirks. His wife of 50 years, Mary Dirks died on March, 30, 2004. Mr. Dirks graduated with the Yale Class of 1939 and was a Captain in the United States Army. Mr. Dirks collaborated with his father on The Captain and The Kids comic strip from 1955 until 1968, and he continued the strip until 1979. John was also a well known sculptor in mixed metal fountains. He installed hundreds of fountains all over the world, including museums, multiple gallery shows and private collections. He is survived by his sister Barbara Dirks of Brattleboro, VT. Memorial donations may be made to Rudolph & John Dirks Fund, PO Box 769, New London, CT 06320. Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home, Old Lyme is handling services which are private.

For the performance artist Marina Abramovic, the staff of life is endurance. Her appearances, which have involved fasting, cutting her belly with a razor, kissing till she faints, and staring into the eyes of a stranger over extended periods of time until she -- and her audience -- experience a cathartic levitation of the spirit that requires intense concentration and enormous strength of character. The well from which she draws her strength of purpose will soon be available to everyone. To accompany her career retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, opening March 14, Abramovic collaborated with the non-profit outreach organization, More Art, to produce the "Energy Blanket." Available next month from either More Art or MoMA, it comes with fourteen magnets and a drawing of Abramovic's body indicating where they ought to go before climbing under it. $460 is a small price to pay for inner peace - or, come to think of it, for a wearable piece of art.

Bakelite, the 20th century's first plastic, was invented in 1907, 60 years before "The Graduate" suggested the industry was on the cutting edge. "Bakelite in Yonkers: Pioneering the Age of Plastics," an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the Hudson River Museum, showcases 300 objects from the 1910s to the early 21st century that exploit the unique properties of Phenol-formaldehyde: brilliant color, heat resistance and strength. Bakelite is still used today in car parts, plywood and pan handles (Revere Ware, for example), but the earliest pieces in the exhibition show its decorative side."The early Bakelite objects have a very 19th-century form," said Bartholomew F. Bland, curator of exhibitions at the museum. "The designers were consciously trying to mimic marble, ebony and burled wood." By the 1920s and 1930s, the age of streamlining made moldable plastics appealing in their own right. Star designers like Raymond Loewy exploited the range of possible colors and shapes, and the exhibition includes a camera he designed in 1937, along with toys, bangles, radios, typewriters, dominoes and intercoms, all of which were culled from the Amsterdam Bakelite® Collection, the holdings of Hugh Karraker, a great-grandson of Bakelite's inventor, Leo Baekeland, and the Yonkers Historical Society.

Langston Hughes has a block named after him in New York: Langston Hughes Place, East 127th Street between Madison and Fifth. But the house where Hughes lived, at No. 20 East 127th, is no longer open to the public. In 2008 the owner evicted tenants who had been running an informal Hughes museum there and now the only trace of Hughes is a plaque in front of the building, which was designated as a landmark in 1981.

Updated | 12:37 p.m. As my colleague Eric Asimov notes on The Pour blog, three crates of Scotch whisky and two crates of brandy left beneath the floorboards of a hut by the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton in 1909, at the end of a failed expedition to the South Pole, have been unearthed by a team from the Antarctic Heritage Trust.

After screening this German New Wave tear-jerker, you might be surprised to find yourself coveting locally sourced heirloom denim. "Paris, Texas" (1984) isn't just an epic drama that won the Palm d'Or at Cannes; nowadays it feels curiously in step with the current culture's ongoing American heritage trip. Shot largely in the Southwest, the film is a paean to America the Authentic: ghost towns, cuffed jeans, the highway, the mustache, the desert landscape, Marlboros, leather boots, chamois shirts, motels, Super-8 home movies, railroad tracks. How convenient then that the Criterion Collection has just remastered the film under the supervision of its director, Wim Wenders, and packaged it stylishly for DVD and Blu-ray. The film, written by Sam Shepard, comes across like a sumptuous coffee-table book inhabited by Harry Dean Stanton, Dean Stockwell and Nastassja Kinski, haunted by the melancholy vibrato of Ry Cooder's slide guitar. As the writer Nick Roddick laments in the accompanying essay, "The world to which Wenders pays homage is vanishing fast" - cellphones have replaced photogenic phone booths, McDonald's franchises have gobbled up roadside diners. No amount of limited-edition Red Wings can turn back that tide, as watching the film makes ravishingly and heartbreakingly clear."Paris, Texas," DVD or Blu-ray ($31.96), available at Criterion.com.

Nine games on Thursday, but the big news was New Jersey nabbing Ilya Kovalchuk from Atlanta for a package of young players who may or may not pan out. Kovalchuk, whose 328 career goals makes him the N.H.L.'s top goal scorer since entering the league in 2001, turned down the Thrashers' $101 million 12-year contract offer. So Atlanta G.M. Don Waddell dealt him and defenseman Anssi Salmela to the Devils. In return, Devils G.M. Lou Lamoriello gave up slumping Swedish Olympic defenseman Johnny Oduya, slumping rookie forward Niclas Bergfors, disgraced prospect Patrice Cormier (banned for the season by the Quebec junior league for deliberately elbowing an opponent in the head) and the club's No. 1 draft choice next June.

A Bagger pal has pointed us to an incredible artifact of the early collaboration between Oscar frontrunners James Cameron and Kathryn Bigelow, back when they were Mr. and Mrs. It's a music video - the only one Mr. Cameron directed, apparently - for a shortlived band in the 1980s, Martini Ranch, formed by the actor Bill Paxton - who appeared in Ms. Bigelow's "Near Dark" - and the musician Andrew Todd Rosenthal. The group released only one album, "Holy Cow," but it had guest appearances from members of Devo (who had a little something to do with the track called "How Can the Labouring Man Find Time for Self-Culture?") and the B-52s, as well as Bud Cort ("Harold and Maude") and Judge Reinhold. Good god, the Internet is just fantastic.The video, for "Reach," includes cameos by Mr. Reinhold, Paul Reiser and actors from "Aliens" and "Terminator," and is, of course, set in the Wild West. Ms. Bigelow stars as the leader of an outlaw band of female gunslingers who manage to persuade a few good-time gals to join them. There's also a mariachi band that plays through a hanging and a guy buried up to his neck in sand, trying to get at a martini glass with his tongue. ("Reach!") It's over seven minutes long and the music doesn't start until nearly three minutes in, but that's for the best.

The producers of "The Hurt Locker" and "The Blind Side" can start figuring out who they're going to elbow out of the way at the podium on Oscar night. Though it normally allows only three producers to accept credit for a film, the Academy has ruled that all four from "The Hurt Locker" - Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal, Nicolas Chartier and Greg Shapiro - "had fully functioned as genuine producers of the film," according to a statement, and bent its rules according to a clause which permits it to do so "under extraordinary circumstances." The decision follows an appeal by the "Hurt Locker" team. The three producers of "The Blind Side" -- Gil Netter, Andrew A. Kosove and Broderick Johnson - were also deemed acceptable, if one person short of extraordinary.

Our manga list tends to be filled with double-digit volume numbers, making it a little scary to jump on board and try a series for the first time. This is not the case for "Black Butler," published by Yen Press, which lands at No. 1 this week. This is the book's first volume. It centers on Sebastian, the trusted aide to a 12-year-old English noble. The publisher's Web site describes Sebastian as all capable, whether he's "called to save a dinner party gone awry or probe the dark secrets of London's underbelly." There are also hints that Sebastian, perhaps, may not be completely human. Volumes 2 and 3 will go on sale in May and October.

As Europe is roiled by sovereign debt fears, it's important to realize that the crisis in the largest of the PIIGS (Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Greece, Spain) has nothing to do with fiscal irresponsibility. On the eve of the crisis, Spain was running a budget surplus; its debts, as you can see in the figure above, were low relative to GDP.

Segregation at Charter Schools | Charter schools nationwide are racially segregated, according to a study from the Civil Rights Project at the University of California, Los Angeles. About three out of four black students who attend charter schools are among student populations that are at least 90 percent minority. The pattern of racial isolation is similar in Bay Area and California charter schools. These are "the very kind of schools that decades of civil rights struggles fought to abolish in the South," researchers said. Charter school supporters criticized the study. "The civil rights issue here is the persistent achievement gap and high dropout rates for these students when they are left to languish in traditional schools that fail to meet their academic needs," said Jed Wallace, chief executive and president of the California Charter Schools Association. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

Help With Health Care When Prison Doors Open | As former prisoners, and their illnesses, move back into communities, they will struggle to overcome a new set of obstacles and find a way to better care. "What happens in the prison system isn't isolated in the prison system," said Dr. John Stobo, senior vice president for health sciences and services for the University of California system. "It spills over into the free world." But some Bay Area counties are looking to the Transitions Clinic in San Francisco as a possible model for ensuring that this group gets health care. The clinic is the first in the country specifically for parolees, combining aggressive outreach - like recruiting prisoners before their release - with a nonjudgmental approach.

The exhibition "Arts of Ancient Vietnam: From River Plain to Open Sea," now on view at the Asia Society Museum, took over 20 years to produce. Is the show worth the wait? It is, according to Holland Cotter. "From the moment you enter the galleries you're seeing things you won't find anywhere else and certainly not in this combination: a bronze drum as hefty as a hot tub; a wooden Buddha, tall, dark, and Giacometti-thin. Avid-eyed Hindu deities keep company with contortionist dancers. A tiny serpent of beaten gold basks in a spotlight. Ceramic plates and bowls crowd a room just as they had once filled the hold of a ship that went down in the South China Sea." As a trade hub, Vietnam absorbed cultural influences from China, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand and more, and these disparate influences are reflected in the show. "Once you've made your way through the society's suave installation, you've seen treasures from 10 Vietnamese museums. You've time-traveled from the first millennium B.C. to the 17th century A.D. And you've style-traveled through dozens of cultures both inside and outside Vietnam itself."

Grab your sled, snowboard, skis, snowshoes and whatever other cold-weather gear you've got stacked in the basement and head this Saturday to Central Park for Winter Jam 2010. The annual winter sports festival is presented by the New York City Parks Department and the Olympic Regional Development Authority. Channel your inner Shaun White while testing out a backside 180 at Switch Academy Rail Jam, where the professional snowboarder Pat Moore will serve as a judge. The less daring can play in the snow at the Lake Placid Snow Field or watch a screening of "Project X," a short film documenting Mr. White's Olympic training. The high-flying Skyriders will perform trampoline tricks on skis and snowboards. Free samples from Pride of New York Winter Market will keep participants warm and toasty. The event begins at 11 a.m.; enter at West 72nd Street and head south toward the Sheep Meadow to join the festivities.

Tired of spending the Super Bowl slipping on beer-soaked floors and fighting over congealed seven-layer dip? City Winery is offering a slightly more elegant way to watch the pigskins fly with its first Super Bowl party on Sunday. Watch the game on a projector and 150-inch screen or on one of the multiple 50-inch HD flat screens. Entry is free, and the Winery is offering an all-day happy hour with $5 glasses of wine and $15 carafes, as well as discounts on beer and alcohol. Wings, slow-braised ribs, burgers and more are on the menu, and the best part — especially for those nonfootball fans — everyone who attends will be entered into a raffle to win two V.I.P. tickets to the Music of the Who tribute at Carnegie Hall on March 2. The festivities kick off at 4 p.m.

PECK--Irwin, beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend succumbed peacefully on February 3 of complications due to heart failure. An enlisted veteran of World War Two, Mr. Peck served as a Cryptanalyst providing actionable intelligence for Patton's 3rd Army. Mr. Peck was a successful businessman in the Flushing community for over 50 years as the owner of Peck's Office Plus. He had just celebrated his 60th wedding anniversary this past October with his beloved wife and best friend, Esther. He is survived by his wife, children Judith Pollack, Beth Peck-Block, and Robert Peck. He has seven loving grandchildren.

Facing food shortages, severe price increases and social unrest, North Korea appears to have relaxed, at least temporarily, its broad crackdown on private markets, news reports and officials in Seoul said Thursday. If confirmed, the move to allow the buying and selling of goods outside the country's tightly controlled state distribution system could signal a political setback for the government of Kim Jong-il. North Korea had recently introduced a new currency and closed private markets in an effort to restore a purer form of central economic planning.

SNOW--Lydia, 91, of NYC passed away February 3, 2010. Beloved mother of Michael, grandmother to Mark, Alison, Max and Ben. Services will be held at The JCOH, Easthampton, NY on Sunday, February 7, 2:15pm.

An obituary last Friday about Howard Zinn, the author of ''A People's History of the United States,'' erroneously included an award among his many honors. His book ''La Guardia in Congress'' received an honorable mention in the competition for the American Historical Association's Albert J. Beveridge Award; it did not win the award itself.

An editorial on Thursday about the delay in confirming Dawn Johnsen to lead the Office of Legal Counsel, misidentified the university where she teaches. It is Indiana University, not the University of Indiana.

It almost sounds fancy, especially when it's said in its native Scottish brogue -- Buckfast Tonic Wine, as if it cures the drinker of any ailments, besides their wits and sobriety. A potent mix of alcohol and caffeine, it has come under attack in Scotland for making people drunk and disorderly, and empty bottles of the stuff have a way of showing up at crime scenes and brawls. City Room got to wondering -- what is our equivalent in the five boroughs? In New York, there is no ''tonic wine,'' thank you very much. Here in the city of straight talk, such a beverage goes by nicknames stripped of euphemism.

BASSOLA-HEALY--Sarah Jean, 26 years old, of Jupiter, FL, passed away unexpectedly, on Monday, February 1, 2010. Born in Australia, Sarah grew up on Long Island, NY, moved into New York City and later to Santa Monica, CA. Sarah is a graduate of Our Lady of Mercy Academy, Syosset, NY and also holds an Associates Degree from Santa Monica City College. She was also preparing for her Florida State Real Estate License. Sarah recently purchased a home with her sisters in Jupiter, FL, that she was renovating. Her legacy includes helping her family to live each day with happiness and illuminating the room like the brightest shinning star. A devoted daughter and sister, She was the daughter of Kathryn Healy, stepdaughter of Daniel Healy, Sr. and daughter of Barry Bassola, and sister to Angela, Camilla, Mary, Daniel, Jr., Matthew, and Christine Healy. Friends may visit with the family between the hours of 6 to 8pm on Friday, February 5, 2010 at Quattlebaum Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. A Funeral Mass will be held at 9:30am on Saturday, February 6, 2010, at St. Patrick's Church, 13591 Prosperity Farms Road, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Cremation will follow. To express condolences and share memories, please visit Sarah's Memorial Website at: www.quattlebaum.org. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Sarah Jean Ectopic Pregnancy Foundation. Mr. Daniel Healy, Sr., Premier American Bank, N.A., 5301 Blue Lagoon Drive, Miami, FL 33126.

President Obama challenged lawmakers and religious leaders on Thursday to step beyond their comfort zones and unify around the pressing challenges facing the country, not simply join forces only when a calamity like the earthquake in Haiti strikes. ''Too often that spirit is missing without the spectacular tragedy,'' Mr. Obama said. ''We become numb to the day-to-day crises. We become absorbed with our abstract arguments, our ideological disputes, our contests for power. And in this tower of babble, we lose the sound of God's voice.''

GAFFIN--Ruth Mildred, 96, passed away in Manhattan at home on February 3, 2010. An extremely successful business person who excelled as a buyer for H.S. Benedict, the buying agent for many of America's top drug chains at a time when it was a rarity for a woman to reach the top of her field. She was the only daughter in a family with four older and adoring brothers. She is the beloved aunt, great-aunt and great-great-aunt of many nieces and nephews who will miss her deeply. Services Sunday, February 7, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.
As predictions pour in, it should come as no surprise that Tony Dungy, the former Colts head coach, is choosing Indianapolis. What is surprising is that Dungy does not think the game will be close.

President Obama's aunt, who has been fighting a deportation order for years, testified for more than two hours Thursday at a closed-door immigration hearing in Boston, which ended without a resolution. The aunt, Zeituni Onyango, did not speak as she left the hearing, walking with a cane. She had entered the courtroom in the John F. Kennedy Federal Building in a wheelchair, the cane across her lap.

Steve Phillips, whom ESPN fired last year as a baseball analyst after his affair with a production assistant became public knowledge, spent 45 days in a sex addiction clinic in Hattiesburg, Miss., said his agent, Steve Lefkowitz. Phillips, a former Mets general manager, was treated at the Gentle Path clinic, which Tiger Woods reportedly attended. Phillips is attending after-care therapy; his wife, Marni, is also in therapy in Arizona, Lefkowitz said. Lefkowitz said Phillips expected to discuss his affair, his therapy and his perspective on Woods's infidelities in an interview Monday with Matt Lauer on the ''Today'' show. The stadium known as KeySpan Park will now be MCU Park, for the Municipal Credit Union. The home of the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets' Class A team in Coney Island, bore the KeySpan name from its opening in 2001. But the original 20-year deal was dissolved last week, a recognition that National Grid, the British utility that acquired KeySpan in 2007, is not devoted to sports marketing in Brooklyn. Nate Robinson will start at point guard for the Knicks on Friday, completing a stunning turnaround. Coach Mike D'Antoni made the announcement Thursday, a day after Robinson sparked a comeback victory over the Washington Wizards. Robinson scored 23 points and started the second half in place of Chris Duhon, who will go to the bench.

Here are excerpts from the most-viewed posts on this week's Bay Area blog. MUNI Of all the problems facing San Francisco's cash-strapped City Hall, none has more political and financial impact than the crisis at the city's Municipal Transportation Agency. Muni, which already made sweeping changes to bus routes and cut 80 jobs in December to save $3.2 million, faces a midyear deficit of $16.9 million.

The new year may not have brought an end to unemployment woes, but many workers who are laid off in 2010 will receive a helping hand paying for health insurance if a little-noticed proposal in President Obama's budget for the fiscal year 2011 is adopted. The proposal would subsidize 65 percent of the premium for workers who lose their jobs between March 1 and the end of 2010 if they want to continue with their employer's health coverage under the federal law known as Cobra.

FUCHSBERG--Seymour, 90. Gentle and generous soul, attorney, lifelong tennis enthusiast. Died February 3, 2010, after an extended illness. Loving husband for 50 years to the late Esta. Devoted father of Jane, Paula and Gilbert; father-in-law of Deborah Halperin; and grandfather of Ella and Julian. Last surviving child of the late Max and Gussie Fuchsberg, he was predeceased by brothers Jack, Abe and Meyer and sister Frances. A graduate of City College, he served in the Army Air Forces in the Pacific in World War II. After two decades in New York's garment industry, he earned his law degree at age 48 and joined his brothers in practice at the firm of Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg, working until he was 80. Throughout his life, he actively supported the Jewish community and other worthy causes. He was wise, witty and wonderful. In his final years, he was deeply fortunate to benefit from the saintly dedication and tender care of Lena Hunter, Mary Samuel, Diane Brown and Dolly Moncrieffe. Services at 9:30am Sunday, February 7, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91st Street). Donations in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

CONNERS--Joyce Benaye, nee Harris, died on February 1, 2010 at 1:00pm PST at her daughter's home in Murrieta, CA, surrounded by her children. Born in Hamilton, OH on August 16, 1941 to George Bernard Harris and Marguerite Minanette Isaacs, Joyce died of end stage renal failure and COPD. Joyce performed with her husband, Steven J. Conners, in several touring productions as singer, dancer and magician's assistant, before raising five children. Later, a writer and painter, Joyce lived in Ohio, Michigan, Louisiana, and Arizona. For the last ten years, Joyce worked as an apartment manager in Long Beach, CA. Scolding is a habit -- and almost an art -- in the San Francisco Bay Area. A recent example: A patron of the Berkeley Public Library makes an eloquent plea that the library reconsider its insect exhibit. She writes that ''as a parent who is constantly trying to build on children's natural empathy and expand their circle of compassion to include all living beings, I worry about the message you send to impressionable children by treating insects in such a manner contrary to their natures.''

A senior Chinese official said Thursday that China would not bow to pressure from the United States to revalue its currency, which President Obama says is kept at an artificially low value to give China an unfair advantage in selling its exports. The official, Ma Zhaoxu, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said at a news conference that ''wrongful accusations and pressure will not help solve this issue.''

The Graduate Center community mourns the loss of a distinguished colleague and dedicated teacher, who co-founded CUNY's Ph.D. Program in Theatre and generously established the Vera Mowry Roberts Chair in American Theatre, a field of research she pioneered. What's not to like? Saul's Delicatessen in Berkeley has been trying to be good: It sources its ingredients locally, favors organic produce and offers a seasonal menu.

Defensemen Ryan Whitney of the Anaheim Ducks and Tim Gleason of the Carolina Hurricanes were added to the United States men's Olympic roster. Whitney and Gleason replaced the injured defensemen Paul Martin of the Devils and Mike Komisarek of the Toronto Maple Leafs. Final rosters are due Feb. 15 when the United States will hold its only pre-Olympics practice. The team's first game is Feb. 16 against Switzerland.

The snowboarder Kevin Pearce, a likely Olympian before sustaining a severe head injury Dec. 31 during training in Utah, has been transferred to a brain-rehabilitation hospital in Colorado. In a statement, one of his doctors, Holly Ledyard, said that Pearce ''is able to walk and do many daily activities with some assistance.''

ROSS--John Porter, (JP), 86, formerly of Summit and Loveladies, NJ, passed away on February 2nd at his home in Princeton, NJ. Born in West Orange, NJ, January 8, 1924, John graduated from the Lawrenceville School in 1943. He deferred his admission to Princeton to serve in the 101st Infantry Regiment, 26th Infantry Division of Patton's Third Army. He received the Purple Heart for wounds received during the Battle of the Bulge. He also received the Bronze Star, Combat Infantry Badge, Good Conduct Medal, Victory Medal and The New Jersey Distinguished Service Medal with an Oak Leaf Cluster. His battalion received the Presidential Unit Citation for combat during the Battle for Northern France. After the war he returned to Princeton and graduated Class of 1947. He then embarked on a 40 year career as an Insurance Broker and Executive Vice President with Schiff Terhune Inc. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Patricia Norton Ross, his five children, Robert, Natalie, Susan, Win and John and twelve grandchildren.

Prayers, protests, appeals to conscience and pleas for love filled Nneka's set at S.O.B.'s on Tuesday night. She's a petite firebrand with serious intentions: ''It's very important that you pay attention to the lyrics,'' she insisted as one song began. Her message is steadfastness above all: ''You can't take my soul away,'' she sang. ''You can't make me go astray.'' Nneka Egbuna (pronounced NAY-ka EG-boo-na), whose parents are Nigerian and German, grew up in Nigeria and built her career in Germany, where she has been recording with hip-hop producers since 2005, although she performed with a live band. She now has homes in Lagos and Hamburg, while her songs are in English with some pidgin Nigerian. She has just released her American debut album, ''Concrete Jungle'' (Yo Mama/Decon/Epic), a compilation from her European releases.

Both the Senate and House health care bills propose incentives to help corporate wellness programs intended to help employees stay healthier and to keep a lid on a company's insurance costs. But those programs have hit a legal speed bump with the recent enactment of a law that generally prohibits employers and insurers from asking workers about their family medical history. Workplace wellness programs are common these days. More than half of employers offer programs to stop smoking or to manage weight, according to a 2009 survey by Aon Consulting. More than a third have on-site fitness centers.

For all the Saints' talk about trying to hit Peyton Manning and disrupt his game, the Colts say it has not quickened their pulse. ''We get that every week and we get that from teams in our division twice a year,'' offensive guard Ryan Lilja said. ''It's nothing new.''

As birds in the rafters at Prudential Center heralded his arrival, Patrik Elias rejoined his teammates for practice Thursday morning -- a positive development for the struggling Devils, as well as the Czech Republic national team. The Devils (35-18-2) have lost 7 of 10 games, including the Jan. 16 game in which Elias was knocked unconscious by Colorado Avalanche defenseman Ryan Wilson. They were shut out in three of those losses and managed just a goal in three other defeats.

An obituary on Thursday about Dick McGuire, the former New York Knicks player, coach and scout, misidentified the area of Queens where he grew up and where his parents owned a bar. It is Rockaway Park, not Far Rockaway. The obituary also omitted a survivor -- a daughter, Leslie Dwyer, of Glen Rock, N.J.

About 72 hours before Super Bowl kickoff, the rivals' blocking and tackling and eye-gouging broke out, if only rhetorically, in dueling presentations from the union and the league over the N.F.L.'s looming labor situation and games that might be lost some 19 months from now. DeMaurice Smith used his first Super Bowl news conference as the union's executive director to castigate ownership for crying poor, using obfuscatory math and readying for a lockout in 2011, when the current labor deal expires, endangering the season. More ebullient and wry than his predecessor, Gene Upshaw, Smith said ''I dig it'' several times to imply he was on to management's tactics.

Levels of radioactive tritium measured in new monitoring wells around the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant have jumped tenfold, to 774,825 picocuries per liter, since Monday, a plant spokesman said Thursday. That is nearly 40 times higher than the standard for drinking water, although the new sample came from a monitoring well, not a drinking water well; no drinking water samples have been shown to be contaminated.

Reflecting a growing catalog of disputes between Washington and Beijing, a senior Chinese official said Thursday that pressure for tighter sanctions against Iran over its nuclear program could block chances of a diplomatic settlement on the issue. The official, Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi, was speaking in Paris less than a week after Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clintonrebuked China over its opposition to stronger measures against Tehran, saying Beijing's position was shortsighted.

News about Haiti is quickly moving off the front pages, but that doesn't mean relief efforts are slowing down. Mary J. Blige, André Balazs, Donna Karan and Andre Harrell are hosting a benefit on Monday night to remind New Yorkers of the people still in need. The event, "A Night of Humanity" at the Urban Zen Center, is followed by a "Relief Party" at the Standard Hotel and includes appearances by P. Diddy, Russell Simmons, Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren and others. Soledad O'Brien will act as master of ceremonies, Wyclef Jean will be the featured speaker, Whoopi Goldberg will be the night's auctioneer and Ms. Blige will perform. All proceeds from the evening will go to Habitat for Humanity, Partners in Health and Yéle Haiti.

"Them Crooked Vultures is unswervingly faithful to its pedigree," writes Nate Chinen. "Along with Josh Homme, best known as the frontman of Queens of the Stone Age, it features Dave Grohl, the former drummer in Nirvana, and John Paul Jones, the former bassist in Led Zeppelin. That their output delivers a punch to the gut can only be seen as the fulfillment of a promise. The band doesn't feel like naked derivation, but its parentage is hammered home with every fat and bruising riff." The motley supergroup will be churning out more rock and roll riffs tonight at the Roseland Ballroom.

Perhaps no role-playing game has provoked more controversy or more devoted followers than "Dungeons and Dragons." In his documentary, "The Dungeon Masters," Keven McAlester follows two men and one woman who devote their lives to D&D. One is an evil drow elf displaced by Hurricane Katrina, another is a sanitation worker who lures friends into a "Sphere of Annihilation" and the third is a failed supervillain who starts a cable-access show involving ninjas, puppets and a cooking segment. Their fantasy lives clash with their real ones in this movie, which is being shown as part of the Tribeca Cinemas Presents: Doc Series. The screening begins at 7:30. Stick around after to grill the director on druid spells.

The image of a shot blocker in the N.B.A. is, and probably always will be, a plodding 7-footer piling up huge amounts of blocks in spurts. Doing his best to change that stereotype, the Atlanta Hawks' Josh Smith, at an athletic 6 feet 9 inches, became the fastest player to reach 1,000 career blocks in a loss to Oklahoma City last Tuesday.

Dr. Denis Mukwege and his young patient try to assert humanity and dignity in war-torn eastern Congo, Nicholas D. Kristof reports.

My Sunday column is again from Congo, through the lens of a doctor (Denis Mukwege) and his patient (Jeanne Mukuninwa). They are both extraordinary figures, and Dr. Mukwege is sometimes mentioned -- most deservedly -- as a candidate for the Nobel Peace Prize. His Panzi Hospital is an oasis in South Kivu, just as the Heal Africa Hospital is in North Kivu.

Preparing for my part-time National Guard training, I am transported into a former life. Getting my old "number two on the sides and back, trim the top" haircut and putting on my digital camouflage uniform is like going through a time warp. Looking in the mirror, I feel as if I am staring at a person I used to be. Like a rusty foreign language speaker, I struggle to talk like a soldier. Once second nature, the clipped sentences and vocabulary of sirs, ma'ams, rogers, hoo-ahs, acronyms, four letter words and colorful expressions now take effort. I also return to a world where the conflicts in Afghanistan and Iraq are an impending reality, not a distant abstraction.

When the people of Tulsa, Okla., buried a Plymouth Belvedere in front of the courthouse in 1957, it was a huge event for the city as it marked the state's centennial. For years the cluster of Pearl Paint stores in Lower Manhattan -- one in a cast-iron building on Canal Street and two in the next block, on Lispenard Street -- have been the supply depots where artists found their next blank canvas, that extra tube of cerulean blue or another quart of turpenoid, an odorless substitute for turpentine. ''It's like a household word for students: 'I'll go to Pearl, get it cheaper,' '' said Robert Cenedella, an instructor at the Art Students League of New York and a painter. ''The key word is cheap, on sale, and they have everything. There's hardly anything you couldn't get there.''

DICK--Marion Pokoik. June 7, 1926 - January 28, 2010. Deeply mourned by your children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and other devoted friends. Your kindness, generosity and sense of humor will live on forever. Everyone is heartbroken by your sudden demise. Your loving daughter, Gail

Hamas, the militant Islamic organization that controls Gaza, insisted that it did not intentionally aim rockets at Israeli civilians during the Gaza war last winter, according to a report submitted to the United Nations this week. Hamas said accusations that it had deliberately made targets of Israeli civilians were unfounded. But a Gaza-based Palestinian human rights group said Friday that the Hamas government's report was disappointing and lacked credibility. Hamas also said in the report, delivered to the United Nations office in Gaza, that it regretted any harm to Israeli civilians, but it defended Palestinians' right to respond to Israeli attacks. The report was meant as a response to a harshly critical United Nations study of the three-week conflict that accused Israel, and to a lesser extent Hamas, of possible war crimes.

8 P.M. (HBO) TEMPLE GRANDIN (2010) Claire Danes, left, plays Ms. Grandin, the autistic animal behaviorist whose designs for humane slaughterhouses are used in the cattle industry. ''I'm not like other people,'' she has said. ''I think in pictures.'' Mick Jackson directed this film, using a series of snapshot images that trace Ms. Grandin's self-perceptions from her early diagnosis through her turbulent school years and the unwavering support of her mother (Julia Ormond), aunt (Catherine O'Hara) and science teacher (David Strathairn). ''Hers is a tale that could be easily played up for drama, intrigue and weepy reconciliations, but this narrative is loyal to Ms. Grandin's credo: emotions are secondary to tangible results,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. ''And the result is a movie that is funny, instructive and also intangibly charming.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton explores how Haitian and Dominican churches are putting aside historic tensions to lead earthquake relief efforts. The author Mitch Albom discusses the New Jersey rabbi and Detroit pastor who inspired his latest book, ''Have a Little Faith.'' And Bob Abernethy and Ms. Lawton report on the 10 Americans, most of them members of an Idaho Baptist congregation, who have been charged in Haiti with child abduction and criminal conspiracy for trying to take 33 Haitian children out of the country on Jan. 29 without the government's consent.

Contributions to Pearl Rochelson Fund at Brooklyn Museum, Hadassah, or Myasthenia Gravis Foundation. Service Sunday, 11:15am, at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

St. Louis Rams Coach Steve Spagnuolo did not close the door on the Rams' acquiring Michael Vick in the off-season. Vick has been linked repeatedly to the Rams because General Manager Billy Devaney knew Vick while he was with the Falcons and because the Rams' quarterback situation is tenuous at best. Vick has another year on his contract with Philadelphia, but he was used on a limited basis, leading to speculation that the Eagles might try to trade him or even cut him. ''I've got a lot of respect for Michael as a player,'' Spagnuolo said. ''Everything I have heard out of Philadelphia is kind of good. We haven't gone down that road in our process yet.''
