SEIDMAN--Lloyd G.,96, on February 4. Devoted husband of the late Judith, loving father of Elinor Berlin and husband Robert and David Seidman and wife Ruth Greenstein, adoring grandfather of Daniel Berlin and wife Elizabeth Beaumont, Michael Berlin and wife Amelia, and Joanna Berlin, and great-grandfather to Lucia. His zest for life was incomparable. Services will be held at Larchmont Temple Axelrod Chapel, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY at 1pm on Sunday, February 7.

''Letter grades are nothing more than a scarlet letter that will keep people from eating out,'' Geoff Kravitz, a spokesman for the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce, said Friday at the first public hearing called to consider the city's proposal to rate restaurant cleanliness with letter grades. He was not the only one to invoke the stigma of an upper-case A. In point of fact, the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene would assign a bright-blue letter ''A'' or a green B to New York restaurants that have passed inspection, instead of handing out a numerical grade as is done now. But still, many in the restaurant business objected as if the city had likened them to Hester Prynne at a public shaming.

PEACOCK--Grant Allen, Jr. New York Jeweler, died February 3, 2010, in Redding, CT, at age 86. Beloved husband of 62 years of Jo Ann Peacock. Also survived by six loving children: Christine Bauler (husband Brad), of Framingham, MA; Grant Peacock III (wife Lawson), of Tucker, GA; Kathleen Benchley (husband Nathaniel), of New York City; Mary Jo Teetor (husband Mark), of Poultney, VT; Frances Stanulonis (husband Mark), of Groton Long Point, CT; and Andrew (wife Lizz), of Newry, ME; and six grandchildren. Mr. Peacock took over the fine jewelry business started in the 1920s by his father, Grant, Sr. He maintained the old-world attention to individual customers' needs while updating a boutique still rooted in turn-of-the-century manners. When he retired from Grant A. Peacock, Inc. in 1989, his daughter Kathleen took over the business. Born in Garden City in 1923, he attended The Lawrenceville School and graduated from Princeton University in the Class of 1946. He served in the U.S. Navy During World War II and eventually retired with the rank of Commander. During many years in Ridgefield, CT, he was a member of the Town Republican Committee and the Ridgefield Men's Republican Club, although in his later years he became a democrat; Board member of the Ridgefield Community Center; President of the Ridgefield Lions Club; on the Board of Governors of the Silver Spring Country Club; and the U.S. Naval Reserve. His three siblings, Janet, Mary and George, all predeceased him. A memorial mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Friday, February 12 at 11am at Sacred Heart Church, Church Street, Georgetown, CT, 06829. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Dorothy Day Soup Kitchen, 11 Spring Street, Danbury, CT, 06810, or Meadow Ridge Scholarship Fund, 100 Redding Road, Redding, CT, 06896.

VON BLON--Philip. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Walker Art Center mourn the passing of their Honorary Trustee and former President and Chairman of the Board, whose intelligent care, steadfast commitment, and passion for the Walker were deeply appreciated. Philip served as a Walker trustee since 1959 and was a beloved friend. The Walker extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Joanne, their children Margaret and Martha, and extended family and friends. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis, MN

Ending months of dispute that threatened to bring down Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, the prime ministers of Britain and Ireland on Friday hailed a breakthrough agreement to transfer the province's police and justice system from Britain to local control on April 12. Prime Ministers Gordon Brown of Britain and Brian Cowen of Ireland met near Belfast with Northern Ireland's Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders after a late-night announcement that the main party of the unionists, who are committed to the province's remaining part of Britain, had agreed to the transfer. Handing over the powers has been the most important and contentious of the issues still outstanding in the long-running and still fragile effort to bring peace to the six British-ruled counties of Northern Ireland.

ELLISON--Viola, of New York City, died on February 4, 2010, in her 90th year, after a long illness. A daughter of the late Ernest Ellison and Edna Lockwood Ellison of Charlotte, North Caroline, she was preceded in death by her sister, Harriet Ellison Woodward, and her brother, Robert Emmet Ellison. A graduate of Rosemary Hall, she studied with Helen Stout's International Travel School in Europe, and later traveled to Europe, South Africa, South America, and throughout the United States. She was a member of St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York City, was President of the Women of Saint Thomas, and served on the Altar Guild of the Church, on the Altar Guild of New York, and was a Board Member of the Halsey Day Nursery. She was also a member of The Huguenot Society of New York, The Colony Club, and several tennis clubs. She is survived by her nephews, Ernest Ellison II, of Charlotte, NC, and Christopher Gaillard Ellison, of Austin, TX; a niece, Larkin Ellison Fultz, of Beaufort, SC; great-nephews David Lockwood Carpenter, Patrick Miles Carpenter, Ernest Ellison III, and Matthew Wendell Fultz; a great-niece, Neel Ellison Horne; and by three great-great-nephews and three great-great-nieces. A memorial service will be held in the Chantry Chapel of St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street, New York City, and a graveside service will be held at Swan Point Cemetery in Providence, Rhode Island, on dates to be announced. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to St. Thomas Choir Guild, 202 W. 58th St., NYC, NY 10018. Bluebird, we will miss you.

The youngest son of Brian Burke, the general manager of the United States ice hockey team and of the Toronto Maple Leafs, has died in a car crash. The Maple Leafs said the 21-year-old Brendan Burke, who publicly revealed he was gay in an ESPN.com article in November, was fatally injured in an accident Friday in Indiana.

President Obama paid tribute on Friday to the seven C.I.A. operatives who were killed in a suicide bombing late last year in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, one of the deadliest attacks in the agency's history. ''Let their sacrifice be a summons,'' Mr. Obama said, ''to carry on their work, to complete this mission, to win this war and to keep our country safe.''

A lot has been made this week of the New Orleans Saints' defense, with its ''remember me'' hits and its ability to keep the opposing team's offense out of the end zone by any means necessary. But lurking behind Peyton Manning is the Colts' defense, a group that has been impressive in Indianapolis's two playoff victories. ''We do get overlooked,'' Colts linebacker Clint Session said, referring to opponents' emphasis on Manning. ''It's kind of a thing that comes with good teams. He's been here before all of us on our entire defense, so we know this is his team. He should get all the credit, but every now and then throw us a little bone.''

POOR--Eloise, 84, died Tuesday, February 2, at Sunrise. Sweet, gentle, loving mother of Candida Monteith, Anna Poor, Graham Poor, grandmother of five, sweetheart of Peter Poor since the eighth grade and patient wife for over 59 years. Everyone who knew her will miss her warm smile and gentle laugh. Memorial at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue, will be announced later.

FUCHSBERG--Seymour, 90. Gentle and generous soul, attorney, lifelong tennis enthusiast. Died February 3, 2010, after an extended illness. Loving husband for 50 years to the late Esta. Devoted father of Jane, Paula and Gilbert; father-in-law of Deborah Halperin; and grandfather of Ella and Julian. Last surviving child of the late Max and Gussie Fuchsberg, he was predeceased by brothers Jack, Abe and Meyer and sister Frances. A graduate of City College, he served in the Army Air Forces in the Pacific in World War II. After two decades in New York's garment industry, he earned his law degree at age 48 and joined his brothers in practice at the firm of Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg, working until he was 80. Throughout his life, he actively supported the Jewish community and other worthy causes. He was wise, witty and wonderful. In his final years, he was deeply fortunate to benefit from the saintly dedication and tender care of Lena Hunter, Mary Samuel, Diane Brown and Dolly Moncrieffe. Services at 9:30am Sunday, February 7, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91st Street). Donations in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

Shelby, Republican of Alabama, who on Thursday put a ''blanket hold'' on dozens of President Obama's nominees awaiting confirmation before the Senate. Poems that shun trickery and flirt with both beauty and boredom.
VISITING THE VACTICAN.

Commentators in the English media often bemoan the national team's lack of elite strikers. Manager Fabio Capello has tried Jermain Defoe, Peter Crouch, Gabriel Agbonlahor and Darren Bent as partners to the mercurial Wayne Rooney. And then there has been the long-running saga about whether or not to recall Michael Owen for the World Cup in South Africa. With few firmly-established players up front, Capello's first choice to partner Rooney in attack might be Emile Heskey, the rarest breed of striker - one who rarely scores.

Peter Olenick, a 25-year-old freestyle skier and three-time medalist in the halfpipe at the Winter X Games, vividly recalls the first time he tried the Whiskey Flip, his self-invented marquee trick, a twisty, somersaulting double flip executed 20 feet or so above the halfpipe's lip. ''It was terrifying,'' he says. ''I didn't even know if it could be done. But I'd been doing it over and over in my head, so I figured I could make it go right.'' Some deep breaths, some mental finger-crossing and ''I just kind of hucked it,'' he says, landing cleanly, exhilarated. A second attempt was even ''scarier. Now my body knew what was happening. But I did it. Fear kind of keeps all of us going.'' Fear may be the signature emotion of the Winter Olympics, prickling the skin hairs and sharpening the senses of all those athletes moving fast over slick, unforgiving surfaces. ''Everybody feels fear out there, and I mean everybody,'' says Ross Hindman, the founder and program director of the International Snowboard Training Centers in Colorado and California, which specialize in training midlevel and elite snowboarders. Fear affects those of us too who recreationally strap on skis, snowboards, skates or, more rarely, a skin suit in advance of a bobsled run. ''The issue is how you deal with fear,'' Hindman says.

WHO are these people? Seriously. I want names. That, of course, is exactly the problem when it comes to online commenters, even on high school sports blogs. Hiding behind a screen name allows the unidentified to say anything without taking responsibility for their words.

HERBST--Lois Gabbe, died on February 4, 2010. Survived by her children daughter Sandra and son Brian and their spouses Ben and Stacey, grandchildren Samantha and Gabrielle, her mother Beatrice, brother Fred, his wife Joan, former husband Edward and brother-in-law Ronald. Service to be held at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York on February 8, at 11:30am. Donations in her memory may be made to Gilda's Club, 80 Maple Avenue, White Plains NY, 10601 or International Committee Against Mental Illness, P.O. Box 1921, Grand Central Station, New York, NY 10163. A loving mother, daughter and friend, adored and cherished by all who knew her. She will be deeply missed.

AS the art director of Proenza Schouler, a position he has held since the label's inception, Alejandro Cardenas was responsible for creating the exotic fish prints (right) that were so talked about in the spring collection. And it was no easy feat. ''I spent two months drawing them,'' he said. ''I had to figure out how to make a flat image glow, like a fish.'' Difficult as it was, the experience inspired Mr. Cardenas's latest work: a series of gouache and watercolors, now on view at the James Fuentes gallery in Chinatown. The show, entitled ''Narcomedusa'' after a jellyfish found in the darkest ocean depths, is a psychedelic deep-sea exploration, enhanced by all-black walls and picture frames. The only things visible are the vibrant underwater creatures.

''As an athlete, you're No. 1. You're A-No. 1, you're on the front burner burning on high, and everything is for you. When you're a mom, we put ourselves on the back burner. We become last, and the family becomes everything, and that is vastly different.'' Picabo Street, the former Olympic skier and gold- and silver-medal winner, with her 6-month-old son, dax.

Podcast Scheduled for this week: Amy Bloom discusses her story collection ''Where the God of Love Hangs Out''; the critic Lee Siegel revisits Christopher Lasch's ''Culture of Narcissism''; Motoko Rich presents notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. SMART USA, like many automakers, did not have a good 2009, but sales of its Smart Fortwo continued to plummet in 2010. Sales of the diminutive coupe fell 40 percent last year, but were down an astonishing 84 percent in January, when only 278 of the cars were sold. That's down from 864 cars in December and from 1,776 in January 2009.

FRUGAL TRAVELER Tired of Twitter? Overwhelmed by Yelp? This week, Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, checks out Foursquare, a year-old social networking service, to suss out deals in Brooklyn and beyond.

SPERRY--Carl Blake, died January 25, 2010. He was 76. Born in Riverdale, NY, graduated from Fieldston 1951, Swarthmore College 1955 and Columbia University later. He served two years in the US Navy, 14 years with IBM and later with Depository Trust Co., Wall Street. He sang with the Barbershop Harmony Society for 50 years including the Big Apple Chorus in New York. He married Suzanne Pedrick in 1988, retired in 1993 and moved to Florida. A memorial service will be held on February 9th.

The winter Olympics were held in Lake Placid, N.Y., 30 years ago. This winter, for those who cannot make it to Vancouver, the Lake Placid Lodge, an Adirondack-style inn offering rustic luxury, has discounted packages. Through April 1, the accommodations in the lodge and cabins are $385 to $1,050, a 30 percent reduction with a two-night minimum. The rate includes breakfast, a box lunch and tea. Wines from the lodge's cellar are available at a 30 percent discount.

He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Patricia Riordan Reilly; his children Brendan, Kenneth, William and Marianne; 13 grandchildren; and, six great-grandchildren. Dr. Reilly's son, Dr. Philip Cullen Reilly Jr. MD, died in 1995. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Shelter Island Senior Citizens Foundation.

CONSUMER advocates say the Dorel Juvenile Group's recall of four million child car seats comes so late it does not matter anymore. Many of the children who once used those seats could have driver's licenses by now, because Dorel and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration fought over the recall for almost a decade. What's more, the seats were so old that Dorel and other safety experts recommended that they no longer be used -- even if the new, safer anchoring straps the safety agency had demanded were installed.

This year's N.B.A. All-Star Game is going up against the Olympics and Valentine's Day. So the basketball fan who has a love of international sports or a significant other could feel a little conflicted about their plans Sunday night. One person who surely will not be conflicted is Kenny Smith.

EDWARD--Jess, M.D.,88, died February 3, 2010. Former Chief of Anesthesia, South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, NY, proud graduate of Wesleyan University and Hahnemann Medical College. Served in the U.S. Navy, Medical Corps, Pacific Theatre, WWII and again at St. Albans Naval Hospital, Korean War. Beloved husband of 65 years to Joyce and devoted father to Jim, Deborah, Greg and Dave. Loving father-in-law to Lynn, Carol and Bonnie, and delighted grandfather of Jess, Dana, Jono, Robin, Jared, Kyle, Kevin, Laura and Jenny. Jess brought style to his passions -music, art, poetry, skiing, wood carving, enjoying the Vermont woods and everything L.L. Bean. A memorial service will follow this Spring. Donations can be made to the Jefferson's Ferry Foundation, Employee Emergency Fund, S. Setauket, NY 11720.

THE NEWS At a House hearing, Ray LaHood, the secretary of transportation, said his advice for anyone who owned a recalled Toyota car or S.U.V. was to ''stop driving it -- and take it to a Toyota dealer.'' Minutes after the hearing, he told reporters the remark ''was obviously a misstatement'' and that he had meant that worried owners should not put off having their cars repaired. BEHIND THE NEWS Investors rushed to dump Toyota stock when the ''stop driving it'' remark flashed on news wires. Meanwhile, the company's woes spread to more problems in more cars, including the popular Prius hybrid.

MARQUARD--Margaret Haager Thoben, died peacefully at her home in Lexington, KY on January 15, 2010 at the age of 90. Born and raised in Louisville, KY, she was granddaughter of the city's chief of police and daughter of the first woman to drive an automobile there. She was a member of the Junior League of New York City, where she resided for 20 years. She was the devoted wife of William A. Marquard for 64 years until his death in 2006, and the adoring and caring mother of three children, Pamela Ann, Lexington, KY, Suzanne Thoben, Brooklyn, NY and Stephen Allen, Ridgewood, NJ. A brother, Edward, of Louisville, KY, and seven grandchildren also survive her. Known to all for her immaculate and elegant style and grace, she will truly be missed. Memorials to the Headley-Whitney Museum, Midway College (both of which she served as a board member), The Sanders-Brown Center for the Aging or a charity of one's choice.

Sure, everyone knows that West Hollywood is a gay-friendly neighborhood, with rainbow flags flying from restaurants and bars. But did you also know that the phrase ''lipstick lesbian'' originated at Peanuts, a ''femme'' bar on Santa Monica Boulevard? Or that there was a riot against police brutality in Silverlake on New Year's Eve 1966, several years before Stonewall? Those are among the tidbits offered in a three-hour gay-themed tour of Los Angeles run by Out and About, a bus tour company started in response to Proposition 8, the California ballot initiative that outlawed same-sex marriage.

EYDENBERG--Judith. Beloved wife of Morton for more than 63 years. Adored mother of Bette and Paul Schneiderman and Susan Westlake. Devoted grandmother of Andy, Scott, Danny and Rebecca. Loving sister of Maurice and the late Elenore Rosenthal and of Barbara and Lee Rubin. Judy was loved by all for her warmth and kindness. Services Sunday, 11:30am, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

BISHOP--Jonathan, P.,82, of Ithaca, NY, died peacefully on January 22, 2010. Son of John Peale Bishop and Margaret Hutchins Bishop, he attended Middlesex and Harvard, served in the US Army, married Alison Lurie in 1948, and taught at Amherst College, UCLA and Cornell. Professor Bishop's work focused on American literature, the Bible as literature and freshman writing. Member of the Cornell Catholic Community, enthusiastic volunteer and contributor to charity, Jonathan is survived by his brother, Robert, sons John, Jeremy and Joshua, and grandchildren Wells, Susanna and Jonathan A.

IT'S easy to recognize the Bad Girl. She's usually a bottle blonde, stuffed into a tight sweater that outlines her oddly conical breasts. Her mouth is wide, painted and clamped on a cigarette. Her eyes burn a little too brightly, and her legs, planted in a pair of high-rise pumps, go on forever. This exotic specimen began appearing in American movies around 1944, when one of her first interpreters was Barbara Stanwyck in Billy Wilder's ''Double Indemnity,'' from the James M. Cain novel. An American variation on the femme fatale of the 19th-century romantics, she was not the figure of mystery and dark allure that her European predecessors were, but a more carnal, blatantly sexual and self-interested creature. She was more fond of chewing gum than smoking opium, less concerned with luring men to their metaphysical doom than cleaning out their bank accounts and moving on to the next sucker.

Frances Buss, who at the dawn of commercial television parlayed a job as a temporary receptionist into a pioneering career as a director whose work helped establish the talk show, the game show and the cooking show as television staples, died on Jan. 19 in Hendersonville, N.C. She was 92. She died a few days after having a stroke, said Mark Spencer, her great-nephew.

GALLAGHER--John Frank, passed away in Wilkes-Barre, PA on January 29, 2010 at the age of 91. He served as captain in the U.S. Army during World War II in the ETO, then graduated from Hamilton College where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He received his M.A. from Johns Hopkins. He had a distinguished career in publishing, rising to prominence at Harcourt Brace in the 1950s. He later headed the Michigan State University Press and the college departments at T. Y. Crowell and St. Martin's Press. He worked with such authors as Robert Penn Warren, Loren Eiseley, Abba Lerner, A. J. Ayer, Isaac Asimov, Allen Tate, George Gaylord Simpson, Cleanth Brooks, and Jacques Barzun. He edited and wrote the introduction to the best-selling memoir, "My Life and Loves" by Frank Harris, the eminent Victorian literary figure. He is survived by his four daughters, Sarah W. Gallagher of New York, NY; Elizabeth C. Gallagher of Denver, CO; Julia C.P. Gallagher of New York, NY, and Frances M.C. Gallagher of Farmersville, TX, his son-in-law Richard Dangerfield (Elizabeth's husband), and many cousins, nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews.

FRANTZ THERMILUS, the chief of Haiti's National Judicial Police. [16]

After the powerful mid-Atlantic storm grounded flights and shut down highways Friday night, Amtrak's Capitol Limited, bound for Chicago from Washington, seemed to offer its 115 passengers a cozy alternative as it sped through the snow-swept countryside. But around 2:45 a.m. Saturday, the train made an unscheduled stop outside Connellsville, Pa., a former coal-mining town 57 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. Downed trees and power lines blocked the Capitol Limited, stranding and infuriating passengers.

Art While most of us might not fancy wearing a dress fashioned from wool cobwebs or cheesecloth, metallic mohair fringe or twine, it's fascinating stuff to appreciate as 21st-century wearable art. Clothes made from all of the above can be found at ''QUICKTAKE: RODARTE,'' an exhibition at the Smithsonian's COOPER-HEWITT, NATIONAL DESIGN MUSEUM from Thursday through March 14.

FUCHSBERG--Seymour, 90. Gentle and generous soul, attorney, lifelong tennis enthusiast. Died February 3, 2010, after an extended illness. Loving husband for 50 years to the late Esta. Devoted father of Jane, Paula and Gilbert; father-in-law of Deborah Halperin; and grandfather of Ella and Julian. Last surviving child of the late Max and Gussie Fuchsberg, he was predeceased by brothers Jack, Abe and Meyer and sister Frances. A graduate of City College, he served in the Army Air Forces in the Pacific in World War II. After two decades in New York's garment industry, he earned his law degree at age 48 and joined his brothers in practice at the firm of Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg, working until he was 80. Throughout his life, he actively supported the Jewish community and other worthy causes. He was wise, witty and wonderful. In his final years, he was deeply fortunate to benefit from the saintly dedication and tender care of Lena Hunter, Mary Samuel, Diane Brown and Dolly Moncrieffe. Services at 9:30am Sunday, February 7, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91st Street). Donations in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

New Yorkers can be quite creative when they want to put their affection into words. Some leave Post-it notes on the bathroom mirror. Some take out billboards in Times Square. Those still racking their brains for the perfect way to say ''I love you'' this Valentine's Day can take a cue from the memorable expressions of love left behind by famous New Yorkers. ''The frankest and freest product of the human mind and heart is a love letter,'' Mark Twain once wrote. ''The writer gets his limitless freedom of statement and expression from his sense that no stranger is going to see what he is writing.''

While many of the athletes at the Olympic Games this month will count on gravity to do its work as they try to get to the bottom of their race courses asfast as they can, others will be going in the opposite direction -- up in the air. This is where their action is: where the figure skaters make their turns, the skiers and snowboarders perform their tricks. This is where their events are won. But these bursts of competition are also moments of artful levitation and, especially for spectators, of transcendence. Who better to capture such moments than Ryan McGinley, an artist whose photography so often catches bodies in motion? For this portfolio, he visited rinks and mountains in California, Utah, Colorado, New Hampshireand New Jersey in order to choreograph the lightness of being an Olympian. The ice and the snow became his stages, and a dozen of the UnitedStates' greatest winter athletes his players, most of them individually costumed by Kate and Laura Mulleavy, who design clothing for their hipL.A. label, Rodarte. What McGinley captured is the joyousness, the dreaminess, the miraculousness of lifting off and, if only for a moment, flying.

Loving mother of Dale and Brett Yacker, Marc and Hannah Kalikow, and Richard and Rosemary Kalikow. Adored sister of Lillian Blatt. Loving and devoted grandmother of Liat, Brett, Leora, Wade, Gallee, and Weslee. Funeral services will be held Monday, February 8th, at 10am at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, NYC.

ELLISON--Viola, of New York City, died on February 4, 2010, in her 90th year, after a long illness. A daughter of the late Ernest Ellison and Edna Lockwood Ellison of Charlotte, North Caroline, she was preceded in death by her sister, Harriet Ellison Woodward, and her brother, Robert Emmet Ellison. A graduate of Rosemary Hall, she studied with Helen Stout's International Travel School in Europe, and later traveled to Europe, South Africa, South America, and throughout the United States. She was a member of St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York City, was President of the Women of Saint Thomas, and served on the Altar Guild of the Church, on the Altar Guild of New York, and was a Board Member of the Halsey Day Nursery. She was also a member of The Huguenot Society of New York, The Colony Club, and several tennis clubs. She is survived by her nephews, Ernest Ellison II, of Charlotte, NC, and Christopher Gaillard Ellison, of Austin, TX; a niece, Larkin Ellison Fultz, of Beaufort, SC; great-nephews David Lockwood Carpenter, Patrick Miles Carpenter, Ernest Ellison III, and Matthew Wendell Fultz; a great-niece, Neel Ellison Horne; and by three great-great-nephews and three great-great-nieces. A memorial service will be held in the Chantry Chapel of St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street, New York City, and a graveside service will be held at Swan Point Cemetery in Providence, Rhode Island, on dates to be announced. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to St. Thomas Choir Guild, 202 W. 58th St., NYC, NY 10018. Bluebird, we will miss you.
LAX--Ruth. IPTAR mourns the loss of Dr. Ruth Lax: training analyst, supervisor, teacher and mentor. The work of this brilliant, persistent and constructive psychoanalyst will endure.

The two-story-high buffed ebony figures in the Madison Avenue windows of Calvin Klein illustrate the way men's bodies are now celebrated. The streets of New York, with their wide range of sartorial fantasies, also suggest the return of the peacock to everyday life and provide a contrast to the sedate mood of the men's collections last month in Europe. The sidewalk parade here ranges from conservative dark coats worn with colorful scarves to flamboyant extremes of dress reminiscent of the Incroyables, who set Paris on its ear with their witty and imaginative dress in the early 1800s.
Seller's Responsibility After the Closing

SAY what you will about the double-denim look, but, as the fashion blogger Mister Mort wrote on his site in November, it ''is not always wrong.'' To illustrate his point, he posted a pic of a young Johnny Hallyday, sprawled on his side like a Calvin Klein model, the collar of his denim jacket popped and the cuffs of his blue jeans rolled. Maybe it has to do with the economy, but that down-home country cool still has appeal -- and, as is visible on the streets and the spring runways, it's having a moment. Witness the February cover of Vogue, which features Jessica Biel in a three-piece denim ensemble from Ralph Lauren. Like a handful of labels this season, including D & G and Mulberry, Mr. Lauren was looking to communicate a more rugged sense of chic, one exemplified by the jewelry designer Gaia Repossi (bottom left), who showed up at Valentino's recent couture show after-party in an outfit right off the ranch.

WILLIAM D. COHAN To date, a few elusive but important Wall Street executives have kept an exceedingly low profile, hoping against hope that the whole thing just blows over. We can't let that happen. There is just too much at stake now, and Wall Street has proved repeatedly over the past 40 years -- since the firms went from private partnerships (where partners had their entire net worth on the line) to public companies (where bankers and traders were encouraged to take huge risks with other people's money) -- that it is incapable of regulating itself. -- Excerpt from

ANN DEXTER-JONES, the socialite, writer, Reiki master and former rock 'n' roll wife, had no intention of also becoming a jewelry designer. But after years of collecting ID bracelets while on tour with the Foreigner guitarist Mick Jones, her husband at the time, she hatched the idea of making one herself. ''I thought, wouldn't it be great if they were a little more glam?'' Amped up with polished stone and inlaid diamonds, the bracelet caught the attention of quite a few friends, all of whom asked Ms. Dexter-Jones to design one for them. ''Finally I said 'yes.' '' Her new line, produced by local artisans (her stonecutter restores jewels for Fabergé; her goldsmith creates prototypes for Cartier), includes five ''rock 'n' roll chic'' bracelets, each piece individually numbered. Kate Moss is a fan of the onyx Midnight Hour design, an oversize watch with a diamond hand fixed to 12.

Health care legislation in Washington may be stalled, but that has not stopped legislatures in more than two-thirds of the states from objecting to one of its central planks: a requirement that everyone buy health insurance. The objections, many of them driven by the Tea Party movement, may turn out to be largely symbolic. But they nonetheless serve notice to President Obama and the Democrats of real anger over their health care plans and signal the potential for political upheaval down the road.

Dance Looking up at lighted apartment windows at night, it's easy to wonder about the people inside. Who are they? What are they feeling? What do they hope? What do they fear? How has life treated them? In 1955 Anna Sokolow, a choreographer with a strong social conscience who must often have mulled over such matters, put her wonderings onstage in ''Rooms.'' She created a portrait gallery of city dwellers -- most of them lonely or unhappy -- in a shabby apartment house, and she theatrically symbolized their rooms with arrangements of chairs. Sokolow, who died in 2000, would have been 100 years old this year, and the LIMÓN DANCE COMPANY is honoring her with a revival of ''Rooms,'' with its searing jazz score by Kenyon Hopkins played live by performers from the Manhattan School of Music jazz department, conducted by Justin DiCioccio. The Limón company's program also includes one of José Limón's best-known works of the '50s, ''There Is a Time'' (1956), a dance interpretation of the passage from Ecclesiastes that in the English Standard Version begins, ''For everything there is a season, and a time for every matter under heaven: a time to be born, and a time to die'' and ''a time for war, and a time for peace.'' Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 p.m., Baryshnikov Arts Center, 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-3353, Ext. 10; $50.

FAUGHNAN--Mary Agnes Rios Pugliese, born in Manhattan, NY on June 4, 1918 passed away from natural causes in the state of grace and with dignity on February 5, 2010 in Jupiter, FL: Mary raised her family with her husband George Pugliese in Whitestone Queens, NY for 46 years. Following George's passing and relocating to Deerfield Beach, FL, she became the loving wife of Hugh Faughnan, who passed away in 1999. Mary will always be remembered as the loving mother of Georgiana Benatti, Paul Pugliese, Catherine Anderson, and Regina Fee. She was the loving Grandmother of Christine Del Vecchio, Janice Whitley, and Theodore George Anderson Sr. and the loving Great Grandmother of Paul, Annabelle and Kate Whitley; Jeanna and Olivia Del Vecchio; and Christopher and Theodore George Anderson Jr. All of whom experienced and adored her kind and loving devotion. Mary was the life of all gatherings. Always ready to cut a rug and grab a microphone to sing her favorite tunes such as Bill Bailey, Spanish Eyes, San Francisco. Known to her great grandchildren as Gigi, they gave her the happiest moments. Mary knew no strangers! All throughout her life, Mary's undying faith gave her the strength and longevity to carry out Gods work with every one she met in the spirit of a Mother Theresa. She considered Jesus Christ her best friend. Her lifetime devotion to family and to Jesus Christ was exemplified by her active support of Catholicism and as an ecumenical minister at St. Jude's Catholic Church in Tequesta, FL. Mary always felt her extended family at St. Jude's was a precious gift from God to her. Mary will be remembered by all those that she touched! Mary was a beautiful person in every way and we will miss her. Visitation will be held on Saturday, February 6, 2010 from 2pm to 4pm and from 6pm to 8pm at Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, 250 Center St, Jupiter 33458 (561-744-2030). Requiem Mass will be held at St Jude's Church, 204 N US Hwy One, Tequesta, FL on Monday February 8, 2010 at 12 Noon. Services in Port Washington, New York are to be announced.

On Feb. 11, 1990 -- 20 years ago this Thursday -- Nelson Mandela walked through the gates of a South African prison after 27 years of confinement. His release was celebrated the world over. But it had a particular effect on those who were being held as political prisoners by other repressive regimes. The Op-Ed editors asked seven of these former captives to describe what it was like when they heard the news of Mr. Mandela's liberation.

Sunil Gulati, one of the architects of Major League Soccer, was re-elected unanimously to another term as president of the United States Soccer Federation at the group's annual general meeting in New Orleans. Gulati, 50, was first elected to the volunteer position in March 2006. Under Gulati's leadership, the United States dropped Bruce Arena as coach after the 2006 World Cup and hired Bob Bradley. Since then the United States has qualified for another World Cup -- this summer in South Africa -- and Gulati is also leading American efforts to host the 2018 or 2022 World Cups.

TOWNSEND--Mark. Former Director of Bell Labs Electronic Switching Systems, dies at 95. Mark A. Townsend, an electrical engineer with 23 patents who participated in the development of the fluorescent light, the first trans-Atlantic telephone cable, airplane instrument panel lighting, and the electronic telephone switching system that changed the way telephones connected across the world, died Friday, January 29, 2010 in Aurora, Colorado. In the early 1940s, while at General Electric Vapor Lamp Company in Cleveland, he patented the fluorescent starter switch with a reset button. His team at GE developed the 12" fluorescent light and an ultraviolet light that provided night illumination to fighter aircraft. After WWII, at AT&T Bell Laboratories, he worked on an electronic switching system enabling instantaneous national and international telephone call switching. In 1966, Mr. Townsend became Laboratory Director responsible for the Electronic PBX and ESS (Electronic Switching System). He earned a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering from Texas Tech University and a Master Science in Electrical Engineering from Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Mr. Townsend is survived by his wife of 19 years, Del Samac Townsend of Aurora, CO, and was preceded in death by his first wife, Jean McClelland Townsend. Mr. Townsend is also survived by his daughters Patricia Townsend Spence, of Juneau, AK; Marcia Townsend DeWitt, of Sedgwick, ME; and Evelyn Townsend Glaspey, of Milwaukee, WI; and a son, Mark A. Townsend, Jr., of Framingham, MA. Mr. Townsend's survivors include 13 grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren. Memorials are suggested to The Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 833 W. Washington Blvd., Chicago, IL 60607-2331.

Where to Study in Spain I'm trying to decide where to study abroad for the winter semester of 2011. I've narrowed it down to five cities in Spain: Barcelona, Valencia, Alicante, Seville and Granada. All the programs are relatively similar, so at this point I'm trying to make the decision based on weather, culture and how easy it is to travel to other countries. My Spanish is fairly good, but I am concerned that the Catalan in Barcelona might be a problem. Which city would you recommend for a 20-year-old college student? -- Carolyn Fanning, Berkeley Heights, N.J.

Born in Hamilton, OH on August 16, 1941 to George Bernard Harris and Marguerite Minanette Isaacs, Joyce died of end stage renal failure and COPD. Joyce performed with her husband, Steven J. Conners, in several touring productions as singer, dancer and magician's assistant, before raising five children. Later, a writer and painter, Joyce lived in Ohio, Michigan, Louisiana, and Arizona. For the last ten years, Joyce worked as an apartment manager in Long Beach, CA. Joyce will be cremated and a memorial service will be held at Grand Canyon, AZ, her favorite place, on her birthday. She is loved...

Film Two recent, smart French films -- ''Angel of Mine'' and ''The Joy of Singing'' -- can be seen on IFC Films video-on-demand service. ''ANGEL OF MINE,'' directed by Safy Nebbou, stars Catherine Frot as Elsa, an emotionally unstable woman in the midst of a divorce who spots a pretty little girl at a birthday party attended by her son and is convinced that the girl is her daughter, who died in a hospital fire days after her birth. Elsa stalks the girl's mother, Claire (Sandrine Bonnaire), by posing as a prospective buyer for the house of the family, which is moving to Canada. There is an inevitable showdown. The beautifully acted film suggests a sophisticated descendant of ''The Great Lie,'' the 1941 weepie starring Bette Davis and Mary Astor.

More than any of their Super Bowl teammates, Peyton Manning and Drew Brees will duel for the property rights. One will be considered to have won, the other to have lost. Such is the quarterback's bonanza and burden. Coaches also deserve ownership or censure, but other players are mostly remembered for having earned, or having missed an opportunity for the ring. How many people know that linebacker/defensive end Charles Haley,playing for the 49ers and the Cowboys, won a record total of five Super Bowl rings? But anybody worth his or her flat-screen television knows that Joe Montana and Terry Bradshaw each won four Super Bowls. And that Jim Kelly lost four.

Super Bowl square pools are popular in offices and among friends because they require no knowledge of football. Square pools are based on a 10x10 grid, with 100 squares. After participants choose their squares, numbers from 0 through 9 are randomly assigned across the top of the grid and down the left side, with each axis associated with one team. Each box is assigned two numbers.

VELLA--Stephen Christopher, an historian of Britain and her empire in the eighteenth and nineteenth century, died on January 30, 2010 at age 34. The cause was cancer. He was buried at Green-Wood Historical Cemetery in Brooklyn, NY, on February 4. He was a graduate of Princeton (1997), and studied with Linda Colley, Frank Turner and Jay Winter at Yale, from which he received his doctorate in 2007. His dissertation on the effect on Britain waging war in what we now call Afghanistan in the period 1776-1851, won Yale's John Addison Porter Prize, which is awarded to the most distinguished dissertation of the year. He taught at Wake Forest University, where he was Assistant Professor of History before the final stages of his illness required him to take a sabbatical. His keen intellect and playful wit made him the most charming of companions, but it was his kindness, generosity of spirit, acute sense of justice and zest for life that most endeared him to his friends. Beloved son of Ann and James. Loving brother of Susan Vantuyn, her husband Marcel and the late James. Cherished uncle of Alexander, Natalie and Nicole. Fond nephew of Catherine Capona.

PEACOCK--Grant Allen, Jr. New York Jeweler, died February 3, 2010, in Redding, CT, at age 86. Beloved husband of 62 years of Jo Ann Peacock. Also survived by six loving children: Christine Bauler (husband Brad), of Framingham, MA; Grant Peacock III (wife Lawson), of Tucker, GA; Kathleen Benchley (husband Nathaniel), of New York City; Mary Jo Teetor (husband Mark), of Poultney, VT; Frances Stanulonis (husband Mark), of Groton Long Point, CT; and Andrew (wife Lizz), of Newry, ME; and six grandchildren. Mr. Peacock took over the fine jewelry business started in the 1920s by his father, Grant, Sr. He maintained the old-world attention to individual customers' needs while updating a boutique still rooted in turn-of-the-century manners. When he retired from Grant A. Peacock, Inc. in 1989, his daughter Kathleen took over the business. Born in Garden City in 1923, he attended The Lawrenceville School and graduated from Princeton University in the Class of 1946. He served in the U.S. Navy During World War II and eventually retired with the rank of Commander. During many years in Ridgefield, CT, he was a member of the Town Republican Committee and the Ridgefield Men's Republican Club, although in his later years he became a democrat; Board member of the Ridgefield Community Center; President of the Ridgefield Lions Club; on the Board of Governors of the Silver Spring Country Club; and the U.S. Naval Reserve. His three siblings, Janet, Mary and George, all predeceased him. A memorial mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Friday, February 12 at 11am at Sacred Heart Church, Church Street, Georgetown, CT, 06829. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Dorothy Day Soup Kitchen, 11 Spring Street, Danbury, CT, 06810, or Meadow Ridge Scholarship Fund, 100 Redding Road, Redding, CT, 06896.

Classical In the summer of 2008 at the Mostly Mozart Festival, KARI KRIIKKU offered a remarkable performance of Mozart's glorious Clarinet Concerto with the Minnesota Orchestra, performing with a ravishing tone and alluring sensitivity. On Saturday at Carnegie Hall he joins the NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC for the United States premiere of the Clarinet Concerto by Magnus Lindberg, the Philharmonic's composer in residence. In this welcome chance to hear the orchestra away from Avery Fisher Hall, the music director, Alan Gilbert, also conducts Wagner's ''Rienzi'' Overture and Sibelius's Symphony No. 2. Saturday at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $39 to $116.

RESNICK--Abraham C. (Chub), May 11, 1907 - January 29, 2010. Devoted husband of Mary, loving father of Paul and Elsa, fond grandfather of Adam. Born and raised in Brooklyn, graduate of City College, Class of 1927. High school mathematics teacher for more than 40 years at Boys High and Brooklyn Tech. An extraordinarily gifted teacher and a true gentleman. He will be missed by all.

Huacachina, Peru, Jan. 9, 2009 Peru often conjures images of the untamed rain forest, but south of Lima lies a vast, Sahara-like desert. The oasis village of Huacachina offers sunset sandboarding to those willing to trek over and up countless sand dunes. I used the timer function on my camera, and it's actually a miracle I made it in time for the photo. The thrill of looking down from atop a slope of sand, waiting to start the descent, made all the effort worth it. Laine Strutton, Phoenix

GLASCOCK--James A.,Jr., died suddenly and unexpectedly on January 29, 2010 in Richmond, VA at age 91. A native of Richmond and a member of the Yale College Class of 1939 and the Yale Law School Class of 1942, he initially practiced law with the IRS in Washington and New York. In the mid-1950s, he joined Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, where he became a partner specializing in tax litigation. He was a retired partner at the time of his death. He lived in Short Hills, NJ for 35 years before moving back to Richmond in 1991. He was a past president of the Yale Club of Central NJ, and a longtime member of the Short Hills Club, The Yale Club of New York City, the Commonwealth Club of Richmond and the New York and Virginia Bars. A true gentleman and loyal Yale alumnus, he will be much missed by his family and friends. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Adelaide Boze Glascock of Richmond, his son J. Scott Glascock of New York City, and by five nephews and their wives and children.

Charles Isherwood engages in a form of white liberal minstrelsy by conflating his aesthetic issues concerning ''Fela!'' with issues of race. He's correct that the characters in the show could have been better written. This fact makes them poorly written characters, not the conjurings of minstrelsy. Black people, like the rest of the world, sing and dance. America's racist history should not rob of us of that joy by complicating these elemental, universal impulses. Dwayne R. Rogers of Brooklyn, responding to Mr. Isherwood's essay on ''Fela!''

FUSSA--Saturnina, age 103, NYC, NY and Bound Brook, NJ. She died on January 22, 2010, at Greenbrook Nursing Home, New Jersey. Born in Rincon, PR she moved in 1928 with her family to NYC where she met her husband Juan. They settled in Bound Brook in 1931 to start a family and for work. She was a respected and sought after dressmaker, a 50 year member of the I.L.G.W.U.

CREATED in New York more than 80 years ago by Irving Schott and named after his favorite Cuban cigar, the Perfecto motorcycle jacket is an American classic, sported by every stylish rebel since Marlon Brando and duplicated by just as many designers. Now, finally, comes the women's Perfecto -- a streamlined lambskin version made, by hand, on the same turn-of-the-century machines as the men's, and worn rather superbly by Blake Lively on the cover of the February Esquire. No surprise, the jacket has generated considerable excitement among the fashion masses -- if not for its authenticity, then for its affordability: at $386, it is a steal compared with, say, Balenciaga's much-coveted $2,600 biker jacket. But then, as Jason Schott, the company's C.O.O. and Irving's great-grandson, put it, ''Not everything made in the U.S.A. has to carry a luxury price tag.''

PATCH--Kathryn W.,84, a retired estates lawyer who earlier was a field agent and intelligence analyst with the State Department, died Tuesday, February 2, in Linden, MI, after a long illness. Born Kathryn Virginia Woodward in Port Washington, NY, the youngest of four children, she graduated Wellesley College in 1946 and joined the State Department, officially as a foreign-service secretary, but also attached to the Office of Special Operations, forerunner to the CIA. Posted to several European and South American embassies, she later was an intelligence analyst and operations instructor at Langley. She left the Agency for her third year at Georgetown Law School, graduating in 1961. The first female associate hired by Coudert Brothers, she worked in Paris and Manhattan specializing in estates and trusts. She entered private practice in 1979 in Pelham, NY, then retired with husband Howard R. Patch Jr., to Old Lyme, CT, in 1982. Mrs. Patch was a director emeritus with the Oratorio Society of New York, with which she sang tenor for several decades and then served on the board of directors. She was active with several other choral groups, including the founding of Con Brio in Connecticut. In her youth she raced sailboats, and she and Mr. Patch served for years on The Corinthians' race committee. She married Mr. Patch on January 6, 1965, and he died in 1992. Two sons and three grandchildren survive. Memorial service at 2pm Thursday, St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Old Lyme. Donations in lieu of flowers, to the Oratorio Society or the Humane Society of New York.

Stay Balanced The Saints are thought of as a pass-happy team, but they are more likely to run (240 plays) than pass (233) on first down. That first-down balance keeps teams from blitzing or using nickel packages on early downs. It also allows Drew Brees to use play-action to surprise defenses when he does pass: Brees has thrown 29 passes of 20 or more yards on first down, and the play-action bomb is one of his favorite plays. The Saints average 4.6 yards per carry on first-and-10, so when they do run they will have success against the undersized Colts defense. A solid running game and an unpredictable offense will keep the Colts from sitting back in two-deep zones and waiting for Brees to darken the skies with footballs.

PLACE--Sabrina Creswell, of New York, died January 24, 2010, age 43, of cancer. Survived by her mother Cynthia S-H Bowers, brother David W. Sinclair, sister Tinsley Place Lockhart. She graduated from Ethel Walkers School, Simsbury, CT, Skidmore College and Columbia University Teachers College. She was loved by her students, enjoyed nature, poetry, philosophy and laughter. Memorial service in the spring, email to: cshbowers@gmail.com

SEIDMAN--Lloyd G.,96, on February 4. Devoted husband of the late Judith, loving father of Elinor Berlin and husband Robert and David Seidman and wife Ruth Greenstein, adoring grandfather of Daniel Berlin and wife Elizabeth Beaumont, Michael Berlin and wife Amelia, and Joanna Berlin, and great-grandfather to Lucia. His zest for life was incomparable. Services will be held at Larchmont Temple Axelrod Chapel, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY at 1pm on Sunday, February 7.

Theater If William Shakespeare did return Sir John Falstaff to life on the orders of the queen, as the legend about the origins of ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' goes, what does that say about the playwright? The idea that Shakespeare would do such a thing usually draws knowing chuckles from college professors, but since it's been more than four centuries now, and the guy's reputation is pretty secure, can't we say that ''Merry Wives'' may have been something of a sellout? If Harry S. Truman asked Arthur Miller to bring back that wonderful Willy Loman in the early 1950s, I'd like to think that Miller would have balked. Bill Cain's speculative historical drama, ''Equivocation,'' imagines the thought process of a Shakespeare-like character under pressure from the state. That character, named Shag and played by John Pankow, is ordered by King James to write a friendly drama about the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 that fabricates history to serve the purposes of the government. Filled with historical digressions, literary in-jokes and plays within plays (expect scenes from ''Macbeth'' and ''King Lear''), the ambitious comic play, which has received stellar reviews in regional productions, presents a pragmatic artist struggling with his conscience, among other considerations. The great Garry Hynes (''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'') directs. Starts previews on Tuesday, Manhattan Theater Club at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212, mtc-nyc.org; $75.

DeSMEDT--A. Theodore. On February 5, 2010 A. Theodore (Ted) DeSmedt was called home. Born in the Bronx, New York on April 29, 1917, he was the son of Belgian emigres Albert and Mary DeSmedt. In 1940 he married Eleanor Schneier and soon thereafter went into service for his country as a navigator in the Army Air Force. On December 30th, 1943 their B-24 nicknamed "Sad Sack" was shot down by German fighter planes on the outskirts of Paris. Ted would spend the remainder of the war as a POW in Luftstalag One on the Baltic Sea. Released by the advancing Russian Army he came home and resumed his work with the United States Shipping Lines in the scheduling department. Ted then moved to the Isbrandsten Company and over the years held a number of positions eventually becoming President of the merged American Export Isbrandsten Lines. His career would take him to chief executive positions in the shipping world at States Marine Isthmian, Prudential Grace, Marchessini and Reefer Express Lines. Ted was invited to participate in the renowned Harvard Amp Business School in 1969 along with other corporate executives. He was elected class President. Outside of work, Ted found time to enjoy many other activities. He loved the opera and became the first corporate sponsor of The Metropolitan Opera House. A member of the Downtown Athletic Club, he swam for an hour each day prior to going to the office. He was an Elder in the Upper Saddle River Dutch Reformed Church. He traveled internationally on business and had friends and associates throughout the world. He was equally comfortable in the company of princes, ministers, business executives and longshoremen. In 1982 Ted retired and started a ship chartering and brokerage firm, Shipping Services Company, Inc. in San Mateo, California. Eleanor, his beloved wife of 48 years, passed away in 1988. In 1990 he married Nancy Conway Holland of San Mateo. She was his loving companion for the remainder of his life. His friends and family will always remember him for his calm demeanor and his sage advice. There never was a problem so large or so small that he couldn't help you to work through it. His wisdom will be missed by everyone who had the good fortune to know him as a father, friend, or mentor. Ted is survived by his wife Nancy, his sons Bill (Kathrin), Bob (Dale), four grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, five stepsons, Michael, Patrick, Stephen, Dan, and Kevin and their families.

GINSBERG--Stanley A.,September 1938 - January 2010. Passed away suddenly in Boca Raton, FL. He is survived by his wife, children, grandchildren and brother. President of Inter City Tire Export. SCHAFFNER--Bertram H.,M.D. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society, proud of our long association with him, mourn the loss of Bertram H. Schaffner, M.D. As psychoanalyst, psychiatrist, soldier, teacher, researcher, writer, gay rights advocate, arts patron, organizer of Caribbean and worldwide mental health programs, and champion of human dignity, his ideals will continue to inspire us. Jay S. Kwawer, Ph.D., Director, White Institute Paul Lippmann, Ph.D., President, White Society Jay W. Seeman, President, Board of Trustees

Sustain Drives The Colts gain an average of 36.8 yards per offensive drive, the second-highest figure in the N.F.L. (the Patriots led the league). The Saints defense is designed to force turnovers, not three-and-outs, so opponents can move the ball on them. Saints opponents gained an average of 31 yards per drive, 22nd in the league. The Colts' 12-play drives do more than put points on the board: they keep the opposing offense off the field, and they put opponents in bad field position when the Colts are forced to punt. Ball control is crucial against the Saints offense. Their quick-strike offense can turn a close game into a blowout if given too many opportunities.

REISS--Jerry. His constant care changed our lives forever as he made us a closer family. This in itself will never be overlooked. Jerry Reiss was the keystone of our family and more importantly, the heart. Adam, Faith and Eric

The image of a shot blocker in the N.B.A. is, and probably always will be, a plodding 7-footer piling up huge amounts of blocks in spurts. Doing his best to change that stereotype, the Atlanta Hawks' Josh Smith, at an athletic 6 feet 9 inches, became the fastest player to reach 1,000 career blocks in a loss to Oklahoma City last Tuesday. At 24, Smith reached the feat more quickly than any player has reached 900, but he has done it with a relatively slow and steady approach, never recording more than 227 blocks in a season or averaging more than 2.9 blocks a game. The single-season N.B.A. record for blocks is 456 by Mark Eaton in 1984-85, when he averaged 5.56 a game.

Update | 10:07 a.m. The filmmakers behind "The Cove" have been open about their goal: not to win an Oscar - though they wouldn't mind - but to stop the dolphin slaughter that the documentary depicts. They may have moved one step closer to that goal with the news that the Oscar-nominated film, which shows a secret dolphin-killing field in Taiji, Japan, will now be distributed in Japan. The Japanese company Medallion Media is planning a tentative release date of April 2010, according to a statement released late Monday by the filmmakers' representatives. The director, Louie Psihoyos, considers the move a coup because the film had drawn the threat of legal action in Japan.

Overview | How can we "reintroduce" ourselves to math so as to take the mystery out of numbers and start thinking of numbers and mathematics as helpful and useful instead of mysterious and inaccessible? How can math lovers convey the beauty and value of math in both concrete and abstract ways? In this lesson, students consider how math is indispensible and then develop and perform skits that illustrate how certain math concepts and processes can make life easier. They then respond to philosophical prompts about the value and qualities of math.

The foundation that runs the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum said on Monday that it had reached an agreement with the heirs of the artist Kazimir Malevich over the ownership of an untitled work by him that the museum plans to include in an exhibition this month. In a joint news release, the foundation and the heirs of Malevich, the Russian Suprematist, said they had reached "an amicable settlement" over an oil painting on canvas made by the artist around 1916, which was acquired by Peggy Guggenheim in 1942 and has been part of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice. The painting is one of about 70 Malevich works that were presented at an exhibition in Berlin in 1927, during which the artist was called back to the Soviet Union and entrusted the works to several friends. Malevich died in 1935 and his work was subsequently banned by the Nazis, but his paintings, drawings and other art have since become part of the collections of museums and private owners, setting the stage for efforts by his heirs to reclaim ownership of these works.

It is the idea that paved the way for Legos, rifles and the Industrial Revolution: standardized parts. Now Bay Area researchers are applying it to the field of bioengineering. With a new $1.4 million grant from the National Science Foundation, scientists from Stanford University and the University of California, Berkeley are now designing, making and testing thousands of pieces of DNA in an Emeryville facility which hopes to standardize these parts for the first time. The Bay Area is one of the country's biggest hubs for synthetic biology - a multidisciplinary field that aims to create new biological systems - so it is fitting that it will house the first lab dedicated to churning out standard DNA parts, a lab known as Biofab.

In today's story, "A Well-Written War, Told in the First Person," The Times's Elisabeth Bumiller surveys some of the first-rate writing by veterans about the Iraq war, including that of Brian Turner, a contributing writer to Home Fires. While New Yorkers are generally more welcoming to tourists than your average French waiter, apartment dwellers become prickly when those same tourists move in next door. The issue is not without its collection of advocates willing to stage protests at City Hall, especially before the summer tourist season kicks off (seen here in 2008).

Today is a special day in the history of the United Federation of Planets. Monday, February 8, 2010 is the date to which space adventurer Bert Stein made a heroic unidirectional leap backward into time from the 23rd century. He spent (is spending?) about six months in our time, before returning with his cargo of dilithium which helped jump-start the Federation. This day will always be known as "The Beginning of the Federation," and we will unravel its mystery by means of a puzzle. But before we do so, here's a warm-up question.

It's not only the New York theater scene that has come to be dominated by film and television celebrities: the roster of performers nominated on Monday for the Laurence Olivier awards, among the highest honors of the London stage, is rich with actors well known for their work outside the theater, The Guardian reported. Contenders in the best actress category include the "X-Files" star Gillian Anderson for "A Doll's House," Rachel Weisz for "A Streetcar Named Desire" and Imelda Staunton for "Entertaining Mr Sloane." Best actor nominees include James Earl Jones ("Cat on a Hot Tin Roof"), Jude Law ("Hamlet") and James McAvoy ("Three Days of Rain"), and Keira Knightley ("The Misanthrope") was nominated in the best supporting actress category. The dramas "Enron" by Lucy Prebble and "Red" by John Logan, both headed to Broadway, were nominated for best new play. The winners will be announced on March 21.A complete list of Laurence Olivier Award nominees can be found here.

While his "Lost" co-stars prepare to pack up and leave Hawaii, Daniel Dae Kim can plan to remain in that real-life locale for at least a few more months. Mr. Kim, who plays the time-traveling tough guy Jin on "Lost," has been the first actor cast in a coming remake of the crime drama "Hawaii Five-O," The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Kim will not be playing Danno or the other guy (our knowledge of "Hawaii Five-O" extends only to its famous catchphrase and its surf-rock theme song). He has been cast as Chin Ho Kelly, a detective played by Kam Fong in the original 1968 series. No casting has been announced for the roles of Danny Williams (the Danno in "Book 'em, Danno") or Steve McGarrett (the lead character played by Jack Lord), though The Hollywood Reporter said that Alex O'Loughlin ("Moonlight") was in talks for the McGarrett role. The "Hawaii Five-O" revival is being developed by the screenwriters Alex Kurtzman and Roberto Orci ("Star Trek," "Fringe") and Peter Lenkov, an executive producer of "CSI: NY."

Vampires are so last decade - these days, it's all about monsters. At the center of this scary trend is Lady Gaga, whose stage performances feature "Thriller"-style choreography and ghoulish costume changes. (Even Filipino prisoners helped push the trend with their famous YouTube video.) Alexander McQueen, who has cited Lady Gaga as an influence, recently showed an otherworldly collection accented with prosthetic makeup and podlike 10-inch reptilian platforms. Gareth Pugh also unleashed a legion of threatening, heavily powdered models in a broodingly romantic zombie romp, and Lanvin's disturbing new ad campaign stars the photographers Vinoodh Matadin and Inez van Lamsweerde - the latter in full-body makeup that makes her look as if she's been skinned alive.Perhaps the house should consider a partnership with the jewelry designer Emily Miranda, whose chunky pieces feature flesh-ripping animal claws. The film world is also right on trend. Spike Jonze got things going with "Where the Wild Things Are," which was followed by remakes of "The Wolfman" and, in theaters soon, "A Nightmare on Elm Street." Natalie Portman has signed on for "Pride and Prejudice and Zombies," and Tim Burton's dark directorial oeuvre is being celebrated in a career retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art through April 26. From a pop-psych perspective, this macabre obsession reads as a projection of the collective anxiety we're dealing with, given a glossy sheen to make it less scary. Wouldn't it be nice if instead of financial crises and terrorist attacks, all we had to worry about were things that go bump in the night?

My column today makes the argument that the quest for nuclear abolition, which has gained traction in the Obama era (and which is clearly dear to the president's heart), shouldn't be linked to the quest to forestall proliferation. Iran would still be seeking nuclear weapons even if America didn't have a vast nuclear arsenal - and right now, at least, our arsenal tends to prevent local arms races, rather than encouraging them.

Big Signature Collectors Shun Constitution Petitions | In California, it is almost always planting season and almost always signature-gathering season. Like big farmers, the major signature-gathering companies can determine what measures they want to plant on the statewide ballot - and what they do not. Kimball Petition Management does not want anyone to plant initiatives promoting a constitutional convention. Fred Kimball, who runs the petition firm, said he opposed such ballot initiatives and said he had warned independent managers that he would blacklist them if they work with Repair California, the Bay Area group promoting constitutional reform. One issue: the state constitutional convention, if it materializes, might remake the ballot initiative process. John Grubb, a spokesman for Repair California, said signature-gathering firms had blacklisted their petitions and shouted at their volunteers. Repair California has sent cease-and-desist letters to the major signature gathering firms. In the meantime, while those gathering signatures to put measures on the ballot usually carry multiple proposed propositions, some will not carry those two initiatives. [The Economist, The Contra Costa Times]

By the measures of the movie rental market, YouTube's first foray into charging users to stream full-length feature films was hardly a runaway success. The most effective product placement on a television show last year was in the 10th episode of ''Celebrity Apprentice,'' according to iTVX, a company that measures branding. The contestants on that show, including Clint Black, above, were asked to write a jingle for Chicken of the Sea brand tuna. ITVX's Q-Ratio is a measurement of factors such as how often the product is on the screen, how it is woven into the story of the program and if characters hold it or speak about it. The company also predicted that 85 percent of the audience would recall Chicken of the Sea after the show. SHELLY FREIERMAN

An obituary on Jan. 29 about the author J. D. Salinger referred incorrectly to one element in the plot of his short story ''A Perfect Day for Bananafish.'' The character Seymour Glass commits suicide while on vacation with his wife, not while on his honeymoon. (The error also appeared in a news article on Aug. 31, 2000; a book review on Oct. 8, 2000; and in essays on March 23 and Dec. 31, 2008.) The obituary also misstated the name of the yearbook at Valley Forge Military Academy in Pennsylvania, for which Mr. Salinger was literary editor when he was a student there; it was Crossed Sabres, not Crossed Swords. And the obituary referred incorrectly to a work he had written while at Valley Forge. It was a poem that was later set to music; it was not a school song.

Gov. David A. Paterson provided the second cash infusion in a week Sunday to St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan in Greenwich Village, but said concessions from unions and physicians would be needed to keep the hospital open. The governor said Sunday that after ''hours of intensive discussions and calls between all parties'' the state had agreed to put up $3 million and creditors another $3 million to keep the hospital going temporarily.

Warren Sapp, the former Tampa Bay and Oakland defensive tackle who is now an NFL Network analyst, was released on bond Sunday morning after spending the night in jail following his arrest for allegedly choking a woman. The NFL Network pulled Sapp off the air while it investigates the matter. Sapp, who starred for the University of Miami before going on to an N.F.L. career that is likely to eventually land him in the Hall of Fame, was arrested Saturday on a charge of misdemeanor domestic battery. The alleged incident took place in a Miami Beach hotel room. The woman said she had been dating Sapp for about two years.

A year ago, Sling Media, a subsidiary of EchoStar, introduced a nifty application for the Apple iPhone that allowed users with a Slingbox at home to watch and control their home television signal from their handsets. The only problem was that AT&T said such a bandwidth-intensive video service would overwhelm its network, so it limited the application to work only over an iPhone's Wi-Fi connection. TV lovers and techies worldwide criticized the decision.

There are few thoroughfares that reflect Haiti's economic past and future predicament more than the Grande Rue. Running north and south, a few blocks from the port, it is Broadway and Wall Street combined, a boulevard of commerce, where Haitians have been buying and selling for more than a century. Politicians have tried to name it many things; in the 1930s, it was the Rue Rafael Trujillo, after the Dominican dictator, and since the era of François Duvalier, known as Papa Doc, its official name has been the Boulevard Jean-Jacques Dessalines, a reference to a Haitian revolutionary.

One of the iconic images of football is of linemen preparing to square off, face mask to face mask, with one hand dug into the turf in a three-point stance, but Commissioner Roger Goodell said Sunday that it was conceivable such showdowns could be prohibited. Goodell told Bob Schieffer on CBS's ''Face the Nation'' that the league was continuing to assess ways to make the game safer, especially in reducing head injuries. In response to a question from Schieffer, Goodell said, ''You'll see a lot of players that never get down in the three-point stance, so it's possible that that would happen.''

WOOD--Genevieve Ella, on February 5, 2010 at home in New York City. Born April 10, 1918 in Utica, NY. Friend - Gail and Portia and so many others lucky enough to be in her universe grew better from the extraordinary texture of her being. Pioneer - Wave U.S. Navy, WWII (in first group of inductees, radio operator, one of five women trained in engine repair.) Writer - her life's work, she knew how to make a word count, how to turn a phrase. Spoke softly, understood the music of words. Candid, intelligent, well read, informed, witty, colorful, challenging. Loved brevity. Couldn't abide pretension, discrimination, or cruelty to animals. Her swing was the highest swing in the world.

LIONEL LOUEKE ''Mwaliko'' (Blue Note) The guitarist Lionel Loueke grew up in Benin, absorbing the guitar traditions of Mali and Nigeria as well as samba and jazz. He sings in a gentle baritone; he also clicks and whistles and makes his guitar speak in a similar way: in taps and scratches, damped single-notes as if struck on a thumb piano, and chords with ringing Impressionist harmony.

Jay Leno closed the least successful chapter of his long comedy career Tuesday night -- a rather abrupt midweek stop to what had been trumpeted as a new paradigm for prime-time television. Instead the show lasted only five months, cut short by ratings deemed unacceptable by NBC's affiliated stations, which saw their late local newscasts damaged by low lead-in audiences from Mr. Leno.

Thursday promises to be another dramatic day in Iran, and to lift hopes here in the West. It's the 31st anniversary of the 1979 revolution, and opposition leaders have scheduled rallies of the sort that the increasingly repressive government has had trouble gracefully repressing. As we watch reformers once again face off against the black-clad motorcycle-riding Basij militia, it will be tempting to hope that maybe, somehow, the good guys will win this time; and with a new, liberal regime ascendant, maybe the "Iran problem" - in particular, the nuclear standoff, which took a turn for the worse this week - can at last be solved.

The Mets have seemingly made more changes to Citi Field this off-season than to their roster. All were cosmetic - think more blue and orange in and around the ballpark - but none were about to affect the course of a game. At least until Tuesday, when it was revealed that the Mets will chop in half the 16-foot wall that shields a sliver of straightaway center field - otherwise known as the area that houses the Home Run Apple. When the Mets begin the 2010 season April 5 against Florida, that fence, 408 feet from home plate, will stand 8 feet high. The modification was first reported by The Daily News.

There's a scene in David Malouf's "Ransom" - a novel based mainly on Homer's "Iliad" - in which King Priam of Troy is slaughtered by Neoptolemus, the son of the Greek hero Achilles. That episode, which is not described in the "Iliad," ultimately derives from a lost archaic Greek epic, the "Iliou Persis," or "Sack of Troy." But the best-known surviving version of the death of Priam appears in the second book of Virgil's "Aeneid," and Latinists took me to task for not mentioning it in my review of "Ransom" published in the Book Review last month.

The Obama administration has scrapped NASA's plan to return humans to the Moon by 2020, which was behind schedule because of technical and budgetary problems. Instead, the administration will focus on developing new technologies to make long-distance space travel cheaper and faster, with astronaut trips to the Moon, asteroids and Mars possible in the future.

Honda is recalling 378,000 additional vehicles because the driver's side air bag may deploy too forcefully, causing an injury or death. The company had announced the recall of 440,000 vehicles for that reason last year.

When it comes to sex and reproduction, mammals are ultra-orthodox and, frankly, rather dull. Individuals are either male or female, no one changes sex and there are never more than two sexes in a species. No mammal reproduces asexually - by budding off a small piece of itself, say, or by splitting down the middle and growing a new individual from each half. Nope: among mammals, offspring are always produced by sex. That is, an egg fuses with a sperm to produce a child that is genetically distinct from both parents.

To the surprising list of people who benefit from Oscar nominations - stylists, make-up artists, awards consultants, bloggers - let's add Thomas Cobb, author. Mr. Cobb, 62, wrote the novel "Crazy Heart," which was the basis of the movie that's meant to give Jeff Bridges his long-overdue Academy Award. First published 23 years ago, the book was well received but sold only about 11,000 copies; re-released on Feb. 2 by HarperCollins - complete with photo of Mr. Bridges on the cover - it has already racked up five times that in sales and pre-orders. The film, too, has received more of an Oscar box office boost than its fellow nominees, according to The Los Angeles Times.

Once reserved for nurses and vegans, clogs were seen stomping all over the spring runways. For Chanel, it was "Green Acres" complete with aprons, flower baskets and hopsack clogs with bold CC's - a nod to the thick-soled footwear favored by Dutch and Swedish farmers. Marc Jacobs outfitted his sportier, colorful clogs with kitten heels, tassels and a mustache-like fur. (A buxom Lara Stone wears them in the new Louis Vuitton ad campaign; she is surrounded by moss, trees and white doves in a bucolic scene of innocence and luxury.) Meanwhile, Miu Miu took clogs the '70s route with huge platforms and kitschy prints of dogs, birds and daises.

At the end of 2005, Nicholas Felton decided to publish a report that would chronicle his life over the previous year. He looked through his music archives to see how many songs he had listened to. He checked his airline ticket stubs to see how many miles he had flown. He aggregated the number of books read and photos taken. He compiled those and myriad other data points into his first annual report about his life, aptly titled, "The Feltron Annual Report." (The "r" in "Feltron" was added to include a subtle pseudonym component to the report.)

Update | 1:29 p.m. New Yorker Films, the 44-year-old film distributor that abruptly announced last year that it was shuttering its doors, will live on as a new owner has been found for its estimable movie library. On Tuesday, Aladdin Distribution LLC of Marina del Rey, Calif., said that it had purchased more than 400 foreign and independent titles that comprise the catalog of New Yorker Films, which previously handled the release of movies like Jean-Luc Godard's "Breathless" and Claude Lanzmann's Holocaust documentary "Shoah," as well as films by Bernardo Bertolucci, Federico Fellini, Akira Kurosawa and numerous other directors. The revived New Yorker Films, which was originally founded in 1965 by Dan Talbot, will be run by Jose Lopez, a business partner of Mr. Talbot's and former vice-president who will now serve as president of the company. In a statement, New Yorker Films said that it intends to acquire six to eight films a year for theatrical release, and will continue to seek movies for its non-theatrical and home video divisions.

It seems you just can't celebrate Wagner anymore without at least a little bit of behind-the-scenes intrigue. The Salzburg Easter Festival in Austria may be in for a lot of it, as state prosecutors there have announced that they are investigating eight people involved with the event on suspicion of deception and embezzlement, The Independent of London reported. "We expect our inquiries to take months," a spokesman for the prosecutors told The Independent. "It involves non-existent companies and offshore bank accounts." The announcement follows the dismissal in December of the festival's executive director, Michael Dewitte, who is now being sought by the police on charges that he misused its funds and put its money into foreign bank accounts. Last week, The Independent said, the festival's technical chief, Klaus Kretschmer, was found unconscious under a bridge in Salzburg, and is believed to have attempted suicide after being accused of charging the festival for non-existent services. Over all, the festival may have been defrauded of as much as $2.75 million. It is scheduled to open on March 27, and feature Simon Rattle conducting a production of -- what else? -- "Götterdämmerung."
