Question No. 1: Will it be 24 hours long? Question No. 2: Will it still have short breaks roughly every 15 minutes so that its viewers -- and, presumably, its protagonist -- can go to the bathroom? Fans of the Fox action series "24" may soon learn the answer to these and other pressing questions now that a feature film version of the television show is in the works. Variety reported that the motion-picture division of 20th Century Fox has hired the screenwriter Billy Ray ("State of Play," "Shattered Glass") to write a script for a movie-length adventure for Jack Bauer, the secret agent (played by Kiefer Sutherland) whose world-saving exploits always take exactly one day to unfold. The Variety report said that Mr. Ray's screenplay would likely be set in Europe (where clocks are already set to 24-hour time). "24" is now in its eighth season on Fox, which has not yet officially ordered a ninth season of the show; Variety cautioned that a possible movie could be put on hold if the Fox network passes on the television series.

Most press coverage of the eurozone troubles has focused on Greece, which is understandable: Greece is up against the wall to a greater extent than anyone else. But the Greek economy is also very small; in economic terms the heart of the crisis is in Spain, which is much bigger. And as I've tried to point out in a number of posts, Spain's troubles are not, despite what you may have read, the result of fiscal irresponsibility. Instead, they reflect "asymmetric shocks" within the eurozone, which were always known to be a problem, but have turned out to be an even worse problem than the euroskeptics feared.

Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.I find that one of the keys to giving a living room a feeling of depth and substance is to have something -- like a piece of furniture -- visible behind the sofa or chairs. It leads your eye into the distance, giving the room that third dimension it so often lacks. I spent last Friday with a client, moving furniture around. The newly upholstered furniture was arriving in her living room, the first phase in the transformation of a room that has been long-unused into one that can be enjoyed on a daily basis. Behind the new pair of club chairs, we put a chest of drawers between two windows. The room immediately felt substantial in a way it hadn't before, as well as very cozy and warm. (This is also an excellent way to use a piece of furniture that your parents gave you, and which has sentimental value but which is not necessarily to your own taste. Not every piece in a room needs to be your absolute favorite thing; in fact, it is usually preferable for at least one thing not to be.)When chairs or sofas just sit in front of a wall, the space behind them can look rather sad. At home, I have been struggling with the depressing nest of cables and air of general neglect behind my club chair. But what was putting a monkey wrench in the decorating works was that I didn't need a table there -- there is already a desk nearby -- so I left it until finally it came to me. What I wanted, I realized as I put the last of a small stack of logs on the fire, was a really big log basket. I love log baskets, and it has been something I have wanted for a long time. They look so good in rooms, and, in the same way that bookcases and drinks trays do, they imply civilized living is going on!

I'm grappling with a small but puzzling question of motherhood. When it comes to child rearing, there is an array of controversies to pick from that's almost dazzling - breast or bottle, stay at home or work, stay at home and work - but this one seems to be much less vital. O.K., here goes: It might be time to cut off my hair.Every man I have consulted on the issue believes it is a bad idea. And the experts seem to agree that there are historical and biological links between long hair and sexual desirability. (But what are these guys thinking? That we'll go on a date? I'm married.) On the other hand, every mother I talk to has either cut her hair or wishes she was brave enough to do so. Iconic images of mothers principally show women with their hair up, or short. Dorothea Lange's "Migrant Mother" had seven children and hair - from what we can tell in the photographs - no longer than her shoulders. Mary Cassatt's painted mothers always have their hair tied up in a bun or a topknot.

The Bagger is considering instituting an equal-play policy when it comes to the biggest horse race in the Oscars: for every post about "The Hurt Locker" we need one about "Avatar." So voila: there has been a nerd-storm brewing for weeks over the typeface that the master of all media James Cameron used in subtitling the Na'vi language he helped create in his box-office-busting film. The futuristic blue aliens' words, you see, are rendered in a dowdy old font, Papyrus. "It is the only unima­ginative visual aspect of the movie," Allan Haley, a type design master, wrote on a font blog. "If the choice were mine, the subtitles would have been original calli­graphy."

San Francisco to Rethink School Assignment System | The San Francisco School Board will consider proposals at its meeting on Tuesday night to replace its complex and controversial school assignment system with a new system that could take into account a family's proximity to a school. In place since 2002, the current system uses a "diversity index," which looks at factors like family income, but not race, in an effort to ensure a racial mix. Parents have complained that the system is complex and often assigns their children to undesirable schools far from home. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

Akira Kurosawa's centenary doesn't arrive until March, but Film Forum has given devotees of the great Japanese director an early reason to celebrate his work with a tribute series, which runs through Feb. 18. Tonight, catch a screening of "Ran," the 1985 film is a transposition of "King Lear" to 16th-century Japan. The movie, Kurosawa's final epic production, is returning for its 25th anniversary in a print made from the original camera negative. "Tatsuya Nakadai plays the Lear figure, a feudal lord who divides his lands among his three disputatious sons, with predictably disastrous results," writes Dave Kehr. Go especially to watch the battle scenes, "filmed with great flair and bold color."

“In her latest, erotically charged, highly explicit collection of short stories, ‘Where the God of Love Hangs Out,’ ” Amy Bloom’s characters “think and speak in a cheeky if not impudent manner,” writes Francine du Plessix Gray. This “upbeat sassiness of tone is one of the many treasures of the new collection,” which consists of two sets of linked narratives, each consisting of four stories, as well as several free-standing stories. Janet Maslin has also called the book “beautifully astute.” The onetime psychotherapist and best-selling author will read from the collection, well-timed for Valentine’s Day, at Book Court tonight beginning at 7 p.m.

“In the way of many immigrant kids,” Najla Said recalled in a recent interview with Felicia R. Lee, “I just wanted all the questions about identity to go away.” For Ms. Said, an actress, writer and the daughter of Edward W. Said, the Columbia University professor who died in 2003, the questions, however, persisted. And so she created “Palestine,” a one-woman off-Broadway show produced by the Twilight Theater Company in association with New York Theater Workshop, that began previews on Saturday. It is, as Ms. Lee writes, “a coming-of-age story about Ms. Said’s journey to become an Arab-American on her own terms.” The show, which blends the personal with the political, covers her teen years “as a self-described politically agnostic 'Upper West Side princess’ to her vision of herself today, a 35-year-old woman who is deeply moved by the very word 'Palestine.’ ”

8 P.M. (Animal Planet) VENOM IN VEGAS The adventurer Donald Schultz (''Wild Recon''), above, spends 10 consecutive days with pythons, rattlesnakes, cobras and other deadly roommates in a 16-by-20-foot glass enclosure, outfitted with a bed and tiny bathroom, on the Las Vegas Strip. The danger increases every 24 hours as 5 snakes are added to an original 50 until a count of 100 is reached. What's worse, Mr. Schultz won't know which species he'll be living with until he opens each day's delivery. The purpose of this stunt: to extract venom for pharmaceutical research and perform tests to measure its potency, the depth of fang penetration and the strike range of some of the world's fastest snakes. 8 P.M. But Taliban leaders allied to Al Qaeda, including Faqir Muhammad, a senior member of the Pakistani Taliban, escaped over the border into Afghanistan, and the town was virtually empty when the military took control over the weekend, said Abdul Malik, a local government official.

When Nat Sherman, the venerable Midtown tobacconist, opened its new showroom on 42nd Street a few years ago, it quickly ran into a problem. The showroom included a private smoking lounge, known as the Johnson Club Room, where members and guests could have enjoyed a drink or a snack along with their cigars, pipes and cigarettes. But under New York law, smoking is forbidden wherever food or beverages are served to the public. When city officials twice rebuffed the company's requests for a waiver, Nat Sherman sought the intervention of a higher power: The New York State Legislature.

PALEY--Cabot Barber, died peacefully on February 5th. The cause of death was a stroke. Cabot was born on June 14th 1925 in Elizabeth, NJ and grew up in Cranford, NJ. Her parents, Henry Oberly Barber and Sophie Cabot Brewster Barber had three other children: an older brother Ken, an older sister Anne and a younger sister Sophie. After graduating from Cranford High School, Cabot attended Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, where she met the love of her life, Henry David Paley. They were married on April 23, 1946. Over the next decade Cab and Hank moved their growing family from Ohio to California, to South Carolina, New Jersey, Washington D.C., Maryland and Virginia. During these years they had five children: Brewster, Deborah, Andrew, Jonathan and Sarah. In addition to raising her children, she worked alongside Hank, unionizing migrant farm and paper mill workers. In '57, Hank's union job moved from Washington to Albany, NY, and he and Cabot moved their family just north of there to the small town of Crescent, on the Mohawk River. Cabot went back to school at Russell Sage College in Troy, where she got her BA. She had a keen interest in government and politics and had been an active member of the League of Women Voters while living in Virginia. When New York State was gearing up to hold a constitutional convention in '64, Cabot ran her own campaign to serve as a delegate. Cabot taught at Shenendehowa Elementary School in Clifton Park, NY until 1967, when the family moved to Park Slope, Brooklyn. In Brooklyn she became one of the pioneer teachers at High School Redirection, in one of the toughest neighborhoods in the borough. She then attended Hunter College School of Social Work, earned a Masters in Clinical Social Work and became a therapist. In the mid 1970s Cabot and Hank moved back upstate, to Catskill. Cabot had a private practice in Catskill and also saw patients in Albany. Hank, then the president of the Commission for Independent Colleges and Universities, died suddenly on April 16, 1984 at the age of 59. In 1990 Cabot married Donald Thaler of Amagansett, NY where they lived together until 2007, when Cabot moved to Portland, ME. In addition to her five children and second husband, Cabot is survived by two stepchildren, Peter and Cathy Thaler and 12 grandchildren, Nicole, Stephanie, Zack, Violet, Sophie, Henry, Hanna, Logan, Arlyn, Eden, Mathew and David. She will be missed by her friends and family who cherished her unique sense of humor and great sense of adventure. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, 800-381-0075.

Three people were killed Monday evening when unidentified gunmen opened fire at the campaign office of a former federal minister and opposition leader in the garrison city of Rawalpindi, police and rescue officials said. At least five people were wounded. Witnesses said two men on a motorcycle opened fire on the former official, Sheik Rashid Ahmed, and his supporters as they left his election office in the Khayaban-e-Sir-Syed neighborhood. Mr. Ahmed, who was minister for information under President Pervez Musharraf, survived with minor injuries.

NUGENT--Rev. John G.,C.M., former Provincial of the Congregation of the Mission, The Vincentians, a priest for more than 60 years, died peacefully at the Mary Immaculate Seminary in Philadelphia on February 4. Born in Brooklyn in 1922, he graduated from Bishop Loughlin High School where he was inducted into the Hall of Fame as a swimmer. He entered the Seminary in 1940 and was ordained a Vincentian priest in 1949. Father Nugent received a JCD in Canon Law from Catholic University in Washington, DC in 1953. From 1960-66, he was Superior, President of Mary Immaculate Seminary in Northampton, PA. From 1981-84, he was President of Niagara University. Father Nugent received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree at St. John's University in 1981, and the University Gold Medal in 1988. He was also a member of the Board of Trustees at St. John's University (1965-68, 1972-1991). Father Nugent was a selfless and tireless worker who spent any spare time helping others, including being Counselor of Lovers of the Holy Cross Sisters all over the world. He was the eldest of the six children of John and Ann Nugent, those being, Anastasia (deceased), James of Southampton, NY, Eileen of Patchogue, NY, Colonel Robert (deceased), and Martha Ann (deceased). A Funeral Mass will be held February 9, 10:30am at Miraculous Medal Shrine, St. Catherine's Infirmary, Philadelphia, PA followed by a Burial at St. Joseph's Seminary, Princeton, NJ.

BREIER--Eileen G.,64, of Miami, born in Brooklyn, NY to Soloman (deceased) and Lena Gruebel, passed away on February 6, 2010 after a determined and courageous battle against cancer. "Neelie" is survived by her beloved grandchildren, Dylan, Cameron, Hayden (Breier) and Jake Henderson, her adoring husband of 44 years, Robert Breier, her mother, her cherished children Ben Breier and Lylle Breier Henderson, her deeply loved daughter-in-law and son-in-law, Shelly Breier and Cmdr Andrew Henderson, and her brother Jerald Gruebel. A "triple" Graduate of the University of Miami, she received degrees in Education (B.S.), Library Sciences (M.S.) and Law (J.D.). Eileen taught elementary school, was an innovative high school librarian, and lawyer, having clerked for the legendary Judge Wilke D. Ferguson. It is often said of our departed loved ones that they loved life; but Eileen truly adored it. She cherished every day, living with a contagious joy in her heart that touched everyone she met. Fiercely devoted to her family and hopelessly enthralled with her four grandchildren, she was the real glue that bound her growing family together from coast-to-coast and parts in between. A loving wife, a devoted mother, and an adoring grandma, Eileen who loved words and books and poetry -- went by the palindrome "Neelie" with her grandkids. She never let a family event go by without extensive photography to memorialize every cherished moment, and she even had an external computer drive dedicated to her beloved photos and scanned mementos literally thousands upon thousands. Each snapshot was a treasured moment in time with her family and friends, which she then transformed into volume upon volume of photo albums. Five-foot two (including heels and hair) Eileen was a giant! She had scores of friends at each of the two California and Florida homes between which she split time. From bridge games to book clubs, walking groups to wine drinkers, her many friends were as diverse as they were dear to her. She celebrated every joyous occasion, she consoled every loss and she never missed a holiday. Eileen loved people and people loved Eileen. Her laughter permeated the air, and her smile lit up the room. Our pain in losing her is so great that we hesitate at times, wondering how we are going to get by without her guidance, mentorship, advice, love and unbreakable spirit. But we also know how much she detested wallowing, and how spitting mad she'd be if we didn't press on. So we will care for her friends, support her dear causes, take those family photos, and smother our children with love. Because our Neelie wouldn't have it any other way. The world is a better place for her having passed through it. Eileen's memorial service will take place on Tuesday, February 9 at 10am, at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 1920 Alton Road, Miami Beach. (305)531-1151. The burial will follow the service at Mt. Nebo Kendall Cemetery, 5900 S.W. 77 Ave., Miami, FL. (305)274-0641. Memorials, if desired, may be made in Eileen's name to the Bach Ardalon University of Miami Cancer Research Fund in care of Marsha Kegley, University of Miami, Miller School of Medicine, P.O. Box 016960 (R-100), Miami, FL 33101.

Olympic organizers continued to use heavy-lift helicopters, dump trucks and a fleet of snow-grooming machines Monday to deal with the meltdown at the resort hosting the snowboarding and freestyle skiing events at the Vancouver Games. As the United States moguls team set off in the afternoon for the first practice runs of the Games, questions loomed over the state of the site. The persistent snow issues forced organizers to reduce athletes' practice time at Cypress Mountain and move some training sessions to Whistler, the site for downhill skiing at the Games, which has ample snow cover.

Scheduled for launching this week, the Solar Dynamics Observatory is the first mission in NASA's Living With a Star program. The craft will observe the Sun in detail, studying how its magnetic field is generated and measuring its extreme ultraviolet radiation. This information will help scientists predict solar activity, which can affect Earth's climate, knock out power grids and disrupt communications.

Starting tomorrow, Resurrection's "20 Years of Maison Martin Margiela: The Marcia Berger Collection" will be on view at One Jackson Square in downtown Manhattan. The more than 1,000 mint-condition accessories and garments will then go up for auction, in a collaboration between the vintage clothing resource and 1stdibs. There has been a fair amount said about Berger's collection, which includes some 40 one-of-a-kind artisanal pieces, like a top made from vintage opera gloves, a dress-form top and a sweater made from military socks; the collection spans the designer's career from 1989 up until the time he was rumored to be phoning his work in from Ibiza, Spain. But just who is the woman who assembled - and never wore! - this Margiela trove? A quick search yields little on Berger, who is occasionally described as a "fashion doyenne." This is a fair enough assumption for someone who in her lifetime (she died in 2008) amassed enough high-end and avant-garde clothing to fuel multiple sales. (Resurrection already sold off her stash of shoes - Alaia, Yohji, Louboutin, Manolo Blahnik, etc. - in 2008. She was a size 8/8.5 in case you were wondering.) Yet, to hear Resurrection's Mark Haddawy describe her, she was anything but doyenne-ish. Quite the opposite in fact. Like most L.A. women, Berger was typically dressed-down and favored a uniform of jeans, a Margiela AIDS T-shirt and flip-flops. She drove a Ford Taurus. Unlike the python-clad L.A. fashion cowboy Jim Goldstein, Berger was not a front-row fixture on the show circuit. Yet, no doubt when she walked into stores like Laura Urbinati or Maxfield or Mameg, her salespeople's eyes would light up. "It's an amazing collection put together in real time," says Haddawy, who with Katy Rodriguez was responsible for organizing and cataloging the contents of Berger's closets. To the untrained eye, he adds, many of the pieces looked like they should have been tossed in the trash. "They were ripped, burned, wrinkled or otherwise damaged." Intentionally of course.

When Paola Bjaringer returned to Paris after a career in London as a TV news correspondent, she had art on her mind. "The French were really longing for a welcoming, generous place," she says, referring to the many young artists and designers that have come home to Paris - from places like Stockholm, Berlin, New York and London - and were looking for galleries that were open to showing emerging talent. So she decided to create one herself. After two years of searching for the a location, plus another year of gut renovations done with the architect Joseph Caspari, she recently unveiled the gallery Slott in the 10th arrondissement.

The 22-year-old Vail International Dance Festival, a summer destination in the mountains of Colorado for dance lovers, has announced its program for this year. The festival, which runs from July 27  to Aug. 10  and is under the direction of Damian Woetzel, will  present three premieres  and 11 performances. In addition there will be an artist-in-residence and a company residency.  Some highlights: the Vail debut of BeijingDance/LDTX; the American premiere of Natalia Hills and Gabriel Missé's tango show, "Romper el Piso";  and a new work by Larry Keigwin, the festival's first artist-in-residence, who will also perform during the festival.  The Pacific Northwest Ballet will be in residency for a week, and the Paul Taylor Dance Company will perform in honor of the choreographer's 80th birthday. Herman Cornejo, Wendy Whelan, Daniil Simkin, Carla Körbes, Matthew Rushing and Tiler Peck are among the dancers scheduled to appear as part of the International Evenings of Dance, when artists from companies around the world perform. Tickets are available beginning Friday, Feb. 12 at 11 a.m. MST on  the festival's Web site: vaildance.org

If you've ever wanted to be locked in a hotel room with Werner Herzog for four days -and, other than Klaus Kinski, who hasn't? - now's your chance. Mr. Herzog has announced that the second installment of his Rogue Film School will take place in New Jersey on June 11-14, 2010, with a maximum class size of 65 students/disciples. The curriculum once again includes: "the art of lock-picking. Traveling on foot. The exhilaration of being shot at unsuccessfully. The athletic side of filmmaking. The creation of your own shooting permits. The neutralization of bureaucracy. Guerilla tactics."

Today we're publishing an interview with George Cloutier, who is founder of American Management Services and who specializes in advising small and midsize companies. He is the author of "Profits Aren't Everything, They're the Only Thing," and he favors a take-no-prisoners approach to running a business. Among other things, he suggests firing all family members, using fear to motivate employees, micromanaging and not whining about the recession. He also tells business owners to love their businesses more than they love their families -- a message, he acknowledges, that his current wife (his third) doesn't fully endorse. In March, Quentin Tarantino will again be dissecting his craft on one of more than 80 panels announced for the film conference portion of the South by Southwest festival. He'll be joined by the directors Eli Roth ("Hostel"), Ruben Fleischer ("Zombieland") and Ti West ("The House of the Devil") to speak about directing genre films. Michel Gondry, whose film version of "The Green Hornet" has been generating a good amount of buzz, will talk with Elvis Mitchell about Mr. Gondry's filmography. Panels on how to sell graphic novels to Hollywood and how to simultaneously master the television and film production worlds will also be highlights. The film conference runs March 12 to March 16.

If "South Park" teaches us nothing else, it shows how rigid broadcast standards are in countries outside the United States. Mexico has become the latest nation to pull a "South Park" episode from its airwaves, at least temporarily, The Associated Press reported. The episode, called "Pinewood Derby," in which a traditional racing competition accidentally leads to the discovery of extraterrestrial life, caricatures numerous world leaders, including the British prime minister Gordon Brown, the Chinese president Hu Jintao, and Felipe Calderón, the president of Mexico. MTV, which was scheduled to broadcast the episode in Mexico on Monday, said it pulled the show not because it makes fun of Mr. Calderón, but because it depicts the Mexican flag. Mexican law says that its the flag and other national symbols must be treated respectfully. A spokesman for Mexico's interior ministry told The A.P. that it hadn't received a request from MTV for permission to broadcast the episode.

When Kelly Cutrone moved to New York in the mid-'80s, she didn't have much more than a nursing degree and a dauntless attitude. Today she's a scandalously outspoken publicist who reduces young girls to tears on shows like "The City" and "The Hills." Her ruthless work ethic is the result of hard-learned lessons. In the mid-'90s, she divorced her first husband, gave up half of her PR firm, tossed her party wigs and fled to Topanga, Calif., where she conquered her drug addiction and became a spiritual warrior.After reading tarot cards in Santa Monica and working for the Psychic Network, she gradually made her way back to PR.

Sam Sifton is blowing the cover on Novitá. The “perfect neighborhood trattoria” on the corner of Gramercy Park would “sit atop of the heap in many other cities,” but, thanks to the surplus of great restaurants here, “goes unnoticed in New York,” -- that is, until now. The chef Marco Fregonese, who has been at the helm of Novitá since it opened in 1994, has been steadily improving it since then, and his new, simpler approach is worth noting. Go for the pastas, which are “just ridiculous: perfectly prepared, full of flavor, a rejoinder to low expectations.” Try “a plate of gramigna alla carbonara, for instance, thin strands of curled pasta with eggs, pecorino romano, guanciale and black pepper.” It “arrives on the table as a riot of simplicity, a four-member noise band. It is outstanding, firm and pliant, salty and sweet, slick and sticky and rich.” The “breaded baby eggplant baked with tomato, mozzarella and Parmesan is like something out of a Bensonhurst fever dream.” Bring an appetite: “You won’t go away hungry from Novitá; the plates are food, not art.”

“Why can’t there be a new jazz trio that does it all — one that’s flexible, intuitive and strategic, not lugubrious, arid or jammy-boring, and a repository of postwar piano-trio lessons, from Ahmad Jamal to free jazz and beyond? Well, there is, and it can, and it did.” Ben Ratliff’s enthusiastic words were inspired by Vijay Iyer’s trio and album “Historicity,” which topped Mr. Ratliff’s list of best jazz albums of 2009. Mr. Iyer hasn’t slowed down since then and his latest fusion project can be heard Wednesday at Harlem Stages. “Holding It Down” is a work in process by Mr. Iyer and the jazz poet Mike Ladd. It takes on the stress associated with race and war through music and draws from the poems and experiences of an African-American former Marine. It features the musicians and spoken-word artists Pamela Z, Guillermo E. Brown, Liberty Ellman and Okkyung Lee. A discussion of the evolving piece follows the show.

The Flamenco Festival in New York doesn’t officially begin until Thursday, but fans of the flamboyant Spanish art form can get an early taste tonight at the Guggenheim where Works & Process is presenting “Dressed to Dance.” The program, sponsored by the regional government of Madrid, features a performance/runway show with dancers dressed in historic costumes by Spanish artists including Pablo Picasso and Salvador Dalí. The choreography is by Carlos Chamorro and the dancers include Rocío Molina and Company, Manuel Liñan, and others, who will also appear at City Center. The program begins at 9 p.m. with a pre-performance lecture at 8:30 p.m. by Roger Salas, a dance critic for El País and a Spanish dance and costume historian. Also check out the exhibition “No Singing Allowed: Flamenco and Photography” on view through April 1 at Aperture Gallery and Bookstore, which features images of flamenco on stage and off, some of them dating to the 19th century, and where as Alastair Macaulay writes, “you see flamenco both as a source of pride and as a claim to fame.”

KURTZ--Dr. Anthony D. Troutman Sanders, LLP mourns the loss of our long time client and good friend. Dr. Kurtz was a brilliant scientist who founded, built and led Kulite Semiconductor Products, Inc. He was an outstanding leader, creative, compassionate and generous and he will be missed by his many friends and employees. Our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Nora, his children and to all of his family.

A team of nearly three dozen scientists assembled by the International Olympic Committee will conduct more than 2,000 doping tests on athletes competing at the Vancouver Games. But I.O.C. officials say athletes who cheat still might get away with it -- at least for a while. ''No system is foolproof,'' Arne Ljungqvist, the chairman of the committee's medical commission, said at a news conference on Tuesday, adding that it would be naïve to think that every athlete who doped would be caught.

NEWHOUSE--Mary. It is with the deepest sorrow that we must advise her innumerable friends that Mary Newhouse left us this past Sunday, February 7th, 2010. She was born Mary Alice Taylor on April 24th, 1935, in Fitchburg, MA. She received an MA degree in Fine Arts from Smith College in 1957. She subsequently married Dr. Robert P. Newhouse of New York City. After her husband's three year tour in the U.S. Army in Frankfurt, Germany, the family, now with two young daughters, returned to New York City, where a third daughter was born. In 1979, the family purchased property on Block Island, RI, and Mary became proprietress of the Sea Breeze Inn. Over the years she became an active leader of the community, founding several environmental organizations and ultimately becoming a leading member of the town's Planning Board. A lifelong supporter of the arts, she also was the Founder of the Island Gallery. Mary was an accomplished painter throughout her life. Her devotion to the arts included architecture, ceramics and dance. Following a gallant battle for six months, she succumbed finally to her illness. Her ashes will be scattered onto the ocean that she loved so much. She is survived by her loving husband of 52 years. Her siblings Arthur Taylor, Patricia Keany, and Jayne Taraski. Her loving daughters; Alisa, Sarah and her husband Steve Mikulka, Andrea and her husband Eric Moynier, and the grandchildren: Olivia Taylor Smith, Jules H. Smith, Samuel Mikulka, Lucas Moynier and Isabelle Moynier.

Most of the time, athletes who compete in low-profile Olympic sports pursue their passion with few perks. KAYSEN--Carl. It is with great sadness and a deep sense of loss that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the passing of its distinguished Fellow and co-chair of its Committee on International Security Studies (CISS), Carl Kaysen. A noted economist, Carl taught at Harvard University and, since 1976, at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he was the David W. Skinner Professor of Political Economy and directed the Program in Science, Technology, and Society. As Deputy Special Assistant for National Security Affairs under President John F. Kennedy, he oversaw foreign economic policy and advised on national security and disarmament issues. Among the most trusted members of Kennedy's inner circle, he helped to shape the U.S. responses to crises in Berlin and Congo. During the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis he was known as "the Vice President in charge of the rest of the world," and in 1963 he participated in U.S.-Soviet negotiations that resulted in the Limited Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. He brought his breadth of experience, as well as his characteristic wisdom and calm, to his work with CISS, through which he continued actively to address challenges to global peace and security. Most recently, he helped to shape the Academy's international projects on the Global Nuclear Future and on Cybersecurity. He authored or edited numerous Academy publications, including major Academy studies on topics ranging the war in Iraq to corporate governance. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Ruth and his daughters Susanna and Jesse. A memorial service at the Academy will be announced. Louis W. Cabot, Chairman pro tem Leslie Berlowitz, Chief Executive Officer John Reed, Treasurer Jerrold Meinwald, Secretary John Steinbruner, Cochair of CISS

City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, a fixture in Bronx Democratic politics for more than two decades, was charged on Tuesday with money laundering, extortion and fraud in a series of schemes that included helping a close associate win a contract to install boilers in the new Yankee Stadium and siphoning hundreds of thousands of dollars in city money to himself, friends and family members. Most of the charges in the 13-count federal indictment revolve around Mr. Seabrook's use of Council discretionary funds, known as earmarks, to finance a string of nonprofit groups that city and federal authorities say ultimately did little for the communities they were supposed to aid.

LANDER--Bernard. The Yeshiva University and Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary(RIETS) family is deeply saddened by the passing of Rabbi Dr. Bernard Lander, an alumnus of RIETS class of '38 and former dean of YU's Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies from 1954-1959 and he was also instrumental in strengthening YU's graduate schools into individual entities. His record of achievements encompassed many diverse areas such as the building of schools, Touro College, where he served as founder and president, Landers College and Yeshiva Ohr HaChaim, as well as the co-founding Jewish day school, Yeshiva Dov Revel. He impacted many lives by serving on commissions that promoted fair employment and attacked discriminatory quotas in higher education. He was a phenomenal human being and widely respected colleague and friend whose concern for the Jewish people and all of humanity knew no boundaries. We extend heartfelt condolences to his son, Rabbi Daniel Lander, RIETS 1980, his brother Rabbi Dr. Nathan Lander, RIETS 1946, and to his daughters, Mrs. Ester Greenfield, Mrs. Debbie Waxman and Mrs. Hana Lander and to his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor RIETS Board of Directors Julius Berman, Chairman

GREENBERG--David S. of Fort Lee NJ and Ft. Lauderdale FL. passed away on Saturday February 6, 2010. Beloved husband of Harriet. Loving father of Nathan (Skip), Dr. Tia Greenberg and Michelle Russillo, Russell and Cindi Natkin. Devoted brother of Dr. Jesse Greenberg and William Faraminan. David was a prominent real estate attorney and business man for over 30 years in Bergen County NJ. He completed his Juris Doctorate at Rutgers University where he was an active alumni member. He loved traveling the world, studying history and living the cultures of the places he visited. A memorial service to celebrate David's life will be held at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive Tenafly on Friday 4:00-7:00pm. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to The American Heart Association 1 Union St. Suite 301 Robbinsville, NJ 08696. For directions visit www.barrettfuneralhome.net

ALBANY -- The New York State Senate on Tuesday night expelled a senator convicted of assaulting his companion, the first time a member of the Legislature was forced from office in nearly a century. Hiram Monserrate, a Democrat from Queens, was convicted last fall of misdemeanor assault after a fight with his companion, Karla Giraldo, that left her with a deep gash on her face, though he was acquitted of more serious felony assault charges.

Lydia Csato Gasman, an art historian known for her groundbreaking scholarship on the work of Picasso, died on Jan. 15 in Charlottesville, Va. She was 84 and lived in Charlottesville. Her death was confirmed by Larry Goedde, chairman of the McIntire Department of Art at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, where she taught for two decades.

10 P.M. (Logo) THE ROBERT VERDI SHOW STARRING ROBERT VERDI An ice cream flavor named in his honor? A shopping mall? His own television channel? For some, the tandem bicycle is as close as it gets to love on a bike. The machines with two seats and one pair of wheels have often conjured thoughts of everlasting bliss and pedaling in union. For others, like Edward Pino and Liz Baums of Forest Hills, Queens, who own two tandems that they take on rides of up to 70 miles, the bike is somewhat less exalted; it's just a way to stay connected when both partners enjoy riding, but not necessarily at the same speed.

Proven winners on hardwood courts, aircraft carriers, arena roofs and bull rings, the Harlem Globetrotters on Tuesday added outdoor ice rinks to their list of places where they have beaten the Washington Generals. Playing in front of more than 500 children in Central Park's Lasker Rink, the teams brought out many of their familiar tricks but had a fresh audience to try them out on.

CAREY--Robert. It is with profound sorrow that the Forestdale staff and Board of Directors note the passing of longtime board member extraordinaire, Robert C. Carey. He served on our board for 48 years and was Chair for a quarter-century. A lawyer and judge, he dedicated his non-working life to his beloved family and the foster children and families of Forestdale. A milestone achievement of his was the visionary Fatherhood initiative that gives men a last chance to reconnect with their children. Mr. Carey's wife was descended from Benjamin W. Wilson who founded the Brooklyn Home for Children in 1854 (now know as Forestdale). His legacy of outstanding service to vulnerable children has been a gift to the City of New York. We extend our deepest sympathy to his three loving children.

The Roman Catholic Church faces yet another child abuse scandal, this time in Pope Benedict XVI's native Germany. The widening public scandal began last month with allegations that three priests at the elite Canisius Jesuit high school in Berlin had sexually abused students in the 1970s and '80s. In the midst of a steadily growing uproar over the handling of that case, the German magazine Der Spiegel published an article last weekend that said nearly 100 clerics and laypeople had been suspected of abusing children and teenagers nationwide since 1995.
SEIDMAN--Lloyd. Cherished friend and delightful conversationalist. He will be deeply missed. Cecile and Sydney Mitchell

There are few wide-open frontiers in this city, but the streets have long given New Yorkers a little extra room to maneuver around social stricture. So unless you are way out of line, no one is likely to challenge whatever it is you happen to be doing. Like smoking. Ostracized almost everywhere else, smokers can usually find a moment's peace on the sidewalk. For a brief spell, they can forget the nagging voices, the gnawing fears. On most sidewalks, maybe, but perhaps not on East 106th Street right before Halloween last year. Earlier pictures in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

ROBINOWITZ--Harold, 94 years old of Pembroke Pines, FL, formerly of Hartsdale, NY, left us to join his beloved wife Mitzi on February 8, 2010. Husband, father, brother, uncle, cousin and friend, Harold was the wise, loving and sturdy force in so many lives. Deeply cherished by his daughter Wendy and son-in- law Daniel, adored by his granddaughters Samantha and Kimberly, loved and respected by family and friends, Harold, with style, grace, strength and conviction touched and protected all those he held so dear. His guidance, wisdom, and love were precious gifts to each of us. We love you Papa and miss you now and forever. Services will be at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY on February 12, 2010 at 1pm.

An eye-popping increase in health insurance premiums in California has become a White House talking point. Anthem Blue Cross, which is California's largest for-profit health insurer, plans to raise its rates for customers who buy individual coverage by as much as 39 percent by March 1, according to a recent report in The Los Angeles Times.

Given their many question marks these days, the Mets might wish that Keith Hernandez could suit up again in orange and blue. Alas, Hernandez now spends his days in the television booth, writing books and shuttling between his homes in Florida and Sag Harbor, N.Y. But that does not mean his 11 Gold Glove awards are going to waste. This week, he began tutoring Daniel Murphy, the team's presumptive starting first basemen this season. Murphy took over at first base last year after Carlos Delgado had season-ending hip surgery. Murphy was a work in progress in 2009, unafraid to field his position, but overly aggressive at times.

COOK--Norman William, Jr. (Topper), 89, died on February 5. A graduate of Princeton University (1942), he was a television news director for NBC. A longtime resident of Old Greenwich, CT, he retired to Pennswood Village in Newtown, PA in 1999. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, the former Nancy Burge, his son Norman of Osaka, Japan; his daughter Ferris of High Falls, NY; two grandsons (Alex Cook and Isaac Krabbenhoft), one granddaughter (Vanessa Longacre-Wilcox), and one great grandson (Daelen Wilcox). His daughter Sarah Longacre died in 2006. Services will be private.

SANDS--Alan, died February 4, 2010 at age 96, a lifetime New Yorker. Beloved husband of Ceil Sands and devoted father of Brian and Monica. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

To many Americans who watched the Democrats' family feud over the last few months, it might have seemed as if Republicans were more unified on health care. One luxury of being the minority party in Congress is the ability to avoid having internal disagreements in the spotlight. In reality, Republicans generally do not speak with a single voice on health care policy, any more than Democrats do. Consider the tax treatment of employer-sponsored health benefits.

The Mets have seemingly made more changes to Citi Field this off-season than to their roster. All were cosmetic -- think more blue and orange in and around the ballpark -- but none were about to affect the course of a game. At least until Tuesday, when it was revealed that the Mets will chop in half the 16-foot wall that shields a sliver of straightaway center field -- otherwise known as the area that houses the Home Run Apple. When the Mets begin the 2010 season April 5 against Florida, that fence, 408 feet from home plate, will stand 8 feet high. The modification was first reported by The Daily News. None of the dimensions will change, and, just as significant, neither will the heights of any other outfield wall. It's still 15 feet 8 1/2 inches in left field, 18-6 1/2 below the right-field overhang and 11 feet on either side of this new notch. So, why did the Mets decide to change such a modest section?

LANDER--Bernard. The Orthodox Union mourns the loss of Dr. Bernard Lander, a pioneering visionary of the American Jewish community. An Honorary Vice President of the OU, he served for over 70 years as an officer or member of the Board of Directors. He was instrumental in the creation of NCSY, our international youth organization, in 1954, and was an outspoken advocate of the NCSY agenda. The founder and guiding genius of Touro College, he was, above all, a passionate Jew, dedicated to the survival of our people through education. We extend our condolences to his son, Rav Daniel Lander; his daughters Ester Greenfield, Debbie Waxman and Hana Lander; and his entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Steven Weil, Exec VP Rabbi Dr. Tzvi Hersh Weinreb, Exec VP Emeritus Stephen J. Savitsky, President Harvey Blitz, Chairman of the Board

CAFFREY--Kenneth, Jr.,born on June 21, 1961, died unexpectedly on Saturday, February 6, 2010. Ken was a teacher and ski instructor. He attended Immaculate Heart of Mary School, Scarsdale High School and St. Michael's College, VT. He is survived by his daughter Lindsay O'Neill Caffrey, his parents Joan and Kenneth, his brother Dr. Thomas Caffrey and wife Andrea and their daughter Nicolette, his sister Anne Marie and husband Matt DiMatteo and their daughter Lila. He will be missed by his loving family. His short life touched many in a positive way. Visiting will be held at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY on Tuesday and Wednesday at 2-4pm and 7-9pm. For information, 914-725-1137

KURTZ--Dr. Anthony D.,died February 9, 2010. Dr. Kurtz, 80, was the son of the late Jacob and Claire Kurtz. He founded Kulite Semiconductor Products, Inc. in 1959. Under his leadership the company, based in Leonia, New Jersey, has become a world leader in the transducer field. Dr. Kurtz received his undergraduate and doctoral degrees in physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He held more than 200 patents, including some of the earliest for tiny pressure sensors micro machined from silicon. He was inducted into the Inventor's Hall of Fame and was a member of the National Academy of Engineers. Under his leadership Kulite developed relationships sponsoring research with a number of universities including MIT, Technion in Israel, Oxford University in England, NJIT in Newark and Columbia University where he was an adjunct Professor. A firm believer in the importance of education for everyone, he encouraged employees to further their education by enrolling in college and graduate school for which the company paid. He also instituted a scholarship program for employees' children. Dr. Kurtz leaves his beloved wife, Nora, his daughters Sandy and Jennifer, son John, brothers Ronald and Stephen, seven grandchildren and many devoted friends. Funeral services will be held on February 11, 2010 at 12:00 noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Columbia University c/o The Anthony D. Kurtz Fund for Startup Projects in the General Area of Solid State Materials and/or Solid State Electronic Devices or Massachusetts Institute of Technology c/o The Anthony D. Kurtz (1951) Fund for American Competitiveness in Materials Science and Engineering.

VANCOUVER- "Who'll light the Olympic cauldron?" That question is swirling around Canada today, and the most frequent answer is Wayne Gretzky, although the Great One himself is not answering.Gretzky would be the default choice, a figure admired by all Canadians and in many countries around the world, most notably Russia and the United States. But it somehow doesn't seem surprising enough. Could it be Gretzky and Gordie Howe, who met him when Gretzky was a small boy and was a present, guardian angel-like, at all the key points in his career? Or could it be Gretzky and a woman, perhaps Canada's greatest female player, Hayley Wickenheiser, even if she will be playing these Games as well?Clues are offered by some of the torchbearers on Thursday and Friday. The beloved Vancouver Canucks of yesteryear, Richard Brodeur and Stan Smyl are among them, as well as iconic players for the British Columbia Lions and Vancouver Whitecaps. So is Rolly Fox, father of Terry Fox, who enthralled the nation by almost making it all the way across Canada in a cancer benefit run before succumbing to the disease. Walter Gretzky, the country's iconic hockey dad, will carry the flame - an especially poignant torchbearer, in that a 1991 brain aneurysm left him without 20 years of memory, including that of his son's incredible early hockey successes, until intensive therapy enabled him to recover.

In fact Mr. Lewis, a contributing writer for Vanity Fair and The New York Times Magazine, should be riding twice as high right now: not only is "Moneyball" apparently back on track - with Brad Pitt still set to star and Bennett Miller ("Capote") to direct - but, according to New York magazine, Mr. Pitt has optioned Mr. Lewis's next book, "The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine," about the housing bubble. Her last show employed some 50 dancers and musicians, featured Cirque du Soleil-style theatrics with one of the largest indoor LED screens, celestial imagery and trapezes, and spawned its own perfume. On Wednesday Ms. Dion, the Canadian singer and five-time Grammy winner, announced that she would return to the strip, and the Colosseum at Caesars Palace that was originally built for her, in March 2011 for a three-year engagement, Reuters reported. Her previous show, "A New Day," drew nearly 3 million people. This time Ms. Dion, who finished a worldwide tour in 2009, will stage a new show inspired by classic Hollywood films, and it will feature a full orchestra. Tickets for the first 54 shows, which are to begin on March 15, 2011, go on sale Friday through ticketmaster.com.

When I was pregnant with my first child, I went off to the mall one day to buy baby things. All went smoothly at the first stop, but at the second I left the package I was carrying from store one. I remembered to take my purchase from store two, but then forgot that purchase at store three. This went on about half a dozen times with me retracing my steps across The Galleria for much of the afternoon.

Fans of seasonal, local foods have little to celebrate in the depths of winter, especially those of us in the Northeast. Among the notable exceptions is the bay scallop, harvested between the south shore of Cape Cod and the north shore of Long Island. Though they are less sweet, the common sea scallop - which is also less expensive - can step in as a substitute, especially if this much larger scallop is halved or quartered. In this recipe, where the scallops are treated almost as simply as possible, they'll do fine.

For years I have felt that people whose cellphones ring during live theater performances should be regarded and treated as criminals. Not as capital offenders, of course, though there have been moments -- like the time an "Eine Kleine Nachtmusik" ring tone broke a stark silence near the end of "A View From the Bridge" -- when hanging seemed like an appropriate punishment.

The spirit of generosity encouraged by the hit movie "The Blind Side" is continuing to pay dividends to the real-life couple depicted in it, who will write a new book about the power of giving. On Thursday the publisher Henry Holt and Company said it had acquired a book by Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy, the Tennessee couple who adopted the future Baltimore Ravens player Michael Oher, and whose story is told in the Michael Lewis book "The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game" as well as its recent film adaption. In a news release Holt said that in the as-yet untitled book, the Tuohys would tell their story "from their perspective for the first time" and that they "hope to inspire and challenge individuals to turn around and see the needs in their own community." The book, which was acquired by Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher of Holt, is planned for a summer release; terms of the deal were not disclosed.

After 88 years of traveling down that road and back again, are things finally starting to look up for Betty White? Ms. White, known to some as the longtime "Mary Tyler Moore" and "Golden Girls" actor, to others as a perennial game-show and talk-show panelist, and to still others as the breakout star of the Sandra Bullock-Ryan Reynolds comedy "The Proposal," now finds herself the beneficiary of an online campaign to have her host "Saturday Night Live." A Facebook page called "Betty White to Host SNL (please?)!" has compelled more than 182,000 members of that online social network to sign on as fans, and the movement has gained momentum from Ms. White's recent appearances at the Screen Actors Guild Awards (where she received a lifetime achievement honor) and in a popular Super Bowl commercial (with fellow octogenarian Abe Vigoda).

The apparent end of manned spaceflight, under the Obama administration's budgetary scalpel, has produced reactions from some interesting quarters. (Who knew, for instance, that James Cameron wants us to go into space? Doesn't he know that we'll either end up despoiling the flora of an alien world, or being devoured by its megafauna?) On the merits of the decision, I suppose I'm in reluctant agreement with John Derbyshire's "Room For Debate" contribution, in which he argues that "in a time of cratering public finances, the stupendous costs of manned spaceflight - half a billion dollars per shuttle launch - cannot be justified." To look at the sparse audience for the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening, you would think that a full-fledged blizzard had dropped a couple of feet of snow on the city. Outside Lincoln Center it was a bit slushy but navigable; the subways were running and cabs were plentiful. (Admittedly, for Philharmonic subscribers outside Manhattan, getting into the city was a messier, more complicated matter.) But the orchestra's press spokesman said the phones had been ringing all day with questions about whether the concert (reviewed here) would be canceled, and at 7:30 - curtain time - most rows in the hall seemed to have more empty seats than full ones.

Silicon Valley's Economy at Risk | A new study says that Silicon Valley lost 90,000 jobs in 2009, compared with the same period in 2008. The drop in the number of midlevel jobs, like engineers, has been the sharpest, as employers hire contractors instead of regular employees or hire people abroad, according to the annual report produced by the Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network and the Silicon Valley Community Foundation. But the report says the region's troubles go beyond the current job picture and the area could lose its competitive edge. "Let me give you a few snapshots in despair," wrote Chris O'Brien, in a column in The San Jose Mercury News. "The venture capital industry is collapsing. Our educational system is failing. State government is dysfunctional. Other regions are cleaning up on federal funding for green-tech jobs. And immigrants who have kept our innovation economy humming are feeling less and less welcome." [The New York Times, The San Jose Mercury News].

Billing itself as the "world's first art mall," K11 opened in mid-December, with 340,000 square feet of retail space and 13 permanent installations by prominent Hong Kong artists. Though the "world's first" tag is a bit of a stretch - many modern malls feature bits of artistic flare - K11 highlights local artists in a city that tends to be all business. The new shopping center (18 Hanoi Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon; www.k11concepts.com) is the brainchild of Adrian Cheng, the retail specialist who also happens to be the grandson of Cheng Yu-tung, the head of New World Development, which developed the mall.

...just went up, with a bit more of a look at what can be done. There's no magic bullet, but the four steps I outline seem to reflect a common view about what would help. And there's a risk in writing about eastern Congo that readers think that the whole country is a catastrophe. In fact, most of the country has stabilized and is much better off. On my first visit to Congo in 1997, I drove from Kisangani all the way to the east (it took a week), and for years that was then impossible for security reasons. Now it can be done again, and the road has improved enough that the route takes just two days.

Thursday night, you can revel in that unique form of humiliation at the 92YTribeca where Comedy Below Canal is presenting a heartbreak edition of "Mortified." The show is a comedic "excavation of teen angst artifacts" including journals, letters, poems, lyrics, home movies and more as shared by their original authors before total strangers. This show is hosted by Anne Altman and features Adam Wade, Jenn Wehrung, Jasmin Singer, Brooke Van Poppelen, Todd Rosenberg, Julia Wright, Boni Joi and Julianna Forlano.

"What is love?" Besides a catchy 1993 dance track by the singer Haddaway, it is a perennial question around Valentine's Day. Thursday night, head to the Algonquin Hotel, where Harper Perennial books is hosting "Love: The Debate." Moderated by Ben Greenman of "The New Yorker," the event will feature commentary and conversation on all things Eros from Ariel Leve, the author of "It Could Be Worse, You Could Be Me," Rachel Shukert, the author of "Everything Is Going to Be Great," and Simon Van Booy, the author of "The Secret Lives of People in Love." There will be wine and appetizers, so bring your sweetheart. It begins at 7 p.m.

It may be impossible to get a seat at their shows, but you can still admire the work of the designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy starting today at Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. The exhibition "Quicktake: Rodarte" features clothes by the sisters from Pasadena, which can be bought at department stores and appreciated "as 21st-century wearable art," writes Carol Vogel. Their designs can also be found in the permanent collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute and the Fashion Institute of Technology. The show, the second in a series of installations featuring emerging names, will include many of Rodarte's most inventive designs. "Like sculptures on mannequins, the pieces in the exhibition will highlight the unusual level of detail and workmanship that goes into every garment. It will also illustrate the sisters' imaginative use of traditional materials." It's a great opportunity to get a close-up look at their clothes this fashion week, minus the flashing lights and pushy fashion editors. Also on Feb. 20, the Vogue editor Sally Singer will interview Laura Mulleavy at the museum; the exhibit is on view through March 14.

A powerful snowstorm, the second to sweep across the Northeast in less than a week, arrived in the New York area on Wednesday morning, closing city schools and the United Nations, and threatening to play havoc with commuter schedules. New York City had gone through a slow windup after days of forecasters' warnings -- and after largely missing out on the storm last weekend that had stopped much of the rest of the East Coast in very deep tracks: by the time most New Yorkers turned out the lights and went to bed on Tuesday, only light snow was falling -- a tease for what the meteorologists said was coming. But by 7 a.m., the thick, wet flakes were sticking, even in places where snow almost never accumulates, like Times Square.

More than 30 athletes who were expected to compete in the Vancouver Games were barred from competition after failing pre-Games testing, David Howman, the director general of the World Anti-Doping Agency, said Wednesday. Howman said that the antidoping agency did not have the names of the athletes or the sports they compete in. National antidoping agencies or international federations of Winter Games sports conducted the tests, Howman said, so only those organizations know the details.

Anyone who has had to abandon a car during snowmageddon has learned the value of being weather-aware. There are a dozen or so very good weather apps, most specialized for one phone or another. But in the interest of getting critical weather information to as many people as possible, I suggest using Weather Underground's mobile Web page. While it's not technically an app, you can make it act like one by using some shortcut features on your phone. And of all of the weather apps I surveyed, this is the best conversion of a Web page to a phone screen, whether on an Android, a BlackBerry, a Palm, an iPhone, or a phone running Symbian or Windows Mobile.

TAMMANY--Joan (nee Shannahan). Lifelong New Yorker, died February 8, 2010. Faithful parishioner at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Taught 36 years in New York City public elementary schools. Graduate of Notre Dame College and St. John's University. Beloved wife of the late James Francis Tammany. Loving daughter of the late Mary E. and Michael J. Shannahan. Dear sister of Jean, Marion, Patricia and the late Eileen and Rosemary. Proud aunt of many loving nieces and nephews. Visiting Friday, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 9:30am at Our Lady of Angels Church. Burial to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: Sisters of St. Joseph, Building 3, 1725 Brentwood Rd., Brentwood, NY 11717.

Samsung created a whole bunch of fuss at January's consumer electronics extravaganza with its prototype laptop that displayed stunning OLED images on a clear ''see-though'' screen. It all seemed a bit sci-fi-ish, but reports are that the Korean brand will bring Amoled (active-matrix organic light-emitting diode) devices to market in the next year. According to the site PlusPlastic Electronics, as a teaser to the laptop, in the next few months Samsung will offer a portable audio/video player, the IceTouch, that incorporates the technology, much as Sony has dipped a toe into the OLED pool with its $2,500, 11-inch desktop TV and its Walkman X series. OLED screens have also found their way into mobile phones, an advantage in that arena because they consume less battery power.
Jesse Lumsden Bobsled

WELTZ--Joan, beloved music teacher at P.S. 79 in Whitestone, NY for over 40 years, died February 6. Mrs. Weltz, 70, inspired thousands of children, parents and teachers as well as the community. Funeral will be held February 11 at 1:15pm at the Riverside Chapel in Great Neck, NY. A special memorial service is being held at P.S. 79 on February 12 at 3:15pm. She is survived by her daughter, Lisa Waldman, and two grandchildren, Robert and Nicole. The "Joan Weltz Music Fund" has been established to help students from P.S. 79 pursue their passion for school and music. Please direct donations to the "Joan Weltz Music Fund" at 10 Century Trail, Harrison, NY 10528.

Now here's a really useful app from the Apple app store: a program that turns an iPhone or iPod Touch into a wireless computer trackpad and touch-screen keyboard. The free app, available here via iTunes, is called Touch Mouse, and it was developed by Logitech. It supports the multitouch functions common to most devices of the type: right and left clicks, single and two-finger scrolling, and a keyboard that sets up in portrait or landscape modes and allows access to control, alt and command keys.

Two top North American skeleton contenders voiced concerns Wednesday over the sledding equipment used by Germany, a powerhouse in the sport. Jeff Pain of Canada, the silver medalist at the 2006 Olympic Games in Turin, Italy, accused the Germans of equipping their sleds with magnetic components and questioned their legality. The suspicions were echoed by an American skeleton racer, Zach Lund.

Nikon has unwrapped seven new Coolpix point-and-shoot cameras that include a performance model with a 26X optical zoom and a slim compact camera that packs a 10X optical zoom. The $399 Coolpix P100 has a versatile lens that covers 26mm to 678mm (equivalent). It's also the first Nikon point-and-shoot to use a CMOS image sensor. The company says the 10.3-megapixel back-illuminated CMOS sensor enables the P100 to capture full 1080p high-definition video with stereo sound.

Kim Yu-na of South Korea, the reigning world champion, and her coach, Brian Orser, explain how she executes a triple lutz-triple toe loop, one of the most difficult jump sequences that will be attempted by the female figure skaters in Vancouver.

SIEGAL--Richard D.,passed away peacefully and surrounded by his loving family on Tuesday following a courageous battle with Leukemia. Richard ("Big T" "Rick City" "Grandpa" "Bop Bop") is survived by his adoring wife of 47 years, Gail; his children, Michael, Bippy, Arlo, Jody, Dean, Jackie and Rev; his grandchildren, Samantha, Nicki, Gabriela, Daniela, Zackary, Ava and Anya; his sister, Alice, and countless other friends, colleagues and beneficiaries of his endless philanthropic generosity whose lives have forever been so beautifully impacted by this incredible man. He was larger than life and left a magnificent imprint on the lives of all he touched. To many, Richard was an entrepreneur who built one of the most prolific oil and gas exploration companies in the United States. To others, he was a thoughtful, caring and generous employer. And to others still, he was an institutional benefactor who gave endlessly and applied his entrepreneurial determination to facilitate the research and development of cures and treatments for various diseases. But to those who knew and loved him best, Richard was all about the family. Simply put - nothing mattered more. His marriage to his soul-mate Gail will remain the heart and soul of his entire existence and the relationships he shared with his children and his grandchildren were unique and will forever serve as the standard by which inter-family relationships will be measured for generations to come that is Richard's true legacy. Born in Brooklyn on December 26, 1938 to Dr. and Mrs. Manheim Siegal, Richard attended Midwood High School and later received both undergraduate and law degrees from The University of Virginia, where he served as a long-time member of the Campaign Executive Committee. Richard was an appointee to the Citizens Financial Accountability Oversight Committee of California's new stem cell agency and also served on the Board of Trustees of New York-Presbyterian Hospital. Richard's philanthropic activities span a broad spectrum of organizations, including New York-Presbyterian Hospital, The Gail S. and Richard D. Siegal Professorship in Ophthalmology at the University of Virginia, the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary in Boston, The Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, The Women's International Zionist Organization, Hadassah and various educational scholarships. Services will be held on Friday at 10:00am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels located at 1450 Broadway in Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Richard's memory to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and specifically earmarked for research to be conducted by Dr. Steven Nimer.

RUBIN--Jane, of Jericho, New York and Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved wife of Peter, passed away from lung cancer on February 9, 2010. Born May 18, 1935 in Brooklyn, New York. She was a beloved mother of David and Marci and son-in-law, Hector. Grandmother to Anaeve and mother-in-law to Tricia and sister to Myrna. Jane was a graduate of NYU. Jane loved the theatre and supported the arts. She most surely will be missed by her loving family and her many friends whom she considered family. The world is losing a fine heart-warming, fun-loving, giving individual. The funeral will take place at Gutterman's Funeral Chapel in Woodbury, New York Friday, February 12, 2010 at 12pm.
SIEGAL--Richard. His great light brought magic to every corner of the world. The Mitchell Family

REUBEN--Samuel, passed away February 8, 2010 from pancreatic cancer. Devoted husband of Janet Bartucci Samuel, cherished father of Alexandra and David Samuel; beloved friend to many. Born 1942 in Sarid, Israel, he brought an infectious joie-de-vivre to life that made an indelible mark on all who knew him. Distinguished NYC real estate attorney; partner at Levine Samuel, LLP. Vice President, General Counsel (residential), Sumitomo Real Estate Sales (NY). Admitted 1976 to NY and US District Court, Southern and Eastern Districts; US Supreme Court in 1980. Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department: Member Disciplinary Committee; NY County Lawyers Assoc; Chair Family Court Advisory Committee 1981-1988; Committee on Child Abuse and Neglect, 1984-1985; Member Committee on Dyslexia and Learning Disabilities 1982-1989; Member and Treasurer: NY State Task Force on Foster Care, 1990-1995; Real Property Law Section; Co-op and Condo. He served as a First Lieutenant, US Army, Inf. 1961-1963; NY National Guard, 1965-1970. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Lustgarten Foundation or Project City Kids. Service, Friday 11:15am at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will receive visitors at home in Scarsdale.
FORREST--Bradley. With ever-lasting love yesterday, today, forever and thereafter. Oh how much you are missed. Thank you for the gift of you. With undying love, Mom and Dad

Loving father of Nathan (Skip), Dr. Tia Greenberg and Michelle Russillo, Russell and Cindi Natkin. Devoted brother of Dr. Jesse Greenberg and William Faraminan. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to The American Heart Association 1 Union St. Suite 301 Robbinsville, NJ 08696. For directions visit www.barrettfuneralhome.net

CIRKER--IRA, Esteemed Director-Producer of theatre and television passes at 86. Although Ira Cirker's directorial opus spanned from Shakespeare to soap operas to Stein, a constant in his eclectic career was his love of actors and the process of acting. Emmy Award-winning actress Linda Dano wrote: "An exceptionally talented director, Ira Cirker understood the delicate balance between quality work, delicate guidance and friendship." His introduction to the world of theatre was as the youngest cast member of Moss Hart's "Winged Victory", a hit Broadway stage production during WWII. He also appeared in the Darryl Zanuck produced and George Cukor directed film. He began his directorial career as co-director with Oscar Homolka of Ibsen's The Master Builder and was assistant director to Burgess Meredith for the Actors Studio production on Broadway of James Baldwin's Blues for Mr. Charlie. He also assisted Jean Renoir for the film Elena et Les Hommes with Ingrid Bergman. A pioneer in the early days of live television, Ira Cirker directed shows such as Robert Montgomery Presents, Search for Tomorrow, Nash Airflyte Theatre, and Valiant Lady, and recounted the days when dream sequences were signaled by filming colored water stirred in a pail. For 17 years, Ira Cirker was the director of NBC's Another World and he became the first person in daytime television to direct the hour and 90 minute formats. In his tenure at Another World he was nominated for six Emmy awards and directed actors such as Linda Dano, Brad Davis, Morgan Freeman, Constance Ford, Ray Liotta, Anne Meacham, Douglas Watson, and Victoria Wyndham. He instituted a training program for directors in television and Melvin Bernhardt, Jack Hofsiss, Barnet Kellman, Jeff Bleckner, and Casey Childs all were under his tutelage. In Los Angeles in the 1960's he directed the controversial one acts by LeRoi Jones, Dutchman and The Toilet, and was the executive director of Theatre in the Parks where he directed an interracial version of Anthony and Cleopatra starring Diana Sands and Robert Lansing. In the aftermath of the Watts riots in Los Angeles, he and William DuBois established the Watts Training Center, educating young people for careers in television, theatre and film. In 1961, Ira Cirker directed the telecast of John Kennedy's Inaugural Gala in Washington, DC that featured Frank Sinatra as master of ceremonies, and in 1962 assisted in the production of the Kennedy birthday party that featured Marilyn Monroe singing Happy Birthday. Off-Broadway, he directed Take A Giant Step by Lou Petersen with Louis Gossett, Jr., A Mighty Man is He with Claudette Colbert, Clerembard with Tammy Grimes and Claude Dauphin, A Whisper in God's Ear with Alan Alda, Naomi Court by Michael Sawyer with Brad Davis, My Prince My King by Victor Wolfson in association with Lee Strasberg at The Actor's Studio, and Gertrude Stein and a Companionby Win Wells with Jan Miner and Marian Seldes, produced by Lucille Lortel. In 1986, Ira Cirker's company, Mitchon Productions, in association with Leonard Herbst and Tapestry Productions, produced Gertrude Stein and a Companion with Jan Miner and Marian Seldes for the Bravo network garnering an Emmy for Outstanding Entertainment Programming, a Silver Hugo Award and an American Video Award for Drama. In 1993, Ira Cirker was inducted into the National Academy for Television Arts and Sciences' Silver Circle. Mr. Cirker was a founding member of the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society and a member of the Directors Guild of America. He is survived by his business partner and companion Leonard Herbst, former wife Lenore DeKoven and their two sons, Mitchell and Jason, his grandchildren Marlon and Mia, and their mother, Christine. A memorial has been planned for April 15th.

SIEGAL--Richard D. Dear Gail, This is a day I will never forget. It is a day when you lost the most loving and adoring husband anyone ever had. Of course Michael, Bippy, and Arlo have suffered a similar loss much too early. I, for one, am so saddened, because I too have lost someone who I loved, respected and enjoyed being his friend. For years we have had a close relationship, and even when we didn't see each other for a while, we maintained strong feelings for each other. I knew that I could always rely on Richard and I think he knew that I would always be there for him. I thought of him as indestructible. His strong personality was coupled with great intellect and an unusually good sense of humor. He was a caring, feeling and humane person, which is a rare combination. There are so many good qualities that I think about. I guess his devotion to his family and friends stands out most. I only hope that you and the children can use these wonderful memories to sustain you. This is a loss that leaves a great void in so many lives. All of our love and grief at this time, Cookie and Buzzy Hoffner

Striking civil servants brought public services to a halt across Greece on Wednesday, in a largely peaceful one-day protest against the tough austerity measures officials have said are necessary to stave off a mounting financial crisis. Greece has been under intense pressure from other members of the European Union to cut its huge budget deficit and is in danger of failing to refinance some $28 billion in debt coming due in April and May. Fears of default in Greece and other struggling European countries have roiled financial markets around the world in recent weeks.

Gov. John Lynch asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Wednesday to investigate the Entergy Corporation's Vermont Yankee nuclear plant. Mr. Lynch said he wanted an inquiry into elevated levels of tritium in groundwater monitoring wells at the site in Vernon, Vt., which is across the Connecticut River from New Hampshire. Vermont Yankee reported finding the tritium, a radioactive form of hydrogen, to the Vermont Department of Health on Jan. 7.

ROBINOWITZ--Harold, 94 years old of Pembroke Pines, FL, formerly of Hartsdale, NY, left us to join his beloved wife Mitzi on February 8, 2010. Deeply cherished by his daughter Wendy and son-in- law Daniel, adored by his granddaughters Samantha and Kimberly, loved and respected by family and friends, Harold, with style, grace, strength and conviction touched and protected all those he held so dear. His guidance, wisdom, and love were precious gifts to each of us. We love you Papa and miss you now and forever. Services will be at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY on February 12, 2010 at 1pm.

Wednesday was the first day he woke up in America. The first time he looked down at the Bronx street before dawn. And as a winter storm began to swirl outside, the first time that Aung, a 37-year-old Burmese refugee, saw real snow. ''I saw the snow raining snow,'' Aung said a few hours later, eyes wide under the knit cap that had just been provided by the International Rescue Committee, a refugee resettlement organization in New York. ''I saw, like, ice-ice. On the ground, also, everything white.''

LANDER--Bernard. The Federation of Jewish Communities of Russia and Chief Rabiie of Russia Berel Lazar note with profound sorrow the passing of Rabbi Dr. Bernard Lander. Dr. Lander, founder and president of Touro College, was a pioneer of Jewish education in Russia. He opened Touro College in the FSU and more recently signed an agreement between Machon Chamesh, the Jewish University in Moscow, and Touro College enabling students to receive opportunities heretofore unavailable in the FSU.

THIS YEAR'S Olympic tournament could turn out to be the greatest in the history of ice hockey, given the quality of the teams in Vancouver. Below, a look at the men's competition. CANADA The favorite, but will the pressure to win in a land where hockey is the secular religion prove too much for Coach Mike Babcock's team? Sidney Crosby leads a superb group of forwards who combine flash (Rick Nash and the San Jose teammates Dany Heatley, Joe Thornton and Patrick Marleau) with two-way grit (Jarome Iginla, Jonathan Toews and Corey Perry). Despite the snarly presence of Chris Pronger, the defense is not so much big and tough as skilled, with Scott Niedermayer, Duncan Keith, Dan Boyle and Drew Doughty anchoring the tournament's most solid blue-line corps. LANDER--Bernard, Ph.D. With profound sorrow Touro College, its affiliates, Board of Trustees, faculty, and administration mourns the passing of its founder and president Dr. Bernard Lander. To paraphrase the words of the prophet Elisha, Dr. Lander was the consummate father both to his family and to his people. Imbued with a love of Torah he was single-minded in his commitment to spread its learning and values to the entire Jewish people. Those values also compelled him to be a champion for the civil rights and education of all peoples. Born on the lower east side of Manhattan 94 years ago to David and Goldie Lander he rose to become a pulpit rabbi, a professor of sociology at Hunter College, Dean of Yeshiva University's Bernard Revel Graduate School, advisor to Presidents of the United States, and in 1971 - the founder and President of Touro College. As our President for almost forty years, the college grew from a handful of students to an institution of higher education serving over 17,000 students throughout the world. His vision, which at all times informed the mission of the College, was to enhance Judaism and strengthen the Jewish people as well as to serve humanity. He not only recognized but made a reality the holy obligation to serve society's needs as a whole while promoting the welfare of his people. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his brother Nathan, his son Rabbi Daniel Lander, Rosh Yeshiva of Yeshiva Ohr Ha Chaim, Ester Greenfield, Debbie Waxman and Hana Lander, and to his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Touro College Dr. Alan Kadish, Senior Provost Mark Hasten, Chairman of the Board

In my first year teaching, I discovered that a student had copied part of an essay from something he found online. I went over the passages with the student and discussed with him why it had violated school policy on academic integrity, and what he could do to make up the assignment.
