Even people who don't like poetry tend to make an exception on Valentine's Day. But what about people who do like poetry, and don't like valentines? If your plans for this Sunday include being depressed and embittered and alone, may I recommend the anthology "It's Not You, It's Me: The Poetry of Breakup"? The editor, Jerry Williams, has had some experience with romantic disappointment, as he details in his slightly painful introduction: "Bitter humor aside," he says after one girlfriend leaves him for a chemistry major, "this new development opened the door to that dim, airless room of anguish just down the hall." Yikes.

Round 2. After receiving a lot of criticism for his 4,300-word take-down of Andrew Sullivan for his comments on Israel and Jews, Leon Wieseltier, literary editor of The New Republic, has written another piece, titled "A reply to Andrew Sullivan's reply." Mr. Sullivan's M.O. is to make offensive remarks and then apologize for his remarks being taken the wrong way, Mr. Wieselter writes. "If I should be more careful about the question of anti-Semitism, so should Sullivan. He complacently says that on this score 'I did my best.' No, he did not. There is a lot of this prejudice in the world right now, and this is really no time to be sloppy."

Has the Allman Brothers Band put some sort of Southern-fried hex on the Canadian clowns of Cirque du Soleil? On Friday Cirque du Soleil said that it would again delay the start of its coming show "Banana Shpeel" at the Beacon Theater -- the same show that pushed the Allmans band out of its longtime March residency at the Beacon. In a news release, press representatives for "Banana Shpeel" said it would now begin preview performances on March 17; back in December, the show had moved its first performances to Feb. 25, from an original date of Feb. 4. In the release, the press representative said the latest delay had occurred because "the rehearsal period at the theater has been extended to integrate new performance elements." An official opening date at the Beacon has not yet been announced. A Chicago production of "Banana Shpeel" was presented last year, and disapproving critics more or less tied it to the whipping post.

"The Secret of Kells," the film that grabbed a surprise Academy Award nomination for best animated feature earlier this month, won't be a secret to American audiences for much longer. On Thursday, the distributor GKIDS said that it would show the movie at the IFC Center in New York on March 5, two days before it vies with "Coraline," "The Princess and the Frog," "Up" and "Fantastic Mr. Fox" for Oscar honors. Directed by Tomm Moore, "The Secret of Kells" tells the story of a boy living in a Celtic abbey, whose adventures with fairies, she-wolves and barbarians lead to the creation of the Book of Kells, the 1,200-year-old illuminated manuscript. The film was already planned to be shown in Boston on March 19, but after its Oscar nomination gave it a little extra shine, it will now receive a wider national release in cities including Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago starting April 2.

In 1829, a year before Belgium gained independence from Holland, Charles Delvaux founded what would become the world's oldest luxury leather-goods company. Now pushing 200, Delvaux continues to make bags in small runs signed by master craftsmen. Which doesn't mean the label isn't looking toward the future. It has forged bag collaborations with the designer Bruno Pieters, the model Hannelore Knuts and the Belgian avant-gardist Natalia Brilli, who wraps watches and objects in taut lambskin. But Delvaux's biggest score to date was hiring Veronique Branquinho as artistic director. "It's a legendary brand with a great history," says Branquinho, who in addition to reworking existing classics is introducing several new bag styles for spring - most notably a deep-blue duffel and a buttery beige envelope (right). "Many years ago, I received my first Delvaux from friends who purchased it at a vintage store," she says. "It's still contemporary and beautiful after all these years."

Mark it down: Never again will the Bagger make fun of the accountants involved in the Oscar tabulation. Those fine, kind briefcase-toters are often the brunt of nerd jokes or, even worse, simply ignored in favor of, "Hey, is there any more beer left?" They haven't even gotten to appear on the awards show for the last two years, their 15 minutes relegated to a few seconds on the red carpet, where even the briefcases get a star turn. But this year, the year of the 10 best picture nominees and the complicated preferential voting system, the folks at PricewaterhouseCoopers may actually get the attention they so richly deserve. Well, we're writing about them anyway.

Back before fashion became a global corporate enterprise, it was a haven for deviants from the norm. Fey boys, gawky girls, misfits in their own homes and their own hometowns, they left their backgrounds behind and emigrated to the land of Style, where they were welcomed into the business of making and marketing illusion. In time, they landed jobs as designers, photographers, display directors, makeup artists, hairdressers, stylists, editors, arbiters.

Andrew Lacis, a climate scientist at NASA, flashed around the skeptic blogosphere after A.W. This Sunday kicks off the beginning of the Chinese lunar calendar. Celebrate the year of the tiger with a visit to the China Institute with your friends and family for a dumpling-making class beginning at 1 p.m. on Saturday. After you've mastered the culinary art, pay a visit to Sara D. Roosevelt Park on Sunday for a traditional firecracker ceremony at noon. Don't stop there though — continue the celebration next Friday when the institute hosts a big New Year's party at Gotham Hall. It will include a cocktail reception, multi-course family style dinner, an awards ceremony, the traditional lion dance, a special performance by the Princeton Tigertones and lots of dancing. Xin Nian Kuai Le!

Skip the celebrity-infested "Valentine's Day" movie, which Manohla Dargis calls "a disaster," and instead head to BAM on Sunday night to share one of the best romantic comedies of all time with your love. In the original 1934 review, Mordaunt Hall called "It Happened One Night," "a screen feast." The Frank Capra directed screwball stars Claudette Colbert and Clark Gable on a madcap cross-country romp. Colbert is the spoiled rich girl on the run from a forced marriage and Gable is the poor newspaper reporter with charm to spare. Delightfully, you know how it all ends. Stick around after for a special Valentine's dinner. On the menu: wild mushroom fettuccine, lobster risotto, duck confit crepes, slow-baked lemon-scented Dover sole and warm chocolate fondant cake, and a slew of other dishes.

"If you watched 'Sesame Street' or 'The Electric Company,' the children's educational programs, in the 1970s to the mid-1990s, you saw dozens of short animated films that no doubt helped to shape your view of the world, or at least your aesthetic sense," writes Melena Ryzik. "But you probably didn't know that they were chiefly the creation of one artist, Al Jarnow." Mr. Jarnow, 62, is a Brooklyn-born painter, sculptor and filmmaker who now lives in Northport, N.Y., and is an expert in the design of children's museums. He is also the man probably most responsible for why you associate Y with Yak. Mr. Jarnow made "Yak," "the minute-long film in which the titular animal introduces himself and then overuses the words 'you' and 'yes' — in a whimsical, educational fashion, of course, for Sesame Street." That film and many others that Mr. Jarnow made over a 30-year affiliation with "Sesame Street" and others children's shows are part of a new hourlong DVD, "Celestial Navigations: The Short Films of Al Jarnow," which will screen twice on Friday at the 92Y Tribeca. A question-and-answer session with Mr. Jarnow will take place after the first showing.

When Didier Gailhaguet last had an Olympic credential around his neck, he was in the midst of a firestorm in Salt Lake City that might have razed for good the career of a less combative sports administrator. But Gailhaguet, who was eventually suspended from international figure skating for three years, has proved to be a survivor, which is no surprise to those who know him well.

''Who'll light the Olympic caldron?'' That question was swirling around Canada on Thursday, and the most common answer was Wayne Gretzky, although he was not answering. Gretzky would be the default choice, a figure admired by Canadians and in many countries around the world, most notably Russia and the United States. But it somehow does not seem surprising enough. Maybe it could be Gretzky and Gordie Howe, who met him when Gretzky was a small boy and was present at all the key points in his career. Or maybe it could be Gretzky and a woman, perhaps Canada's greatest female player, Hayley Wickenheiser, even if she will be playing these Games as well.

Hong Kong's highest court on Thursday overturned the murder conviction of an American woman who was accused of spiking her husband's strawberry milkshake with a date-rape drug and then bashing him in the head with a brass figurine. The Court of Final Appeal ordered a new trial for the American, Nancy Kissel, left, who admitted killing her husband, Robert, a wealthy investment banker for Merrill Lynch, during an argument about divorce and the custody of their three children. Mrs. Kissel, 46, from Adrian, Mich., has contended that she was a victim of domestic violence and killed her husband in 2003 in self-defense. In their ruling on Thursday, the justices cited prejudicial evidence by the prosecution that was not properly explained to the jury or dismissed by the original trial judge.

When Louisville Coach Rick Pitino returned to Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, he maintained that he had not had contact, directly or indirectly, with the Nets. SCHWEBER--Seymour, 94, loving husband to Laura; father to Stephen, Dennis, Kenneth and Neal; father-in-law to Leslie, Ellen, Catherine; grandfather and great-grandfather, died peacefully on February 8, 2010. Founder of Schweber Electronics, a specialist in the distribution of semi-conductors, connectors and other electronic components. Seymour Schweber, both personally and through Schweber Electronics, provided the leadership and futuristic vision for the modern electronics industry. Patron of the arts, great supporter of artists and philanthropist, his love and devotion for his family and the life examples he set for all will remain in our hearts forever.

SMELIN--Dr. Raanan, 84, died suddenly February 7, 2010. Consummate New Yorker, graduate of Townsend Harris HS, NYU Medical School. He was a practicing internist in Riverdale, an attending physician at Montefiore Hospital and taught at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Generous and extraordinarily kind with a sharp intellect and remarkable sense of humor, he loved the arts and literature, a scholar of Shakespeare and Joyce. A devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend, his guidance, wisdom and love will always be with us. Memorial service to be held on Saturday, February 20, 4:30pm at NY Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Public Library.

Brooks Thomas, who led Harper & Row Publishers during a period of turmoil and consolidation in the publishing industry and who was its chief executive when it was acquired by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation in 1987, died Friday in San Diego. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan; Essex, Conn.; and Vail, Colo. The cause was complications of a brain injury after a fall several weeks ago, Sari Roboff, a friend, said.

PARKINSON--William Brown, age 91 of Teaneck formerly of Glen Rock and Ridgewood died Wednesday, February 10, 2010. Beloved husband of Dolores (nee) Parachini. Devoted father of Janice Boyd, Dolores Childers and her husband William, and Mary Louise Parkinson. Loving grandfather of Amy (Daniel), Katherine, and Carolyn. He was predeceased by his brother Edward and is also survived by his many loving nieces and nephews. William was the Owner and CEO of Mercury International Travel in New York City. He was a Captain in the US Army 3rd Division Artillery, having served in Europe and North Africa during WWII. He was also the Past Exalted Ruler of the Teaneck Elks Lodge 2080. Family and friends are invited to visit Friday, 4:30-8pm at Volk Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Rd., Teaneck, NJ. Interment to be held privately however, a memorial service will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to the St. Joseph's Home for the Blind, 537 Pavonia Ave., Jersey City, NJ 07306 or to St. Jude's Children's Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105.

DITKOFF--Shirley, 82, of Southbury CT, on February 11. She will be greatly missed by her cherished husband of 60 years, Leo, her beloved sons, Michael, Larry, Andrew, treasured daughter-in-law Beth, her adored grandchildren Sarah and Matthew, numerous nieces and nephews, as well as a host of friends and relatives. Predeceased by brother Bernard and sisters Hannah and Frances. She was selfless and tireless in helping others. She attended Adelphi U. receiving an MSW and spent 11 years counseling patients at New York State institutions. After retirement in 1988, she continued her many charitable undertakings in CT, including the Volunteer Ambulance, Hospice, Americaire and counseling inmates at Garner Correctional Facility. She became deeply involved in facilitating understanding between different peoples through her work in the local Interfaith Committee and made friends from every background and persuasion. There is a great loss to her family and all who knew and loved this most extraordinary woman. A memorial service will be held in the near future.

HARMON--Belle Kirschner, daughter of John and Anna Kirschner, was born August 4, 1906 in New Haven, CT; she died February 8 in Pompano Beach, FL, at the age of 103. She was preceded in death by her husband of 62 years, Bert Harmon, in 1991, her sister Sylvia Cohn, and her daughter Carol Lane, in 2004. She is survived by her son James Harmon and daughter-in-law Jane Harmon of Weston, CT, her grandchildren Wendy Zeifer, Deborah Harmon-Seder, Laurie Feit, Douglas Harmon, and Jennifer Harmon, and her great-grandchildren Dan Seder, Rachel Zeifer, Brad Zeifer and Amelia Seder. All of her life Belle was the epitome of an elegant, fashionable, well-dressed woman. After moving from New York City to Mamaroneck, NY, she capitalized on her abilities in both fashion and business, and in 1942 opened a women's apparel boutique, Jane Allen, naming the store after the middle names of her daughter Carol and son James. Jane Allen had a loyal following and was the major women's retail establishment in Mamaroneck for 30 years. Upon retirement from retailing, she and her husband lived in Rye, NY, Westhampton, NY, and Pompano Beach, FL. Belle, nicknamed "Gum," was a loving wife, devoted mother, adoring grandmother, and caring, considerate, generous friend. She was the center of her family. Lively, well-read and always well dressed, Belle was the focus of many family and friend celebrations and visits. Her vigorous and loving presence, lit by her welcoming smile and unfailing interest in others, will be deeply missed. It will be very hard to accept the fact that Gum is no longer with us. Interment will be private. Donations in her memory may be made online to MDA, specifically designated to Myotonic muscular dystrophy, at www.mda.org, or sent to MDA, Direct Marketing Department, 3300 East Sunrise Dr., Tucson, AZ 85718.

MITCHELL--David Lindsay, aged 88, died on February 9, 2010 after a short illness. Born on September 1921 in Montreal, he was the son of the former Georgie Brown and William Arthur Mitchell. As a young child, he moved with his family to Short Hills, New Jersey when his father became a partner of J.P. Morgan and Sons. He attended the Buxton School and Avon Old Farms, and graduated from Yale University in 1944. He was a Staff Sergeant in the Army Air Corps and was awarded the Bronze Star. David started his banking career at The Chemical Bank, and later became a Director of S. G. Warburg Ltd. in England, and was the first Managing Director of its American subsidiary. In 1984, he founded Mitchell and Associates, an investment banking boutique, and remained active until his death. Among his many civic and philanthropic involvements, he was a board member for many years of Citizen's Union, the International Center for the Disabled (ICD), and the Board of Associates of the Whitehead Institute. David was also a member of The Century Association, the Rafter Rats and The Friends of Gibraltar Society. He had a strong artistic sensibility and was an avid hiker who climbed the Matterhorn in his early 50s. David is survived by his wife of 56 years, Frances Binger Mitchell, his daughter Beatrice and her husband Paul Sperry of New York City, his daughter Caroline and her husband Jim Clark of London, his daughter Janet of Washington D.C., his daughter Anne and her husband Dror Navaro of New City, New York, and his six grandchildren. He will be remembered for his great kindness, charm, interest in people, humor, thoughtfulness and wisdom. There will be a memorial celebration later in the spring.

7:30 P.M. (NBC) 2010 OLYMPIC WINTER GAMES The 21st Winter Games will open indoors at the B.C. Place in Vancouver, British Columbia, with a ceremony that John Furlong, the chief executive of the city's organizing committee, says will ''tell the story of a contemporary Canada that will inspire the world.'' Though details have been guarded, the focus is expected to be on traditions of the Canadian aboriginal people. Ralph Lauren designed the uniforms worn by the United States team; the luger Mark Grimmette is to be the flag bearer for his countrymen. (Luge events will be at the Whistler Sliding Center, above.) Bob Costas returns as NBC's prime-time host for the games; Al Michaels will oversee daytime coverage. And Dick Button will appear for a 17th time at Winter Games as a correspondent alongside Cris Collinsworth, who is making his debut. 11 A.M. MITCHELL--David. With profound sorrow, ICD-International Center for the Disabled mourns the loss of David L. Mitchell, a distinguished Trustee and great friend. As a longtime Board member, he was dedicated to supporting ICD's mission and tireless in his efforts to support ICD's success. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him and enjoyed his intellect and humor. We extend deepest condolences to his family. Justin Wender, Chair Les Halpert, Ph.D., President and CEO ICD-International Center for the Disabled

The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Brooklyn Museum record with deep sorrow the passing of our friend Janet Tamagni and extend deepest condolences to her husband of 52 years, Museum Trustee John Tamagni, and to their children Susan, Jordan, Chip, and Christina. SIEGAL--Richard D. The employees of Palace Exploration Company and Bistate Oil Management Corp. deeply mourn the untimely passing of Richard D. Siegal, our founder, mentor and friend. We were privileged to have known and worked with a man of such extraordinary intelligence, vision, generosity and integrity. We will cherish our memories of his many acts of kindness. Our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Gail, and to Michael, Bippy, Arlo, Jody and their families.

KULICK--Alvin L.,Dr. on February 9, 2010. Beloved husband of Lillian, loving father of Eric (Leslie) and Cyndi (Ken). Cherished grandfather of Robert, Marc and Melanie. Services: 10am, Sunday at "Boulevard-Riverside" Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

TAYLOR--Marion (Riki) Richardson, on February 10, 2010, beloved wife of the late author and diplomat, Ambassador Henry J. Taylor. An international artist, philanthropist and lifelong Republican, Riki was surrounded by a wide and diverse circle of friends. A conservative in political matters, she was a vanguard in her artistic work and advocacy. Her own artworks are in private collections and corporate headquarters, with several of her paintings part of the permanent collection of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Collection. Serving on the Advisory Board of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice, Italy, she was active during their European expansion and beyond, and was an active member of many other institutions, including The Metropolitan Museum, Museum of Modern Art, The Frick Collection and Whitney Museum of American Art. Her charitable efforts and event chairmanships included the American Cancer Society, Women's National Republican Club, American-Swiss Association, American-Scottish Foundation, Manhattan Institute, Friends of Art and Preservation in Embassies, and many others. Her dinner parties were legendary, and attracted the political, diplomatic, creative and intellectual communities. A member of the Council of American Ambassadors, Riki was an advocate for and supporter of our foreign embassies as both positive and beneficial links to the international community. The letters, a total of 11, were written between 1951 and 1993, from one buddy, or ''Buddyroo,'' to another. In sharp and familiar prose, laced with humor and biting wit, the writer gives an intimate peek into his life and thoughts at precise moments in time. Read so many years later, they are filled with surprises. The recipient of the letters was E. Michael Mitchell, a Westport, Conn., commercial artist who had designed the jacket for a best-selling novel.

Mr. Manwell was also an avid collector of books and music, but his greatest passion was the game of golf. He will be truly missed by all who knew him.

On the first day of his ''Computer Science 106A: Program Methodology'' course at Stanford University in January, the professor, Eric Roberts, told his students: Cheat, and you will be caught. And if you are caught cheating, your classmates will suffer. More weight will be given to the final exam when calculating grades. These are not idle threats in a department where it may be easy to cheat -- but just as easy to detect cheating. Jay de la Torre, a senior, was caught and has been suspended this quarter as part of his punishment. Mr. de la Torre was taking the computer science class for a second time in his junior year when he cheated. He resigned from his position as student body vice president in November.

As news of Alexander McQueen's death rippled through the tents of Bryant Park, where the fashion world was gathered Thursday on the first day of the New York collections for fall, there was shock at the loss of a designer of outsize talents, perhaps even genius. Mr. McQueen, who was found dead earlier in the day in his London home, was remembered as embodying an unlikely pairing of the insular worlds of Savile Row and French haute couture.

SIEGAL--Richard D. The University of Virginia School of Law mourns the loss of Richard Siegal, a beloved graduate of the Law School and a champion of its ambitions. Richard made our students a priority of his life and charity. With Gail, he opened the Law School's doors to talented young men and women who shared his devotion to excellence and the public good. Richard was a senior member of the Law School's Campaign Executive Committee and a trusted friend of the institution and its leadership. We will cherish Richard for his enormous spirit and great heart, and we extend our deepest sympathies to Gail and their family.

Thailand will deport the crew of an aircraft that flew into Bangkok two months ago laden with North Korean weapons, a Thai official said Thursday. The five crew members will be sent back to their home countries, Belarus and Kazakhstan, but the aircraft they flew from North Korea and the 35 tons of weapons it carried will remain in Thailand for now, said Panitan Wattanayagorn, a government spokesman. The attorney general's office announced that it was dropping charges of arms smuggling against all five men. A statement from the attorney general's office said the plane had been refueling in Thailand, and the government had no obligation under a United Nations arms embargo on North Korea to take action against the crew. The statement also suggested Thailand did not want to harm diplomatic relations with Kazakhstan and Belarus. The aircraft, seized on Dec. 11, was filled with rockets, fuses, rocket-propelled grenades and missile components. A document on the aircraft indicated that the weapons were bound for Iran, but Thai officials say the final destination remained unclear.

THOMAS--Brooks B.,Age 78, the dearly beloved husband of Kiono Tucciarone Thomas. A resident of New York City, Essex CT, and Vail CO, Brooks died on Feb 5, 2010 of injuries due to a fall. He was known to his colleagues and the many members of his extended family as a driving intellectual and outstanding publisher, litigator, Socratic debater, sailor, and skier, committed curmudgeon, and most generous of souls. For many years, Brooks dedicated his leadership skills honed as a young senior naval officer on the USS Essex to support the growth and advancement of Outward Bound, Young Audiences, Inc., and the Vail Valley Institute, all of which he served as Chairman of the Board. He was an active supporter of his alma maters - The Episcopal Academy in Newtown Square, PA, where he was a member of the Board, and Yale University (B.A., LL.B.). Brooks also attended the Harvard Business School as an executive at Harper & Row (now Harper/Collins), of which he later became Chairman and CEO. A memorial service will be held in the near future, to be announced, at St. Bartholo-mew's Church in Manhattan. Donations can be made in his memory to Outward Bound, Young Audiences, Inc., The Vail Valley Institute, The Episcopal Academy, and Yale University.

The Board of Directors and staff of Young Audiences Arts for Learning mourn the loss of our Chairman Emeritus, Brooks Thomas, who served for 25 years as YA's leader and champion of its mission to bring quality arts learning experiences to young people across the country. Brooks' unwavering commitment to excellence has guided the course of the YA National Network in ways that cannot be measured. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Kiono, and wish her comfort in the knowledge that his good works will endure, as surely as his legacy of wise counsel will continue to inform the efforts of those who follow. FRANK--Bonita Wetmore. Bonnie passed away February 6th after a long battle with cancer. Loving wife of Warren Frank. Beloved mother of Christopher and Liz, Aimee and Ali. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, February 14, 11am at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue, 131 Remsen St., Brooklyn.

FELTENSTEIN--Minnie, passed away February 2, at age 97. Predeceased in 1973 by her beloved husband, William, she was the cherished and devoted mother of Arlene Marin and Maxine Skopov and their husbands Gil and Marc. She was adored by her grandchildren Stewart, Scott, Emily, Carolyn and Lauren, and lived to welcome and treasure eight great-grandchildren. A graduate of Hunter College High School, class of 1929, she attended Hunter College, and was a retired NYC school secretary. The epitome of good taste and refinement, she was an excellent homemaker, hostess and cook well into her 80s. She was intellectually sharp and enjoyed all forms of arts and entertainment, equally favoring Frank Sinatra, classical music, Broadway theater and the opera. Always a lady, she lived as she dressed -- with utmost style and grace. Loved and admired by all who knew her, she will be dearly missed.

Two suicide bombers attacked police officers in northwestern Pakistan on Thursday, killing 15 people and wounding 20 in the second attack on Pakistani police officers in as many days, the authorities said. A local security official said the bombers -- one in a vehicle and one on foot -- attacked a police complex in Bannu, in the North-West Frontier Province, and a police station. A hospital official said that nine of the dead were police officials and six were civilians, and that many of the injured were children. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but the Pakistani Taliban have been tied to previous attacks in the area. Bannu lies next to North Waziristan, a stronghold of the Pakistani Taliban that has been the site of multiple drone missile strikes in recent weeks.

Thank the presidents for giving the Metropolitan Museum of Art an excuse to stay open on a Monday. Today, spend some time with one of the smaller exhibitions that might on a normal day get overlooked. For instance, "Cinnabar: The Chinese Art of Carved Lacquer," which runs through Feb. 21. "The exhibition's approximately 50 carved lacquer dishes, platters, boxes, vases and other domestic objects — including a spectacular folding screen — are as engrossing for their formal beauty as for their amazing craftsmanship," writes Ken Johnson. The pigment cinnabar gives them a rich, dark red color, and intricate patterns, ornamental animals and pastoral vignettes carved and incised into their lustrous surfaces make every object a pleasure to behold."

"The Plastic Ono Band fell together in 1969 when John Lennon and Yoko Ono wanted to record. It was the loose aggregation that knocked out 'Give Peace a Chance' in a Montreal hotel room," Jon Pareles writes. "Ms. Ono's vocals — discordant yips and shrieks — were more avant-garde than most Beatles fans preferred, and she turned to more conventional songwriting as she continued to make albums. She left behind the Plastic Ono Band moniker in the mid-1970s but reclaimed it in the 2000s as she re-emerged." Ms. Ono has since convened a new Plastic Ono Band and for the concert "We are Plastic Ono Band," at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the lineup includes Sean Ono Lennon, Yuka Honda from Cibo Matto and two Japanese electronic musicians, Haruomi Hosono (from the Yellow Magic Orchestra) and Cornelius as well as performances by unnamed original members of the 1960s group — an appearance by Eric Clapton has been rumored. The show on Tuesday is already sold out, but tonight go listen to a special "dress rehearsal" beginning at 8 p.m.

My Sunday column looks at whether political differences may be rooted partly in personality differences, possibly even fundamental physiological differences. In particular, as described in the column, there's some evidence of variations in our sense of fear of threats. Presumably we have evolved to be wary of enemies (that seems to be the biological basis of suspicion of "out groups," including racism), and some people are more wary than others. These days, that wariness isn't directed at sabertooth tigers or enemy clans but at, say, Iranians -- or even the French. And those who register higher in sensitivity to threats tend to be more conservative. For example, one study that I didn't have space to talk about in the column presented people with images of faces with ambiguous expressions. Those who thought that the facial expressions were more conservative.

When "We Are the World" was recorded in 1985, to benefit famine relief in Africa, Bob Dylan sang some pivotal lines with his usual wayward phrasing. Now Lil Wayne shows up in the same spot, using Auto-Tune on his vocal, in "We Are the World 25 for Haiti," the remake to aid earthquake victims that had its video premiere on Friday night during the Olympics. Similarities aside -- scratchy voice, gift for free association -- Lil Wayne, you're no Bob Dylan. It's one measure of the slippage between the original and the remake, which can be seen on You Tube or downloaded from iTunes.

The Congressional Black Caucus Foundation -- a charity dedicated to internships, public policy research and healthy living among African Americans -- spends more on its special events than it does on scholarships, internships and its health and education programs, according to an analysis by The New York Times. Money is donated to finance the Annual Legislative Conference by corporations and labor unions that often also turn to the members of the black caucus for support on their issues in Congress. But the donations to the foundation are not subject to limits, like contributions to political campaigns are.

The Miami Dolphins appeased disgruntled linebacker Joey Porter by releasing him Friday. Hours before the opening ceremony in Vancouver, the worst kind of Olympic accident occurred, casting a sorrowful shadow on the start of the Games. A crash on the luge track, which has been described as the fastest and most dangerous in the world, claimed the life of Nodar Kumaritashvili of the Republic of Georgia. Ranked 44th in the world, the 21-year-old Kumaritashvili lost control of his sled, went airborne and hit an unpadded vertical support that holds a canopy and lights over the course. He  was pronounced dead at the hospital.

Last evening I went to Grand Central, boarded a train and went home. The past 36 hours had been depressing because of Alexander McQueen's death, and absurdly disconnected because of the shows and the chattering. If there is an answer to Mr. McQueen's death -  and no doubt there will be some thoughtful attempts at an explanation in the coming weeks - it will have to begin with his work. Looking at photographs of some of his great shows - the dance marathon show, the glass box and "Girl in the Tree" shows and of course last season's spectacular Web presentation - I think the keys are all there. It's one thing to have the vision and technical ability to realize those kinds of expressions; it is a more difficult burden to also constantly live with the emotions and ideas that those expressions embrace. And Mr. McQueen didn't just have three or four exceptional shows in his career; he had a steady run of them, and the last few seasons really saw him reaching further.

Organizers quickly changed the Olympic torch relay's zigzagging route through Vancouver on Friday morning to avoid a small protest. About 150 protesters were blocked by the police as they attempted to confront the relay in the Downtown Eastside, an impoverished neighborhood with a large number of homeless residents. At the same time, the relay's convoy, which included a large contingent of mounted police officers, was quickly diverted onto an alternate route.

Ferran Adrià, the Catalan chef who for two decades has been the leading catalyst and inspiration for avant-garde cuisine, has decided to permanently close his restaurant, El Bulli, considered by many to be the world's greatest, and to replace it with an academy for advanced culinary study, he said in an interview on Friday. In January, Mr. Adrià said that the restaurant would go on hiatus starting in 2012 , but that it would reopen in 2014. For many years El Bulli, in the Mediterranean town of Roses, north of Barcelona, closed for half the year so that Mr. Adrià and his chefs could spend the off months developing new techniques, like the foams, airs and other culinary wizardry that he has created.

A consortium of private equity firms has agreed to buy SkillSoft, a Web-based business training company, in an all-cash deal valued at $1.1 billion. The buyers, including Berkshire Partners, Advent International and Bain Capital, will pay $10.80 for each American Depositary Share, a 9.6 premium over Thursday's closing price. SkillSoft, which was founded in 1989, will continue to be based in Dublin, and the current management will remain.

SIEGAL--Richard D. The University of Virginia School of Law mourns the loss of Richard Siegal, a beloved graduate of the Law School and a champion of its ambitions. Richard made our students a priority of his life and charity. With Gail, he opened the Law School's doors to talented young men and women who shared his devotion to excellence and the public good. Richard was a senior member of the Law School's Campaign Executive Committee and a trusted friend of the institution and its leadership. We will cherish Richard for his enormous spirit and great heart, and we extend our deepest sympathies to Gail and their family.

TAYLOR--Marion (Riki) Richardson, on February 10, 2010, beloved wife of the late author and diplomat, Ambassador Henry J. Taylor. An international artist, philanthropist and lifelong Republican, Riki was surrounded by a wide and diverse circle of friends. A conservative in political matters, she was a vanguard in her artistic work and advocacy. Her own artworks are in private collections and corporate headquarters, with several of her paintings part of the permanent collection of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Collection. Serving on the Advisory Board of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice, Italy, she was active during their European expansion and beyond, and was an active member of many other institutions, including The Metropolitan Museum, Museum of Modern Art, The Frick Collection and Whitney Museum of American Art. Her charitable efforts and event chairmanships included the American Cancer Society, Women's National Republican Club, American-Swiss Association, American-Scottish Foundation, Manhattan Institute, Friends of Art and Preservation in Embassies, and many others. Her dinner parties were legendary, and attracted the political, diplomatic, creative and intellectual communities. A member of the Council of American Ambassadors, Riki was an advocate for and supporter of our foreign embassies as both positive and beneficial links to the international community. She will be sadly missed by her sister, Penny Borda, cousins Pegeen and Milton Snoeyenbos, and many friends. Funeral service Sunday, 2:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation for the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice, 1071 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128, or to the Manhattan Institute, 52 Vanderbilt Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

Kiss and Toll It was one of those ridiculously complicated Brooklyn-to-Manhattan journeys that required, for reasons lost to me now, careful planning, two vehicles and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. We were dating at the time, which is another way of saying we were just getting to know each other, which is another way of saying we knew very little about each other.

IN the latest show by the Dutch artist Erwin Olaf, which opened in New York last week, his gift for highly detailed but ambiguous storytelling is very much on display. Inspired by Mr. Olaf's own time spent alone in rented rooms, the photo series he calls ''Hotel'' features models in sets that replicate places where Mr. Olaf himself has stayed. At first, one room doesn't look that different from another until you spot a message light glowing on a phone; a pair of pants strewn over a chair, a discarded shoe. Spare but calculated, the scenes are suggestive of Edward Hopper's work, and their cinematic nature reflects Mr. Olaf's evolution as an artist. It is the uneasy feeling they evoke, the mystery of each scene's role in a greater story, that draws you in. ''Erwin Olaf: Hotel, Dawn & Dusk,'' through March 20 at Hasted Hunt Kraeutler, 537 West 24th Street. ANNA CARNICK

STEVEN STROGATZ Like anything else, arithmetic has its serious side and its playful side. The serious side is what we all learned in school: how to work with columns of numbers, adding them, subtracting them, grinding them through the spreadsheet calculations needed for tax returns and year-end reports. This side of arithmetic is important, practical and -- for many people -- joyless.

CARROLL--Thomas Sylvester, 90, retired CEO of Lever Brothers, president and CEO emeritus of the International Executive Service Corps (IESC) and resident of New Canaan, CT for over sixty years, passed away February 1st, 2010. He was born October 1st, 1919 in Washington Heights, NY. A graduate of Catawba College in Salisbury, NC, Tom pursued graduate studies at MIT and received his MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1947. He served during WWII with the U.S. Army Air Corps, advancing to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. In 1947 Tom and Sidney G. Burke wed and together raised five sons. Tom derived both personal and professional fulfillment overseeing the expansion of the IESC, which was founded in 1964 by David Rockefeller and Sol Linowitz as a "business person's Peace Corps," whose mission is to promote private enterprise in developing countries. During his tenure from 1981-1993 as president and CEO, the group experienced its greatest growth, to date, and tripled the number of projects undertaken by its volunteers worldwide. Prior to leading the IESC, Tom served as president and CEO of Lever Brothers, from April 1967 until February 1980 when he announced his retirement. He continued as a director of the company and chairman of the finance committee of the board and as a director of Unilever, U.S. until 1983. Tom was trustee emeritus of the Museum of Modern Art, advising the museum in its economic development. He was also a trustee of Catawba College, a Woodrow Wilson Fellow, director of Associates of Harvard Business School, former president of the Harvard Business School Association, chairman of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, member of the board of directors of American Airlines, Interpace Corporation and Associated Dry Goods Corporation. From 1964-1966 Tom served as Police Commissioner in New Canaan, and was an Honorary Deputy Fire Commissioner, NYFD. A lifelong athlete, Tom boxed in his youth and attended Catawba College on a football scholarship. Tom was a tennis champion at both the New Canaan Field and the Country Club of New Canaan. As a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, Tom was ranked third nationally in 1995-1996 in men's singles squash (75+) by the United States Squash Racquets Association. While raising his family he became an avid skier, returning to Alta, Utah annually from 1965-1999. He skied his last run in the shadow of Mount Baldy at seventy-nine. In 1981, Tom Carroll and Caroline E. Wheelwright married; she predeceased him in 2005. One son, Thomas Jeremiah also predeceased him, in 1973. Tom will be deeply missed by his four sons: Jeffrey, James, Matthew and Charles; favorite daughters-in-law: Lynda, Nancy, and Penny; nine grandchildren: Elizabeth, Julia, Nicholas, Clara, Finn, Amanda, Thomas "TJ" Jeremiah, Liam and Dylan; and two stepchildren: George and Sophia Wheelwright. The son of Irish immigrants and the youngest of six fun loving siblings, Tom made the most of his opportunities and, in return, gave generously to many people, rich and poor, around the globe. Tom was and remains a preeminent example of his favorite saying, "it is better to be born lucky than rich". A celebration of Tom's life will be held at 2pm on March 21st at the New Canaan Country Club. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that those so inclined send donations to either The Thomas S. Carroll Executive Symposium Endowment at Catawba College, Development Office, 2300 West Innes St., Salisbury, NC 28144, or International Executive Service Corp., 1900 M Street NW, Washington, DC 20036.

Moonlight and Clear Sky, the Fundamental Things I had my first date with the woman who would become my wife in a rough little art bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, back when the neighborhood had hipsters but no mustachioed ones, restaurants but no difficulty getting into them, cheap rents but no condominiums.

Look at the comments on the Amazon and Barnes & Noble Web sites if you want to know how some readers feel about the price of an e-book. The readers are used to $9.99, the price Amazon set when it introduced Kindle, and when they see an e-book costing more, or when an e-book's release is delayed while the far more expensive hardcover grabs up buyers -- well, you could fill a book with the grumbling. Readers are latecomers to the battle over digital price. Until recently, publishers and retailers have hashed it out, with publishers generally worried that $9.99 -- not a magic number but the one that managed to hook digital readers -- devalued books in readers' minds. Publishers gained back ground when Apple and Google indicated they were open to higher prices. Readers may have the last word.

SIEGAL--Richard. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, benefactor and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Trustee Richard Siegal. He and his beloved wife, Gail, for whom he would do anything, are longstanding and generous supporters of patient care and medical research. They are particularly committed to advancing treatments for breast cancer and vision disorders and recently are providing important support for our program to address heart disease at our Vivian and Seymour Milstein Family Heart Center. Richard was the most caring man and used his knowledge and skills to support patients and their families. Munificent and kind with an abiding love for his family, he will be greatly missed. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Gail, their children, grandchildren and all their friends and family. John Mack Chairman Board of Trustees Frank A. Bennack, Jr. Charlotte M. Ford Peter A. 'An Affair to Remember,' with Changes in the Plot I've done a lot of things I'm reluctant to admit in public. Near the top of the list is proposing to the woman I wanted to marry atop the Empire State Building.

FOR the performance artist Marina Abramovic, the staff of life is endurance. Her performances have involved fasting, cutting her belly with a razor, kissing till she faints, and staring into the eyes of a stranger over extended periods of time until she -- and her audience supposedly -- experience a cathartic levitation of the spirit. The source of her strength will soon be available to everyone. To accompany her retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, opening March 14, Ms. Abramovic collaborated on the Energy Blanket with the nonprofit organization More Art. Available next month, the blanket comes in a pouch, above, with four magnets to be strategically placed on the body; the blanket bears a sketch of Ms. Abramovic's body, so you know where your ''energy meridians'' are. If you consider $460 pricey for a dubious bit of science, it might help to think of it as a small work of art. LINDA YABLONSKY

As Republicans and Democrats claim to be searching for common ground in the health care debate, one idea that lawmakers on both sides seem to agree on is that health insurance should be sold across state lines. MITCHELL--David Lindsay, aged 88, died on February 9, 2010 after a short illness. Born on September 1921 in Montreal, he was the son of the former Georgie Brown and William Arthur Mitchell. As a young child, he moved with his family to Short Hills, New Jersey when his father became a partner of J.P. Morgan and Sons. He attended the Buxton School and Avon Old Farms, and graduated from Yale University in 1944. He was a Staff Sergeant in the Army Air Corps and was awarded the Bronze Star. David started his banking career at The Chemical Bank, and later became a Director of S. G. Warburg Ltd. in England, and was the first Managing Director of its American subsidiary. In 1984, he founded Mitchell and Associates, an investment banking boutique, and remained active until his death. Among his many civic and philanthropic involvements, he was a board member for many years of Citizen's Union, the International Center for the Disabled (ICD), and the Board of Associates of the Whitehead Institute. David was also a member of The Century Association, the Rafter Rats and The Friends of Gibraltar Society. He had a strong artistic sensibility and was an avid hiker who climbed the Matterhorn in his early 50s. David is survived by his wife of 56 years, Frances Binger Mitchell, his daughter Beatrice and her husband Paul Sperry of New York City, his daughter Caroline and her husband Jim Clark of London, his daughter Janet of Washington D.C., his daughter Anne and her husband Dror Navaro of New City, New York, and his six grandchildren. He will be remembered for his great kindness, charm, interest in people, humor, thoughtfulness and wisdom. There will be a memorial celebration later in the spring.

SOMMER--Dr. Nolan B.,90, formerly of Franklin Lakes, NJ, died February 8 in Gainesville, GA. A graduate of the University of Nebraska (B.S., M.S.) and Indiana University (Ph.D. Chemistry), he joined American Cyanamid in 1944 as a research scientist and held several management positions before becoming President of Jefferson Chemical Company in 1964 and President of the Formica Corporation in 1966. He served as Executive Vice-President and Director of American Cyanamid until retiring in 1978 after 34 years of dedicated service during which he received the 1968 Honor Award of the Commercial Chemical Development Association. Dr. Sommer devoted his retirement to health care as Chairman of the Board of Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, NJ and Vice Chairman of the New Jersey Health Care Administration Board. He was honored with the 1989 West Bergen Mental Health and the 1992 New Jersey Hospital Association Distinguished Service Awards. Dr. Sommer is survived by wife, Eula, and three generations of his loving family. His wife of 60 years, Gloria, and son, Bradford, predeceased him. In both his professional and philanthropic activities, Dr. Sommer was admired for his congenial personality, optimistic and energetic spirit and gracious service to others.

It took Francis Drake almost three years to circumnavigate the globe, and it's safe to say that his 16th-century voyage wasn't exactly a pleasant one. But times have changed. Next January, the Silver Spirit, the newest addition to the Silversea cruise line, will embark on a 119-day cruise hitting destinations around the world -- and should be more comfortable than Drake's vessel. The 540-passenger Silver Spirit departs Jan. 20, 2011, from Los Angeles and will visit 60 destinations in 25 countries before docking in Southampton, England, on May 19. Stops include a winery in Adelaide, Australia; a dinner and stay at the Shangri-La Hotel in Bangkok; a traditional souk in Dubai; and a private tour of Barcelona's Museu Picasso.

SEEKING to stimulate the nation's moribund economy, Congress offered Americans a variety of tax-based incentives to spend money and to help cope with daily living last year. Among them are new or expanded credits for home purchases, energy-efficient home improvements and college costs; the making-work-pay credit; and the right to enhance the standard deduction with additional deductions for real estate taxes and sales taxes on purchases of new vehicles. The breaks will please many taxpayers, and using tax software can ease the complications they may bring to preparing a return. To help taxpayers understand the changes and claim all the breaks to which they are entitled, Jan M. Rosen of The New York Times prepared a sample return for a hypothetical New York suburban couple. She used the TurboTax program, published by Intuit, in consultation with Bob Meighan, vice president of TurboTax.

MORE than two years before moviegoers would don 3-D glasses to watch ''Avatar,'' administrators at Hobart and William Smith Colleges gathered to contemplate new ways to get the attention of 16- and 17-year-old potential applicants. DAVIS--John Kent, 70, of Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, died Tuesday, February 9, 2010. Known to family and friends as Kent, he was a man of optimism and integrity who lived with grace, dignity, courage and a love for life, even as his health declined. Born in Berkeley, California, on September 2, 1939 to Arthur Clayton Davis and Katherine (Carr) Davis, he spent his early years there and in San Francisco; he cherished his western roots throughout his life. Kent enjoyed reading, especially history and short stories, and took great pleasure in music, French toast, camping, yoga, tennis, running, walking, hiking, learning Spanish and fly fishing, and he shared his enthusiasm with others whenever possible. The National Parks held a special place in his heart, as did the Hudson River. He loved his family; in recent years he especially enjoyed being "Gramps" and inventing songs and reading stories to his two grandchildren. Until his health failed he was an active member of the First Unitarian Society of Westchester and was grateful for the fellowship found there. A graduate of St. Ignatius College Preparatory (1957) and the University of San Francisco (B.S. 1961), Kent served in the US Coast Guard Reserve while continuing studies at Ohio University (M.S. 1968) and Syracuse University (Ph.D. 1971). As part of his doctoral training he completed a child clinical psychology internship at the Astor Home for Children in Rhinebeck, NY. Dr. Davis worked as a child clinical psychologist at Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry until 1977, when he joined New York Medical College as Chief of Pediatric Psychology with service in Pediatrics and Psychiatry at affiliates Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center and Metropolitan Hospital Center. In addition to his clinical responsibilities, Dr. Davis was an educator of medical students and residents, supervisor of psychology interns, and co-author of a book and numerous peer reviewed papers. For many years he was an active member of the Westchester County Psychological Association (WCPA), serving as President (1989-1991), Chair of its Ethics Committee (1982-1985), and on its Board of Directors (1982-1985, 1987-1993); he was honored to receive its Distinguished Service Award in 2005, the year of his retirement. Survivors include his wife of 44 years, Sue (Galasso) of Hastings-on-Hudson; daughter Brigid Davis, son-in-law Iain Bason, and grandchildren of Winchester, MA; daughter Monica Davis and son-in-law Charles Alexander of Arlington, MA; brothers James C. Davis of San Francisco, CA and Peter C. Davis of Lake Oswego, OR; his aunt Marie Carr Fitzgerald of Anderson, CA and many cousins, nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory can be made to Doctors Without Borders. Services: Westchester Funeral Home, www.westchesterfuneralhome.com

Ms. Hadid, the architect, has tried and failed twice to intervene in Wright's spiral: first in 1992, during the run of ''The Great Utopia,'' a show of Russian avant-garde art for which she did the exhibition design, and again in 2006, when the museum devoted a show to her own work. Originally she wanted to do ''a spiral within a spiral,'' Ms. Hadid said, ''but there were budget constraints.'' ''Z-Wave,'' her second architectural proposal, depicts a twisting, three-story-high sculptural form in fiberglass that appears to merge with the ramp's handrails. It touches down on three levels, creating spaces for seating or tables, crossing the rotunda at several points on its way. Ms. Hadid said that she thinks of it as ''an elevated street, or extended pavement.''

SOME entrepreneurs are counting on a lot of support from China for making hybrids in the United States. Why? Because supporting green technology can mean a green card for an entire family. Under a federal program, people who invest at least $500,000 in a business that helps create jobs in a rural or high-unemployment area can move, along with their immediate family, to the United States. If the business works out, they can get green cards and permanent residency.

KAUFMAN--Richard Ira. Athlete, intellectual, and civil war enthusiast died on February 7, 2010 at age 90. Devoted husband of Rhoda, father of Weslea Sidon and Margo Hirsch, and grandfather of Forrest, he served his country in World War II and went on to serve the children of NYC for over 35 years. An avid reader and puzzler, he was never far from his book or his Sunday Times crossword. In addition to those listed above he is survived by his brother and sister-in-law Dr. Raymond and Patricia Kaufman. He will be missed.

The opening ceremony on NBC Friday night attracted an average of 32.6 million viewers, the second most for a non-United States Winter Olympics carried by an American network. The figure exceeded by 14 million the opening ceremony viewership of the Winter Olympics from Turin four years ago. In the last Olympics in Canada, held in Calgary in 1988 and carried by ABC, the opening ceremony averaged 20.1 million viewers.

FOR a parallel universe often derided as mindlessly juvenile, Planet Fashion isn't particularly welcoming to new inhabitants. That's why the rapid ascent of the designer Julian Louie, 25, (bottom right) and the model Jacquelyn Jablonski -- two of the young guns in The Nifty 50 (T: The Times Style Magazine's inaugural list of American up-and-comers) -- is so noteworthy. After only three collections, Mr. Louie, 25, has emerged as a name to watch and to drop, thanks to his brand of esoteric glamour, with influences including surf culture and samurai armor. (He showed a video presentation Feb. 12 as part of New York Fashion Week.) For her part, Ms. Jablonski, 17, used the runway for takeoff last year; she walked a staggering 58 shows in her freshman season -- including Balenciaga and Prada -- and landed the cK Jeans campaign. And they say that youth is wasted on the young. HORACIO SILVA

SCHEINES--Joe, February 8, 2010. He was called Joe, Dad, Uncle or Poppa, known for his curmudgeon exterior, quick wit, and huge heart. He was Head of Communications for Kurt Salmon Associates, 30 years in a job he created. He will be missed by many, but mostly those who survive him. His children Daniel Scheines, Lisa (Peter) Horton. His grandchildren Alexandra and Jessica Horton, Thalia and Dorothy Scheines.

ZEEMAN--Stanley Edward, M.D. January 7, 1924 - February 10, 2010. Age: 86, Longboat Key, FL, previously from Allentown, PA. US Army, Private, Captain Medical Corps 11th Field Hospital Augsburg, Germany 1943-44. Dr. Zeeman was a retired cardiologist. He graduated from Jefferson Medical College in 1948 after serving as a captain in the US Army Medical Corps. He founded Cardiovascular Associates, Inc. in Allentown, PA. He brought modern cardiology to the Lehigh Valley by establishing its first cardiac catheterization unit. He developed the first paramedic cardiac response team for EMTs in the greater Lehigh Valley. Dr. Zeeman served as Chief of Cardiology at Allentown Hospital and Lehigh Valley Hospital Center from 1974 to 1980. He was President of the Medical Staff there from 1980 to 1982. Dr. Zeeman was the recipient of the Leonard Pool Prize for Service to Lehigh Valley Hospital Center. He was a Clinical Professor in Medicine for Hahnemann University for the Allentown Affiliated Hospitals. Dr. Zeeman served on the Board of Trustees for LVHC and HealthEast from 1982 to 1986. Dr. Zeeman was a beloved physician, medical visionary, and teacher. He was married to his beloved wife, Bonnie, for 44 years. He was a role model and dedicated father to his five daughters and a loving grandfather to eleven grandchildren and one great grandson. He was a committed, progressive democrat. He was an avid golfer and historian. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Dr. Stanley and Bonnie Zeeman Family Endowment Fund for Cardiology, 1247 South Cedar Crest Boulevard, Allentown, PA 18103.

I went to Murrow and Rianne went to Midwood. She was the prettiest girl there. She had a great big head of curly brown hair. We went out for the second half of my senior year. Her 16th birthday came, and this was my idea of a big date: dinner at Pizzeria Uno in the Village, then ''A Chorus Line'' on Broadway. I bought the tickets that afternoon at TKTS with money lent from my mother (never repaid). I wore a used dark gray suit with thin lapels that I thought made me look like a legitimate ska rocker. Maybe, though I doubt many actual ska rockers went to see ''A Chorus Line.''

THOMAS--Marita A.,67, died Monday, January 25 at Keystone Hospice, Wyndmoor, PA. Marita was born in Erie, PA, graduated from McDowell High School and Indiana University of Pennsylvania. After teaching high school English briefly, Marita moved to New York City to begin a successful 40-year career as writer and editor of print and online publications. Blessed with a vast circle of devoted friends, Marita loved life, was passionate about politics, literature and gardening. She welcomed many guests into her gracious apartments in the West Village in Manhattan and most recently, Philadelphia. Charming, opinionated, vivacious, Marita is survived by her brother William Williams, sisters Pat Hartley, Nancy Durlin, and her nephew Scott Williams. Her ashes will be scattered this summer near her beloved Saranac Lake. Memorials may be made to support recovery efforts in Haiti, a country to which Marita traveled and always felt a special connection.
Art Roberta Smith

THE Kia Ray plug-in hybrid concept car, which was shown at the Chicago auto show on Wednesday, is a study in aerodynamics with a blunt front end, a long tail, a low roof, skinny tires and an emphasis on being eco-friendly. Built on the Forte platform and designed at Kia's California studio, the front-drive concept is powered by a direct-injection 1.4-liter engine and a 78-kilowatt electric motor. The car has a continuously variable transmission.

Ms. Salcedo's mash-up submission combines a downward view of the rotunda with a photograph of a New York tenement by the German-born artist Hans Haacke. The tenement photograph, part of his series documenting the holdings of a local real-estate baron, was scheduled to be featured in the 1971 Haacke show at the Guggenheim that was canceled for what were widely believed at the time to be political concerns by the museum's director. ''What Hans was doing was amazing, and it was censored,'' said Ms. Salcedo, a sculptor who is also politically inclined. She wrote to Mr. Haacke to obtain his image and then worked with four architects over several months to create the perfect alignment with the other picture. ''It was a nightmare in Photoshop,'' she said.

Mr. Kapoor, the sculptor, who currently has a huge steel installation on view at the museum, proposed what he called a ''smoke event,'' a bright red plume that would be released from a smoke machine at the bottom of the rotunda and travel upward. ''Much of my work results in an ephemeral moment,'' he said. The key to the plan, he added, was recognizing that Wright's void is not really a void. ''It's never an empty volume,'' Mr. Kapoor said. ''It's always active, and your body is always active in it.'' The inherent energy of the space, he said, calls for a ''very playful'' response.

She will live in all of our hearts forever. She leaves her sister and brother-in-law, Jane and Richard Perin; her niece, Amanda Perin; her cousin, Charles Karchmer; her ex-husband, Frank Cavestani; and many friends. A celebration of her life will take place at a later date. Donations may be made to Women In Need, 115 W. 31st Street, New York, NY 10001 or the charity of your choice.
KLOTZ--Schulman Brenda. February 11, 1938-February 15, 2007. In memory of my twin sister Bren. My first love, my other half. I miss us. Evie

Twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, Germany is still coming to terms with its divided past in sports as well as in society and politics. Ingo Steuer, the coach of gold medal favorites in pairs skating at the Vancouver Olympics, was a teenage informant who wrote reports on fellow athletes for the Stasi, the secret police in East Germany.

BIRNBAUM--Mathew F.,age 90, of Harrison, NY and later Delray Beach, FL died peacefully on February 6, 2010, in Middlebury, VT. He graduated from New York's Straubenmuller Textile High School and the Philadelphia Textile Institute. After serving in the U.S. Army in Iceland during World War II, he rose to lead the family firm, Native Laces and Textiles, to great success. Mat and his wife Josephine were deeply devoted to each other for more than 65 years. Photography, reading history, and listening to very loud symphonic music were lifelong passions. Always a gentleman, always down to earth, he was beloved for his generosity and good cheer. Mat is survived by Jo, brother Ira (Marilyn), sons Michael (Karen) and Raoul (Celesta), grandchildren Corrina Gitterman (Paul), Max, and Tyler, great-grandchildren Jack and Annabelle, nieces and nephews, and countless friends. He was predeceased by daughter Liane and brother Robert. Donations may be made to Blythedale Children's Hospital (Liane Birnbaum Fund), Valhalla, NY 10595.

GOLFINOS--Argyrios John Physician, died February 8, 2010 in New York City at age 88. Husband of 60 years of Andromache Giannakou Golfinos. Also survived by three loving children, all Princetonians, Terina A. Golfinos (husband Robert Lisi), Dr. Anastasia G. Daifotis (husband Christopher) and Dr. John G. Golfinos (wife Stephanie) and six adored grandchildren (Alexander, Helen, and Christine Daifotis and Jason, Chloe and Phoebe Golfinos). Born in Akrata, Greece in 1922, Dr. Golfinos graduated summa cum laude in 1947 from the University of Athens and earned a Ph.D. in medicine in 1955. That same year, he embarked upon a distinguished career in New York City, holding senior positions at the Hospital for Joint Diseases (North General Hospital), St. Clare's Hospital and Harlem Hospital, specializing in cardiology and epidemiology. He became a fellow in human pharmacology at the Cornell Medical Center in 1964, focusing on the treatment of hypertension. During his association with Cornell from 1957-1970, he published over 10 research papers in the fields of clinical pharmacology, cardiology and cardio-pharmacology. Prior to his retirement, he was a member of the New York Cardiological Society, the New York Academy of Sciences and the American Geriatrics Society. His insightful mind, his unending knowledge of all subjects, his command of multiple languages, his wicked wit, and his passion for gardening, the opera, the ocean, and the Dow Jones will always be remembered by family and friends. TYMS. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Atlantic Beach Rescue Unit, Inc., P.O. Box 262, Atlantic Beach, NY 11509.

MAYER--Martin F.,of New Haven, CT passed away on Thursday, February 11, 2010. Beloved husband of Diane. Loving father of David, Christopher, Michael and Matthew. Devoted grandfather of Emily, Abigail, Kevin, Caroline and Kaatje. Martin was born January 11, 1937 in Minneapolis, MN to the late Emily Dunn and Frank Mayer. He was an alumnus of Yale, Class of '58 and a recipient of a M.B.A from Harvard University '62. He served in the Navy from 1958-1960. Martin was many things to many people, executive, teacher, writer, mentor, friend and will be missed by all. Visiting at Hawley Lincoln Memorial Funeral Service, 493 Whitney Ave., New Haven, CT, Tuesday, February 16, 4-7pm. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of St. Mary's, 5 Hillhouse Ave., New Haven, CT, Wednesday, February 17, 10am. In lieu of flowers please make donations in honor of Martin F. Mayer to the Yale Club of New Haven in support of a scholarship fund for the Yale Entrepreneurial Society to fund the summer internship program, which was near and dear to Martin. Please send donations to the Yale Club of New Haven, PO Box 775, New Haven, CT 06503-0775.

BERGER--Janice (Wald), of Summit, NJ passed away on February 11, 2010 after a long illness. Formerly a resident of the Devonshire in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. She also resided in West Palm Beach, FL and Rockville Centre, NY. She leaves to cherish her memories two children, Michael and Leslie Wald, three grandchildren, Daniel and Rachel Wald, and Samantha Massengill, and her sister Alice Chafetz.

GREEN--Richard Lloyd, of Kailua, HI, January 2, 1930 to February 5, 2010. Born in Kenosha, WI, Mr. Green attended Culver Academy and Van Wert High School, Van Wert, Ohio. After a year at the U.S. Coast Guard Academy and graduation from Indiana University in 1953 with a BS in Marketing, he became a member of the Air Force until 1956 serving as an Advanced Navigation Instructor. After his service years, he joined Manpower, Inc. becoming Vice President of West Coast Operations. He left Manpower in 1962 to start a business called Financial Reports, Inc., eventually establishing offices in Chicago, Los Angeles, New York, and San Francisco. The company name was changed in 1978 to Compliance Data Center, Inc. The primary service offered by Compliance Data Center, Inc. was to insure that clients fulfilled their stock brokerage obligations. When the business was sold to Equifax in 2000, Mr. Green retired. He enjoyed world travel and had many great experiences from Antartica to Tibet. He resided in Hawaii since 2003. Survived by his wife, Bonnie; daughter, Julia Berschauer and grandson, Christopher Douglas Berschauer or Tacoma, WA; sister, Doris Green of Santa Barbara, CA and niece, Gabriella Green of Livingston, MT.

The principals of the architectural firm WORKac, Amale Andraos and Dan Wood, once frolicked in the ''Lazy River'' feature of an Aspen water park, an experience that stayed with them. ''You have to take ideas wherever you can,'' Mr. Wood said. Their ''Flow Show,'' rendered in cross section, is a water slide on the Guggenheim ramp. ''We wanted a sustainable element, so it uses rain that is filtered on the roof,'' Mr. Wood said. The small eye-shaped pool at the bottom of the rotunda served as inspiration too. ''Wright put water in the center of the museum,'' Mr. Wood added. ''He was obsessed with the organic.''

BAKALAR--Elsa (Holtom), 91, formerly of London, NYC, Heath, Ashfield, in Leeds, MA, January 29, 2010, at 91. Inspirational, beloved mentor to many. Educator first in wartime England, later at Ethical Culture/ Fieldston Schools and Greenfield Community College; camp director; garden author-lecturer-workshop leader. Devoted wife of the late Michael Bakalar, affectionate family member and friend. "Gaiety transcending all that dread." Memorial gathering in the early summer. TAMAGNI--Janet B.,at the age of 75, died peacefully in Summit, New Jersey on February 10 after a brief illness. Born Jeannette Augusta Brown in Charlotte, North Carolina, her family moved to New York when she was a girl. She attended Green Mountain College in Poultney, Vermont, and was a member of the Dartmouth alumni community (Jack Tamagni, Class of '56). An avid lover of art, music and fashion, she also devoted her time to supporting charitable organizations such as the St. Hubert's Animal Shelter, the Raptor Trust, and the Summit Child Care Center. She cared deeply about young people living with disabilities, and was a passionate animal lover. She was married for 52 years to John Searle Tamagni, who survives her. She is also survived by four children, Susan Searle Tamagni, Lisa Jordan Tamagni, John Searle Tamagni, Jr., and Christina Jordan Tamagni; four grandchildren, Natasha Orisha Kulick, Michael John Kulick, Richard Jake Searle Schlein and Zachary August Searle Schlein; her sons-in-law Thomas P. Fastert and Michael E. Schlein; and innumerable friends who loved her deeply. A memorial service will be held at Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, New Jersey, on Friday, February 19, 2010 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Overlook Hospital Foundation or St. Hubert's Animal Shelter would be appreciated by the family. For information, please contact Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ, 908-273-2323.

KURTZ--Dr. Anthony D. Troutman Sanders, LLP mourns the loss of our long time client and good friend. Dr. Kurtz was a brilliant scientist who founded, built and led Kulite Semiconductor Products, Inc. CIMINO--James E.,M.D. The Calvary Hospital and Calvary Fund Boards of Directors, Administration, Department of Medicine, and entire staff mourn the passing on February 11, 2010, of James E. Cimino, M.D. As a seminal leader in palliative care, he dedicated his life to caring for terminally ill cancer patients and their families, the transformation of the House of Calvary to an internationally recognized palliative care hospital, and to teaching medical students, and fellows the importance of the non-abandonment of patients at the end of their lives. TO paraphrase Jerry Lee Lewis, there is a whole lot of art making going on right now. All different kinds. But you'd hardly know it from the contemporary art that New York's major museums have been serving up lately, and particularly this season. The current exhibition of Gabriel Orozco at the Museum of Modern Art along with the recent ones of Roni Horn at the Whitney Museum and of Urs Fischer at the New Museum have generated a lot of comment pro and con. So has the Tino Sehgal performance exhibition now on view in an otherwise emptied-out Guggenheim rotunda. But regardless of what you think about these artists individually, their shows share a visual austerity and coolness of temperature that are dispiritingly one-note. After encountering so many bare walls and open spaces, after examining so many amalgams of photography, altered objects, seductive materials and Conceptual puzzles awaiting deciphering, I started to feel as if it were all part of a big-box chain featuring only one brand.

THE NEWS Before the city could finish digging out from the two feet of snow that fell last weekend, Washington was hit with another blizzard, making the winter of 2009-10 the snowiest on record in the capital. BEHIND THE NEWS The one-two punch made for a lost week of snow days in Washington and its suburbs, with schools closed and the federal government largely shut down. Throughout the mid-Atlantic region, seasonal snowfall records fell as municipalities struggled to clear roads and utilities battled to restore power to thousands of shivering customers.

MANWELL--Edmund R. Prominent San Francisco Attorney, dies at 67. Mr. Manwell, a prominent San Francisco, CA attorney, was a true Renaissance man. His scope of knowledge was broad and deep. Mr. Manwell was also an avid collector of books and music, but his greatest passion was the game of golf. He will be truly missed by all who knew him.

LITWAK--Doris Elizabeth, 83, of Tenafly, NJ, on February 11th at home. She was a loving caregiver her entire life from nurse, to cherished wife, mother, and grandmother. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Robert S. Litwak, her children, Robert and Barbara, and granddaughter Chloe. A memorial service will be held at the Trinity Lutheran Church, 430 Knickerbocker Road, Tenafly, NJ on Tuesday, February 16th, at 10am. Shuffleboard and snorkeling are two ways to play at sea. Toying with technology is another, thanks to social media networks and mobile apps that are popping up on cruises. Among the first is Carnival Cruise Lines, which introduced a Facebook-like message board on the Carnival Dream, the 3,646-passenger ship that launched in September. Passengers can upload personal profiles, join communities based on interests like food and fitness, and post messages.

THOMAS--Brooks B.,Age 78, the dearly beloved husband of Kiono Tucciarone Thomas. A resident of New York City, Essex CT, and Vail CO, Brooks died on Feb 5, 2010 of injuries due to a fall. He was known to his colleagues and the many members of his extended family as a driving intellectual and outstanding publisher, litigator, Socratic debater, sailor, and skier, committed curmudgeon, and most generous of souls. For many years, Brooks dedicated his leadership skills honed as a young senior naval officer on the USS Essex to support the growth and advancement of Outward Bound, Young Audiences, Inc., and the Vail Valley Institute, all of which he served as Chairman of the Board. He was an active supporter of his alma maters - The Episcopal Academy in Newtown Square, PA, where he was a member of the Board, and Yale University (B.A., LL.B.). Brooks also attended the Harvard Business School as an executive at Harper & Row (now Harper/Collins), of which he later became Chairman and CEO. A memorial service will be held in the near future, to be announced, at St. Bartholo-mew's Church in Manhattan. Donations can be made in his memory to Outward Bound, Young Audiences, Inc., The Vail Valley Institute, The Episcopal Academy, and Yale University.

SURFING, ABOVE THE WAVES, IN THE CARIBBEAN, FEB. 7, 2010. Gaétan Gariepy, 51, a plumber from St.-Roch-de-l'Achigan, Quebec, on Royal Caribbean's Oasis of the Seas, the world's largest cruise ship, as it travels from Fort Lauderdale to St. Thomas. ''Our kids are all grown up, so we've begun taking Caribbean boat trips each year with our friends. We were told this was the biggest cruise ship in the world, and that it was brand new, so we wanted to check it out. The boat is amazing, and really beautiful. With -- what, 6,000 people? -- you can't imagine. It's like a small town. There's a huge park full of trees in the middle of the boat. Then you walk outside, and you can go surfing. The surfing was fantastic. Very challenging and otherworldly -- just like being on the sea, but you're surrounded by this applauding crowd. And there was also this real feeling of freedom. Here you are, surfing on top of a boat, and you can look out and see the sea itself, while being hundreds of feet above it. It's kind of magical.'' As told to Austin Considine

A small group of demonstrators smashed large plate-glass windows at the official department store of the Vancouver Olympics on Saturday morning as protests disrupted downtown traffic for a second straight day. The march was far smaller than a demonstration held before Friday's opening ceremony that stretched for almost two city blocks. The police estimated the crowd Saturday at 200; Friday's crowd was estimated at 1,500. In addition to breaking windows and splashing them with red paint at the department store, Hudson's Bay Company, demonstrators also vandalized some parked cars.

A devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend, his guidance, wisdom and love will always be with us. Memorial service to be held on Saturday, February 20, 4:30pm at NY Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Public Library.

ALYA KAZAKEVICH'S workshop cum store, a.b.k Custom Leather Craft, is an otherworldly atelier in deepest Chinatown. Surrounded by potted plants, old sewing machines and Russian army coats sent to her by her parents in Belarus, Ms. Kazakevich, 28, makes bags, shoes, belts and other leather goods by hand, from tanning the leather herself to hammering each brass tack. She opened the store in November, paying for it with credit cards and tips from her job as a waitress at Vinegar Hill House in Brooklyn. After deciding not to pursue a career in finance, she learned shoemaking from Barbara Shaum, whose Grecian sandals have been a fixture on East Fourth Street since the '60s. (''It sounds very Daniel Day-Lewis,'' she jokes.) If you like the canvas bag with leather straps, you'll have to be patient: everything is made to order. Prices range from $95 to $125 for belts; $275 and up for bags; and $375 to $425 for sandals and shoes. 105 Henry Street; (646) 479-6035. CHRISTINE MUHLKE
