PULLEN--Catherine (Kay) B.,89, passed away February 8, at Greenwich Woods Health Care Center. She was born in Greenwich, CT. December 27, 1920 to Elizabeth and Patrick Brennan. Kay was a long time resident of Stamford and also lived in New Canaan, Marco Island, Florida and Royal Oak, Maryland. She married William H. Cleary in 1942 and raised their four children, Carol Ann, William Jr., Albert Ward, and Mary Alice. After Bill Sr.'s passing in 1960, Kay started Mrs. Kay's Training Center, a Montessori Program for four and five year olds. She pursued her own education at the University of Oxford as well as the Universities of Florence and Vienna. She loved the city of Stamford and was very involved in its civic affairs. Kay was an original member of Board of the Representatives of Stamford and also served on the Boards of Education, St. John's Towers, St. Joseph's Hospital Auxiliary, Catholic Mother's Circles, the Rehabilitation Center of Stamford, Sacred Heart University, and Hubbard Heights Garden Club. In 1951, she was given the Christopher Award for her work in having bronze plaques stating, "In God We Trust" put into the then 18 public schools of Stamford. She married E. Markey Pullen, MD in 1975 and lived in New Canaan, Royal Oak, Md, and Marco Island, FL. After Markey passed away in 1980 Kay returned to Stamford. She is survived by her brother John P. Brennan of Greenwich and her children: Carol C. Cusick of Tarrytown, NY and grandchildren Thomas and Catherine; William H. and wife Patricia of Hendersonville, NC and grandchildren Megan and William Jr.; Albert Ward of Brooklyn, NY and grandchildren Albert Jr., Elizabeth and John; Mary Alice and husband Craig R. Sanford, DDS of Nantucket, MA and grandchildren Geoffrey and Christopher and three great-grandchildren Sean, Mia and Ryan; also survived by many nieces and nephews. The family would like to express its deep appreciation and thanks to the Staff of Greenwich Woods Healthcare Center for their kindness and excellent care they rendered to Kay over the past year. A memorial service will be held at The Basilica of Saint John the Evangelist on Tuesday, February 23 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Kay's memory to The Basilica of Saint John the Evangelist at 279 Atlantic Street, Stamford, CT 06901.

BERK--Charles. September 3, 1947 - February 14, 2008. It was a year ago that you silently, peacefully slipped away from us in your sleep. Too soon and too suddenly. And on that day a great void opened in our lives and in our hearts - places that cannot be filled. This journey that we've begun without you hasn't gotten easier as the days pass, as some have said it would. It sometimes seems to get harder. Though we cherish every precious memory and will carry them with us always, we miss your smile, your laugh, your touch and your love more with each passing day. We miss you Chuck! You're so hard to live without! Now and forever you will stay in our hearts. Joan and Samantha

COLE--James C.,84, died January 24, 2010. He was an actor and model for 20 years in New York City and a retired dentist from Norman, OK. Born August 7, 1925 to Ira E. and Carrie (Shoemake) Cole in Porum, OK. Dr. Cole moved to New York City in 1990 to pursue an acting career. For many years, he loved acting with the Off Broadway murder mystery troupe, Murder Mystery Inc. He appeared in many advertising campaigns. Dr. Cole was also involved in volunteer work helping ill Screen Actors Guild actors. Survivors include daughter Carol Cole-Frowe and husband Robert of Shady Shores, TX; sons J. Paul Cole and partner Randy Gaugert of Raleigh, NC, and Robert F. Cole of New York City; and sisters Louise Purdy and Jean Magoon. Services are under the direction of Brown-Wynne Funeral Home in Raleigh. A memorial service will be March 20 in Norman, OK, with interment afterward at Porum.

GLIEDMAN--John Lowell, on February 2, 2010 in New York City. He was a man with a brilliant, sparkling mind. Stargazer, runner, there was never a boring thought or conversation. He co-authored with William Roth, The Unexpected Minority; a classic work on disability, difference and civil rights. An academic without portfolio, he meditated on the many worlds hypothesis of quantum physics, free will and determinism. He published three books of non fiction and articles on science and computing. He loved science fiction because it best described our future possibilities in work, play and love. Funny, deep, soulful: a true partner. He will be missed by his wife Margot Adler and his son Alexander. Memorial Service March 10, 4pm, All Souls, 80th and Lexington.

ROUNTREE--Asa, age 83, died on Thursday, February 11, 2010. He was born in Birmingham, AL. He attended the public schools there, in Tuscaloosa, and in Montgomery. He was graduated from the Capitol Page School in Washington, DC, where he was a page at the United States Supreme Court. He was graduated in 1949 from the University of Alabama, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Scabbard and Blade honorary societies and Phi Delta Theta social fraternity. In 1954, he was graduated magna cum laude from the Harvard Law School where he was a member of the Lincoln's Inn Society and the Choate Club. From 1954 until 1962, he practiced law in Birmingham, where he became a partner of the firm of Cabaniss & Johnston. He also served as president of the Birmingham Junior Bar Association, as vice president of the Family Counseling Association, and as a member of the Budget Committee of the Community Chest. In 1962, he moved to New York City, where he became a partner of the firm Debevoise & Plimpton. He was a corporate litigator with that firm, and for many years served as its chief financial officer. When he retired from that firm in 1991, he returned to Birmingham and became a shareholder in the firm of Maynard, Cooper & Gale, P.C., from which he retired in 2000. He wrote and published The Roman Republic: An Historical Parallel?; Human Nature, Morality, and the State; and Words: Essays and Other Words, as well as many unpublished writings. He was, he liked to say, a consummate collector of rejection slips. In the Second World War he served in the Army, first in the Ordnance Corps and then as a military policeman. In the Korean War, he served as an infantry officer in combat, first as a rifle platoon leader and then as assistant battalion operations officer. He was active in the American Bar Association and was one of the founders of its Litigation Section, serving as chairman of the section during 1980 through 1981. He was admitted to practice before the United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama and the Southern District of New York, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and Fifth Circuit and the United States Supreme Court. He was a member of the Alabama Bar Association, New York State Bar Association, Birmingham Bar Association, The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, Alabama Law School Foundation, American College of Trial Lawyers, the American Law Institute, American Bar Foundation. He was a member of The River Club in New York and the Mountain Brook Club in Birmingham. He is survived by his wife, Helen Hill Rountree, who is known professionally as Helen Hill Updike, by his two sons, Robert B. Rountree and John A. Rountree (Cheryl); and by a grandson, Ben, and a granddaughter, Sarah Rose. A memorial service will be held the Cathedral Church of the Advent, Birmingham, Alabama on February 24, 2010 at 4pm. The family will receive friends after the service in Clingmon Commons. A memorial service will be held in New York at All Souls Unitarian Church on Tuesday, March 23rd, at 11:00am. Immediately afterward, the family will join with friends in the church hall. In lieu of flowers, unrestricted contributions may be made to the Weill Cornell Medical Center, 425 East 68th Street, Box 123, 10065 in honor of Joseph Ruggiero, MD, and his staff. The family is grateful to eleven complete strangers who gave the blood that gave us seven more months with Asa, and hopes that those who also loved and admired him will consider giving in future blood drives.

WELSH--Donald. The Outward Bound Board of Directors and staff lost a great friend and advocate for our organization with the passing of Donald Welsh. Don believed intensely in the life-changing experience of an Outward Bound course and, with John Mack Carter used his extensive network of publishing contacts to launch a successful Public Service Ad program on our behalf. Since his first Outward Bound course in 1983, Don could often be found climbing Kilimanjaro, trekking in Tibet, river rafting in Colorado, or hiking across England, bringing along with him his peers in the publishing industry, so they too could understand the power of Outward Bound and help expose its mission and educational philosophy to countless young people. His creative mind, engaging personality and boundless energy will be deeply missed. George McCown, Chairman Lee Skold, Vice Chair John C. Read, President & CEO

Dustin Johnson and Paul Goydos each shot a 64 on Saturday and were tied for the lead at 18 under after three rounds of the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am. Rarely will any tournament fall into a final-round story line like the one that snapped into focus on a sharp, clear day on the Monterey Peninsula. In one corner will be Johnson, the defending champion, the longest hitter in golf, averaging 310.7 yards off the tee this week. In the other is Goydos, one of the game's shortest hitters, whose driving average is 48 yards shorter this week at 262.7.

FISHER--Dr. Andrea, passed away peacefully at her home on the morning of February 12, 2010, at the age of 44 years, after fighting a long and courageous battle against a malignant brain tumor. She had been surrounded by family and friends. Andrea grew up in Livingston, New Jersey, the daughter of Drs. Hyman and Rosalie Fisher. She received a Bachelor's Degree in Art History from the Honors Program at University of Michigan and received her MD degree from the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. Andrea (known as Andi to her friends and family) was a radiologist at the New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. She is the wife of Craig Seitel and the mother of Max Seitel. Andi was an incredible human being. A stunning beauty who turned heads wherever she went, Andi also possessed a magnificent inner beauty. She always wore a gentle smile on her face and was filled with warmth, kindness and a true love of life. Andrea was modest and soft-spoken and never uttered an angry word. Yet she managed to speak honestly and directly and had a quick sense of humor. She responded to any difficulties or challenges with poise and equanimity. She was a talented physician and educator, a gifted photographer, and a craftswoman who excelled at pottery and knitting. She was an avid reader, movie-goer and traveler. She made deep and lasting friendships at every stage of her life and maintained these friendships with loyalty and compassion. Above all, she found pleasure in being with her loving family. Andrea is beloved by her husband, Craig, and son, Max, by her parents Hyman and Rosalie, and by her siblings and their spouses--Edward and Vivian, Laura and Adi, Naomi and Ashley, David and Tammy, Daniel and Karla, and Jonathan and Julie. She has been the doting and beloved aunt of Becca, Alex, Oliver, Micaela, Jesse, Gabriella, Talya, Arielle, Aaron, Daniela, Isaac, Eli, Sammy, Henry, Charlie, Noah and Jonas. Contributions may be made to The American Friends of Magen David Adom (http://www.afmda.org/) or to Migdal Ohr (http://migdalohrusa.org/).

SCHWEBER--Seymour, 94, loving husband to Laura; father to Stephen, Dennis, Kenneth and Neal; father-in-law to Leslie, Ellen, Catherine; grandfather and great-grandfather, died peacefully on February 8, 2010. Founder of Schweber Electronics, a specialist in the distribution of semi-conductors, connectors and other electronic components. Seymour Schweber, both personally and through Schweber Electronics, provided the leadership and futuristic vision for the modern electronics industry. Patron of the arts, great supporter of artists and philanthropist, his love and devotion for his family and the life examples he set for all will remain in our hearts forever.

The Zambezi Queen (zambeziqueen.com), a new 150-foot-long river boat described by its co-owner Tony Stern as a ''five-star floating boutique hotel,'' is a far cry from Hepburn's African Queen. But it does offer a luxurious way to explore one of the lesser-known waterways of the continent: the Chobe River in Botswana.

The Outward Bound Board of Directors, staff and countless students who benefited from the leadership and generosity of Brooks Thomas mourn the loss of a stalwart supporter, friend and board member. Brooks Thomas became a trustee of Outward Bound USA in 1980, served as Chairman from 1984-1987, he was a trustee of Outward Bound International from 1997-2003, trustee of Expeditionary Learning Schools Outward Bound in 2000 and one of the founders of New York City Outward Bound. John Tavares, the Islanders' 19-year-old center, has not scored a goal in 13 games, or four long weeks, but who is counting? The drought did not seem to matter as much to him Saturday as a hard-earned 5-4 victory against the Tampa Bay Lightning. Tavares, the No. 1 overall pick in the 2009 N.H.L. draft, had two chances to score in a game that included 75 shots on goal, but his backhand sailed wide of the net, and Tampa Bay defenseman Victor Hedman, the No. 2 choice in the draft, broke up an odd-man rush.

I went to Murrow and Rianne went to Midwood. She was the prettiest girl there. She had a great big head of curly brown hair. We went out for the second half of my senior year. Her 16th birthday came, and this was my idea of a big date: dinner at Pizzeria Uno in the Village, then ''A Chorus Line'' on Broadway. I bought the tickets that afternoon at TKTS with money lent from my mother (never repaid). I wore a used dark gray suit with thin lapels that I thought made me look like a legitimate ska rocker. Maybe, though I doubt many actual ska rockers went to see ''A Chorus Line.''

Mr. Aitken, a multimedia artist best known for the video ''Sleepwalkers,'' which he projected onto the exterior walls of the Museum of Modern Art in 2007, contemplated the void over several weeks. ''I didn't want to make it a quick exercise,'' he said. Ultimately, his ''intervention'' involved reproducing the rotunda at a different scale and on the other side of the country. With the help of assistants he built a foam-core model of the Guggenheim several feet tall and placed it over his ''lady friend,'' Gemma Ponsa, with only her legs exposed. (''She has a great body for it,'' Mr. Aitken explained of the casting choice.)

Fernandez, her daughter Helen Fernandez and husband Gerard Murphy, her daughter Carmen Romero and her husband Tobin Romero, her son Oscar G. VICTOR--Robert L.,85, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Teaneck, NJ, passed away on February 11. Beloved husband of Nyna (nee Singer) and loving father of Jill and husband Paul, and Bruce and wife Debbie. Avid sportsman, worked over 50 years in linen supply.

TROUSDALE--Sabina Cronin, 67, died unexpectedly on January 16th in the hospital from complications of severe pneumonia. She was the daughter of Sabina Larkin Cronin and Eugene John Cronin, Jr. of New York and the granddaughter of Marie Blanche and Dr. Eugene J. Cronin, Sr., of Cedarhurst, L.I. and Sabina Weber of New York. Born in August 1942, she was the last child recorded in the Havemeyer family history published shortly thereafter. After her parents divorce when she was four, Sabina lived with her mother in Forest Hills Gardens, spending time each summer with her father and a number of aunts and uncles in her grandparents' home. She graduated from Kew Forest School and Southern Seminary in Buena Vista, VA. At that time, always of independent mind, she refused her family's request to be listed in the Social Register. She had a great personal sense of honor and loyalty to good friends that remained with her all her life. Because she was also very talented and creative, she then graduated from the New York School of Interior Design, going on to accept a design assistant position with McMillan, Inc., a leading interior design firm. After several years, she opened her own practice. She never sought publicity for her work, but carried on a very successful practice for many years, primarily in Manhattan, but in Greenwich, Locust Valley and Mill Neck as well, for clients including the then American Minister to Great Britain, Raymond Seitz, Nelson Doubleday and the author, Roxanna Robinson. Later in life, she took up painting and then photography. Her very first painting was accepted for exhibition by the prestigious Silvermine Art Show, vetted by the Curator of Paintings at the Metropolitan Museum, Henry Geldzahler. Sabina accomplished all this through a deep determination to live a normal life, despite a lifelong burden of inherited anxiety and depression. She truly succeeded, but was finally forced to close her practice in 2003 by increasing illness, because she finally felt unable to continue for her clients in the high standards she set for herself. In 1970, she had married Allen Trousdale, an architect and native of Louisiana. Together over the years they restored several historic residences, both in New York and Newburyport, MA, the last a brownstone in Cobble Hill. She is survived by her stepmother, Mrs. Celestine Cronin of Wilton, CT., her half-sister Cathe and her children of Atlanta and her half-brothers, Sean and Christopher Cronin. She is and will be very much missed.

Maybe I should've been a soldier in Israel's army. As of 10 years ago, that country's women have been allowed to serve in the Israeli Defense Force (I.D.F.) in any capacity that male soldiers serve, including combat units. They can serve in the infantry or mechanized units, or any other combat occupation. They make up a third of the I.D.F., and are treated as equals with males. This CNN segment features footage of Israeli female soldiers who can and do serve in any capacity.

For a while there, the Copenhagen fashion scene convinced itself (and attempted to convince everyone else) that the city would be the fifth fashion capital. This season, however, was as close as you're going to get to an all-out admission that, well, it's just not going to happen. With a smaller-than-usual show roster and largely lackluster runway displays, the three-and-a-half-day Copenhagen fashion "week" that wrapped up on Saturday evening, felt like an unintentional homage to defeat. But not all was lost - indeed, there were a few gems that made it all worthwhile:Spon Diogo is the sartorial love child of a couple-turned-design-duo, and together they create refined, modernist looks - read: structured, well-cut frocks - lush, perfectly tailored coats and sheer, feminine blouses. And hallelujah for their use of thick woolens and luxe leathers - a sophisticated breath of fresh air amid a sea of commercial shows where the nylon-polyester blends practically screamed "keep away from flame."

As the Bagger winds her way through the final weeks before the big show, whose outcome increasingly seems a fait accompli (raise your hand if you're betting against Jeff Bridges and Mo'Nique yeah, still typing comments with both left and right, just as we thought) there are still pats on the back to be delivered from various influential guilds. Conventional wisdom holds that an editing nomination is a must for an eventual best-picture winner - when "Up in the Air" didn't garner one, veteran awards-watchers concluded that its chances were nil - so the results of the American Cinema Editors Eddie awards on Sunday were closely watched. And the winners are: "The Hurt Locker" (best drama); "Up" (best animated); "The Cove" (best documentary); and "The Hangover" (best comedy).

WHISTLER, British Columbia -- Last Friday, after another women's downhill training session was canceled, the Canadian Alpine skier Emily Brydon finished her course inspection early and spent a few minutes at the bottom of the course talking to reporters. She joked that she was the fastest that day, able to survey the turns and dips of the slope quicker than her competitors, including the gold medal favorite Lindsey Vonn.

Almost four decades after the federal education law called Title IX opened the door for girls to participate in high school and college athletics, a crucial question has remained unanswered: Do sports make a long-term difference in a woman's life?

When Canada celebrated its first Olympic victory on home soil yesterday, one could sense a nationwide sigh of relief. Expectations here have been over the top, only to be thwarted by a series of mishaps. From loss of life on the luge run, to a series of challenges including uncooperative weather; an opening ceremony malfunction during the lighting of the Olympic torch and finally, a traffic accident involving Vice President Joe Biden's motorcade which sent U. S. Olympic icons Peggy Fleming and Vonetta Flowers to the hospital with whiplash. Organizers here have been wondering when they would get a break.

I've trudged through Stage 3 prostate cancer and its treatment in good shape. Nearly two years after learning I had cancer, I'm an active 52-year-old, I exercise regularly, my blood tests are where they need to be and my oncologist wants to see me only twice a year.

"Chefs' tools are technical. I want to make them simple for the home cook and to have fewer of them," said Matali Crasset, the French industrial designer. Crasset, who worked with Philippe Starck for five years before starting her own studio in 1998, got the opportunity to put her ideas to work when she met with Alberto Alessi, the Italian design impresario. When Alessi learned that she had once collaborated on a cake knife with Pierre Hermé, the famous Parisian pastry chef, he knew immediately that the three of them had to work on a collection of patisserie tools. Alessi, an accomplished cook, has a passion for pastry. (His favorite recipe is one for torta de panna, a cake made with old bread. "You add milk to soften it, then mix in raisins, eggs, chocolate, amaretti and a little grappa. Then you bake it," he instructed.)

The Off Broadway production of Lucinda Coxon's play "Happy Now?" at Primary Stages will be extended for two weeks, through March 21, executives of the not-for-profit theater company announced on Monday. The production of the new play, about a professional London woman dealing with the pressures of life, received generally positive reviews, with Charles Isherwood of The Times calling it a "trenchant comedy" with a "skilled, appealing cast." The production is running at the 59E59 Theaters in Manhattan.

We interrupt this blog for a moment of shameless self-promotion. Two things coming up that I thought I should mention. First is that this Thursday, Feb. 18, at 9:30 pm, HBO will show a documentary about me, called "Reporter." It was filmed during my 2007 win-a-trip journey to Congo and looks at such larger issues such as how we can get American audiences to care about distant tragedies. The documentary was made by Eric Metzgar, and exec-produced by Ben Affleck. I stayed out of the decision-making, since I don't know a thing about film, but it came out very well. It gives you a chance to tag along on my reporting, including the opportunity to join a dinner I had with a warlord in the bush. It conveys the texture of the kind of reporting I often do.

I'm trying, with some difficulty, to imagine myself as a woman in her 80s, someone with such advanced cognitive impairment that I can correctly answer fewer than a third of the questions on a commonly used test. I might not know who the president is, or what day or date it is; I might not be able to remember a few nouns the test giver just recited. Asked the question, "What is the object used to cut paper?" I might not be able to come up with the word scissors.

WELSH--Donald. The Outward Bound Board of Directors and staff lost a great friend and advocate for our organization with the passing of Donald Welsh. Don believed intensely in the life-changing experience of an Outward Bound course and, with John Mack Carter used his extensive network of publishing contacts to launch a successful Public Service Ad program on our behalf. Since his first Outward Bound course in 1983, Don could often be found climbing Kilimanjaro, trekking in Tibet, river rafting in Colorado, or hiking across England, bringing along with him his peers in the publishing industry, so they too could understand the power of Outward Bound and help expose its mission and educational philosophy to countless young people. His creative mind, engaging personality and boundless energy will be deeply missed. George McCown, Chairman Lee Skold, Vice Chair John C. Read, President & CEO

HAIR is a language; it announces our gender, class and even our politics. George Washington rejected wigs as too aristocratic for the new Republic. He tied his long powdered hair in a ''queue,'' while his successors embraced unpowdered styles inspired by ancient Rome. Federalists like John Adams wore long hair, while Jefferson's Democrats countered with shortened cuts. By the mid-19th century, beards returned after a long absence. Virile-looking and practical on the battlefield, beards were suited to the Civil War; Grant kept his when he entered the White House. The safety razor's invention around 1900 marked the beginning of the end for presidential facial hair. For the last 100 years, there have been very few stylistic developments of note; the most significant change of late comes with our current commander in chief, whose hair has brought welcome diversity to the presidential scalp. -- PENNY HOWELL JOLLY,a professor of art history at Skidmore College and the author of ''Hair: Untangling a Social History''

8 P.M. (USA) 134TH WESTMINSTER KENNEL CLUB DOG SHOWHow can you choose just one? Some 2,500 dogs, representing 173 breeds and varieties, trot around the ring in pursuit of top honors in the country's second-oldest continuously held sporting event. (The first is the Kentucky Derby.) California leads the states with the most entries, 251; New York comes in second with 224. Australian shepherds (44) and Rhodesian ridgebacks (43) are the largest categories, with Labrador retrievers, golden retrievers, pugs, French bulldogs and German shorthaired pointers close on their heels. (Above, Penny Lane, a 2-year-old King Charles cavalier from Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.) New breeds for 2010 are the Irish red and white setter, the Norwegian buhund and the Pyrenean shepherd, both smooth and rough. The judging begins with the hound, toy, nonsporting and herding groups in this opening-night program. 7 A.M. PAGE--Virginia Barfield, July 5, 1919 - February 4, 2010, died peacefully at home in Florida, February 4, 2010. Born in Hahira, Georgia, she graduated cum laude from the University of Georgia, and received a Masters in Social Work from Tulane University. She was a founding member of Kappa Alpha Theta sorority at the University of Georgia. A licensed social worker, she worked for the Department of Children and Families of the State of Georgia. During the Second World War she worked as the head on non-military personnel at Moody Army Air Corps Base in Moultrie, Georgia, where she met and married Frank Jarvis Page, a fighter pilot and her husband of over 60 years. A long time resident of Garden City, New York, she was a member of the Aaron Ogden Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the Altar Guild of The Cathedral of the Incarnation, a founder of the children's choir, Founding President of the Garden City Historical Society, Co-Founder of the Cornelia Cotillion Debutante Ball and member of the Ladies Golf Association of the Cherry Valley Club. Virginia was a gracious hostess and talented cook. Her Christmas Eve parties will be long remembered by attendants at the midnight mass at the Cathedral. Virginia is survived by two daughters, Ferrell Page McClean of Locust Valley, Hobe Sound, and Vail Colorado, and Beatty Page Cramer of Southampton, Palm Beach and Vail Colorado, and two grandchildren, Ferrell Page McClean, a teacher in Bariloche, Argentina, and William Chichester McClean IV, a musician-composer in San Francisco. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, February 19th at 3pm at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, 141 South County Road, Palm Beach. In lieu of flowers, contributions honoring Virginia may be made to the Page Family Endowment at The Foxcroft School, P.O. Box 5555, Middleburg, Virginia 20118 or Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc., 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. Services entrusted to Aycock Funeral Home, Jupiter, Florida. Online condolences may be made at: www.aycockfuneral homejupiter.com

BALLARD--Claude M.,Jr., born September 27, 1929, passed away peacefully at his home on Thursday, February 11, 2010 in Little Rock, Arkansas. He was surrounded by family and friends. Claude Ballard was a General Partner of Goldman, Sachs & Co in New York from 1981 to 1988 at which time he became a Limited Partner. Prior to that, he was a Senior Vice President with the Prudential Insurance Company. He had been a Director on a number of public, private and not-for profit enterprises, including CBL and Associates, Rockefeller Center Properties (Chairman of the Board), The Urban Land Institute (President), Wells Fargo Trust Co., Taubman Centers, Inc., Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, St. Vincent Health Care System (Little Rock, AR), Quapaw Area Council Boy Scouts of America, Greater New York Council Boy Scouts of America, and others. He was Emeritus member of New York University's Real Estate Institute and former chairman of its Real Estate Finance Advisory Council. He was a former member of the Overseer's Visiting Committee for the Graduate School of Design at Harvard as well as Chairman Emeritus and member of the Advisory Board of the Wharton School Department of Real Estate at the University of Pennsylvania. He was a member of the Policy Advisory Board of the Business School at the University of Wisconsin. He enjoyed lecturing on real estate development at Wharton, Harvard, Cornell, Stanford, Southern Methodist University, Michigan State, University of Wisconsin, and NYU, and was designated a Distinguished Fellow by the National Society for Real Estate Finance and is Fellow of The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (United Kingdom). He is survived by his wife, Mary Birnbach Ballard, their three daughters -- Karen Hart, Melinda Ballard and Robyn Ziperski -- two sons-in-law -- Alan Hart and Jim Ziperski -- and six grandchildren -- Stephanie and Michael Hart, Reese Allison, Andrew, Laura and Claire Ziperski -- a sister and brother-in-law, Nancy and Mel Woolsey and their five children. He will be dearly missed by his family, friends and colleagues.

It used to be so simple. You wanted to go to Paris, so you called a travel agency, gave them your dates and budget, and with any luck, you soon had in your hands a real paper ticket with a real dollar value. Even in the early days of the Internet, it was easier. You went to one of the few booking sites - Travelocity or Expedia, most likely - searched for your route, paid with a credit card and that was it. Maybe you even got a paper ticket in the mail. After a rash of rabies cases among the raccoons of Central Park and environs -- 39 cases in Manhattan already this year -- the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced on Tuesday the start of a mass raccoon-vaccination effort. Broadway box offices rebounded robustly last week after three weeks of modest ticket sales during the traditional mid-winter chill for plays and musicals. Over all, Broadway productions grossed $15.8 million last week, up from $12.9 million the previous week and the highest total since mid-January. Among the shows with the greatest proportional increase in sales were the musicals "In the Heights," which added $287,605 for a weekly total of $740,580, and "Chicago," which shot up about 70 percent to $578,407. Both shows still earned less than two-thirds of their maximum possible potential grosses, however. The musical revival "Hair," which has also seen a decline in ticket sales recently, also increased its grosses by $111,744, to $593,128, though swaths of seats still went empty at some performances. Most other plays and musicals did better at the box office as well, in part because of Presidents' Day vacation schedules, but the performance was still notable given the fears about ticket falloff because of a snowstorm across the New York City area last Wednesday.

After releasing Antonio Pierce, the Giants are in the market for a middle linebacker. Cardinals inside linebacker Karlos Dansby is expected to be a free agent come March. Dansby said on Sirius Radio that there were four teams on his wish list: the Chargers, the Dolphins, the Redskins and the Giants. (Though in a later radio interview, Dansby claimed there is no wish list.) Dansby's best work has come in Arizona's 3-4 scheme. He doesn't have elite speed, but he's versatile enough to handle nickel duties, and he's a near-perfect tackler.

A while ago I wrote about eating Spanish smoked anchovies in London.  And on a more recent trip my wife, Jackie,  and I were reminded of how frequently these salty little fish - generally the traditional unsmoked ones we find in cans - turn up on traditional and not-so-traditional English menus. Since my student days in the 1970s I'd been dimly aware of this: soon after my arrival, my friend Tom introduced me to a brownish substance called Patum Peperium - The Gentleman's Relish (see here), which came in a lovely ceramic tub (now plastic except for special presentation packs) and which consisted of anchovies, butter and seasonings. Spread on toast, it tasted just as its ingredients would suggest: to me at that age, weird. But now that I get the point of anchovies, not so weird.

Richard Misrach's large-scale photographs now on view at PaceWildenstein are stunning examples of landscape photography, but not for the reason you might think. These are not the ominous aerial views of beaches or the desert vistas we've come to know as his work. Instead, all of the images in this show have been inverted to resemble enormous color negatives. While the environments are still recognizable, many of the photos - like one in which a lone figure appears like a specter in the distance - seem almost supernatural. Misrach shot most of these landscapes and seascapes with an advanced digital camera and then reversed the positive captures to transform them into strange and incongruous settings. The bluish rocks strewn along a craggy shoreline look more like icebergs. Not only does the series continue Misrach's probing exploration of the natural world, but it also reminds us of the rapid demise of analog photography - this is, after all, Misrach's first showing of digital prints. At a time when more and more photographers are embracing digital technologies, it's nice to see work that bridges the medium's past and present.

Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.My bedroom is on the brink of big change. I can't stand its lack of decoration a minute longer. I have never been any good at sleeping within white walls and this (cell-like) room has been pitifully neglected since I moved in a year ago. Well, not for much longer! I have chosen the wallpaper, a fantastic allover fuchsia design from one of my favorite companies, Twigs, in L.A.; I've ordered window shades inspired by Hamish Bowles's Paris apartment; and I am about to order a headboard covered in that fabulous, classic zebra-print linen from Brunschwig & Fils. It is strange how you can do nothing for so long, and then all of a sudden, you have to have everything, instantly.

An intramural fight involving the members of Aerosmith hasn't prevented the group from committing to a coming summer festival at which promoters say Steven Tyler will definitely be appearing with the band. NME.com, the Web site of the British music magazine New Musical Express, reported that Aerosmith will be among the headliners at the Download Festival, which will take place June 11 to June 13 at Donington Park in Leicestershire, and will also feature bands like Rage Against the Machine and AC/DC. If Aerosmith roadies aren't already excitedly tying scarves to Mr. Tyler's microphone stand, that may be because he's been feuding with his band mates for months, and a lawyer for the singer recently warned the group against attempting to replace him. The Aerosmith guitarist Joe Perry said in November that Mr. Tyler had quit the band, then reunited with him at a concert a few days later. Mr. Tyler entered a rehabilitation facility in December to treat an addiction to prescription painkillers.

Britain has certainly been generous in sharing its theatrical talents with its former American colonies lately, as it plans to send plays like "Red" and "Enron" -- not to mention the Royal Shakespeare Company -- Stateside in the months ahead. Now add to that list a new production of David Hirson's Molière-style comedy "La Bête," which is headed to Broadway in September after it runs in London this summer. On Tuesday, publicists for the trans-Atlantic production of "La Bête," said that it will star David Hyde Pierce (as Elomire, the high-brow playwright), Mark Rylance (as Valere, the low-brow street entertainer) and Joanna Lumley (as the princess who comes between them). The play, to be directed by Matthew Warchus (a Tony Award-winner for "God of Carnage" and "Boeing-Boeing," which also starred Mr. Rylance) will be presented at the Comedy Theater in London from June 26 to Aug. 28, before it heads to an as-yet-undetermined Shubert theater in the fall. "La Bête" was previously performed on Broadway at the Eugene O'Neill Theater in 1991, where its cast included Michael Cumpsty, Tom McGowan and Dylan Baker. The revival will be produced by Scott Landis & Sonia Friedman Productions, Roger Berlind, Robert Bartner and Roy Furman.

The Academy's nominees luncheon seems like a perfectly nice occasion for all the contenders to meet and greet, congratulate each other and have their photo taken. Between 1,000 and 1,200 people, including the Bagger, watched the stream, which focused not on the stars' tables - where all the good gossip that doesn't take place in the smoking area happens - but on the speeches delivered by the Academy president, Tom Sherak, and the telecast's producers, Bill Mechanic and Adam Shankman.

Please share your thoughts on "Jules and Jim" and where you rank it among the films of the French New Wave.

Last week, another daytime shooting claimed the life of a 23-year-old woman.  "We are very concerned about the brazen level of these daytime attacks," said Sgt. Bisa French.  ﻿Nat Bates, a Richmond city councilman, said he would try to reinstate a local ordinance allowing the police to randomly search vehicles for weapons. Seth Wickersham recently wrote an excellent article for ESPN The Magazine in which he explains the N.F.L.'s labor issues and the ramifications for 2010. In short, the uncapped year was initially installed as an incentive to extend the collective bargaining agreement before 2010. It was thought that failure to do so would lead to a spending free-for-all. As it turns out, the opposite is true. The free-agent market is thin; many unrestricted free agents have become restricted free agents. Teams have strict limits on what they can spend in free agency.

Celebrate Fat Tuesday tonight Brooklyn-style. A Mardi Gras affair, presented by L Magazine and Southern Comfort, features a parade with a marching band and burlesque dancers beginning at 7 p.m. at McCarren Park and Driggs. Costumed revelers and bicyclists are invited to join. The parade will then proceed down Driggs, up Bedford and over to Wythe Avenue, arriving at Brooklyn Bowl around 8 p.m., where prizes await the best bicycle float. The event will be topped off with a performance by the 22-year-old noise-pop artist Nathan Williams — who performs under the alias Wavves (the second "v" is silent). He'll be performing off his second self-titled album, "dissonant but sparkly, a collection of shimmering synthesizers, distorted vocals and twittering drums," writes Amanda Petrusich, along with MNDR.

Calling all Wilderness Girls and those who love them. As any baby of the '80s will tell you, "Troop Beverly Hills" is a welcome addition to the pantheon of cult films. The 1989 movie stars Shelly Long as a "spoiled, princessy character forced to rough it, in this case as the troop leader commanding a group of equally spoiled little scouts," writes Janet Maslin in her original review. Go to the Bell House on Tuesday night to watch, sing, dance and quote along to the film. Look out for a very young Tori Spelling and Jenny Lewis as well as Ms. Long who, while "tossing her carrot-colored hair and modeling a succession of fabulously awful outfits by Theadora Van Runkle, makes the story's predictable moves in a refreshingly trim, buoyant way." Join your fellow scouts beginning at 7:30; the director, Jeff Kanew, is scheduled to be there too. Dressing up encouraged.

"I always feel sorry for the parts of the stage that aren't being used," Trisha Brown once said. "I have in the past felt sorry for the ceilings and the walls. It's perfectly good space, why doesn't anyone use it?" It's been 40 years since the choreographer founded her company and broke boundaries by dangling dancers off city rooftops and walls. "Stepping back in time with her art is a wild ride," writes Gia Kourlas, "not just because of how the work has held up, but also because of how wittily relevant it remains." As part of a yearlong celebration of that work, Ms. Brown and her dancers will present a series of talks about her career and breakthrough pieces. Tuesday night, Ms. Brown, Diane Madden and Julie Martin discuss the creation of "Opal Loop" in 1980, and its recent reconstruction at 7:30 p.m. at Dance Theater Workshop.

Tucked among the titles in the SXSW 2010 program in Austin, Tex., from March 12 to 20 -- films that include ''MacGruber,'' ''Barbershop Punk,'' ''The People vs. George Lucas,'' ''The White Stripes: Under Great White Northern Lights'' and others -- is ''Pelada,'' an ode to soccer around the globe.

MELTZER--Elton. Remembered with everlasting love and treasured memories by his adoring wife, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

MARCUVITZ--Nathan. We send our heartfelt condolences to our dear friends Karen and Paul Levy and their daughters Rebecca and Charlotte on the death of their beloved father and grandfather, Nathan Marcuvitz. We know that his boundless love and profound intellect will always be a blessing and source of inspiration to you. Alan, Patti, Adam and Josh Abramson

JACOBSON--Matthew D.,35, died on February 13, 2010. Beloved son of Leon and Judith Jacobson; dear brother of Alexander Jacobson; cherished nephew of Dorothy and Robert Wigod; affectionate cousin of Dewey Wigod, Emily Pincus, and Michael and Andrew Solloway; warm and wonderful friend to many. Funeral services 11:30am, Tuesday at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Scholars for Peace in the Middle East (www.spme.net).

STIMOLA--Joseph N.,Jr. of Glen Cove, NY on February 13, 2010. Beloved husband of Nancy. Loving father of James. Loving son of Evelyn and the late Joseph N., Sr. Dear brother of Sharon Bales, Joanna Fairchild, Maureen Huson, Nick, Greg and Paul. He is also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Head, NY. Funeral Service 11:30am Saturday at the Locust Valley Reformed Church, Locust Valley, NY. Interment Private. Contributions may be made to a foundation to be set up in Joe's name. Further information on the foundation will be posted on www.joestimola.com.

ADLER--Ira R.,passed away at 93 on February 14, of complications related to a stroke. A Bronx native, born in 1916. Owner of Samuel Adler & Sons Kosher Caterers. Loving husband of the late Mabel Adler; devoted father of Arlene Adler and the late Linda Stein; adoring pop-pop to Samantha and Mandy Stein, Mark and David Kleiman; great-grandfather of Dora and admired and respected uncle. Survived by sister Anita Schwartz and loving companion Roberta Roth. Services: 12noon, Wednesday, February 17 at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to Mason Camp Seven.

And in a gesture of informality, King Abdullah reached for his remote control to switch on a giant flat-screen TV as soon as they sat down to chat over a buffet of lamb, rice, hummus and other dishes.

Behind a veil of secrecy, the United States, the European Union, Japan and other countries are forging ahead with plans to coordinate an international crackdown on illegally copied music, movies, designer bags and other goods that change hands in sidewalk souks and Internet bazaars. Negotiators, under intense pressure from media companies, luxury brands and other corporate victims of piracy, are scrambling to complete a so-called Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement by the end of the year.

To all the other woes of these Winter Olympics, one can add malfunctioning ice resurfacing machines. At the Richmond Olympic Oval on Monday night, two machines broke down while smoothing the ice midway through the first round of the men's 500 meters, causing a delay of over an hour. The scene overshadowed the speedskating, which as far as the partisan crowd was concerned was probably just as well. After the machines sputtered, so did Canada's favorite speedskating son, Jeremy Wotherspoon. Trying for the fourth time to win his first Olympic gold in his specialty race, Wotherspoon finished ninth. Mo Tae-bum of South Korea won the gold with a total time of 1 minute 9.82 seconds. He was followed by Japan's Nagashima Keilchiro and Joji Kato.

He had a passion for law, religion and politics. Services at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills on February 17, 12pm.

The cold temperatures that accommodated a smooth men's downhill at Whistler on Monday after two days of weather delays could jeopardize Tuesday's super combined and throw havoc into the Alpine schedule again. Organizers were pessimistic that Tuesday's event would start on time. A weather forecast that originally called for light rain in the morning turned into a prediction of snow beginning at 3 a.m. local time and ending around 9 a.m. The super combined was scheduled to begin at 10.

SIEGAL--Richard D. The family of Richard D. Siegal would like to thank the hundreds of people who donated blood and platelets to the Sloan Kettering Blood Bank in Richard's name. His doctors, Dr. Steven Nimer, Dr. Larry Norton, Dr. Scott Hammer, Dr. Shike, Dr. Chawla, Dr. Glickman, Dr. Huang, the staff at ADH and all the people on the 4th and 12th floors who Richard adored, as well as the nurses and physicians from the ICU, who were compassionate caregivers and worked in concert with the family to make Richard comfortable, can never know the level of gratitude the family feels. We also extend our profound thanks to the hundreds of people who came to honor Richard at both the funeral and during our traditional period of mourning. All of this is truly testimony to the expansive and generous life he led and the tremendous number of people whose lives he touched. For those wishing to honor Richard's extraordinary life, donations can be made to MSKCC-Research Dr. Steven Nimer and sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Office of Development, 633 3rd Avenue, New York, NY 10017; Att: Ann McSweeny

(49) MINE In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, which hit in August 2005, the filmmaker Geralyn Pezanoski headed to New Orleans, where for six weeks she documented efforts to rescue animals left behind when residents were separated from their pets. Many of these animals, like the puppy above, were loaded onto trucks and planes and sent to shelters around the country, where they were adopted by other families and given new names. In this ''Independent Lens'' presentation, Ms. Pezanoski tells the story of some pet owners struggling to find their companions and bring them home --like Malvin Cavalier, who had to leave his dog behind when he sought shelter in the Superdome, and Gloria Richardson, who refused to evacuate without her black Labrador, but was then forcibly separated from it by the authorities. The film also examines what happens when two families grow attached to the same pet. ''Home,'' a short film by Matt Faust about his family's house in pre- and post-hurricane New Orleans, follows. 7 A.M. A statue of President Barack Obama as a 10-year-old boy was transferred Monday from a public park here to an elementary school that Mr. Obama attended as a child. The removal of the statue came after criticism of its placement by Indonesian users of Facebook. Officials in Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia, bowed to protesters who said that the park should be reserved to honor Indonesians and that Mr. Obama had yet to make any particular contributions to the country.

Last year, the State Legislature levied a new tariff on most of the businesses in the New York City region. The metropolitan commuter transportation mobility tax requires employers to set aside 34 cents for every $100 in payroll costs, and hand the money over to a battered, barely breathing patient on the state's fiscal operating table: the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The tax has not worked out so well. So far, its projected revenues are coming in about $400 million below the state's estimates -- which, in part, will mean reduced subway and bus service for New Yorkers starting this summer. It has also prompted a furious backlash from suburban officials who resent bankrolling an agency that, they say, benefits the city at the expense of its surrounding counties.

As the 10 Americans imprisoned in Haiti for trying to remove children from the country awaited a decision on their fate Monday, the legal woes of the man who falsely portrayed himself as the group's lawyer mounted. The onetime legal adviser, who calls himself Jorge Puello, now acknowledges that he faces sex trafficking charges in El Salvador under the name Jorge Aníbal Torres Puello. He remained at large on Monday, as Dominican, Salvadoran and American law enforcement officials worked with Interpol to interview his relatives and search border and immigration records to find him.

CLIFTON--Lucille, June 27, 1936 - February 13, 2010. The Poetry Society of America mourns the loss of the poet Lucille Clifton, selected to receive the 2010 Frost Medal, the highest honor of the organization in its Centennial year, given to an individual for "lifetime achievement in American poetry." Lucille Clifton was also awarded the Poetry Society's Shelley Memorial Award in 1991, and the Poetry Society--in tandem with Cave Canem, the Hunter College MFA Program in Creative Writing, HoPoLitSo of Maryland, BOA Editions, and St. Mary's College--paid tribute to her in 2004 at a splendid and joyful ceremony featuring Elizabeth Alexander, Robert Hass, Brenda Hillman, Galway Kinnell, Toni Morrison, Walter Mosley, Sonia Sanchez, Kevin Young, and many other distinguished poets and writers. The PSA intends to honor her as planned on April 1, 2010, at 7pm at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, New York.

In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the cancer research organization of your choice.

Banks Violette is one artist who lives for the idea that nothing is ever lost or destroyed, only transformed. His "blackouts/blackholes (and all the things between)/for DS 7.13.09," the massive three-part sculpture he just unveiled at the Gladstone Gallery in Chelsea (and dedicated to the late Dash Snow), looks like a shiny black pyramid frozen in midcollapse. Or the remains of the stage at an arena rock show disrupted by stampeding fans. Or the walls of a nightclub after a bombing. It's made of high-gloss fiberglass, and the much-tattooed Violette, 37, stomped the glossy black material till it buckled, then erected it on steel scaffolding weighted by absurdly small black sandbags. Reflected in the wall's surface is "throne," a chandelier of fluorescent tubes that resembles an umbrella clothes dryer trailing long tendrils of black wires to a common instrument case. Both works simultaneously pay homage to, and thumb their noses at, Minimalist sculptures by Dan Flavin and Robert Smithson, while proving there is light in darkness, and in grief, redemption.

American utility industry executives see nuclear energy as the most promising carbon-free power source, are skeptical of climate change science, and are uncertain about the future, according to a report to be issued Thursday by Black & Veatch, the engineering and consulting giant.

The German photographer Ute Mahler became one of the G.D.R.'s fashion visionaries, her work a testament to the subversive role fashion can assume as a mode of expression in an authoritarian state. Mahler was focused not on extreme fantasy but on a heightened sense of reality. She presented women as strong individuals, concerned more with style than with the latest fashions (which weren't available anyway to citizens of the G.D.R). Her work is the subject of a show at Berlin's Galerie für Moderne Fotografie until March 10. She sat down for a fascinating conversation and shed some light on a rarely discussed period of fashion history.

Terra Industries has made a surprising decision to sell itself to Yara International of Norway for $4.1 billion. Only a month ago, Terra successfully fended off a hostile bid by CF Industries Holdings. And during Terra's yearlong fight against CF Industries, it had failed to obtain any other interest, making its rejection of CF's advances perilous and leaving its shareholders clamoring for returns equivalent to those CF offered. Terra's announcement of a deal with Yara is a clear vindication of that "just say no" strategy.

Ever the contrarian, Mike Milbury's remarks after the U.S. Olympic team's victory over Switzerland (video at around the 1:20 mark) hardly overflowed with glowing praise. "It was all right. They got the win," Milbury told the USA Network's postgame audience. "The best thing you can say about these guys is they put the two points in the bank and it's behind them. But they have to be a lot better than that going forward. They were careless with the puck. I thought they made some decisions that were questionable on pinches, and they gave away far too many opportunities."

The Baltimore Ravens are signing wide receiver Donte' Stallworth to a one-year, $900,000 contract. Before his year-long suspension for pleading guilty to D.U.I. manslaughter, Stallworth specialized in one-year tenures.

After making Sebastian Janikowski the only kicker of his generation to be a first-round draft choice, the Oakland Raiders have now made him the highest-paid place-kicker in the game. Janikowski's four-year, $16 million contract carries $9 million in guarantees.

The Washington theater company Arena Stage on Wednesday announced productions for its 2010-11 season that coincide with the grand opening of its new campus. The complex, the Mead Center for American Theater,  will include three theaters, rehearsal and shop space, and offices and will bring every part of Arena Stage under the same roof for the first time.

Mr. de la Renta was very much in a luxe-glam zone, now with a leaner silhouette than recent seasons, below-the-knee skirts in tweed embroidered at the hem and finished with a nutria band, and a palette that included magenta, lapis blue and emerald paired with black. Evening clothes were predominantly in black, silvery gray and champagne.

Juliet Kinsman is the editor-in-chief of Mr & Mrs Smith, a London-based company that books high-end hotels and travel experiences for a global membership of travel connoisseurs. In addition to publishing a series of guidebooks and tending to the needs of members, Kinsman regularly writes about travel and interior design for newspapers and magazines on both sides of the Atlantic. She lives in London - but her Canadian passport can attest to extended stays in Athens, North Africa, India and on New York's Lower East Side. This week, from a laptop somewhere in the world, Kinsman shares her insider's view on what's driving gallivanters now.

Last season, Marc Jacobs's girl was a dancer who had just left the cabaret with post-performance hair and makeup. This season, she's a chic, unfussy '70s French sophisticate sitting at a cafe in Saint Germain des Pres. "It's very about an individual kind of woman, very untortured and at ease," said the hairstylist Guido Palau. Jacobs wanted new faces that would capture that kind of feeling, so he assembled a casting of over 150 new models and selected an interesting-looking group that included the unknown brunette Tati Cotliar, who opened the show.

Finally, there is something that all the Oscarologists, movie fans and industry folks can agree on (aside from the fact that the awards season is too long). Chris Jones's profile of Roger Ebert in the March issue of Esquire has been making the rounds as a must-read, and it is: emotionally challenging, richly detailed and open, a portrait of a film lover who has done as much to promote cinema as any director, and a man who still has his voice even though it's been nearly four years since he lost his lower jaw and ability to speak. The Bagger interviewed Mr. Ebert years ago, back when he was still flaunting his thumbs on television, and he was generous and savvy about how the media industry was changing. Now he is a first-rate blogger and Twitterer, and still an inspiration.

Updated, 4:14 p.m. | To settle a longstanding suit alleging that the Salvation Army preached Christianity in the course of its government-financed social services work, an agreement has been reached to ensure that it does not do so, the New York Civil Liberties Union announced Wednesday.

As Stephanie Clifford wrote Tuesday, Wired magazine unveiled an iPad application with a fair amount of fanfare, including a demo of what a mashed-up future of old media and new might look like. It was a cool demo, but it left some of us confused. During the announcement of the iPad, much was made of the fact that it didn't work with Flash, the software from Adobe that animates much of the video on the Web. And yet, the Wired app was clearly built with Flash. What gives?

They sweep through the streets of Haiti's fourth-largest city, Jacmel, photographing the evolving daily life of a nation as it rebuilds. Moving quickly, they capture the resurfacing of a bustling market or a family settling into its new home inside a brightly colored canvas tent. Sometimes they meet resistance from residents, who worry that their tragedy might be exploited. Other times, they breeze through areas unnoticed, candidly photographing subjects who are acclimating to their new environments.

For fans of James Cameron who have always believed that the best thing about his work is the writing, you'll be delighted to know that he's got a book in the works -- and not just any book, but a novel that will serve as a prequel to his money-minting 3-D science-fiction film "Avatar." In an interview with MTV.com, Jon Landau, who produced "Avatar" with Mr. Cameron, said that the novel (whose printed words will presumably exist in boring old 2-D) will "give a foundation" for the story told in the film, providing back stories for characters like Jake Sully (played by Sam Worthington), Grace Augustine (Sigourney Weaver) and Colonel Quaritch (Stephen Lang).

After more than 400 years, there were still a few milestones that Shakespeare's Globe Theater in London had not yet reached. Now hold onto your jerkin, because for the first time since the doors of the original Globe opened in 1599, the theater plans to present a play by a female author. The Guardian reported that the playwright Nell Leyshon will have her play "Bedlam," about the notorious London mental hospital, the Bethlem, performed at the Globe as part of its coming season.

As I bounded over a snowbank yesterday near 531 West 36th Street, thinking one false step and I'll end up in New Jersey, some magazine editors were debouching from their cars in nice clothes with platforms and stiletto suede boots. The snow was blowing up the street. Who doesn't know that feeling of being one-upped by someone else's ability to look utterly fabulous in all weathers? It's too incredible to deplore. I climbed the stairs for the first showing of the Row, Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen's line, wishing I had my fuzzy slippers.

David W. Johnson has worked for Gov. David A. Paterson for much of his adult life. He began as an intern and is now one of the most senior people in the administration, paid $132,000 a year. Should you ever find yourself in the later stages of Hollywood Week on "American Idol" and you make it to the round where singers are segmented into several empty hotel conference rooms, don't just sit on the ground and mope. Look around. Observe the competition. In each room is a blatant tell, someone who's a sure thing for the next round, or a sure thing to go home. Identify that person. (N.B.: These rules also work for viewers, who if they successfully do this can skip an entire hour of "Idol" programming.)

When Electrolux, the Swedish electrical appliance maker, proposed a project called Art Home (pronounced aroma in French) to the Palais de Tokyo (13, avenue du Président-Wilson) late last year, the result was a partnership as close to heaven as the contemporary art museum could get. Conceived by the award-winning artist Laurent Grasso, the rectangular, purple-hued, glass-and-steel box, which sits atop the museum, houses Nomiya, a conceptual dining space for 12, orchestrated by the experimentalist chef Gilles Stassart.

"Viola Frey's giant ceramic sculptures of men and women are among the underappreciated wonders of late-20th-century art," writes Ken Johnson. "Rising 11 feet and higher, wearing business suits and ties and nondescript dresses, they have a spookily imposing physical presence and a clunky, cartoonish ugliness." These massive, mysterious sculptures are on view at "Bigger, Better, More: The Art of Viola Frey" through May 2 at the Museum of Arts and Design at Columbus Circle. A few more by Frey can also be seen at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery in Chelsea through Saturday. Unlike the museum, the gallery provides the kind of space the pieces deserve, but both exhibits showcase the work of "a true original," whose pieces, "because of their size and their blank or seemingly angry expressions, may remind you of what it was like to be a child among grown-ups troubled by incomprehensible problems."

Where is the best pizza in New York? For many of this city's residents the question takes on proportions that are nothing less than existential. Thankfully, for the moment, at least, foodie rabbi Sam Sifton has an answer. Motorino "serves the city's best pizza," he writes. The restaurant, which has locations in Brooklyn and the East Village, has attracted culinary celebrities like Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, who run the Frankies's restaurants, and Rachel Ray. Made to the chef Mathieu Palombino's specifications and "cooked in the tempering heat of a wood fire, his crust emerges from the oven as a Neapolitan fantasy of crispness that is also pillowy and soft, sweet but not sugared, tangy without too much salt." Multiple visits to the restaurants conform: "Motorino pies are great hot out of the oven, five minutes later, 10. You can order too much, watch a pie go cool on the plate, eat it anyway and discover: terrific. You can order pizzas to take out, drive them across the boroughs in freezing conditions, get home and reheat the pies: still terrific. Even a slice in the morning, fridge-cooled mozzarella over tangy red sauce, exhibits the pliancy and flavor of bread, not cardboard."

MEYERS--Betty Gardner of Santa Fe, NM passed away peacefully at home on Thursday, February 11, 2010. Her partner, Diane B. Jergins, also of Santa Fe, NM, was with her as she passed from this world to the next. Ms. Meyers was born on September 14, 1928 in New York City where she grew up. She graduated from high school at sixteen and finished college in just three years earning her bachelors degree from Syracuse University at just nineteen years old. Ms. Meyers married Edward M. Meyers and they had two children together. Ms. Meyers and her former husband championed advancements that revolutionized the advertising industry on New York's Madison Avenue during the 1950s and 1960s. After divorcing, Ms. Meyers moved to Santa Fe and built her life with Diane B. Jergins. Together they opened a store called Cook Works which offered comprehensive culinary and cookware items for the novice cook as well as the seasoned chef. They expanded the store to include two others: one for fine dining instruments and table wares; the other for superb foods, rare coffees and teas and other gourmet items. Ms. Meyers designed the stores with Ms. Jergins to reflect a particular level of taste and to offer the accoutrements of fine cooking and dining elegance to the public at large. Their clientele came from across the United States to shop in a store where the best was essential but was not necessarily the most expensive: it was simply what they found to be the best: of design, of function -- the best. The couple traveled the globe in search of those rarified items which would continue their store's beautiful mission -- a mission that grew out of Ms. Meyers' impeccable and unerring vision. Betty Gardner Meyers is survived by her loving partner, Diane B. Jergins of Santa Fe with whom she shared her life. She is also survived by her daughter, Elizabeth Meyers Rogers, 56, and her grandson, Matthew Adam Portnoy, 21, both of New Jersey and with whom she was especially close. Ms. Meyers is also survived by two granddaughters, Clare Meyers and Cynthia Meyers of California, and a son, William Meyers. Ms. Meyers was buried privately in Santa Fe. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial contributions to the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival. For details please contact: Kristen Tidwell, Development and Outreach Director, The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival P.O. Box 2227, Santa Fe, NM 87504-2227. Voice: 505-983-2075, ext. 108, Fax: 505-986-0251 e-mail: kristen@sfcmf.org

KROLL--Arthur H. Passed away this past Monday morning. He was 70 years old. Born in New York, he graduated from Cornell University and St. Johns Law School, where he was an editor of the law review. He had a distinguished legal career where he became an outstanding specialist in ERISA, Tax and Executive Compensation. He spent many years at Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler as a senior partner and rainmaker. He then continued his practice at Pryor Cashman. In his later years, he served as a consultant to some of the most important executives in business. He published many books and articles and was a mentor to some of the most distinguished lawyers practicing throughout the country. He and his wife, Lois (Handmacher) have lived in Scarsdale NY for 44 years where they raised two children, Douglas and Pamela, whom he adored. Douglas passed away from Leukemia (AML) in 2002. It then became his mission to continue his son's work to find a treatment, if not a cure, for this disease. He worked tirelessly with the Leukemia and Lymphoma society, where he raised well over $1,000,000 to fund outstanding doctors dedicated to this effort. He had two grandchildren, DJ and Stephen, who were the apples of his eye. Arthur had a great zest for life, and nothing could get him down. He also served many years on the boards of the Westchester chapter of the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society and Student Advocacy. He also, with the support of his daughter, son-in-law Alan Winnikoff and daughter-in-law Lucy Kroll Treadwell set up a scholarship at the Youth Counseling League of the Jewish Board of Children and Family Services, where his son had been a beloved social worker. The scholarship is awarded to worthy clients of YCL who have graduated from high school and wish to continue their education. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, February 18 at 12noon at the Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, (914) 946-8851. Family will receive visitors following the service and on Friday, Saturday and Sunday at their home in Scarsdale from 1-5pm. Donations in lieu of flowers, can be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society of Westchester (Douglas Kroll Research Program) c/o KST Consulting Group, 250 Hartsdale Avenue, Suite 30, Hartsdale, NY 10530 or Youth Counseling League of Jewish Board of Children and Family Services, (JBFCS/Youth Counseling League, Attn: Douglas Kroll Scholarship, 9th Floor, 120 W. 57th St. New York, NY 10019).

CUMMIS--Clive S.,born November 21, 1928, passed away Tuesday, February 9, 2010. His legal expertise, business acumen, philanthropy and commitment to the community are reflected in the many honors bestowed upon him during his lifetime. In 1971, Mr. Cummis founded Sills Beck Cummis Radin & Tischman now known as Sills Cummis & Gross, with over 150 attorneys in Newark, Princeton and Manhattan. Mr. Cummis, a litigator, focused on administrative law, appellate law and casino law. In the 1990s, his casino law experience led him to become Vice Chairman and Board member of Park Place Entertainment (Bally's), once the largest gambling company in the world. Mr. Cummis held an A.B. from Tulane University, where he was a member of the President's Council, and a J.D. from the University of Pennsylvania Law School, where he served a six-year term on the Board of Overseers, a two-year term as President of the Law Alumni Society and was named as a member of the Academy of the University of Pennsylvania. He also received an LL.M. in administrative and public law from New York University. He was well known in national and state politics and served as a delegate and super delegate at Democratic National Conventions. Appointed by President Clinton, he served as a member of the President's Commission on White House Fellowships from 1993 to 2001. He was a founding member of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and served on its Executive Committee. In 2006, the Newark Museum, where he served as a trustee, appointed him Chairman of its Signature Project Campaign. He is survived by his wife, the former Ann Denburg, a brother, state Superior Court Judge, Philip Cummis, four daughters, Andrea Cummis and her husband Renard Fiscus, Deborah Cummis-Sandlaufer and her husband Douglas Sandlaufer, Cynthia Cummis and her husband Gary Bacher, and Jessica Cummis. Three grandchildren, Samuel, Loni and Simon also survive him. Donations may be made to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the Newark Museum or Integrity House of Newark. He will be truly missed by his family, friends and colleagues.

WEINBERG--Irving, D.D.S.,on February 16, 2010. Loving father of Gail and Dr. William Reiss. Cherished grandfather of Mark and Wendy Reiss, Randi and Douglas Olin. Great-grandfather of Emily, Noah, Daniel and Samantha. A pillar of strength, an icon who will be dearly missed by all who knew him. Services today 10:45am. Graveside at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

GOLDMAN--Dr. Mitchell A.,age 65, passed away on February 16 after a courageous battle with cancer. Mitch was the consummate family man and professional. His dedication to wife Barbara and daughter Amy, as well as his parents Leo and Beatrice Goldman, sister Laura Chasin and extended family formed the nucleus of his life. Mitch was our leader and guiding light whose interest and care for his families both at home and at work was inspirational. One of the most respected radiologists in the country, Mitch was on staff for 34 years at North Shore University Hospital, the last 12 years as Chairman of the Departments of Radiology at NSUH and Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Mitch trained multiple generations of radiologists and will be remembered as a beloved and dedicated mentor, friend and colleague. He was a former President of the NYS Radiology Society and was inducted as a Fellow of the American College of Radiology in 1990, an honor bestowed on only 10% of the radiologists in the country. Mitch graduated from Queens College, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and was Chief Resident of Diagnostic Radiology at McGill University's Royal Victoria Hospital. Funeral will held on Friday, February 19, 2010, 11:30am, at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the NSLIJ Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021 for a fund in Dr. Goldman's memory to be determined by the family. In addition to his wife of 37 years, daughter, devoted parents and sister, Mitch is survived by his in-laws and six nieces and nephews. Mitch will be remembered by all the people whose lives he touched for his boundless energy and optimism, his sense of humor and enthusiasm for life, and his passionate love of food. We will miss you. Your place will always be set at our table.

SHERLIP--Ruth, died December 21, 2009, in Richmond, VA, at 90 years of age. A Greenwich Village resident for more than 50 years, Ruth was predeceased by her husband Milton, and children Robert and Jane. She is survived by her granddaughter Corinna, and two great-grandchildren. Ruth was born, raised and educated in Manhattan, and was active in Greenwich Village life and politics. She was an outspoken and articulate member of the local Community Board, and committed to the after-school reading programs she created, supported and ran for underprivileged children throughout the City. She was tough, lovable and will be missed. The Schanback and Baer families.

GOLDMAN--Mitch, MD. Physicians, employees and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System are deeply saddened by Tuesday's passing of our dear friend and colleague, Mitch Goldman, MD, who had served as chairman of radiology since 1998. Mitch's talents as a radiologist and clinical leader were outmatched only by his personal skills and attributes. His affable and kind nature made him a friend to all who knew and worked with him, and his enthusiasm for his profession was embraced by generations of radiologists who he mentored. Dr. Goldman's tenure at North Shore-LIJ dates back to 1976, when he joined the radiology department at North Shore University Hospital (NSUH) in Manhasset, NY, after completing his residency and fellowship at McGill University in Montreal. He was appointed chief of diagnostic ultrasound and body computed tomography at NSUH in 1980, named associate chairman of radiology in 1992 and promoted chairman in 1998, following the death of his friend and colleague Roger Hyman, MD. Shortly thereafter, he became the clinical leader of radiology at both NSUH and LIJ Medical Center. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Barbara, daughter Amy, parents Leo and Beatrice Goldman, sister Laura Chasin and the entire family. Michael Dowling, President & CEO Saul Katz, Chairman

ROSS--Chester. February 15 at the age of 95. Chester died "young at heart" with laughter and love for everyone around him. Oldest "big brother" of Big Brothers/Big Sisters in U.S.; successful textile designer, best known for metallic jersey and ribbon knit. Beloved husband of Barbara of 67 years; loving father of Alice Ross Gold and Joan Ross Sorkin; cherished grandfather of Lauren, Andrew, Katharine and Suzanne; adored great-grandfather of Julia; extraordinary "brother" to David Loughran; favorite "Uncle Chester" to extended family and friends. Services on Thursday, February 18 at 11:30am at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale.
