LEWIS--Dr. Ralph J.,77, Prominent Thoracic Surgeon. Dr Ralph J. Lewis, of Basking Ridge, NJ, a loving husband, father and grandfather and a prominent thoracic surgeon, peacefully passed away at home surrounded by his loving family on February 15, 2010 of advanced cancer. Dr Lewis spent his whole professional career caring for and helping others. He made enormous contributions to the field of thoracic surgery. He was a graduate of Manhattan College and Cornell University Medical School. He completed his surgical training at New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center and opened his surgical practice in New Jersey in the mid 1960's. During his career, Dr Lewis participated in the development of Robert Wood Johnson Medical School where he became a clinical professor of thoracic surgery. Dr Lewis was also Chief of Thoracic Surgery at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, St Peter's University Hospital and Somerset Medical Center. He served as president of the NJ Society of Thoracic Surgeons and was a member of the American College of Surgeons, the American Association for Thoracic Surgery and the Society of Thoracic Surgeons in which he held numerous offices. As an innovative surgeon, Dr Lewis made many contributions to the field of Thoracic Surgery. He published original works in peer reviewed medical journals and surgical textbooks and he developed surgical techniques and surgical instruments. Dr Lewis was a pioneer in the surgical technique "VATS", (Video Assisted Thoracic Surgery) which resulted in far less pain for the patient, quicker recovery with shorter hospital stays and speedier return to work. This is one of the new surgical techniques currently used in thoracic surgery worldwide today. Dr Lewis taught and performed his surgical techniques at many national and international medical centers. Prominent surgeons came to New Brunswick, NJ, from throughout the US and abroad to enroll in courses which he taught on VATS. Patients also traveled from various areas to benefit from these techniques. Dr Lewis received many prestigious medical awards and honors from countries in Europe, Asia and South America. He received NJ Pride Award as well as "America's Best Doctors" award. He retired from surgery in 2000 but remained active and continued to publish in the field of thoracic surgery. Dr Lewis had a long and distinguished career in surgery, but he always said his greatest accomplishment in life was enjoying his loving family. He made it a priority to attend his six children's activities as frequently as possible and to participate in their daily lives. This, he felt, developed a sound and strong relationship with his family. Dr Lewis is survived by his loving wife of 50 years, Pat, whom he met at New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center where she was a nurse. He remained devoted to her his entire life. He leaves behind his six children who were his pride and joy, who will miss very much. Deirdre Lewis Bichsel and her husband Rick, of Cranbury, NJ; Tom Lewis and his wife Ann of Lawrenceville, NJ; Kimberly Lewis Roswech and her husband John of Chester, NJ; Paul Lewis and his wife Micheline of Asbury, NJ; Peter Lewis and his wife Danette of Peapack, NJ; and Greg Lewis and his wife Lauren of Summit, NJ. Dr Lewis also leaves behind 17 grandchildren who adored their grandpa. They are: Meredith, Whitney, Jonathan, Kylie and Helen Bichsel; Brad, Parker and Gwyneth Lewis; Connor and Megan Roswech; Matthew, Madeleine, Morgan and Mikaela Lewis; Mason and Logan Lewis; and Alexandra Lewis. Visitation will be held at Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home, 101 South Finley Ave, Basking Ridge, NJ on Wednesday February 17, 2010 2-4 and 6-8pm. Liturgy of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 1890 Washington Valley Road, Martinsville, NJ on Thursday February 18, 2010 at 10am. Those planning an expression of sympathy may make a memorial contribution in Dr Ralph Lewis's name to: Weill Cornell Medical College Scholarship Fund Class of 1958 Box 123, 1300 York Ave NY, NY 10065 or Compassionate Care Hospice, 140 Littleton Road, Suite 200, Parsippany, NJ 07054.

Nguyen Minh Tam said he got used to the routine during three months in a government drug detention center, although he sometimes lost consciousness: three punches to the chest when he woke up in the morning and three more before he went to bed. Another heroin addict said he was whipped until he passed out with a twisted metal wire as thick as his thumb. ''They used a blanket to cover me, and they beat me,'' said the detainee, who insisted that only his first name, Chandara, be used. ''There were 10 of them beating me.''

King Tutankhamen, the boy pharaoh, was frail and lame and suffered ''multiple disorders'' when he died at age 19 about 1324 B.C., but scientists have now determined the most likely agents of death: a severe bout of malaria combined with a degenerative bone condition. The researchers said that to their knowledge ''this is the oldest genetic proof of malaria in precisely dated mummies.'' Several other mummies in the study also showed DNA evidence of the presence of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum, perhaps not surprising in a place like the Nile Valley.

HAYES--Dr. Arthur Hull, Jr. Former FDA Commissioner, dies at 76. Dr. Arthur Hull Hayes, Jr. who led the US Food and Drug Administration during the Tylenol crisis of 1982 and was a nationally known professor of clinical pharmacology, died on February 11, 2010 from complications caused by a chronic illness. In 1981, Dr. Hayes was appointed Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration by President Ronald Reagan. During his years at the agency, he directed the FDA's response to the Tylenol tampering cases, called for a voluntary moratorium on direct-to-consumer advertising of prescription medicines and weathered criticism on the FDA's approval of the sweetener aspartame. Born in Highland Park, Michigan in 1933 to Arthur Hull Hayes and Florence (Gruber) Hayes, he loved to travel and visited countries on five continents with his wife of 49 years. In 1970, he and his wife co-founded a medical clinic on the Pacific island of Pohnpei, and they worked as a doctor and nurse team on behalf of the Jesuit Missions. Hayes was ordained a permanent deacon in the Roman Catholic Church in 1978 and served in parishes in Pennsylvania, Maryland and New York. Dr. Hayes received his A.B. in philosophy magna cum laude from Santa Clara University in 1955 and then went to Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, earning a degree in philosophy, politics and economics in 1957. He returned to the US to study medicine; first at Georgetown University Medical School and graduated from Cornell University Medical School in 1964. Following his graduation, he served in the United States Army Medical Corps from 1965 to 1967-achieving the rank of Captain. Dr. Hayes worked as an Assistant Professor of medicine and pharmacology and Associate Dean for Academic Programs at Cornell before becoming a Professor of Medicine and Pharmacology and Director of Clinical Pharmacology at Pennsylvania State University Medical School in Hershey, Pennsylvania. After leaving the FDA, Dr. Hayes worked as Provost and Dean at New York Medical College and later, in 1986, was appointed President of E.M. Pharmaceuticals, a division of the German company E. Merck. Five years later, he founded MediScience Associates, a consulting firm, part of Nelson Communications, Inc., and stayed there until 2005, when he retired. Dr. Hayes served on numerous commercial and pro bono boards, received many honorary degrees and awards and was named a visiting professor at a several academic institutions. He consulted for a dozen foreign governments, authored more than a hundred professional papers, delivered thousands of lectures and trained many clinical pharmacologists working today. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Anne (Carey) of Oxford, CT ; his three children Arthur of Westport, CT, Lisa of The Netherlands and Kathy of Oxford, CT and their spouses; two sisters, MaryAnn Kelley of Kensington, MD and Florence of Southbury, CT, a brother, Joseph of New York, and eight grandchildren. Calling hours will be held on Thursday, February 18, 2010 at the Southbury Funeral Home of Munson-Lovetere, 235 Main St. North, from 4pm to 7pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church, 733 Oxford Road, Oxford, CT at 11am on Friday, February 19, 2010. Burial will follow in Southford Cemetery, Oxford. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, P.O. Box 9026, Pittsfield, MA 01202 and/or Ann's Place Cancer Support Services, 39 Old Ridgebury Rd., Suite 17, Danbury, CT 06810. To send online condolences, please visit www.munsonloveterefuneralhome.com.

GILGORE--Sheldon G.,MD. February 13, 1932February12, 2010. A leader in the pharmaceutical industry who led some of the nation's top companies and championed patients' rights and product integrity, died at his home in Naples, FL, of pancreatic cancer. He was 77. Known for his innovative marketing strategies and his early work as an endocrinologist who participated in important diabetes research, Dr. Gilgore was one of the very few industry leaders trained as a physician, and this gave him valuable insights into the needs and rights of patients as he continued his career in the pharmaceutical industry. As president of Pfizer Pharmaceuticals from 1971 to 1986, Dr. Gilgore established a reputation as an innovative marketing executive overseeing an unprecedented period of growth and product innovation in Pfizer's evolution. He later would become Chairman, CEO and President of G.D. Searle, succeeding Donald Rumsfeld, from 1986 until his retirement in 1995. His transformative leadership ironically positioned the company to become -- after his tenure -- an acquisition of Pfizer, where he had started his corporate career. Sheldon G. Gilgore was born in Philadelphia, PA, attended Villanova University and graduated from Jefferson Medical School in 1956 at the precocious age of 24. Dr. Gilgore was a past Chairman of PHARMA (the pharmaceutical industry trade organization formerly known as PMA), which flourished under his leadership. Dr. Gilgore's interest in the arts was profound and perhaps best exemplified by an art collection assembled by him and his wife, Irma, who is a highly successful painter. Housed in a private museum that they established, the frequently touring Gilgore Collection is widely viewed as the most important collection of 19th century Italian painting and sculpture outside of Italy. Pieces from their collection have been exhibited at the Chicago Art Institute, the Philadelphia Museum of Fine Arts and the Museum of Contemporary Art, Rovereto, Italy. Future exhibitions include Cologne, Copenhagen and Italy. A former resident of Winnetka, Ill., Dr. Gilgore was a past Board Director of Chicago Lyric Opera and Evanston Hospital. In Philadelphia, the city of his birth, he served on the Board of the Philadelphia Grand Opera. His love of opera led to his founding two opera companies in Connecticut. He served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Clark University in the 1980s and on the board of his alma mater, Jefferson Medical College, where he was honored with their annual "Distinguished Alumni Award" in 1986. He also served as Chairman of Applied Microbiology from 1995 to 1997. Dr. Gilgore's passion for beautiful automobiles, sports and the arts was exceeded only by his love of family, particularly his life partner and wife of 53 years, Irma (maiden name Swartz), who survives Dr. Gilgore. He is also survived by his sons, Lance, Laurence and Lloyd; his daughters-in-law, Debby, Susan and Cathy; his brother, Dr. Gary Gilgore and his wife, Beth; his five grandchildren, Sara, Jenna, Chloe, Jarrett and Erika; and nieces Gayle, Amy and Jan. Funeral services are private. A Memorial tribute will be scheduled in the near future. For further information, contact Fuller Funeral Home at 239-417-5000. In lieu of flowers, donations made to a charity of one's choice would be greatly appreciated.

PRESSLER--Sylvia B.,long time resident of Englewood, NJ died February 15, 2010 at age 75. She is survived by her husband David, daughter Jessica (David), son Noah and grandchildren Rachael, Brandon and Isabella, step-grandchild Sofia. She was retired as presiding judge of the Appellate Division of the Superior Court of New Jersey. She was chairman of the Civil Practice Committee, Law Revision Commission and the Council of Local Mandates, as well as the author of the annotations to the court rules of the state of New Jersey published by Gann Law Books. She was a valedictorian of Hunter High School, graduated from Boston University and Rutgers Law School Class of 1960 where she edited the law review and won seven of the ten graduation rewards for outstanding scholarships. Her professional career was characterized by a continuous driving for excellence and ethics in her own work and the work of her esteemed colleagues, many of whom have distinguished themselves and added to the luster of American law. She will be greatly missed by all, including many who did not know her but benefited by her leadership and illuminating presence as a jurist and tenacious defender of the law and the people it is intended to protect and defend. Services Wednesday, 12noon at Gutterman-Musicant in Hackensack, NJ.

MARCUVITZ--Nathan, 96, died peacefully at home in Naples, Florida, on February 14, 2010. He was an internationally recognized electro-physicist. During WWII he did ground-breaking work at MIT RadLab when a national priority was the rapid development of microwave radar. During that time, he authored the Waveguide Handbook which is still considered a classic work characterizing microwave behavior and is well known to anyone working today in the fields of microwaves or optics. He was a key member of the faculty of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, later renamed Polytechnic Institute of NY. His primary love was his research in electrodynamics, plasma physics and the supervision of the many graduate students who did their doctoral work with him. From 1963-1964, on leave from Polytechnic, he served as Assistant Director of Defense Research and Engineering for the Department of Defense, under Robert McNamara. At Poly he served in several administrative capacities, as Director of the Microwave Research Institute, Chairman of the Department of Electrophysics and as acting Dean of the Graduate School, but was always drawn back to his research and graduate teaching activities. In 1965 he became an Institute Professor, the first appointment of this kind at Polytechnic. In 1966 he joined the faculty of the School of Engineering and Science at New York University as a Professor of Applied Physics. He returned in 1973 to the newly-merged Polytechnic Institute of New York with the same position and became an emeritus professor in 1979. He was the author of numerous technical papers, book chapters and reports in electromagnetic and plasma wave dynamics. In addition to authoring the Waveguide Handbook he coauthored, with Leo Felson, Radiation and Scattering of Waves, published in 1973. He was a member of the National Academy of Engineering and was the recipient of the Microwave Career Award of the IEEE Microwave Theory and Techniques Society in 1985 and received the IEEE Heinrich Hertz Award in 1989 for fundamental theoretical and experimental contributions to the engineering formulation of electromagnetic field theory. He received an honorary degree from the Politecnico Di Torino in 1993 and an honorary degree from Polytechnic University in 2000. He is survived by his beloved wife of 63 years, Muriel (Spanier), his adoring children Andrew (Eileen), and Karen Levy (Paul) and the true joys of his life his grandchildren, Rebecca (Darren), Charlotte, Alexis and Adam and great-grandchildren, Hannah and Olivia. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, February 17, at 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia - Women's hockey will continue in future Olympics, although measures may be taken to modify the one-sided nature of the tournament, René Fasel, president of the International Ice Hockey Federation, said Thursday during a news conference at Canada Hockey Place.
In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why it's never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

It is a small note on the major league landscape on Thursday, but discouraging just the same. Joel Hanrahan, a reliever for the Pittsburgh Pirates, has a flexor-pronator strain in his right elbow and will start the season on the disabled list.

Remember an online prank last fall from a Manhattan restaurant, generating real-looking receipts that were offered up as a way to pad expense accounts? Some of the folks behind it are back with a Web site that generates realistic-seeming "hand scans."

Aside from the technical categories - sound editing and the like - foreign-language and short films are often the downfall of most people's Oscar pools. Well, the Bagger is looking out for you. Before you place your bets, we'll help you do a little self-education (or point you to others with the same impulse). At the In Contention blog, Kris Tapley breaks down the foreign-language films, which are somehow ripe for upset every year (last year's winner was the little-seen Japanese film "Departures").

About 13 percent of Americans think it's O.K. to cheat on income taxes, a slight increase from the previous year, according to a new survey from the Internal Revenue Service Oversight Board covered in this Economix blog post.

Overview | What are the elements of a scene? How does deconstructing scenes reveal meaning? In this lesson, students start to think like film directors by storyboarding an experience from their lives. They then examine the Times Movies feature "Anatomy of a Scene" and develop their own analyses of scenes from film and literature.

Juliet Kinsman is the editor-in-chief of Mr & Mrs Smith, a London-based company that books high-end hotels and travel experiences for a global membership of travel connoisseurs. In addition to publishing a series of guidebooks and tending to the needs of members, Kinsman regularly writes about travel and interior design for newspapers and magazines on both sides of the Atlantic. She lives in London - but her Canadian passport can attest to extended stays in Athens, North Africa, India and on New York's Lower East Side. This week, from a laptop somewhere in the world, Kinsman shares her insider's view on what's driving gallivanters now.
The topic was weighty: how music can save the world.

The Cleveland Browns surprised no one by releasing running back Jamal Lewis this week. The 30-year-old workhorse said last season that he would retire in 2010. However, in a recent statement, Lewis said, "I plan to evaluate my future and have not made a final determination on whether I will be playing football next season."

Two theater productions lead the cultural parade this weekend: Lost in Yonkers," by Neil Simon at the Paper Mill Playhouse and "Much Ado About Nothing" by a fellow by the name of William Shakespeare at SOPAC.

Speculation is rampant about Philadelphia's quarterback situation. The latest news: no contract extension for Kevin Kolb (and probably none soon, as he'll be a restricted free agent in 2011); Michael Vick might not be traded until the preseason (it would cost the Eagles $1.5 million in roster bonus money to keep him that long); and Donovan McNabb may or may not be dealt (nothing new here).

Theatergoers who want to see the actors Keir Dullea ("2001: A Space Odyssey") and Marsha Mason ("The Goodbye Girl") show their stuff up close will have an opportunity when they play the parents in the coming Off Broadway revival of "I Never Sang for My Father" at the 99-seat Clurman Theater at Theater Row.

Bigger, shinier and with more moving parts: those could be the key words for this year's Oscars. They certainly apply to the telecast's set, which was revealed on Wednesday by the designer, David Rockwell. With a quarter-moon curtain made of 100,000 Swarovski crystals, three revolving platforms, multiple rotating L.E.D. panels, architecture metal work and mirrors, the set is more complex than ever, according to the show's producers, Adam Shankman and Bill Mechanic. Mr. Rockwell, who also designed the stage last year, was inspired by his childhood in Mexico, as well "the optimism of modernism in L.A. and the heyday of Hollywood," he said, according to The Los Angeles Times. The design is meant to encompass the basic elements of moviemaking -- light and movement -- as well as frame the hosts, Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin, and involve the audience in the theater. But capturing it for the audience at home won't be easy.

Out here in Napa Valley the thermometer hit 80 degrees yesterday. I put the top down on the baby-blue Mustang and lit out, care free, whizzing by the mustard flowers blooming a brilliant yellow between the rows of healthy vineyards. Slushy New York seems far, far away at the moment.

One Police Plaza reported last week that 2009 would likely break the record for the annual number of street stops carried out by city officers -- so-called stop and frisks. The total is important because, in a city of 8.4 million people, it is a rough reflection of how many citizens are stopped, questioned and sometimes frisked in encounters that can lead to their being arrested or given a summons. (Some citizens can be stopped more than once in a year.)

The critically praised production of the new play "Venus in Fur" will extend for a second time, for three additional weeks, becoming the longest-running play in the 42-year history of the Off Broadway theater company the Classic Stage Company, the troupe's leaders announced on Thursday afternoon.
Virginia's attorney general, Ken Cuccinelli, filed a petition Tuesday asking the Environmental Protection Agency to reconsider its finding that global warming poses a threat to people.

In an Op-Ed piece in Wednesday's Times, Lara M. Dadkhah writes that American and NATO military leaders - worried that the key to winning the war is the Afghan population's goodwill - have largely relinquished the strategic advantage of air dominance.

Nicole Polizzi, the diminutive reality star who will be known for time immemorial as Snooki, may be shrewder than audiences give her credit for: according to documents published by TheSmokingGun.com, Ms. Polizzi, the "Jersey Shore" cast member, has filed the paperwork to trademark the name Snooki for future uses that may include a book project. In a Feb. 7 filing with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, representatives for Ms. Polizzi - who, by the way, resides in New York and not New Jersey - asked to trademark her nickname for "entertainment in the nature of personal appearances by a television personality" and "printed matter, namely books." (Ms. Polizzi's other handle, Snickers, is already in use by someone else.) Earlier this month, TheSmokingGun.com published documents showing that Ms. Polizzi's "Jersey Shore" cast mate Mike Sorrentino has sought a trademark for the Situation, a nickname that he uses for himself and his abdominal muscles.

President Obama officially created an 18-member commission to propose ways by Dec. 1 to reduce the growing national debt. He named its Republican and Democratic co-chairmen as Congressional Republican leaders agreed, reluctantly, to participate in the effort.

Mr. Benson's photos, particularly his early black-and-white images, are masterly studies in the use of natural light, and I wanted to ask him for tips on shooting in low-light situations. I was going to write something elegiac about the sale of Duane Reade, an emotionally complicated New York institution, but then it seemed as if most everything had been said already. It remains to be seen whether the sushi and the Delish brand will stay, or what will happen to the much-derided new logo. But I never did feel as passionately about the place pro or con as the blogger behind I Hate Duane Reade seems to. I mean, have you been to a Rite Aid?

It's remarkable when a product stays on top of its game for 20 years, and Adobe Photoshop had done just that. The first version of Photoshop shipped on Feb. 19, 1990, at a price of $895. Today it's the go-to tool for professional photographers and graphic designers, and it is used by 10 million people around the world, according to Adobe.

Josh Tyson is now a father of two. He and his wife, Nicole, welcomed a second son, Arius, about a month ago, making Elias a big brother. Josh has written for Motherlode before about merging the old and the new, the person you were before children with the person who is raising children, the child you once were with the parent you are becoming.

Robert Polet, the president and chief executive of Gucci Group, announced on Thursday that the Alexander McQueen label will continue, in response to questions about its future since the designer's death last week.

The Federal Trade Commission has settled with Ticketmaster over complaints that Ticketmaster used deceptive tactics to steer Bruce Springsteen fans to expensive scalped tickets last year. As part of the settlement, the company will pay refunds and, in a move that could have a wide impact on the multibillion-dollar resale business, make disclosures about the availability of the tickets it resells.
Hutchison Telecommunications International, the company run by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, said Thursday that it would postpone reporting its annual results.

In the two full days now that Formula One testing has resumed in Spain, the predicted bad weather has again made it impossible to tell who is really on top.  Yesterday Sebastian Vettel, Lewis Hamilton and Felipe Massa were first, second and third fastest in what seemed to carry some sense of logic to it.  But today, Reubens Barrichello in the Williams and Vitaly Petrov in the Renault were first and second fastest and Vettel was third fastest.  Massa was down to fifth fastest and Hamilton was lost at the bottom of the time sheets.   So still no conclusions, thanks largely to the mixed weather conditions.

The Conservative Political Action Conference opened Thursday morning in Washington, and one leitmotif has emerged as an early favorite: noting that President Obama likes to use a teleprompter when delivering a speech. It was mentioned by David Keene, the head of the American Conservative Union, in his introductory remarks; by Stephen Baldwin, of the famous Baldwin brothers, as part of an attack on Mr. Obama; and by Marco Rubio, the Tea Party-backed candidate who is challenging Gov. Charlie Crist for the Republican senatorial nomination in Florida. Mr. Rubio is clearly a star of the gathering here.

While the Battle of Marja has so far displayed how the ongoing troop surge in Afghanistan has given Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal additional flexibility in manpower by pushing into Taliban-held territories, the forthcoming months will indicate if the proposed complementary civilian surge was merely a talking point or an actual enabler.
Eight of the 10 American missionaries jailed last month for trying to take children out of the country were freed Wednesday.

Oxford University opened nominations on Thursday for the position of professor of poetry, The Guardian reported, less than a year after embarrassing scandals caused one prominent poet to withdraw his candidacy and a second to resign shortly after she assumed the post. In May, the Nobel Prize winner Derek Walcott, top left, withdrew from an election for the professorship after anonymous packages were sent to Oxford academics, containing copies of pages from "The Lecherous Professor," a book that described decades-old acts of sexual harassment that he allegedly committed. Days later, Ruth Padel, above bottom, became the first woman in over 300 years to win the seat. But she quickly resigned after it was learned she sent e-mail messages alerting reporters about "The Lecherous Professor."

The Simon Property Group's unsolicited $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties didn't come as a surprise to industry analysts, who saw the nation's biggest mall operator storing up cash and raising equity over the past year.

The European Union as a whole will meet its goal of 20 percent renewable energy by 2020, according to an analysis by the European Wind Energy Association -- though some individual countries will fall short of their individual production targets, while others now report they will exceed them.

Based on the overnight ratings, NBC's coverage of the Winter Olympics on Wednesday night did not just beat "American Idol" on Wednesday night- it trounced the previously unbeatable singing competition. Jurors in the Michael Mineo police brutality trial asked Thursday morning to review all the physical evidence in the case, and to receive readbacks of the testimony of two officers called by prosecutors to support their charge that Mr. Mineo was sexually abused by police officers at a subway station in Brooklyn in October 2008.
Gary Ginsberg, a politically connected former top adviser to Rupert Murdoch, is joining Time Warner.

Mayor Moves Toward Run for Lieutenant Governor | On Wednesday, Gavin Newsom, the San Francisco mayor, filed a ballot statement with the Secretary of State's office to indicate his interest in seeking the lieutenant governor's post vacated when John Garamendi won a seat in Congress. Mayor Newsom has not made a final determination if he will run and has until March 12 to decide, said an adviser. Still, his statement sounded like he was throwing his hat in. "I'm running for Lieutenant Governor because it's time for us to finally shake up Sacramento and reform state government," read the opening lines. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

Derivatives, trickiest of securities, have been in the news a lot since Greek debt, and all the ways that Greece tried to hide it, have made the headlines, with The New York Times running an extensive piece as recently as this weekend.

If there's a magic spell that can keep J. K. Rowling's name out of lawsuits - Litigio Impedimenta, maybe? - the "Harry Potter" author hasn't mastered it yet. On Thursday, Ms. Rowling said a plagiarism lawsuit filed against her by the estate of another author was "unfounded" and "absurd" after Ms. Rowling's name was added to the case as a defendant, Reuters reported. The estate of Adrian Jacobs, an author who died in 1997, began proceedings against Ms. Rowling and the publisher Bloomsbury, which releases the "Harry Potter" novels in Britain, saying that "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire," the fourth novel in Ms. Rowling's series, was plagiarized from Jacobs's 1987 book, "The Adventures of Willy the Wizard - No 1 Livid Land." In a statement, Ms. Rowling said she was "saddened that yet another claim has been made that I have taken material from another source to write 'Harry.' " She said she had not heard of the Jacobs book before the accusations were made by the estate, and never read it, adding: "We will be applying to the court immediately for a ruling that the claim is without merit and should therefore be dismissed without delay."
One aspect of New York's economy that the financial crisis and recession did not shake is the relatively strong grip labor unions have in the state.

What do you serve at a dinner party for "Food, Inc.," the Oscar-nominated documentary about the evils of agri-business? Especially when it's hosted by Martha Stewart? A healthy buffet and "eco-friendly" cocktails, apparently, along with pigs-in-blankets for the likes of the restaurateur Drew Nieporent, who turned up at the party at the Monkey Bar, along with the documentary filmmaker Albert Maysles and others on Tuesday night.

With the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act measures that have been subsidizing Small Business Administration loan programs scheduled to conclude by the end of the month, the S.B.A. announced Tuesday that it was "finalizing plans for an orderly transition" back to loans with higher fees and lower guarantees.

Environmental advocates are expressing concern over the potential impact of oil discoveries in western Uganda's Lake Albert region, thought to total as much as 1.7 billion barrels.

President Obama meets with a set of somewhat disparate guests at the White House this morning - welcoming Alan K. Simpson and Erskine Bowles, the co-chairmen of the new bipartisan commission on fiscal responsibility, before sitting down with the Dalai Lama.

Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, '98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.
He was discovered by the police around 8 p.m. Tuesday, lying in the snow in Harlem, unresponsive. The police did not know who he was or how he got there.

"I relish being compared to a dictator," said the musician Gonzales, whose piano-based albums - which range from rap to classical to soft rock - have been compared to Mao's cultural revolution. Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco has given the strongest indication thus far that he will run for lieutenant governor of California.
Highlights from Thursday's media coverage in The New York Times:

Mickey Thompson, the great racing superstar, did not limit himself to one motorsports arena. He built cars for the Indianapolis 500 and funny cars for drag racing, and he put together trucks for off-road competition. But he may be best known for his many land-speed achievements.

On Thursday, Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner who was briefly poised to lead the Department of Homeland Security, is expected to be sentenced to two to three years in prison following his guilty plea to eight felony charges, including tax fraud and lying to White House officials.

President Obama's delayed meeting with the Dalai Lama today is notable for how delicate it is diplomatically. It has already angered China's leadership who regard Tibet as an internal problem, and the Obama administration is trying to minimize the focus on it. They're keeping the media away and only plan to release a summary of the meeting, as well as an official photograph.

Buyers, be patient. Even as American International Group considers keeping its derivatives portfolio, Citigroup is said to face obstacles auctioning off it real estate asset management unit, sources told Reuters.

Actavis has severed ties with Sweden's EQT in a bid for German drug maker Ratiopharm, Reuters reported.

The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the biggest U.S. public pension fund, released late on Wednesday a list of 11 firms with which it has invested that did not reply to its request for information on their use of placement agents, who are at the center of a probe of New York's pension fund, Reuters reported.

Swiss Re can apparently see the light of the end of the tunnel when it comes to repaying a costly convertible loan from Warren E. Buffett, Reuters reported.

Paige Miles, that's who. That's not an order so much as an inevitability. Today's idea: Even though crime rates have consistently declined over the years - even in this recession - most Americans believe they are rising. Blame cognitive biases that are prone to political manipulation.

With the Fortress Investment Group reportedly behind on a $524 million loan payment for the company that owns the Whistler ski resort, home of some of the Winter Olympics competitions, creditors have scheduled a Friday auction smack-dab in the middle of the Olympic games, The Associated Press said.

Nearly two weeks after reports emerged that the American International Group had struck a deal with Barclays to keep profiting from certain complex derivatives, The Financial Times said Thursday that the bailed-out American insurer had plans to keep a portfolio of the securities worth as much as $500 billion.

Australia's Arrow Energy said Tuesday that it planned to sell 20 percent of its overseas assets in an Asian initial public offering, and Deutsche Bank is betting that the I.P.O. could net the gas producer as much as 310 million Australian dollars ($278 million), Bloomberg News reported.

The provocative photographer and filmmaker Shirin Neshat has been exploring identity through her art for more than 30 years. Though she is based in New York, her main focus has been her native Iran, especially the situation of Iranian women - until now. In "Games of Desire," an exhibition at La Fábrica Galería (Calle Alameda, 9; 34-91-360-1325; lafabricagaleria.com) that runs through March, Ms. Neshat turns from the Middle East to Laos.
The dire warnings of a London hedge fund exodus due to plans by the British government to levy heavier taxes on the industry may be overdone -- at least, according to a Reuters report.

Nathan Myhrvold wants to shake up the marketplace for ideas. His mission and the activities of the company he heads, Intellectual Ventures, a secretive $5 billion investment firm that has scooped up 30,000 patents, inspire admiration and angst, The New York Times's Steve Lohr writes.
A day after BNP Paribas reported its latest profit in a streak, Société Générale came out with its quarterly and full-year earnings showing it was also in the black.
Several years ago, Greg Whisenant unsuspectedly opened the door of his apartment building for a burglar, who then ripped off several of his neighbors.

"Every respectable closet in New York has one or seven items bought in haste at a Barneys New York Warehouse Sale," Jon Caramanica writes. "For decades, the sale has been feeding the helpless as much as those in the know, probably more so. But while watching the schlubby can make for fun sport, it doesn't hold a candle to the dandy trainspotting: hip-hop hipsters checking out plaid-accented Pendleton down vests; model boys rummaging through the bins of tiny-waisted jeans, hoping for a score; European tourists fiddling with iridescent Dior and Lanvin shoes; dyed-in-the-wool sartorial conservatives looking to buy dark suits, plastic-wrapped shirts and striped ties en masse in preparation for another 12 months of doing battle with a Bloomberg terminal." Leave your pride at the door and scrounge like the rest of them for hidden treasures like angora sweaters from Marc by Marc Jacobs, discounted Alexander McQueen shirts, Gucci jeans and Dries Van Noten blazers. "This scavenger hunt is held twice a year — the current one runs through Feb. 28 — with absolutely no guarantees: Success here comes only with tenacity, tolerance and luck."

WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia Shaun White won the gold medal in the men's halfpipe competition at Cypress Mountain, with a first run score of 46.8 that routed the competition and a second that was even better -- a coronation for back-to-back Olympic gold medals. Finland's Peetu Piiroinen was the only one to put serious pressure on White, with a second run score of 45.0. He finished with the silver medal.

GOLDMAN--Dr. Mitchell A.,age 65, passed away on February 16 after a courageous battle with cancer. Mitch was the consummate family man and professional. His dedication to wife Barbara and daughter Amy, as well as his parents Leo and Beatrice Goldman, sister Laura Chasin and extended family formed the nucleus of his life. Mitch was our leader and guiding light whose interest and care for his families both at home and at work was inspirational. One of the most respected radiologists in the country, Mitch was on staff for 34 years at North Shore University Hospital, the last 12 years as Chairman of the Departments of Radiology at NSUH and Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Mitch trained multiple generations of radiologists and will be remembered as a beloved and dedicated mentor, friend and colleague. He was a former President of the NYS Radiology Society and was inducted as a Fellow of the American College of Radiology in 1990, an honor bestowed on only 10% of the radiologists in the country. Mitch graduated from Queens College, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and was Chief Resident of Diagnostic Radiology at McGill University's Royal Victoria Hospital. Funeral will be held on Friday, February 19, 2010, 11:30am, at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the NSLIJ Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021 for a fund in Dr. Goldman's memory to be determined by the family. In addition to his wife of 37 years, daughter, devoted parents and sister, Mitch is survived by his in-laws and six nieces and nephews. Mitch will be remembered by all the people whose lives he touched for his boundless energy and optimism, his sense of humor and enthusiasm for life, and his passionate love of food. We will miss you. Your place will always be set at our table.

GIVEN all the gear required for skiing, socks can be an afterthought. But socks that are designed for skiing -- and ski boots -- can help make a day on the slopes more comfortable. Ski-specific socks must provide warmth and insulation without bulk so they fit into ski boots, which are tight around the foot, ankle and calf. Wicking materials keep the foot cool, while strategically placed padding can help cushion common pressure points in the toe, heel and shin. Ski socks are calf length to maximize protection and comfort, and some have ribbing meant to fight muscle fatigue.

GOLDMAN--Alan J.,of White Plains, NY on February 16, 2010 at age 77. Beloved husband of Phyllis Goldman for 52 years, father of Bruce Goldman, Michael Goldman and Terri Shapiro, father-in-law of Linda, Karen and Rob, grandfather of Nina, Emily, Julia, Sam, Alanna, Jackson and Jason, brother of Elliot Goldman and brother-in-law of Jill. Owner of Goldman's Yarn Stores of Westchester, the Bronx and Brooklyn, a retail chain founded by his father that was a favorite destination for customers for generations. His sharp mind, consideration, and commitment to family and friends will be missed by all. Services on Friday, February 19th at 12pm at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains. Donations in his memory may be made to the Homeless and Hungry Fund of Temple Israel Center of White Plains, or to a charity of your choice.

Fisher-Price has been showing its new iXL Learning Systems (pronounced ''I excel''), an $80 touch-screen edu-game platform for preschoolers coming in June. Can it dethrone the Leapster, which is rumored for major redesign? Will it compete with your child's urge to smudge up your phone's touch screen?

KROLL--Arthur H. Passed away this past Monday morning. He was 70 years old. Born in New York, he graduated from Cornell University and St. Johns Law School, where he was an editor of the law review. He had a distinguished legal career where he became an outstanding specialist in ERISA, Tax and Executive Compensation. He spent many years at Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler as a senior partner and rainmaker. He then continued his practice at Pryor Cashman. In his later years, he served as a consultant to some of the most important executives in business. He published many books and articles and was a mentor to some of the most distinguished lawyers practicing throughout the country. He and his wife, Lois (Handmacher) have lived in Scarsdale NY for 44 years where they raised two children, Douglas and Pamela, whom he adored. Douglas passed away from Leukemia (AML) in 2002. It then became his mission to continue his son's work to find a treatment, if not a cure, for this disease. He worked tirelessly with the Leukemia and Lymphoma society, where he raised well over $1,000,000 to fund outstanding doctors dedicated to this effort. He had two grandchildren, DJ and Stephen, who were the apples of his eye. Arthur had a great zest for life, and nothing could get him down. He also served many years on the boards of the Westchester chapter of the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society and Student Advocacy. He also, with the support of his daughter, son-in-law Alan Winnikoff and daughter-in-law Lucy Kroll Treadwell set up a scholarship at the Youth Counseling League of the Jewish Board of Children and Family Services, where his son had been a beloved social worker. The scholarship is awarded to worthy clients of YCL who have graduated from high school and wish to continue their education. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, February 18 at 12noon at the Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, (914) 946-8851. Family will receive visitors following the service and on Friday, Saturday and Sunday at their home in Scarsdale from 1-5pm. Donations in lieu of flowers, can be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society of Westchester (Douglas Kroll Research Program) c/o KST Consulting Group, 250 Hartsdale Avenue, Suite 30, Hartsdale, NY 10530 or Youth Counseling League of Jewish Board of Children and Family Services, (JBFCS/Youth Counseling League, Attn: Douglas Kroll Scholarship, 9th Floor, 120 W. 57th St. New York, NY 10019).
LANDAU--Eva J. Feb. 18, 1982. Who found well deserved rest and peace 28 years ago today. Your loving son, Robert

Canon has extended the capabilities of its EOS Rebel consumer D.S.L.R.'s with the new EOS Rebel T2i, which brings some of the features of the midrange EOS 7D to the starter camera space. The new EOS Rebel T2i will be available for $800 (body only) or $900 packaged with a Canon EF-S 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 IS zoom lens. That looks like a pretty sweet deal, considering that its features fall somewhere between those of the $800 EOS Rebel T1i and the $1,699 EOS 7D.

FREEDMAN--Michael, M.D. The Board of Directors of WJCS mourns the passing of one of its members Michael Freedman, M.D. Our sincere condolences go to his wife Cora and their family. Michel Araten, President Alan Trager, CEO

Teemu Selanne, playing in his fifth Winter Games, tied the Olympic hockey career scoring record by registering an assist in Finland's 5-1 victory over Belarus in the teams' opener at Canada Hockey Place. A 39-year-old Anaheim Ducks forward playing in his final N.H.L. season, Selanne helped set up a goal by Olli Jokinen 3 minutes 24 seconds into the game. That gave Selanne 36 career points on 20 goals and 16 assists.

QUITT--Dr. Leonard E.,91, died February 14. Prominent dentist, dedicated violinist, proud military officer. Loving, devoted husband, father, grandfather. Survived by wife of 62 years, Beatrice, son Jonathan (Cindy), grandsons Alexander and Daniel.

HAYES--Dr. Arthur Hull, Jr. The Board and staff of the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation extend our heartfelt sympathies to Arthur's wife, Barbara Anne, their children and spouses, and their grandchildren. FREEDMAN--Michael L. We mourn the passing of our long-time colleague Dr. Michael Freedman. Mike, The Diane and Arthur Belfer Professor of Medicine, established the Division of Geriatrics at NYU. His work at NYU since 1963 benefited students, colleagues and patients for generations, and will for decades to come. Among his many roles, Mike was the devoted Chief of the Linda Laubenstein Firm for teaching medical students. A distinguished scientist, educator, and physician, Mike left an indelible mark and will be missed by all. We extend our condolences to his wife Cora, and children Deborah and Steven Shapiro, and Lawrence Freedman, and to his beloved granddaughters. Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center

Online dating may not be as complicated as the final season of ''Lost,'' but trying to decipher the clues and signals of a digital suitor can be just as tricky. As I report in an article on Saturday, OkCupid, a dating site, has been analyzing the habits and patterns of its members to figure out what does and doesn't work on its site.

EIDENSCHENK--Erich. Partners, colleagues and staff mourn the loss of a kind physician, a skilled radiologist and a congenial and caring friend with the death of Dr. Erich Eidenschenk. In 1962, Dr. Eidenschenk began his career at Lenox Hill Hospital and was a founding partner of Lenox Hill Radiology & Medical Imaging Associates PC in 1988. None of us will ever know a more humane, compassionate person and true gentleman. We extend our profound condolences to Erich's wife Emme, and daughters Alexandra and Cybelle. He will be missed. Services Friday, February 19, 5-8pm, C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 East Ridgewood Ave., Ridgewood, NJ 07450 201-445-0344. Donations in lieu of flowers, should be made to the USO Organization. USO.org 1-800-876-7469.

Several men's figure skating competitors have publicly stated that the winner must execute a quadruple jump, the most difficult jump. But in Tuesday's short program, many who have done quads in the past chose instead to do triples, which can earn them higher scores than a poorly executed quad. Of the five who planned to do a quad, only one, Yevgeny Plushenko from Russia, was rewarded for the risk. The penalty for falling on a quad was increased in 2008, making it even more of a risk. Weighing the Risks

No one disputes the difficulty of cross-country skiing, but even some of its participants acknowledge that it leans toward the geeky end of the sports spectrum. The Olympic sprint races on Wednesday in Whistler were an attempt by the sport to adopt at least a bit of the X Games ethos. Kikkan Randall of Alaska placed eighth, the best cross-country skiing result by an American woman at any Olympics.

MY neighbor Bea produces no garbage. I am serious. None. It's like some kind of amazing magic trick. Bea has a husband, two sons (ages 10 and 8) and a dog, and yet her household generates no empty containers, no food scraps, no dirty paper towels, no broken toys, no crumpled wrapping paper, no empty ketchup packets from fast-food restaurants, no orphan socks with holes in the toes.

A small plane crashed into a residential neighborhood in East Palo Alto on Wednesday morning, killing three employees of Tesla Motors, the California electric car company, and causing widespread power failures, officials said. The twin-engine Cessna 310 crashed in foggy weather shortly after takeoff from Palo Alto Airport. It either struck or clipped three transmission lines, disabling a 100-foot electrical tower. The names of the victims were not released.

''That was 60 years ago.''

VANCOUVER, British Columbia -- Canada spent almost $120 million in an effort to win more medals than any other country at the Vancouver Games. After the first week of the Olympics, the Own the Podium Program has received a mixed return on its investment. Though Alexandre Bilodeau won Canada's first gold medal on home soil in men's moguls, the home country is fourth in the medals standings with seven. That's more than $14 million a medal; presumably though gold and silver are worth more than bronze.

Olympic gold has a way of transcending issues and in Vancouver, America's stellar and growing medal count is helping heal the wounds of a United States Olympic Committee on the mend. America's athletes, performing with dignity and acting with humility, are helping polish its image. U.S.O.C. President Larry Probst, a newcomer to the Olympic world, has been working tirelessly since declaring he was "all in" with the effort to build new bridges with the international Olympic community.

So the core CPI -- consumer prices excluding food and energy -- fell for the first time since 1982. But that could be just a blip. Also, core CPI has been behaving erratically lately, making me doubt whether it's still a good guide to underlying inflation (by which I mean the trend in prices that, unlike commodity prices, have a lot of inertia).

The lasting image of the 1970 N.B.A. finals is a hunched over Willis Reed limping onto the floor at Madison Square Garden during the warmups before Game 7. Reed, who tore a thigh muscle in Game 5, had sat out Game 6 and his status for the deciding game was up in the air until the minute that he came out of the tunnel. Even the Lakers stopped warming up to watch Reed, whose appearance in uniform drove the Garden faithful crazy.

If the new barter economy means that you can trade a Dries Van Noten winter coat for last summer's Marni sandals, things can't be that bad. ReFashioner, a new invitation-only Web site, lets you swap your unwanted designer and vintage clothes for other couture castoffs. Kate Sekules, a New York writer, editor and Comme des Garçons addict, said the site was created for women who love "good designers and good design - and who like turnover." No money is exchanged, though a $5 fee is charged per trade. And while you wait to receive an invite from Anna Wintour, you can window-shop at refashioner.com.

Juliet Kinsman is the editor-in-chief of Mr & Mrs Smith, a London-based company that books high-end hotels and travel experiences for a global membership of travel connoisseurs. In addition to publishing a series of guidebooks and tending to the needs of members, Kinsman regularly writes about travel and interior design for newspapers and magazines on both sides of the Atlantic. She lives in London - but her Canadian passport can attest to extended stays in Athens, North Africa, India and on New York's Lower East Side. This week, from a laptop somewhere in the world, Kinsman shares her insider's view on what's driving gallivanters now.

Critical love is never-ending for Kathryn Bigelow, who won the best director award for "The Hurt Locker" from the London Critics' Circle on Thursday, again besting two of her Oscar opponents, James Cameron and Jason Reitman. Neither of their films, "Avatar" and "Up in the Air" garnered any awards, though other Academy front-runners, including Mo'Nique and Christoph Waltz, continued to rack up the statuettes -- Mo'Nique for her performance in "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire" and Mr. Waltz for his in "Inglourious Basterds." (By this point in the season, the Bagger wishes she had invented some kind of keyboard shortcuts for these statements - maybe a sassy apostrophe for Mo'Nique and a stern but sexy ß for Mr. Waltz. Ms. Bigelow would get a new symbol which would immediately become shorthand for killer-lady-director.)

A common theme among the photojournalists covering the aftermath of the earthquake in Haiti has been a frustration that their pictures cannot capture the immensity of the devastation - its scope, its feel, its smells, its sounds. Perhaps no single photograph could ever be expected to do that. But in his picture of the dump near Cité Soleil, Todd Heisler has conveyed something viscerally. After some moments of reflection, you may find yourself thinking you're looking at a medieval scene. And in a sense you are. There is an uncanny kinship to Bruegel. Specifically, "The Triumph of Death."

One of the main arguments for charter schools is that they will improve the school system as a whole by introducing innovations that traditional schools then adopt. As Twitter's user base continues to grow, the signal-to-noise ratio can become increasingly difficult to sift through. Twitter's new media team has been working to solve this problem -- particularly during major current events like the Super Bowl, the Oscars, and the State of the Union address -- by creating data visualizations based on the chatter and keywords popping up on the social networking service.

In the winter months, with more darkness and creepy fog, I obsess about bike lights, reflecting strips and bike flags, which I use for my children's bicycle trailer. If I could encase my biking operation in neon, I would to do it, even to the point of looking ridiculous. Anything to increase my visibility on the road to drivers. I'm on the hunt for battery-operated Christmas lights to wind up the bike flags.

LAS VEGAS -- Well, he didn't exactly apologize. But President Obama did offer an explanation for his recent controversial remarks about Las Vegas, as well as a tidbit of family news: his mother-in-law is a frequent visitor to the city.
What: Another New York fashion week well and done. Calvin Klein celebrated its women's and men's fall 2010 runway collections with a post-show bash.

This week The Times reported on a new program in which public high schools in eight states will "allow 10th graders who pass a battery of tests to get a diploma two years early and immediately enroll in community college."
Sharon Zukin has a thought or five about what has become of New York City, and her verdict is not great news if you are a lover of cities, and of this one in particular.
Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend's Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

Moved to action by the proposed Anthem Blue Cross premium increases, Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, said Friday that she would introduce legislation to create a "national Medical Insurance Rate Authority" to prevent unfair rate increases by private insurers.

TAMPA, Fla. - The longer Johnny Damon remains unsigned, the more Andy Pettitte can empathize with his soon-to-be-former teammate. Pettitte was in a similar situation last off-season as Damon, rejecting a one-year contract from the Yankees because the money ($10 million, a $6 million pay cut) was not acceptable.

"A Tree Climber Grows in the Bronx" (06:40)For many of us, the workday takes place among cubicles, computers and copy machines. But for arborists, a workday takes place among ropes, trunks and ever-more tenuous branches high in the air. Shayla Harris of The Times assembled this enjoyable and inspiring piece about the training of future arborists under the Million Trees program. The New York City Parks Department seeks to provide young adults with the skills needed for this highly unusual vocation. As the video shows, it is not an easy climb. But those who successfully complete the course may find jobs in one of the city's botanical gardens or with the Central Park Conservancy. (E.O.)
There's no question that frying adds calories to food, but healthful eating doesn't have to mean abandoning fried foods altogether, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this week's Recipes for Health.

Last Saturday evening, as the first day of fighting in Marja between the Taliban and the Marines of Kilo Company, Third Battalion, Sixth Marines was ceasing with the approach of darkness, two Marine platoons converged for the night on a small Afghan compound. The platoons took cover behind the mud walls. The company manned its guns for the night and began to plan its missions for the next day.

This is the second in a series of posts on a proposal to impose municipal fees on college students in New Jersey. An earlier post provided an overview of the matter, and future posts will continue to explore the progress of the proposal, and the issues underlying it.
An environmental group is distributing hundreds of thousands of free condoms with hopes that it will educate the public about the impact of human overpopulation on endangered species.

It's a familiar sight in many casual restaurants: the sign warning patrons against bringing in outside food or beverages. Some offer an explanation -- the health code requires you to consume only those items bought in the restaurant in which you are sitting. (Ah, the cleansing power of money.)

Goldman Sachs has dropped its lawsuit against seven former executives at its private wealth management division who resigned this month to join Credit Suisse, Bloomberg News reports, citing court records.

The long recession that has driven the unemployment rate above 10 percent has been painful for residents of the metropolitan area in many ways. But it has had at least one side benefit: a break in the upward spiral of rents.

"Alles walzer!" With these words, declared by the debutantes at the Vienna Opera Ball, the ballroom floor of the Vienna State Opera house became a colorful mess of swirling gowns and shimmering rhinestones as ballgoers raced for their spot to boogie alongside the newest inductees to Viennese high society.
The Wizarding World of Harry Potter, a theme park set to open this spring at Universal Orlando Resort, announced its first vacation packages for travel starting May 28.

Late Thursday afternoon, after the United States Olympic hockey team's 6-1 victory over Norway (Jeff Z. Klein's Times article), the lingering impression of its efforts from media observers and from within boiled down to this: Despite the flattering five-goal spread, achieved with three third-period goals, this game wasn't the rout the scoreline indicated. And if the Americans were to play the same freewheeling style Sunday, the powerful Canadians would slaughter them.

This week: Ted Conover, author of "The Routes of Man"; The Times's Richard L. Berke revisits Clinton vs. Starr; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)
From Brad Stone at Bits:

In 1988, Jimmy O'Keefe, a native San Franciscan, a car aficionado an a gardener at Golden Gate Park, decided to throw himself a birthday party at Golden Gate Park-and invited other car enthusiasts to join him. That first year, Jimmy's Old Car Picnic attracted around 40 cars to the park's Speedway Meadow. Over the last 21 years, the event has grown substantially, drawing most recently at the October 2009 picnic 800 cars manufactured before 1972.
In an effort to increase enrollment, the Minneapolis College of Art and Design is freezing tuition for one year, Minnesota Public Radio reports.

LAS VEGAS -- City officials here have been demanding an apology from President Obama for two weeks now, ever since the president's off-hand remark during an appearance in New Hampshire that "You don't blow a bunch of cash in Vegas when you're trying to save in college.''

Late Thursday afternoon, after the United States Olympic hockey team's 6-1 victory over Norway (Jeff Z. Klein's Times article), the lingering impression of its efforts from media observers and from within boiled down to this: Despite the flattering five-goal spread, achieved with three third-period goals, this game wasn't the rout the scoreline indicated. And if the Americans were to play the same freewheeling style Sunday, the powerful Canadians would slaughter them.

The Conservative Political Action Conference heard from another likely presidential candidate for 2012 on Friday - Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota. Mr. Pawlenty offered a series of what he called principles for the conservative movement that have become familiar here: Reducing the size of government, opposing President Obama's health care plan, denouncing Mr. Obama's handling of terrorists.

Following is the third and final set of responses from Matthew Bakkom, the editor and creator of "New York City Museum of Complaint," a collection of 132 letters written to the mayor of New York from 1751 to 1969.
While overall deal activity has been relatively sluggish this year, a large number of secondary offerings and cross-border mergers and acquisitions have managed to keep some investment bankers busy.

CHICAGO - Representative Mark Steven Kirk of Illinois, a Republican who is running for President Obama's old Senate seat, said the United Nations' report on Iran gave a "clear and ominous" message that the country was trying to develop a nuclear bomb.
Images from the Newark Museum's exhibit of early 20th-century abstract art.
For all the bold talk at the conservative confab here about taking back Congress in November, one Republican who lost when the majority shifted last time worried that his party might not deserve it.
"Ask an Expert" is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.
First the would-be singers, now the sexy doctors: nothing is standing up to NBC's coverage of the Winter Olympics--not the way several competitors did four years ago, anyway

In addition to releasing four proposed designs for a replacement for the crumbling Kosciuszko Bridge, the State Department of Transportation's Division of Video Games and Special Effects (we made that up) has produced driver's-eye-view simulations of trips across each version of the bridge (we didn't make that up).

The denizens of Madison Avenue, like the residents of so many other streets and avenues around the country, are riveted by Tiger Woods, particularly because of all the money related to his endorsement deals and advertising campaigns.

Prosecutors expect to recommend "extraordinary" leniency for Frank DiPascali Jr., who has admitted being Bernard L. Madoff's crucial lieutenant in history's largest Ponzi scheme, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reports, citing documents made public in federal court in Manhattan on Friday.

Monologue | Thursday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: Spring training started. And the Phillies, look out for the Phillies. They get this guy, Roy Halladay, the best pitcher in all of baseball. But listen to this, the Mets, very competitive. You know who they signed? They signed that guy who threw the shoes at President Bush.
Q.

Monologue | Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: President Obama in Washington today met with the Dalai Lama, despite strong objections from the Chinese government. China considers the Dalai Lama a threat to their sovereignty and warned that if Obama met with him, it would damage U.S.-Chinese relations. They've even threatened to stop sending us poisonous toys.

Overview | Why is Secretary of State Clinton urging an uprising in Iran? What is at stake under Iran's current leadership - for the Iranian people and the rest of the world? In this lesson, students immerse themselves in the complicated issues that have brought growing alarm to the international community. They trace and research the issues, and then create a concept map that connects each issue's causes and effects. Finally, they write an open letter to Secretary Clinton.
Q.

Perhaps the most regular visitor to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts is Greg Sloane, who can be seen nearly every day among the dancers, musicians, actors and culture-mongers who flock to this gem at Lincoln Center.

We have California's Orange County to thank for many things: the Josh Schwartz creations Ryan Atwood and Seth Cohen; the "real" housewives Vicki Gunvalson and Lynne Curtin; the semi-real celebrities Lauren Conrad and Kristin Cavallari; and hot sauce.
At age 22, women and whites are more likely to be on a track leading toward higher educational achievement than men and racial minorities are, according to new data from the Labor Department.
Luring the team behind No. 7, the highly regarded restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to open a sub shop in the Ace Hotel in Manhattan took time.
3:13 p.m. | Updated Representative Brad Ellsworth, an Indiana Democrat, announced on Friday that he will go after the Senate seat being vacated by Democrat Evan Bayh.

Advocates for Palestinian rights have called for a boycott of the Israel Ballet, which is performing Sunday at Brooklyn College. The advocates say there will be protests at the college's Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts to denounce what they call Israel's "apartheid and colonial policies," part of a broader call by some critics of Israel's treatment of Palestinians for a boycott of Israel in cultural and academic circles. The protest was announced on Friday by the group Adalah-NY: The Coalition for Justice in the Middle East. Israel's Batsheva Dance Company faced similar protests during an American tour last year.
Diplomacy can be fun to watch because diplomats often seem to be trained to say negative things in the most polite and convoluted ways, presumably so as not to offend.
New Jersey native and Olympic ice dancer Allison Reed will be skating for the Republic of Georgia; her siblings will be competing against her for Japan.

The Chinese poet Bei Dao, born in Beijing in 1949, has long been mentioned in the West as a potential Nobel laureate, but it's been hard to get to know his work well: curiously, there's been no career-spanning volume of his poetry available in English. That situation is rectified now with the publication of "The Rose of Time: New & Selected Poems" (New Directions, $16.95), edited by the critic and translator Eliot Weinberger.

Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, has a cancerous stomach tumor but expects to make a full recovery and continue working during treatments, his office and one of his doctors said on Friday.

Brad Inman wants to bring books into the 21st century. His year-old start-up, Vook (which we've written about here and here), mashes and mixes videos and photos with text to create multimedia books for devices like the iPhone and, soon, the iPad.

Two more potential buyers for Abbey Road Studios have emerged: Andrew Lloyd Webber and his longtime lyricist Tim Rice. In apparently unrelated statements to the British news media, the two men have both expressed interest in buying the studio, which has reportedly been put for sale by EMI.

Sparked by the grunge spirit of the '90s, Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough - both children of Generation X - presented a collection full of cropped, ribbed turtlenecks (very Kate Moss) and psychedelic-print flannels on a girl with messy, natural hair and a strong face. As the makeup artist Diane Kendal explained, "Being younger designers, they find it inspiring how the girls looked then." But like the sharp tailoring and feminine thigh-high stockings in the show, "their interpretation is a bit more sophisticated and polished."

In the case of the fraudulent pinot noir, a group of French wine brokers were convicted of selling to E. & J. Gallo 3.57 million gallons of red wine from the Languedoc that it falsely called pinot noir but in fact was made from a much less expensive grape, Decanter.com reported.  Gallo then sold the wine as pinot noir under its Red Bicyclette brand.
A federal judge on Friday denied [pdf] former State Senator Hiram Monserrate's petition to block his expulsion and halt the special election called for next month to select his replacement.
Justin Taylor is the author of a story collection, "Everything Here Is the Best Thing Ever."
The German industrial giant Ferrostaal will use solar technology from the California startup eSolar in power plants to be built in Europe, the Middle East and South Africa.
A behind-the-wheel simulation of a trip on one of the state's proposed replacement designs for the Kosciuzsko Bridge.
Tiger Woods admitted to his repeated marital infidelities, acknowledged that he has been in therapy and will immediately return to that treatment.

Some coverage today of Andrew Joseph Stack III, the man who crashed a plane into an I.R.S. office in Texas has focused on his complaints about part of the 1986 tax reform act.  That is fair, although it is hard for some of us to feel great sympathy for those who must have taxes withheld like nearly everyone else.
Do you find walking tours too passive, like sitting through a boring lecture.  Wish they were more like "The Amazing Race," the popular CBS reality show?
Come April 1, the federal courthouse in Manhattan will become a much friendlier place for defense lawyers.
Possible steering problems in about 487,000 Toyota Corolla and Matrix models are being investigated by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBook's White Collar Watch
I ate Alaskan troll-caught king salmon three times this week and wondered why I'd waited so long. There is no better finfish.
The fall 2010 collection from Ralph Lauren.

Meryl Streep's Oscar nomination - for portraying a pitch-perfect Julia Child in "Julie & Julia" - surprised absolutely no one (that was Sandra Bullock's territory). In this Sunday's Arts & Leisure, A.O. Scott considers the Streepness of the woman he calls "the best screen actress in the world" and finds that she is in some ways a late bloomer as a star, and that this makes her all the more appealing.

As health care reform continues to twist in the wind, the problems of the current system continue to become more apparent. It is not hard to find anecdotal evidence of small businesses whose insurance rates have jumped 20 or 30 percent. Here's an article about small-business rate increases from October. Here's an article from today's paper about the recent explosion in insurance rates, especially in California but in other states as well.

Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women's Professional Soccer in the league's first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States women's national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team last week by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog before, during and after her trip to Portugal.

In a lawsuit filed in federal court, a school district in suburban Philadelphia has been accused of using a Webcam embedded in a school-issued laptop to covertly photograph a 15-year-old student in his home.

Shake Shack, Danny Meyer's mini-chain of burger-and-custard stands, has dropped plans to open an outlet in NoLIta after community opposition. Read the whole (brief) article on Diner's Journal.

In a review of "The Ricky Gervais Show," which has its debut on HBO on Friday night, Alessandra Stanley initially sets her sights not on the animated series' title personality or his co-star, Stephen Merchant, but on their lesser-known third wheel, Karl Pilkington. She describes Mr. Pilkington as a performer whose "persona is a cross between the deadpan comedian Steven Wright and Cliff Clavin of 'Cheers' - transposed to a Manchester pub," with an accent that "to an American ear" sounds "a little like Ringo Starr under water."

BAGHDAD - Mohammed Kasim cast a hesitant glance down at the rickety benches in Baghdad's Shahbandar Cafe. He was a big man, after all, looking more like a linebacker than an artist. But a few awkward contortions later, he shoehorned himself behind an equally tattered table, sticky from countless spills of sweet tea, and ordered his own.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

When Armando Iannucci, the director and a screenwriter of "In the Loop," heard the news that it had been nominated for an Oscar for best original screenplay, he was in London, about to have lunch with some friends. He never lifted a fork.
This week's Complaint Box features two views on workout annoyances, from Linda Carlson and Raul A. Reyes.

There are two new books on our lists this week and both involve visitors from the realm of fantasy. On our hardcover list, the third volume of the new Thor series lands at No. 8. It features the latest twist in the saga that finds the fabled city of Asgard hanging over Oklahoma. Other less godly legends are present in volume 13 of Fables, which attains No. 1 on our softcover list. On the Moment blog, Oliver Strand tests out the $160 hand-held Twist espresso maker from Mypressi. It works with a blast of nitrous oxide. He likes it a lot. The coffee, not the nitrous oxide.
The Greeks, always happy to put in a good word for olive oil, have conducted a few tests that show olive oil is a great substitute for shortenings filled with trans fat in commercial recipes.

If you could read Gordon Lightfoot's mind right now, what a tale his thoughts would tell. On Thursday, the Canadian news media (not to mention the general population of the Twitterverse) was abuzz with apparent news that Mr. Lightfoot, 71, the smooth-voiced singer-songwriter of "Sundown" and "Carefree Highway," had died while on tour. But like the man sang in "The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald," the legend lives on: Reuters reported that Mr. Lightfoot called into Toronto's CP24 news station to say he was very much alive. "It seems like a bit of a hoax," Mr. Lightfoot said. "I was quite surprised to hear it myself." He added: "I feel fine."

Scripps says its Food Network is drawing so many advertisers that it's starting a new Cooking Channel to soak them up. Lucky them. When company officials first considered starting the second network, they thought it would have programs that actually taught viewers to cook, but then they came to their senses.

The New York Times on Friday named Richard L. Berke, an assistant managing editor, to be the paper's next national editor, replacing Suzanne M. Daley, who will return to being a reporter as a correspondent writing about Europe.
