When a plane crashed outside Buffalo about 10:20 on a Thursday night last year, killing 50 people, aides to Gov. David A. Paterson could not find him for more than three hours, and it was nearly five hours before his office released any statement about what was the deadliest air disaster in the nation since 2001. Mr. Paterson later had difficulty explaining the delay and suggested that when trying to reach him, an aide had been calling the wrong telephone.

Four hydroelectric dams on the Klamath River in Oregon and Northern California will be removed under an agreement that ends decades of fighting between fishermen, farmers, environmental and Native American groups over water and fishing rights.
Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Hanuk.

The Times reported Friday morning that the White House would release a comprehensive health bill before the bipartisan summit scheduled for Thursday. The bill seems likely to include an individual mandate and a version of the excise tax on expensive plans, as well as subsidies for middle-class families to purchase insurance. Also, the reporter Reed Abelson takes a closer look at the numbers driving Anthem's decision to raise rates in California.
President Obama finishes off his swing out West today, holding a town hall meeting and giving a speech to the Chamber of Commerce in Nevada.

Throughout the last few seasons, the 30-year-old designer Matthew Ames has steadily piqued interest in an increasingly tumultuous fashion climate. Gaining esteem for his austere but no less luxurious frocks, the Washington, D.C.-born, Antwerp-trained and New York-based Ames has championed a new minimalism in the face of maximalist hype. T spoke with a curiously calm Ames moments before his fall 2010 presentation at Milk Studios, and later at his garment-district showroom overlooking Bryant Park.
EveryScape, a start-up that builds 3-D, street-level images of big cities for local businesses, has raised $6 million in a third round of financing, MocoNews reports.

Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, '98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.

LAS VEGAS -- President Obama will announce a modest housing initiative during an appearance in Las Vegas on Friday, according to senior administration officials who say the White House has decided to release $1.5 billion from bank bailout funds to help struggling homeowners in five states - Nevada, California, Arizona, Michigan, Florida -- that are hardest hit by the housing crisis.
Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

A Bid to Tax Medical Marijuana | To help close its $14 million budget shortfall this year, the Berkeley city manager has unveiled a plan to tax three medical marijuana dispensaries at a rate of $10 per square foot of the space they occupy. The dispensaries pay the city $20,000 a year in business license fees based on sales. "Taxing sick people's medicine is not the best way to make up their financial shortfall," said Erik Miller, manager of the Patients Care Collective, who opposes the tax. Last year, Oakland voters approved a sales tax on the city's medical marijuana dispensaries and now collects $18 for every $1,000 in sales. [The Oakland Tribune]
It's shaping up to be another seller's market for British financiers, and even bailed-out banks are coming out of a season of cutbacks to beef up their teams again.

Investigators looking into the cause of the airplane crash that killed three Tesla employees on Wednesday have been given an unusual clue, audio recordings made on the ground of the last few seconds of the flight.

Natixis, the French investment bank, is in exclusive talks with Axa to sell its French private equity business, after Axa's buyout unit made a 507 million euro ($685 million) bid for the assets.

Goldman Sachs plans to buy U.S.-based warehouse and logistics company Metro International Trade Services, a Goldman Sachs spokesman told Reuters on Friday, without revealing how much the deal was worth.

A once mysterious fraternal society continues to put itself in the public eye with the opening of the completely renovated Museum of Freemasonry, which opened in a newly renovated location in Paris last week. The Grand Orient de France, the oldest and largest Masonic organization in the country, has been collecting items dating from as far back as the 1720s, around the time that Freemasonry was established in France. It now has 10,000 objects in total, including a collection of 18th-century earthenware that was recently purchased with the help of the French government.
It appears that resistance is growing to a plan by the managers of Japanese steakhouse Benihana to raise money through a share sale.

Chrysler Group is poised to acquire the Sterling Heights, Mich., assembly plant for $20 million from the company that has managed the automaker's remaining assets since its emergency from bankruptcy last year, The Associated Press reported.
Schlumberger, the oil services company, is in advanced talks to acquire another major industry player, Smith International, The Wall Street Journal reported.
An activist shareholder who joined The New York Times Company's board of directors two years ago will relinquish his seat at the end of April, The Associated Press reported.
Eric Wilson looks at the trends that have emerged from the Fall 2010 collections in Bryant Park.
A Japanese term - "the splitter upper" or "separator" - used to describe professionals employed to end relationships.
Clicker, which says it is the "complete guide to Internet Television," has landed $11 million in a fresh round of funding, PaidContent reported.

Kenneth D. Lewis, the former Bank of America chief executive, said he was briefed twice on his company's decision not to disclose rising losses at Merrill Lynch before the bank's takeover of Merrill was put before shareholders, Reuters reports.

Googleplex, the City | As Silicon Valley companies grew, they tended to stay within their own clean campuses, with the cities around them little more than an incidental item on their stationery. But it is different with Google and Mountain View, where the search-engine giant is recreating the 19th-century company town with a 21st-century accent. The union has produced the same mix of plans, dreams and frustration, of civic-corporate boosterism and local concern about the giant in their midst that Henry Ford might have found familiar. For Google, Mountain View is part home and part beta-testing ground. For the city, Google is part economic engine, part benefactor and a soon-to-be real-estate developer with an opportunistic eye for underused assets - like the landing strip at Moffett Field, where jets of Google executives now come and go.
In “Happy Tears,” the writer and director Mitchell Lichtenstein struggles to find the humor in a host of horrors.

Apparently being an NBA superstar, actor, author, Ph.D. student, platinum-selling rapper, reserve police officer and U.S. Deputy Marshal was not enough for Shaquille O'Neal. Now, the 7-foot-1-inch Cleveland Cavalier is venturing into the art world as a gallery curator. His first exhibition, "Size Does Matter," opens today at the Flag Art Foundation in Chelsea. The show, which runs through May 27, explores "the myriad ways that scale affects the perception of contemporary art" and includes works by Chuck Close, Cindy Sherman, Jeff Koons, Kehinde Wiley, Lisa Yuskavage and others. And if that wasn't enough to get your attention, a catalog with an essay by Cleveland native James Frey will accompany the exhibition.

If Twitter's 140-character max limits expression and long-form journalism no longer holds the attention spans of most Internet users, then is Tumblr the happy medium of the World Wide Web? Fans of the platform, not to mention sites like Awkward Family Photos, This Is Why You're Fat, Cake Wrecks and Pets Who Want to Kill Themselves, certainly think so. Tonight, members of the Tumblr community will be at Housing Works for an open bar and live performance to "celebrate writing, reading, and the art of the second draft." Writers Julie Klausner, Choire Sicha, Meaghan O'Connell, Will Leitch, Emily Gould, Matthew Gallaway, Edith Zimmerman, Bailey Kennedy, Halle Kiefer, Melissa Gira Grant, Foster Kamer and Diana Vilibert will all be there to share their work.

"If you were to talk about it in terms of cars, it's like an old, broken-down Buick that you kind of hold together to just get down the road. All of the characters are in a fractured place, broken into pieces, and the pieces don't really fit together. So it feels kind of rickety to me now," Sam Shepard said in a recent interview about his 1985 play "A Lie of the Mind," about families in meltdown, which opened in its first off-Broadway revival on Thursday. The author and actor might have a few kinder words for that old Buick now. In his review of the show, Ben Brantley writes that "a scary, splendid clarity radiates from the terminally confused kinfolk who are running wild at the Acorn Theater." Go tonight to see the eight-member ensemble, directed by Ethan Hawke, give "crystalline, individual forms to a blurred collective sense of self that anyone who has been part of a family is going to identify with" in a production that "connoisseurs of precision acting will be savoring for years to come" and makes the case for "'A Lie of the Mind' as Mr. Shepard's richest and most penetrating play, a 20th-century masterwork of a family portrait to be compared with Eugene O'Neill's 'Long Day's Journey Into Night' and Harold Pinter's 'Homecoming.' "

Commissioner Gary Bettman on Thursday offered the most publicly detailed list of reasons yet for the National Hockey League's longstanding position not to commit to participation in the 2014 Olympics in Sochi, Russia. ''It costs us money; it disrupts our season,'' Bettman said about the N.H.L.'s shutting down for two weeks every four years to take part in the Winter Games. ''The value of the contracts of our players who are here: $2.1 billion. To be at these Olympics we must basically hand over control of our most important asset, our players.''

For a public work named after a champion of liberty, the Kosciuszko Bridge has taken its share of prisoners over the years. The bridge, the hyphen in the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, connecting the two boroughs as it soars 128 feet above the oily murk of Newtown Creek, is perhaps the city's most notorious span, hated and feared by drivers and synonymous in traffic reports with bottlenecks, stop-and-go and general delay. Last September, it topped a construction-industry group's list of the most decrepit elevated roadways in the city.

The words are splayed in silver scribble all over the city, anchoring lampposts, adorning mailboxes, greeting subway riders: ''Papa Loves Baby.'' The graffiti has earned admirers, adversaries and a lot of curiosity. ''Papa Loves Baby has been just killing it,'' the blogger Paul B wrote of the prolific tagging on the Lower East Side. The police say the tag has been sighted not just in Manhattan and Brooklyn, but in other cities on the East Coast. A band based in Binghamton, N.Y., took its name from the tag.

RAMAGE--The Reverend Dr. David Ramage, Jr. died on February 14, 2010 at Arden Courts in Fairfax, Virginia. Dave was born March 7, 1930 to Margaret White Ramage and David Ramage, Jr. in Cincinnati, Ohio. He graduated from Norwood High School in 1948 and Hanover College in 1951. Dave earned a divinity degree from McCormick Theological Seminary in 1955. He was awarded honorary Doctor of Divinity degrees from both Hanover College and Johnson C. Smith University. Dave was ordained by the Presbytery of Chicago in 1957. He then served in Chicago as director of a youth gang action/research project, as a social worker in settlement houses and as pastor of the Emerald Avenue Presbyterian Church. During this time he teamed up with community organizer Saul Alinsky and served on the Board of Alinsky's Industrial Areas Foundation. In 1963 Dave became an executive officer of the Board of National Missions of Churches in New York. He was Executive Director of its Department of Mission Strategy and Evangelism and Chairman of the Division of Church Strategy and Development. During this time, he also served as an adjunct staff member for the World Council of Church's Division of World Mission and Evangelism and the Committee to Combat Racism and the organization staff of the Joint Committee on Society, Development, and Peace of the Council and the Pontifical Commission for Justice and Peace of the Vatican. In 1970 he joined the staff of the Center for Community Change in Washington, DC as vice president for Field Services and in 1971 became its president. The Center is a national community development assistance and social policy research agency. From 1975 to 1985, Dave held executive positions at the New World Foundation in New York City as vice president, executive director, and president. The Foundation gives priority to encouraging effective education and promoting citizen responsibility and involvement in public issues such as peacemaking, community organization and development, and racial and ethnic opportunity. In 1985 Dave became the eighth president of McCormick Theological Seminary. In the summer of 1993 Dave chaired the Meeting of the Council of a Parliament of World's Religions in Chicago. In 1994 Dave retired from his post as president at McCormick Theological Seminary and became a MacArthur Foundation Fellow. Dave and his wife Betty retired to Marco Island, Florida and Reston, Virginia. In 2001 Dave received the Alumni Achievement Award from Hanover College. Dave is survived by his wife, Betty, their four children and their spouses, David and Corinne, Jonathan and Debbie, Elizabeth and Adam, and Daniel and Lynne, ten grandchildren, one great grandchild, his sister, June, his brother, Dan, and a host of nieces and nephews, cousins, relatives and loving friends.

DOOCHIN--Stephen. NARSAD, the Brain and Behavior Research Fund, mourns the passing on February 16, 2010 of our long serving former Executive Director, Stephen Doochin. He brought remarkable skills and effort to meet our goals of finding better treatments and cures for those suffering from mental illness. His compassion, insight and efforts were vital factors in our organization's growth. Our Scientific Council leadership, our Board of Directors and our staff all share the sense of great loss with his family; his wife, Cheryl Sandler, his daughter, Jamie and his son, Brian. NARSAD will initiate a research grant in his name and memory.

BORNSTEIN--Jacob, M.D.,93, passed away peacefully at home on February 18. He was born in 1917 in Chelsea, Massachusetts to parents who had immigrated from Eastern Europe. His life was a tribute to the uniquely American concept of "anything is possible" if you are born here. He graduated from Harvard College (Phi Beta Kappa) in 1938 and from Harvard Medical School in 1942. After serving as a house officer at the Beth Israel Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts he spent three years as an officer in the United States Army during World War II. He came to New York City after the war where he was in the private practice of Internal Medicine for over sixty years. He spent his entire professional career as a staff member of the Department of Medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital, New York, NY. He devoted his entire life to the study and practice of medicine and was completely and unequivocally committed to the care of his patients, who loved and respected him. He is survived by his loving wife, Maida (Seltzer), of over sixty-five years, his son, Harold Bornstein, M.D., his daughters Bonnie (Hyken) and Gail (Wachtel), his daughter-in-law, Melissa (Brown-Bornstein), his sons-in-law, Richard Hyken and Dr. Clifford Wachtel, and ten grandchildren, Kimberly (Boland), Kari (Seletz), and Matthew (Wachtel), Samuel and Lauren (Hyken), Robyn, Joseph, M.D., Alix, Jeremee and Jackson (Bornstein). His medical practice at 101 East 78th Street, New York, NY will be continued in perpetuity by his son and in the future by his grandsons. Funeral services will be held on Friday, February 19th at 9am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The Swiss pilot Beat Hefti, a favorite to win a medal in the two-man bobsled competition, was held out of training runs Thursday after crashing a day earlier, leaving his status questionable for the event. Hefti, a three-time Olympic medalist, crashed at Curve 13, a turn that the American bobsledder Steven Holcomb nicknamed Curve 50-50. His accident was one of eight during the first evening of two-man bobsled training runs. The competition is scheduled to begin Saturday.

GOLDMAN--Alan J.,of White Plains, NY on February 16, 2010 at age 77. Beloved husband of Phyllis Goldman for 52 years, father of Bruce Goldman, Michael Goldman and Terri Shapiro, father-in-law of Linda, Karen and Rob, grandfather of Nina, Emily, Julia, Sam, Alanna, Jackson and Jason, brother of Elliot Goldman and brother-in-law of Jill. Owner of Goldman's Yarn Stores of Westchester, the Bronx and Brooklyn, a retail chain founded by his father that was a favorite destination for customers for generations. His sharp mind, consideration, and commitment to family and friends will be missed by all. Services on Friday, February 19th at 12pm at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains. Donations in his memory may be made to the Homeless and Hungry Fund of Temple Israel Center of White Plains, or to a charity of your choice.

COHEN--Dr. Ira, husband of the late Bernice Kreindler Cohen, beloved father of Amy Cohen, Bonnie and William Rooney, and loving grandfather of Jacob Burack, Meghan and Kevin Rooney, died on February 17, 2010. His passing will be mourned by his many friends, family, and medical colleagues. Services at Frank Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Sunday February 21st at 11am. In lieu of flowers, send donations to the Dr. Ira Bernard Cohen Internal Medicine Fund, Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th Street and 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10003.
DUBA--Frank, Ph.D.,42. Loved and missed by wife, parents, brothers, and many friends.

PICKETT--Dr. Elisabeth P.,1918 - 2010, died at home in Colorado of an acute heart attack on February 14, 2010, four days before her 92nd birthday. Dr. Pickett graduated from the University of Colorado Medical School in 1944 . She was the first woman in the United States to be certified in both general surgery (1961) and in urology (1962). She held multiple concurrent academic positions and was on the staffs of Memorial-Sloan-Kettering and New York Hospitals. She was an instructor in surgery at Cornell University Medical College and associate professor of both surgery and urology at the New York Infirmary. In addition, she headed the spinal cord injury service at Castle Point Veterans' Hospital in New York. In 1995, the Society of Women in Urology established a research scholarship in her name at the annual meeting of the American Urological Association. She is survived by several nieces and nephews. and at the time of her demise was with her niece, Janet Doyle, of Boulder, Co. Memorials may be sent to the Elisabeth P. Pickett Research Award, c/o The Society of Women in Urology, 1100 E. Woodfield Road, Suite 520, Schaumburg, IL, 60173.

EIDENSCHENK--Erich. Partners, colleagues and staff mourn the loss of a kind physician, a skilled radiologist and a congenial and caring friend with the death of Dr. Erich Eidenschenk. In 1962, Dr. Eidenschenk began his career at Lenox Hill Hospital and was a founding partner of Lenox Hill Radiology & Medical Imaging Associates PC in 1988. None of us will ever know a more humane, compassionate person and true gentleman. We extend our profound condolences to Erich's wife Emme, and daughters Alexandra and Cybelle. He will be missed. Services Friday, February 19, 5-8pm, C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 East Ridgewood Ave., Ridgewood, NJ 07450 201-445-0344. Donations in lieu of flowers, should be made to the USO Organization. Aussie! Aussie! Oy-oy-oy!'' It is a common battle cry for Australian sports fans: from cricket matches, to rugby games to swim meets to the stands of Melbourne Park when Lleyton Hewitt is getting ready to serve. But these are the Winter Olympics, no traditional Australian stamping ground unless you find yourself in Whistler.

COHEN--Ira B.,MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of our dear friend and beloved colleague, Ira B. Cohen, MD, one of the longest serving physicians in the hospital's history. Dr. Cohen's career at Beth Israel began in 1948 and continued until his retirement last year, during which time he held many responsible positions, including tenure as Associate Chairman of the Department of Medicine. He also was a longtime member of the hospital's Medical Board and gave tremendously to Beth Israel in many other capacities. Most importantly, he will be remembered for his extraordinary commitment to his patients, many of whom generously supported Beth Israel in his name. He also was steadfastly committed to medical education. The Ira B. Cohen, MD Award is given annually to the house officer who best demonstrates the care and compassion Dr. Cohen exemplified throughout his career. To his daughters, Bonnie Cohen Rooney and Amy Cohen, the entire Cohen family, and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Morton P. Hyman Chairman Emeritus Harris M. Nagler, MD Interim President Robert G. Newman, MD President Emeritus Louise M. Klebanoff, MD President, Medical Board Henry C. Bodenheimer, Jr., MD Chairman of Medicine

The Canadian men's hockey team survived a scare but did not emerge unscathed on Thursday when it beat Switzerland in a shootout, 3-2. The Canadians led by 1-0 at the end of the first period, on a goal by Dany Heatley (his second of the Games), and picked up another from Patrick Marleau early in the second. But then the Swiss, relentless and physical, came back with two goals in the second period.

The Nets will call the Prudential Center in Newark their home for the next two seasons as part of a deal announced Thursday by Gov. Christopher J. Christie. After that, the team plans to move to Brooklyn, where an arena is being built. To get out of their lease early at the Izod Center, the Nets agreed to pay $4 million to their landlord, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The Nets can offset part of that by paying for two suites at the Prudential Center on behalf of the Sports and Exposition Authority, and donating money to Newark Symphony Hall.

Where else but Boston could a musical homage to the Kennedys have its debut? Keith Lockhart, the Boston Pops Orchestra and the Tanglewood Festival Chorus, as well as celebrity narrators, will honor the brothers John, Robert and Edward Kennedy with a new work called ''The Dream Lives On: A Portrait of the Kennedy Brothers'' as part of the Pops' coming season, it was announced. The work, written by Peter Boyer (''Ellis Island'') with lyrics by Lynn Ahrens (''Ragtime''), will be performed from May 18 through 22, press representatives for the Pops said in a news release. Its full season runs from May 4 through June 20, and opens with a concert featuring Idina Menzel and Doc Severinsen. Other artists this season include Ozomatli, John Williams, Maureen McGovern, Dave Brubeck, Kelli O'Hara and Arlo Guthrie. More information is at bostonpops.org.

If you missed Susie Essman's recent stint at Carolines on Broadway tonight you have another chance to see the stand-up queen in action. Ms. Essman, who is best known for playing Susie Green, Jeff Garlin's obscene, "perpetually scolding wife" on "Curb Your Enthusiasm," will be appearing tonight as part of "Celebrity Autobiography: In Their Own Words." The comedy evening, which features actors reading verbatim from other actors' memoirs, will also include performances by Craig Bierko, Mario Cantone, Rachel Dratch, Eugene Pack, Dayle Reyfel, Michael Riedel, Brooke Shields, Sherri Shepherd, Alan Zweibel and more.

"Sexy, Clean, Cool, Fun, Healthy, Young, Large Underpants." Sarah Haskin's brilliant online videos "Target Women" on current.com hilariously dissect the way marketers advertise to women. "So much of women's advertising these days is built around the construct of a new, modern superwoman who can work, run the household, raise kids, do yoga and still be a sexbot at home," Ms. Haskins recently told Time Out. "No one can do all those things perfectly — but the fear that you're slipping at any of these roles is what advertisers target." You can hear more insights from Ms. Haskins and others tonight at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe during the program "That Not-So-Fresh Feeling: Marketing Embarrassing Products to Women." The panel discussion presented by DoubleX, Slate's section for women, will also feature Susan Kim, author of "Flow," and Allison Silverman, a former executive producer of "The Colbert Report." Hanna Rosin, the co-editor of DoubleX and contributing editor at The Atlantic Monthly, will serve as moderator at the event, which begins at 7 p.m.

Tonight "The Brady Bunch" alum and Internet entrepreneur Florence Henderson is hosting "Broadway Backwards 5." The annual cabaret show at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, which benefits Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS and The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center, features Broadway stars singing songs originally written for the opposite gender, with often hilarious results. Go to listen to Gary Beach, Mario Cantone, Len Cariou, Raúl Esparza, Tony Goldwyn, Ann Harada, Aaron Lazar, Michele Lee, Julia Murney, Tonya Pinkins, Lee Roy Reams, Lea Salonga, Douglas Sills, Bruce Vilanch and more. The curtain rises at 8 p.m.

Monologue | Friday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: I'm kind of embarrassed to say, I actually, and I'm not kidding, I wish I was, set my alarm last night to make sure I was up in time for Tiger Woods' apology. It was covered on pretty much every channel except the Food Network, I think. And the excitement surrounding this historic event could hardly be contained. "Less than three hours before Tiger Woods speaks." "He's going to speak in exactly a minute and a half." "Tiger Woods set to walk out now in about 40 seconds." I guess this is like the closest thing we get to the thrill of a space launch now that we can't afford NASA anymore.

Thursday is one of the most important days of the N.F.L. off-season. It's the deadline for teams to prevent the departure of key unrestricted free agents by using their franchise and transition tags. YONKERS -- The Bronx had ''Fort Apache,'' the police precinct that Paul Newman immortalized in the classic film that pitted lonely cops against ruthless gangs. In Yonkers, just north of the Bronx border, there is the Second Precinct, where police officers have been fighting a losing battle against vandals in their own parking lot.

In much of the nation, ''monument'' is an innocuous word, conjuring up images of historical figures cast in bronze or road-side plaques few stop to read. In the West, though, it's a fighting word, bound up for years with simmering resentments against the federal government and presidential powers. The feeling dates to the days when, with the stroke of a pen, Theodore Roosevelt declared lands he wished to protect as national monuments under the American Antiquities Act.

In a second consecutive shootout at Canada Hockey Place late Thursday, Slovakia upset the Russians, 2-1, in a game that was fast, physical and, if you didn't mind the absence of scoring, the most thrilling of the tournament so far. It took 14 shootout shots to settle the outcome, with Pavol Demitra, a local favorite who plays for the Vancouver Canucks, lifting a shot over the outstretched pad of Ilya Bryzgalov, in goal for the Russians, and sending the Slovak fans home in ecstasy. The Slovaks were playing their second game in 24 hours, not unusual in the N.H.L. but a hardship in the Olympics, yet they looked sharper then they had in their 3-1 loss to the Czechs on Wednesday. The Russians, who appeared to be trying to over-dazzle in their first game, against Latvia, settled down and moved efficiently. But, for supposedly the most gifted team at these Games, the Russians showed a worrisome inability to put the puck in the net when it counted.

Rex Nettleford, a Jamaican scholar, educator and choreographer who devoted his life to studying postcolonial Caribbean culture and in the process helped shape it, died in Washington on Feb. 2, one day before his 77th birthday. The cause was catastrophic brain injury following cardiac arrest, Dr. Christopher Junker of the George Washington University Hospital said.

9 P.M. (Showtime) THE READER (2008) Kate Winslet captured the Oscar as best actress for her portrayal of an illiterate Nazi prison guard on trial for war crimes in this drama from Stephen Daldry, adapted by David Hare from a novel by Bernhard Schlink. Ralph Fiennes also stars as the lawyer she seduced when he was 15 (played as a teenager by David Kross, above with Ms. Winslet). ''Although the commercial imperatives that drive a movie like this one are understandable -- the novel was a best seller and an Oprah's Book Club selection, for starters -- you have to wonder who, exactly, wants or perhaps needs to see another movie about the Holocaust that embalms its horrors with artfully spilled tears and asks us to pity a death-camp guard,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. She added, ''But the film is neither about the Holocaust nor about those Germans who grappled with its legacy: it's about making the audience feel good about a historical catastrophe that grows fainter with each new tasteful interpolation.'' 10:30 A.M. CAREY--Robert Clayton, died on February 7th at age 89. A WWII veteran, he graduated from Washington and Lee University after earning a Law degree in 1951. An Assistant U.S. Attorney from 1956-1962, he spent 20 years in private practice and was an Administrative Law Judge in Manhattan from 1982 until retirement. Bob spent 48 years on the Board of Forestdale, Inc., a major New York City foster care agency, and was the Chairman for 25 years. He also served on the Board of the Brooklyn Eye & Ear Hospital and was a former President of the Brooklyn Heights Association. His beloved late wife Anne Hubert Carey, who died in 1983, was from a long line of Brooklyn Heights residents. He is deeply missed by his children Robert C. Carey Jr., Merrill Carey and Nancy Carey Johnson, Nancy's husband Obie Johnson and sons Forrest, Hunter, Wilder and North. A memorial service will be held on Friday, March 5 at 3:30pm at Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights (254 Hicks Street). Donations in his memory may be made to Forestdale, Inc. or to Grace Church.

A drought has destroyed millions of dollars worth of crops, reduced the country's water supply and is threatening widespread blackouts as power companies contend with low water levels in hydroelectric dams, officials said Friday. ''It is such a difficult situation because we have just survived the typhoons in October that destroyed 1.5 million metric tons of rice and countless basic infrastructure,'' Joel Rudinas, an under secretary at the Department of Agriculture, said Friday. ''We are bracing for the worst.'' The damage to crops is now estimated at more than $61 million, and Mr. Rudinas said the Philippines, already the world's largest importer of rice, had imported an additional 2.4 million tons because of the drought.

I'm devoting tomorrow's class to the big decline in world trade that took place between the two world wars. It's a familiar proposition to international economists: globalization isn't an inexorable trend. In fact, it took until around 1970 before world goods markets were as closely integrated as they had been in 1913, and it wasn't until very recently that we returned to anything like Edwardian levels of capital-market integration.

Despite being held simultaneously on both coasts to add drama, there were few surprises for statuette-counters at the Writers Guild Awards on Saturday night. "Up in the Air," "The Hurt Locker" and "The Cove," favorites all season long, won for best adapted screenplay, best original screenplay and best documentary, respectively, and the winners gave variations on the speeches they've been giving all season long. In Los Angeles, Jason Reitman, of "Up in the Air," thanked his father, Ivan; his co-writer, Sheldon Turner, thanked other writers. And "The Hurt Locker" writer Mark Boal thanked Kathryn Bigelow, the director, for "believing in an unpopular project about an unpopular war." In New York, the Bagger's pal Anthony Mackie rushed over from his curtain call at "A Behanding in Spokane" on Broadway to accept the award on Mr. Boal's behalf, doing a not-very-convincing impression of him.

JACKSON--R. Edward, 85, died of cancer February 5 in New York. Born in Mt. Airy, NC, he served in the Navy in WWII, and graduated from Washington & Lee University in 1947. His 44-year career in journalism began at United Press, where he worked in New York, London and Rome. In 1957 he joined Time magazine in New York, serving as a writer, foreign news-desk editor, Rome bureau chief, deputy chief of correspondents, founding editor of Time's international editions and Washington news editor. He also was the last managing editor of the Time-owned Washington Star, in 1981. After retiring from Time in 1986, he edited World Press Review for five years. He held leadership posts in the Overseas Press Club and the Correspondents Fund, and endowed journalism scholarships at Washington & Lee, UNC-Chapel Hill, and UC-Berkeley. He had a keen mind and boundless curiosity, traveled widely, loved good food and talk, followed sports avidly, and was an astute student of politics and the media. To his family, he was above all an engaged, generous, and supportive husband, father, father-in-law, and grandfather. His marriage to Margaret Jackson ended in divorce. He is survived by his wife, Kathleen Beakley, of New York, two sons from his first marriage, Roger (Pam Percy), of Northfield, MN, and Blair (Regan McMahon), of Oakland, CA, and grandchildren, Ian of St. Paul, MN, and Kyle and Hayley of Oakland. Memorial donations may be made to the Overseas Press Club Foundation, 40 W. 45th St., New York, NY 10036.

ISAACSON--Rick, age 67, died of pancreatic cancer on February 13 at his home in Brooklyn. He is survived by his wife of 40 years, Phyllis, sons Andy and Rabbi Daniel (Liora), sister Arina (Sandy), and grandson Elijah. During his 40-year tenure at IMG, Rick helped create the seminal sports agency's client management, corporate consulting and sports promotions businesses. He founded IMG Licensing in the 1980s, growing it into the world's biggest independent celebrity, trademark and event licensing organization. Highly respected as a brilliant marketing mind, Rick created successful licensing programs for renowned athletes, brands and properties, including Arnold Palmer, Major League Baseball and Steinway. He mentored hundreds of younger professionals, and his generous spirit, integrity and unique humor inspired colleagues around the world. His family and friends will miss him dearly. A memorial service will be held on March 22 from 12-2pm at Plymouth Church in Brooklyn Heights. Donations in Rick's memory may be made to Careers through Culinary Arts Program (C-CAP), the Mohonk Preserve and the Russell Ferber Foundation Scholarship.

''NERD CHIC'' is how Victoria Beckham described her collection of sunglasses, which she introduced last week alongside her fall lineup of dresses. They were little round spectacles worn with corseted cocktail numbers and five-inch platforms. ''I guess that's how you could describe my personal style as well,'' she added. Mmm ... not really. But it is the look that many women, including Chloë Sevigny (below right) , have been going for lately, with tailored blouses, tucked in and buttoned-up tight. And from Marc Jacobs to Miu Miu, Christopher Kane to Chloé, it was the desired effect on many spring runways -- and several fall ones. Of course, worn with a short skirt and ankle boots, as it was for Preen's fall collection (center), or a shot of lipstick and a leopard belt, as Ms. Sevigny sported it, the very prim look takes on a kind of hard-edged cool -- which is much more of Ms. Beckham's groove, we'd say.

Today's wind turbines, though far more sophisticated than the windmills of centuries past, apply the same principle: they transform wind into energy. General Electric makes nearly half the wind turbines used in the United States. In Pensacola, Fla., G.E. workers assemble the hub, or nose cone, of the machine, along with the nacelle, which attaches to the hub and houses the turbine's operating ''brains.'' The blades, meanwhile, are manufactured at a plant in Newton, Iowa. Eventually, all parts of the turbine, made in dozens of locations, are sent to the site of operation for final assembly.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week are Ted Conover, the author of ''The Routes of Man''; The Times's Richard L. Berke on a new book about the investigation and impeachment of Bill Clinton; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. Paper Cuts The Book Review's blog covers books and other forms of printed matter.

Art Who's in? Who's out? There are few things the New York art world likes bickering about more than the WHITNEY BIENNIAL. This year's version, organized by Francesco Bonami, will examine the impact that the ups and downs of the last two years -- from the global financial collapse to the Iraq war -- have had on the work of 55 artists. The show will include familiar faces like George Condo, Ellen Gallagher, Piotr Ulanski and Charles Ray. Among the most unexpected works are a series of disturbing photographs by Stephanie Sinclair, ''Self-Immolation Afghanistan: A Cry for Help,'' and Nina Berman's collection of interviews and photos with an Iraq war veteran. Feb. 23 through May 30, whitney.org.

FRENCH cinema has produced some notable gangster characters and crime films over the years. During their long careers Jean-Paul Belmondo, Alain Delon and Jean Gabin portrayed underworld figures with swagger, world-weariness or elegance, and even after 50 years Jacques Becker's ''Night Watch'' still stands as one of the most memorable psychological dramas ever set in a prison. But Jacques Audiard turns many of the conventions of the genre upside down in ''A Prophet'' (''Un Prophète''), which may help explain why the film won the Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival last year and has been nominated for an Academy Award as best foreign film. Shunning the standard-issue tough-guy protagonist, Mr. Audiard instead offers the story of Malik El Djebena, a meek, illiterate Arab street urchin who manages to survive and prosper in prison through guile and intelligence, not intimidation.

BACK in 1996, if you were going to pick someone to cover the cruise industry, you might not immediately have thought of Carolyn Spencer Brown. A cruise newbie, Ms. Brown easily got seasick and was dumfounded by things like preset dining times. She described her attitude back then as ''Frankly, it's not my style of travel.'' But that didn't stop an editor at The Washington Post from assigning her the cruise beat, and after her first trip, on Celebrity's Zenith ship, she got hooked. Thirteen years and 150 cruises later, the 47-year-old is now an aficionado (she even met her husband on a cruise), and has since moved on from The Post to become editor in chief of CruiseCritic.com, an online magazine and discussion board devoted to all things seaworthy (and not so seaworthy). I recently spoke with her by phone about a business that, all too often, seems out of reach for frugal travelers.

NYGREEN--Glen T.,Senior Vice President of Student Affairs emeritus. Lehman College mourns the passing of this wise mentor, trusted colleague, and founding administrator. His inspiring commitment to our students helped to build a lasting spirit of service and scholarship.

Some high-level Democrats are betting that the outcome of President Obama's health care summit meeting this week could hinge on the extent to which they prove to the American public that they have already incorporated Republican ideas into the Democrats' health care legislation. Making that case, the Democrats believe, could establish political legitimacy for pressing ahead with a combined version of the bills adopted late last year by the House and Senate, even if Congressional Republicans continue to oppose the measures.

SCHUSTERMAN--Ronald, passed away February 11, 2010 after an almost lifelong struggle with heart disease, he was 77. Ron was a scientist and animal behaviorist who worked with chimpanzees early in his career and went on to do pioneering work in behavior and cognition of marine mammals. He was a founding member of the Marine Mammal Society and recently was inducted as a Fellow in the California Academy of Sciences. In retirement Ron lived with his wife Francie in the Monterey Bay area and was in the process of writing a book on his life with marine mammals. He lived a life rich with travel, love of music, a passion for science, and a connection with the ocean and the animals that he loved so much. Ron was raised in the Bronx and always thought of New York as his home. He is survived by Francie Moore Schusterman his three children Marisa, Nikki and Lesli and his loving grandchildren Max, Nacho, Danielle and Alyssa. Memorial contributions should be made to the Palo Alto Medical Clinic Cardiac Research fund in memory of Ron.

TIMOTHY EGAN It seems like eons ago that the Winter Olympics opening ceremony in Vancouver, a triumph complete with magical bears and sub-surface killer whales, prompted some Canadians to take a long overdue bow. ''It made me proud to be from here,'' said Ian Brown, writing in The Globe and Mail, a Canadian national paper. But then he added: ''I hesitate to say it. Such declarations are always unwise.''

MICHELSON--Gerald, 81, known to his family and friends and Jerry, passed away at his home in New York City on February 17, 2010 with his beloved wife Anita and son Lewis at his side. He graduated Rutgers University in 1950 and received his master's from Teachers College of Columbia University in 1954. He served in the public schools in both New Jersey and New York as classroom teacher, department chairman, counselor and guidance director. Jerry's life was filled with love, laughter and accomplishments and his intellect and generosity touched the lives of many. Donations in his memory may be made to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017 attn. Sheila Clay, Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street, New York NY 10022-1202 attn. Reading Services Prog., Rosie Lopez. Through these organizations Jerry continues to lend a helping hand.

Theater Recent snowfall notwithstanding, a change in seasons is not far off, and listings devoted to many spring theater highlights are included in this week's section. The focus is on Broadway and Off Broadway, but New York City continues to teem with adventurous fare in less obvious places too. The fourth annual FRIGID NEW YORK FESTIVAL is a case in point, featuring an eclectic slate of 30 productions presented over 12 days in three East Village theaters.

To the Editor: ''The Art of Being Santa Fe'' (Feb. 7) by Henry Shukman neglected to mention ART Santa Fe (artsantafe.com), an international art fair celebrating its 10th anniversary. The fair will be held July 15 to 18, 2010, at the new Santa Fe Convention Center and will once again present great contemporary art from around the world. With over 5,000 visitors expected, this is a significant event for Santa Fe and its arts community, and should certainly be included in any list of upcoming events. Charlotte Jackson ART Santa Fe Santa Fe, N.M.

PULLEN--Catherine (Kay) B.,89, passed away February 8, at Greenwich Woods Health Care Center. She was born in Greenwich, CT. December 27, 1920 to Elizabeth and Patrick Brennan. Kay was a long time resident of Stamford and also lived in New Canaan, Marco Island, Florida and Royal Oak, Maryland. She married William H. Cleary in 1942 and raised their four children, Carol Ann, William Jr., Albert Ward, and Mary Alice. After Bill Sr.'s passing in 1960, Kay started Mrs. Kay's Training Center, a Montessori Program for four and five year olds. She pursued her own education at the University of Oxford as well as the Universities of Florence and Vienna. She loved the city of Stamford and was very involved in its civic affairs. Kay was an original member of Board of the Representatives of Stamford and also served on the Boards of Education, St. John's Towers, St. Joseph's Hospital Auxiliary, Catholic Mother's Circles, the Rehabilitation Center of Stamford, Sacred Heart University, and Hubbard Heights Garden Club. In 1951, she was given the Christopher Award for her work in having bronze plaques stating, "In God We Trust" put into the then 18 public schools of Stamford. She married E. Markey Pullen, MD in 1975 and lived in New Canaan, Royal Oak, Md, and Marco Island, FL. After Markey passed away in 1980 Kay returned to Stamford. She is survived by her brother John P. Brennan of Greenwich and her children: Carol C. Cusick of Tarrytown, NY and grandchildren Thomas and Catherine; William H. and wife Patricia of Hendersonville, NC and grandchildren Megan and William Jr.; Albert Ward of Brooklyn, NY and grandchildren Albert Jr., Elizabeth and John; Mary Alice and husband Craig R. Sanford, DDS of Nantucket, MA and grandchildren Geoffrey and Christopher and three great-grandchildren Sean, Mia and Ryan; also survived by many nieces and nephews. The family would like to express its deep appreciation and thanks to the Staff of Greenwich Woods Healthcare Center for their kindness and excellent care they rendered to Kay over the past year. A memorial service will be held at The Basilica of Saint John the Evangelist on Tuesday, February 23 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Kay's memory to The Basilica of Saint John the Evangelist at 279 Atlantic Street, Stamford, CT 06901.

Prime Minister Boiko M. Borisov of Bulgaria, a thick-necked former karate instructor, bodyguard and onetime fireman, may seem an unlikely feminist. But the tough-guy politician has in recent months promoted a legion of women, heralding what some are calling a revolution in the politics of this abidingly macho Balkan country.

American Airlines quietly announced this month that it would eliminate free blankets in coach and sell an $8 packet that includes a pillow and blanket on domestic flights starting May 1. According to Joesentme.com, a subscription travel site that first reported the move, the airline based its decision on consumer surveys. Joe Brancatelli, the site's publisher, raised a skeptical brow: ''American executives run focus groups on blankets? You'd think they'd look for customer focus group data on what fliers think about American's worst-in-the-nation on-time performance, its atrocious baggage-handling ability or the hideous condition of its planes.''

As more bobsleds were crashing at the Whistler Sliding Centre on Saturday, the president of the International Olympic Committee said he would do ''everything in my power'' to prevent another accident like the one that killed an Olympic luge athlete on the same track last week. Jacques Rogge, the I.O.C. president, said in an interview with The Associated Press that in response to the death of the luger, Nodar Kumaritashvili of Georgia, his organization and the international luge federation would consider three issues: the competition venue; the competition rules; and the qualification standard and quality of the athletes participating.

HANDREA--Mihai H. We mourn the death on February 18 of our longtime colleague and loyal friend, who served first as Librarian and then as Curator of The Carl H. Pforzheimer Collection of Shelley and His Circle, now part of The New York Public Library's rare book collections. A native of Rumania, he was a discerning bookman, a gifted linguist, a cosmopolitan traveller and a dedicated member of the Grolier Club and the Association Internationale de Bibliophilie. We shall miss him. The Carl and Lily Pforzheimer Foundation, Inc. The Shelley and his Circle Publication Project The Carl H. Pforzheimer Collection of Shelley and His Circle
COHEN--Dr. Ira B. Ira, a loving and loveable part of our family, will be greatly missed. Judy, Jamie, Joseph and Lizbeth Stecher

BOSE--Ajay K. Stevens Institute of Technology mourns the passing of longtime professor Ajay Bose, on Friday, February 12, 2010 at 85. Noted for his research on antibiotics, natural products and microwave-assisted chemistry, he worked tirelessly to provide learning opportunities and career paths to undergraduate students at Stevens, particularly in chemistry and medicine. He is survived by his wife, Margaret; sons Ryan, Ranjan, and Rajendra; daughters Indrani Malinowski, Indira Winders, and Krishna King; and 11 grandchildren.

THE theater critics for The New York Times, Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood, looked at the spring season's offerings and found a number of productions that addressed pressing issues. Are political shows making a comeback? They discussed this and other aspects in an e-mail conversation excerpted below. For the full discussion, see nytimes.com/theater. BEN BRANTLEY Allow me to throw a topic before us, Charles -- namely, the topical in theater. This season we have a hefty number of plays and even musicals dealing with subjects that might be said to have been ripped from the op-ed pages (although slightly yellowed pages). Most notably Broadway will be seeing a Ziegfeld-style re-enactment of the most flamboyant financial scandal in recent years in Lucy Prebble's ''Enron''; American youth is portrayed in a state of suicidal crisis (although that's what being young is, isn't it?) in the Green Day musical ''American Idiot''; and the clash of homosexuality and Christianity is explored in Geoffrey Nauffts's ''Next Fall.'' Off Broadway we're seeing a new play about abortion from Jonathan Reynolds that (for a change) takes the conservative position, as well as re-examinations of fraught chapters in American history like the trial of the Scottsboro Boys, the making public of the Pentagon Papers and the populist presidency of Andrew Jackson.

Until his retirement in 2008, Bill was president of Lucy-McNiece & Bull Surety Agency, established in 1936 to provide surety bonds for contractors. Bill was active in the New York Building Congress as well as the Sub-Contractors' Trade Association. A lifelong New Yorker, he received his undergraduate degree from New York University and an MBA from Pace University

ZAMYN-UUD, MONGOLIA, AUG. 28, 2009. ''Every year I pick a spot in the world to squander my vacation. I tend to travel alone. Here, I was crossing into Erlian (Erenhot), China, from Mongolia. The Trans-Siberian Railroad had no seats left, so going by jeep was the less glamorous but equally exciting alternative. These were fellow travelers who paid $5 each to the driver. They were Mongolians who spoke neither English nor Chinese. During our three-hour ride, we communicated through sign language, played with the baby, shared food and sang. That's what so amazing about traveling. It transports you to a foreign land, where you have nothing to depend on except for your basic humanness. Peipei Zhou, New York
CURTI--Cesare. GEI regrets the death of its long time member Cesare Curti who passed away on February 18, 2010 in Bologna, Italy.

JIMMY KIMMEL I'm not sure what this says about us, but two new polls just came out. One of them found out that 70 percent of Americans support gays and lesbians serving openly in the military. And another poll, by the same company at the same time, found that only 59 percent of Americans support homosexuals serving openly in the military. I guess it means that 11 percent of Americans don't know homosexuals are gay.

The Mets have agreed to a one-year deal with the free-agent catcher Rod Barajas. Although the team has not announced it formally, a person familiar with the negotiations says the deal has been agreed to. Barajas would probably become the starting catcher, with Henry Blanco the likely backup. That would send Omir Santos to Class AAA Buffalo, where he would play behind Josh Thole.

LeSTAGE--Donald III, passed away at home in Attleboro, MA on February 14, 2010 at age 70. Don leaves his wife, Linda, daughter, Julie, son, Gregg and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Murray Universalist Church, 505 North Main Street, Attleboro, MA 02703 on February 26 at 11am. A reception will follow at the Highland Country Club, 104 Mechanic Street, Attleboro, MA 02703. REECE HUDSON, a new handbag line from Reece Solomon and Max Stein, has the pedigree (Ms. Solomon spent three years interning at Proenza Schouler) and craftsmanship (each heavily detailed bag is hand-cut and hand-stitched in New York, using butter-soft Italian leather, exotic skins and, for next fall's collection, velvet) to make it an instant fashion-editor favorite. Thoughtfully designed with credit card slots and adjustable straps and able to transition from day to evening, the oversize clutches and strappy purses assume a certain utilitarian elegance that, not coincidentally, recalls Proenza Schouler's best-selling PS1 satchel -- the gold standard of handbags, as Ms. Solomon sees it. ''It's seasonless and wears well,'' she said. ''It's something all designers aspire to create.'' Reece Hudson bags, $840

COHEN--Dr. Ira B. Our dear friend, a most caring, compassionate and loving man, has left us. We are saddened beyond words, Ira was so special, he was one-of-a-kind. We will always have the warmest thoughts and memories of him. We send our deepest sympathies to his family. Barbara and Bentley

PICKETT--Dr. Elisabeth P.,1918 - 2010, died at home in Colorado of an acute heart attack on February 14, 2010, four days before her 92nd birthday. Dr. Pickett graduated from the University of Colorado Medical School in 1944 . She was the first woman in the United States to be certified in both general surgery (1961) and in urology (1962). She held multiple concurrent academic positions and was on the staffs of Memorial-Sloan-Kettering and New York Hospitals. She was an instructor in surgery at Cornell University Medical College and associate professor of both surgery and urology at the New York Infirmary. In addition, she headed the spinal cord injury service at Castle Point Veterans' Hospital in New York. In 1995, the Society of Women in Urology established a research scholarship in her name at the annual meeting of the American Urological Association. She is survived by several nieces and nephews. and at the time of her demise was with her niece, Janet Doyle, of Boulder, Co. Memorials may be sent to the Elisabeth P. Pickett Research Award, c/o The Society of Women in Urology, 1100 E. Woodfield Road, Suite 520, Schaumburg, IL, 60173.

The provocative photographer and filmmaker Shirin Neshat has been exploring identity through her art for more than 30 years. Though she is based in New York, her main focus has been her native Iran, especially the situation of Iranian women -- until now. In ''Games of Desire,'' above, an exhibition at La Fábrica Galería (Calle Alameda, 9; 34-91-360-1325; lafabricagaleria.com) that runs through March, Ms. Neshat turns from the Middle East to Laos. Through film and photographs, she focuses on the relationships between men and women through the filter of lam, the disappearing Laotian custom of reciting courtship songs. While her Middle Eastern work is often melancholic, her newest series documents the joyful interaction of elderly men and women, happily engaged in sexual patter. Having met Laotians and discovering the lam ritual in her travels, she returned to make videos in a temple by the Mekong River. Using multichannel video installations, she caught the participants joking, singing, making lewd remarks and teasing one another, all in a manner notably lacking in self-consciousness.

Classical Lovers of vocal drama are spoiled for choice this week: Riccardo Muti makes his eagerly anticipated Metropolitan Opera debut with Verdi's ''Attila'' on Tuesday, and Valery Gergiev conducts performers from the Mariinsky Theater in Berlioz's ''Roméo et Juliette'' at Carnegie Hall that same evening. But some of the week's most intriguing options lie just off the beaten path.

MONK--Audrey Marsh (1911-2009), a well-known big band and radio singer and the voice behind the Duz soap, Muriel Cigar and Blue Bonnet Margarine commercials, died at age 98, on December 13th, 2009 in Palm Springs, CA. The daughter of musician parents, she was born in New York City on March 18, 1911. She was married to Theodore Glenn Monk, co-owner of Square Lumber Supply Company in the Bronx, for 63 years. Audrey Monk Marsh is survived by her daughters, New York City composer/ performer Meredith Monk and Tracy Monk Durland of Baha, CA; four grandchildren; longtime friends, caretakers and in-laws. Contributions in Audrey Marsh Monk's name can be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation by contacting 212.923.4700 or visiting www.pdf.org.

FOUNDED in 2002 by Alexis Hubshman, a restless artist, Scope has become the wild child of contemporary art fairs, continually experimenting with new ways to promote and support emerging talent. Markt, an exhibition of work that blurs the line between fashion and art, is the latest. Its curator is Diane Pernet, the fashion journalist known for her Marge Simpson-like pompadour and mantilla veil. The show will feature, among its inspired wares, conceptual knitwear by Sandra Backlund (top), intricately constructed dresses from Lamija Suljevic (above), leather and silver jewelry by Graham Tabor and Miguel Villalobos and prints by Hormazd Narielwalla, an artist who makes collages from the Savile Row suit patterns of customers long gone. And though everything is for sale, Mr. Hubshman would be loath to call it a pop-up shop: ''It's an exhibit -- a curated show of art pieces,'' he explained. ''Not a back-of-the-truck garmento thing.''

Holland America has announced its lineup of Europe voyages for 2011, with rates starting at about $140 a day, and early booking bonuses if reservations are made by June 1. The seven-day Mediterranean Glamour itinerary, which stops in Barcelona and Monte Carlo, starts at $999 for the April 28 sailing. In Northern Europe, the seven-day Scandinavian Getaway, with stops in Oslo and Copenhagen, starts at $1,099 for a May 29 departure. (Prices are based on double occupancy.)

JONES--Walter "Teddy". Beloved husband of Tina, adored and adoring father of Sheryl and Deidre, father-in-law of Glendon Pearce, and loving brother of Dorothy Gordon and Stanley Jones died on February 19, 2010 at age 87. Teddy left a legacy of love to his many friends, colleagues, and extended family whose lives were enriched immeasurably by his strength, wisdom, thoughtfulness, support and warmth. He will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed.

CAREY--Robert Clayton, died on February 7th at age 89. A WWII veteran, he graduated from Washington and Lee University after earning a Law degree in 1951. An Assistant U.S. Attorney from 1956-1962, he spent 20 years in private practice and was an Administrative Law Judge in Manhattan from 1982 until retirement. Bob spent 48 years on the Board of Forestdale, Inc., a major New York City foster care agency, and was the Chairman for 25 years. He also served on the Board of the Brooklyn Eye & Ear Hospital and was a former President of the Brooklyn Heights Association. His beloved late wife Anne Hubert Carey, who died in 1983, was from a long line of Brooklyn Heights residents. He is deeply missed by his children Robert C. Carey Jr., Merrill Carey and Nancy Carey Johnson, Nancy's husband Obie Johnson and sons Forrest, Hunter, Wilder and North. A memorial service will be held on Friday, March 5 at 3:30pm at Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights (254 Hicks Street). Donations in his memory may be made to Forestdale, Inc. or to Grace Church.

BERMAN--David Zvi, died at his home in Manhattan, NY on Sunday, February 14, 2010, at the age of 91. Born August 30th, 1918, in Pittsburgh, PA, David was a longtime resident of New York City. He served in the U.S. Army as a 1st Lieutenant during World War II, and was an executive with the advertising firm of Young & Rubicam for 45 years. David is survived by his brother, Mathias Berman, sister, Anne Zvirman, nephews Peter Levitt and Charles Zvirman, nieces Susan Levitt, Naomi Hyman, Ellen Dobrusin and Wendy Pelletier, and their families. He was preceded in death by his wife, Lois.

The lasting image of the 1970 N.B.A. finals is a hunched over Willis Reed limping onto the floor at Madison Square Garden during the warmups before Game 7. Reed, who tore a thigh muscle in Game 5, had sat out Game 6 and his status for the deciding game was up in the air until the minute that he came out of the tunnel. Even the Lakers stopped warming up to watch Reed, whose appearance in uniform drove the Garden faithful crazy. Reed went on to hit the first two shots of the game, and that was all the Knicks needed. Reed did not score again, but New York won its first title in franchise history.

RICHMAN--Betty Ebert, 84, on February 17, 2010. Loving wife of Henry Richman (deceased). Beloved mother of Eli and Ilene Richman, cherished sister of Judith Ebert, dear grandmother of Hanna and Jonathan Richman and daughter-in-law Leslie Richman. Love and miss you.

These are excerpts from recent posts in the Globespotters series, a travelers' guide to cities around the world, hosted on the In Transit blog. Full entries can be found at nytimes.com/globespotters. PARIS A TABLE IN THE SKY When Electrolux, the Swedish appliance maker, proposed a project called Art Home (pronounced arome, aroma in French) to the Palais de Tokyo (13, avenue du Président-Wilson) late last year, the result was a partnership as close to heaven as the contemporary art museum could get. Conceived by the award-winning artist Laurent Grasso, the rectangular, purple-hued, glass-and-steel box, which sits atop the museum, houses Nomiya, a conceptual dining space for 12, orchestrated by the experimentalist chef Gilles Stassart.

COLT--Robert H.,89, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of White Plains, NY, passed away on Friday, February 19, 2010. Robert is predeceased by his devoted wife of 66 years, Edith, and survived by his beloved children Nancy (Ron) Bleeker, Tricia Dale, and Robert Jr. (Liz); and loving grandchildren Shahar Colt, Allana Dale, Andrew Bleeker, and David Colt. Funeral services were held in Florida. Donations may be made in Bob's memory to the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County, 4601 Community Drive, West Palm Beach, FL 33417. The Colt family may be contacted at: rhcolt@gmail.com. Weiss Memorial Chapel 561-737-0001.

KROLL--Arthur H. Passed away this past Monday morning. He was 70 years old. Born in New York, he graduated from Cornell University and St. Johns Law School, where he was an editor of the law review. He had a distinguished legal career where he became an outstanding specialist in ERISA, Tax and Executive Compensation. He spent many years at Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler as a senior partner and rainmaker. He then continued his practice at Pryor Cashman. In his later years, he served as a consultant to some of the most important executives in business. He published many books and articles and was a mentor to some of the most distinguished lawyers practicing throughout the country. He and his wife, Lois (Handmacher) have lived in Scarsdale NY for 44 years where they raised two children, Douglas and Pamela, whom he adored. Douglas passed away from Leukemia (AML) in 2002. It then became his mission to continue his son's work to find a treatment, if not a cure, for this disease. He worked tirelessly with the Leukemia and Lymphoma society, where he raised well over $1,000,000 to fund outstanding doctors dedicated to this effort. He had two grandchildren, DJ and Stephen, who were the apples of his eye. Arthur had a great zest for life, and nothing could get him down. He also served many years on the boards of the Westchester chapter of the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society and Student Advocacy. He also, with the support of his daughter, son-in-law Alan Winnikoff and daughter-in-law Lucy Kroll Treadwell set up a scholarship at the Youth Counseling League of the Jewish Board of Children and Family Services, where his son had been a beloved social worker. The scholarship is awarded to worthy clients of YCL who have graduated from high school and wish to continue their education. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, February 18 at 12noon at the Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, (914) 946-8851. Family will receive visitors following the service and on Friday, Saturday and Sunday at their home in Scarsdale from 1-5pm. Donations in lieu of flowers, can be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society of Westchester (Douglas Kroll Research Program) c/o KST Consulting Group, 250 Hartsdale Avenue, Suite 30, Hartsdale, NY 10530 or Youth Counseling League of Jewish Board of Children and Family Services, (JBFCS/Youth Counseling League, Attn: Douglas Kroll Scholarship, 9th Floor, 120 W. 57th St. New York, NY 10019).

I HATE the gym in January and February, when it's full of good intentions (''I'm going to lose this couch potato body for real this year!''). All the machines and cardio equipment are swarming with amateurs who don't know how to use them, and those of us who do this for real have to reorganize our routines, wait endlessly for equipment to free up, and indulge people who do not know the first thing about gym etiquette. They sit on equipment after they're done and daydream or watch TV. They don't ask the trainers to show them how to use the machines. They don't dry themselves off when they come from the pool, leaving puddles of water in the bathroom perfect for slipping and breaking one's neck.

FROM the moment it was announced on Feb. 2, Meryl Streep's 16th Oscar nomination -- best performance by an actress in a leading role for ''Julie & Julia,'' in case your attention has been otherwise occupied -- seemed both richly merited and a bit redundant. Of course she would! How could she not? It is barely an exaggeration to say that you can't have an awards season without Ms. Streep, who has been enmeshed in roughly half of them since 1979, when she was nominated for best supporting actress in ''The Deer Hunter.'' She won that category the next year, for ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' and was nominated in it once again, in 2003, for ''Adaptation.'' Those three supporting nods are filigree on top of the 13 nominations for best actress, which she won on her second try, in 1983, for ''Sophie's Choice.''

Film Perhaps you don't think often about Taiwan, that entity near China that either is or isn't China, depending on whom you ask. Why would you, what with all the political, economic and other noise the big China has been making over the years? But darned if Taiwan doesn't keep creeping into the news: Last month the Obama administration approved of a $6 billion arms sale to it, a deal that angered the Chinese government.

RINGUETTE--Adrien Lanthier 84, of Bristol, IN died on January 6, 2010 in Mishawaka, IN. The causes were complications of stroke. Mr. Ringuette retired from Bayer Corporation as Secretary and General Counsel in 1990. During his career at Miles/Bayer he was involved in trade association committees which shaped legislation in the healthcare industry on issues such as the difference between medical devices and pharmaceuticals. He also worked with the FDA and other agencies during their review of over the counter drugs. Mr. Ringuette was born in Attleboro, MA on September 9, 1925, the son of the late Joseph and the late Anita (Lanthier) Ringuette. After serving in the US Army Air Corp during World War II, he graduated magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa from Amherst College. He graduated from Yale Law School in 1951, and began his career at Dwight, Royal, Harris, Koegel and Caskey in New York (1951-1954). Mr. Ringuette worked for Universal Oil Products of Des Plaines, IL from 1954-1957 and for Abbott Laboratories from 1957-1965. In 1965 Mr. Ringuette came to Indiana after joining Miles Laboratories Inc. He is published in both scientific and legal fields. In 1960, Mr. Ringuette spearheaded the defense of an open housing development in Deerfield, IL. These events were chronicled in a 1960 New York Times Magazine article, The South in the North and in a 1962 book by Harry and David Rosen entitled, But Not Next Door. As a descendent of the original settlers of New France, he wrote many articles on French-Canadian history and genealogy. Mr. Ringuette is survived by his wife, Celeste Aaron Ringuette, three children from a prior marriage, Rachel Thomas, Scott W. and Grant L, two grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Woods's Apology Gives Few Hints About His Future,'' Feb. 20: Tiger Woods hit the equivalent of a par-5 hole in one with his public statement Friday. The words, the tone, the minor stumbles, the contrition, the absence of his wife by his side, the stern looks of the audience, a commitment to rebuilding trust, marriage, family and friends over a definitive return to golf, a public rededication to his Buddhist faith and the final maternal embrace.

8 P.M. (Discovery) KING TUT UNWRAPPED Zahi Hawass, right, an Egyptologist who leads the Supreme Council of Antiquities in Cairo, oversees this two-part forensic investigation into the 19-year life of King Tutankhamen, revealing for the first time the identity of the boy pharaoh's parents and grandparents, his cause of death about 1324 B.C. and new details of his nine-year reign. Part 1 begins by following the extraction of DNA from Tut's mummy, which is described in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association. Part 2, on Monday at 8, draws on new evidence to determine what caused Tut's death, and how his afflictions might have affected his military, religious and political leadership. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, Republican of California, and Gov. Edward G. Rendell, Democrat of Pennsylvania, discuss how to break the partisan deadlock in Washington.

PARDEE--Erdice Rockhill of Newport, RI, age 81, passed peacefully with family on February 9, 2010. Born on July 30, 1928 and married to Stewart Trevor Pardee in 1954. They retired aboard their sailing yacht. She is survived by her children Lelia, Trevor, Jr., and Margaret. A private interment will be held at Woodlawn Cemetery.

Simon Ammann of Switzerland won the men's large hill ski jump on Saturday, becoming the first person to win four individual gold ski jumping medals. Ammann's style points were not necessarily the highest of the day, but no other skier equaled the combined distance of his two jumps: 144 and 138 meters. He also won the jumping competition on the normal hill last Saturday, eight years after he swept the same events at the Salt Lake City Games.
WHITMAN--The Reverend Canon Robert Shaw Sturgis, died on February 9, 2010 at the age of 94. For his book, ideas and life visit: www.readbeyondwords.com

THE NEWS After more than a year of holding short-term interest rates at historic lows, the Federal Reserve suddenly raised the interest rate it charges on loans to banks by a quarter-point, to 0.75 percent. BEHIND THE NEWS The surprise was in the timing, not the direction of the move. The Fed had been signaling its desire to drain down the ocean of cheap money it had poured into the banking system to combat the financial crisis. Banks have no trouble borrowing these days. But their customers do, and the Fed stressed that it was not ready yet to start a broad tightening of credit.

MICKEY THOMPSON, the racing superstar, did not limit himself to one motorsports arena. He built cars for the Indianapolis 500 and funny cars for drag racing, and put together trucks for off-road competition. But he may be best known for his many land-speed achievements. Thompson set hundreds of speed and endurance records, many at the Bonneville Salt Flats. Greg Sharp, curator of the Wally Parks National Hot Rod Association museum, has compiled evidence of nearly 500 significant records set by Thompson while participating in more than 10,000 events.

DOOCHIN--Stephen. NARSAD, the Brain and Behavior Research Fund, mourns the passing on February 16, 2010 of our long serving former Executive Director, Stephen Doochin. He brought remarkable skills and effort to meet our goals of finding better treatments and cures for those suffering from mental illness. His compassion, insight and efforts were vital factors in our organization's growth. Our Scientific Council leadership, our Board of Directors and our staff all share the sense of great loss with his family; his wife, Cheryl Sandler, his daughter, Jamie and his son, Brian. NARSAD will initiate a research grant in his name and memory.

SINCE THE EARLY DAYS OF MANNED SPACE FLIGHT, astronauts had only portholes through which to peer into the cosmos. Windows were an engineer's nightmare, vulnerable to meteors and the drastic temperatures of space. But engineers have resolved those concerns, and this past week, the shutters on the windows of the new $27 million Italian-built cupola on the International Space Station were opened for the first time. They provided a view of the neighborhood that moved the astronauts on board to tears. Photos and the complete story are available at: nytimes.com/weekinreview

When the Detroit Tigers reached the 2006 World Series, three of their best players -- Ivan Rodriguez, Kenny Rogers and Magglio Ordonez -- had one thing in common. All were represented by the agent Scott Boras. Now the Tigers' owner, Mike Ilitch, has sprung for another marquee Boras client. Johnny Damon confirmed in a text message Saturday that he had agreed to a one-year contract with the Tigers, pending a physical. The deal, which is worth $8 million, was first reported by Yahoo.com.

CHARLOTTE GAINSBOURG, actress, musician, muse. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW I told Nicolas Ghesquiere from Balenciaga that I needed his help for live shows, so he made me this jacket in three different colors. He made the belt, too. Because I dress in a very simple way, I like having one little thing that comes out a bit. I've been wearing these boots for four or five years. They're from a place in London called R. Soles. They're just easy. I love the color. The shirt is Schweisser. I found it at Opening Ceremony in Los Angeles. The jeans are Notify. I've been wearing these for four years. The patina -- that's what I love. So, I have many pairs, but I keep wearing the same ones until I have holes in them and then I start again. I use them in a brutal way.

New York Fashion Week ended its run at Bryant Park. They knocked the icicles off the fountain, put a tent over it and displayed their looks for fall inside. About 70 shows took place under the tents while 100 other designers showed in locations all over Manhattan. The audience of thousands presented their own spectacle going to the shows. The standout was the long leg -- covered or (a bigger surprise) a revival of the nude leg amid leggings, high boots and impossibly high shoes. Several designers put forth the idea of longer midcalf skirts (like Marc Jacobs, left of the limo). Here we go again: the matronly look.

An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

RODGERS--Anne English Colcord died peacefully at her home in Middlebury, VT on February 11. She was born in Brooklyn, March 27, 1924, the first child of Alice and Alan Colcord and was raised in Scarsdale and Manhattan. She completed degrees in English literature at Wellesley and Bryn Mawr and taught. She married James Beall Rodgers, M.D. in 1950, and together they raised David of Tenafly, NJ; Alan of Melrose, MA; and Alice Rodgers-Graves of Warren, VT. Her immediate survivors are her children, a granddaughter, Charlotte and her sister, Ruth Frerichs of Phoenix, AZ. She was a deeply private person, and always put others before self. She enjoyed languages and art and read widely. She was tickled by the words of wry humor, and rejoiced in her family, and in her garden. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Atonement, Tenafly, NJ, at noon on Friday, March 12. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Wellsely Student's Aid Society: 781-283-2292; www.wellsley.edutudentsaide/home.html

SHERLIP--Ruth, died December 21, 2009, in Richmond, VA, at 90 years of age. A Greenwich Village resident for more than 50 years, Ruth was predeceased by her husband Milton, and children Robert and Jane. She is survived by her granddaughter Corinna, and two great-grandchildren. Ruth was born, raised and educated in Manhattan, and was active in Greenwich Village life and politics. She was an outspoken and articulate member of the local Community Board, and committed to the after-school reading programs she created, supported and ran for underprivileged children throughout the City. She was tough, lovable and will be missed. The Schanback and Baer families.

Downtown Los Angeles continues its conversion from urban blight to tourist site with the opening this month of the JW Marriott Hotel Los Angeles, above, featuring 878 rooms, a rooftop bar and three floors of ballrooms. The hotel, expected to be the largest to open in Los Angeles this year, is part of the L.A. Live entertainment center, a $2.5 billion, 27-acre development that already includes the Staples Center, the Nokia Theater and the Grammy Museum. The JW Marriott (lalivemarriott.com) occupies a 54-story, blue-glass tower designed by the Gensler architecture firm. It rises over the neighboring Los Angeles Convention Center. It also features an outdoor pool, an 8,000-square-foot spa (expected to open in March) and a restaurant from the chef Kerry Simon. Sharing the tower is a 123-room Ritz-Carlton that is expected to open next month.

TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - This puzzle most likely sets a record, but one I'm sure nobody is keeping track of - the most highlighted squares in a weekday puzzle. Online they have circles, in print they're gray, with the print version definitely winning on style points.
