SINCE the two recent NATO-led military strikes that accidentally killed dozens of Afghan civilians, I have been thinking a great deal about the psychic toll that killing takes on soldiers.

The United States men's hockey team's 5-3 victory over Canada on Sunday night was the most watched sports program ever shown on Canadian TV. The average of 10.6 million who watched on six networks, including CTV, exceeded the 10.3 million for Canada's gold-medal-winning game over the Americans at the Salt Lake Games eight years ago.

To salt or not to salt? To regulate right away or conduct more research first? My Findings column takes a skeptical look at the case for salt reduction. (You can also check out my colleague Jane Brody's recent column on salt.) The salt wars can be vicious, pitting what I call the salt reformers against skeptics who say there isn't enough evidence yet to justify public policies restricting salt levels. The reformers want immediate action; the skeptics want to see a randomized clinical trial. Your opinions are welcome.

Don't worry, boys, Scorecard hasn't forgotten you. Today, we check in with a recap of all that's new in New York men's fashion (militaria, outsize proportions, raccoon pelts). While Calvin Klein's women's wear may have failed to square the circle, in his New York men's-wear homecoming, Italo Zucchelli scored one for the team with his quiet take on techno tailoring -- relatively speaking.

LaDainian Tomlinson called his release from the Chargers a "long time coming." No. 8 on the career rushing list, he hits a flimsy free-agent market as a 30-year-old who, statistically speaking, is coming off a third year of decline.

Robert Geller, one of men's fashion's cult ringleaders, has officially joined in on the fun of the pop-up shop. Arguably made popular by Comme des Garçons' "guerrilla stores," a pop-up store (a good one, at least) is more like an art exhibition than a traditional retail experience - a sort of traveling circus making a pit stop in town. So ladies and gentleman, boys and girls, come in and get Geller's ''personal curation of the pieces from the runway that don't always make it to the stores."

On Monday, President Obama outlined a legislative plan to overhaul health care. His blueprint, which tilts toward the Senate bill, is unlikely to win support from Republicans, or even be used as the basis for a compromise. Representative John Boehner of Ohio, the House Minority Leader, called the plan a "back room deal" that "doubles down on the same failed approach that will drive up premiums, destroy jobs, raise taxes and slash Medicare benefits."

Those of you who have followed fashion long before the advent of Twitter, may remember that fairly lame attempt back in the mid-'90s to beam the shows to New York live from Europe via satellite. (Yes, you heard it right, satellite!) What seemed at the time like a glimpse at the future was, in retrospect, the video conferencing equivalent of two tin cans connected together with string. But if you had told us that someday we would be watching the shows on our mobile phones we would have sent you a fax to tell you just how nuts you were. Well, some 15 years later, the future is finally up to speed. Tomorrow Burberry will stream its fall 2010 Prorsum show to around the world live and in 3D no less. That's Lily Donaldson walking right at you folks. And lest you think Anna would be caught dead in a pair of square paper specs with blue and red cellophane lenses (okay, maybe that's not the best example because Anna will no doubt be watching the show live and in 3D from her regular perch in the front row in her regular black sunglasses) Burberry will be handing out these not-to-shabby wrap-arounds. We may just dash off to Avatar and make it a double-feature.
Officials from bobsled's international governing body removed ice from some of the corners at the controversial Whistler Sliding Centre in hopes of curtailing speed and crashes.

The choreographer Christopher Wheeldon, who has decided to leave Morphoses/The Wheeldon Company, the dance troupe he created three years ago, said Monday afternoon that the reasons for his departure had been misrepresented by Lourdes Lopez, the executive director of the company. He said in an e-mail relayed by a publicist that neither Ms. Lopez nor the board asked him to give more time to the company. "She only brought it up as a problem after I decided to leave," he said, also contending that he had made himself available for 17 weeks, not 10, but that the company lacked bookings for some of the weeks he was free.

In a rare bipartisan breakthrough, the Senate pushed a $15 billion measure intended to spur job creation over a crucial preliminary obstacle Monday night after five Senate Republicans broke ranks to back consideration of the Democratic leadership initiative.

After a week in California wine country, thoughts turn naturally to beer. Well, of course. As the saying goes, it takes a lot of beer to make a little wine, meaning that more than a few winemaker regimens include copious amounts of beer. I doubt, though, that many winemakers are heading off after work to drink Belgian golden ales, the subject of my column this week.
General Motors is expected this week to close its sale of Saab Automobile of Sweden to Spyker Cars of the Netherlands, two executives involved with the deal told Bloomberg News.

This week, A. O. Scott looks at Roman Polanski's 1974 film noir "Chinatown." Mr. Scott calls the film, which explores corruption in 1930s Los Angeles, "much more than the sum of its parts." He says that Mr. Polanski "pushes beyond the conventions of the genre to give us a stark encounter between a powerless individual and monstrous evil." Please share your thoughts on "Chinatown."

As the Tents folded on Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week for the very last time, the race was on for a new vision of pared-down American chic. With Calvin, Isaac, Ralph, Michael and Tommy all in a heat, who came out ahead? As Scorecard can tell you, Calvin Klein's women's-wear designer Francisco Costa took his minimalist vision to the max, yet it was Michael Kors who took the gold for his streamlined yet sensual sportswear. See you at Lincoln Center -- and London!

In the always-ongoing debate about the role of religion in public life, the argument most often made on the liberal side (by which I mean the side of Classical Liberalism, not the side of left politics) is that policy decisions should be made on the basis of secular reasons, reasons that, because they do not reflect the commitments or agendas of any religion, morality or ideology, can be accepted as reasons by all citizens no matter what their individual beliefs and affiliations. So it's O.K. to argue that a proposed piece of legislation will benefit the economy, or improve the nation's health, or strengthen national security; but it's not O.K. to argue that a proposed piece of legislation should be passed because it comports with a verse from the book of Genesis or corresponds to the will of God.

My column today on the National Enquirer included two errors. One was a brain-cramp: I referred to John Ensign as a Senator from Arizona, rather than Nevada. The other was more serious: I remarked that today's media "almost seems more uncertain about when and whether to probe into politicians' private lives than it was in the days when The Miami Herald cheerfully ran a photograph of Donna Rice sitting side-saddle on Gary Hart's lap," which missed the rather important point that the photo in question first appeared in the National Enquirer. The Herald broke the story on Hart, after famously staking out his Washington townhouse. But it wasn't the first to publish the scandal's defining image. That distinction belongs (as such things often do) to the Enquirer.

Scientists recently announced that they had discovered a breeding ground for the rare warbler, a species that was last seen in 2006, Afghan Analysts Network points out.

While we're on the topic of the campaign for "Inglourious Basterds" - which, in an extra long awards season with extra few surprises, seems to be the only one with any drama, which is why everyone is talking about it - let's take a closer look at some of the promos that the mad geniuses of the Weinstein Company have been running. Saturday's New York Times featured a full-page ad in the Arts section for an exhibit of reimagined "Inglourious" movie posters, created by some street-cred-y graphic designers, autographed by Quentin Tarantino and sold to benefit earthquake relief in Haiti. Natural connection, right? "The movie that reminds you why you love movies has inspired others to create and give back," blares the ALL-CAPS copy above a series of stylized images of Hitler, screaming eagles, swastikas and Brad Pitt.

Women's figure skating, often the marquee event of the Winter Olympics, begins Tuesday with the short program. Thirty skaters will have a maximum of 2 minutes 50 seconds to deliver a routine that has eight required elements, including jumps, spins and spirals. The short-program session is from 7:30 p.m. to midnight, Eastern time. NBC will have some live coverage on the East Coast from 8 p.m. to midnight.

How can Internet users improve their searches to find reliable information? What are some ways to perform effective searches? In this lesson, students conduct Web searches on open-ended questions, and draw on their experiences to develop guides to searching effectively and finding reliable information online.

It might still be winter, but there's been a warm Italian breeze wafting through the Metropolitan Museum of Art in recent days. As part an agreement reached with the Italian government in 2006, in return for the repatriation of several antiquities from the museum's collection that were thought to have been looted, Italy has recently loaned a small trove of rare works from its own public collections.

I am teaching mergers and acquisitions this semester. In my last class, I made a particular point of highlighting the remarkable flexibility of Delaware corporate law, the law governing the majority of American public companies. Depending upon the type of consideration offered, the structure of the deal (tender offer, merger or the asset sale) or the acquiring party, different Delaware standards, voting and appraisal requirements apply.

Most online travel guides focus on the obvious -- the Eiffel Tower, say, or the Pyramids of Giza. Not Atlas Obscura. The seven-month-old Web site has the opposite goal: highlighting the oddest places the world has to offer: "places that are evocative of wonder, that provoke one's sense of curiosity and that might be under-appreciated or under-celebrated," said Joshua Foer, a co-founder of the site.

The White House, in advance of a televised summit meeting aimed at reviving revive stalled health care legislation, posted a proposal this morning that is meant to "bridge the differences," in the words of Dan Pfeiffer, White House communications director, between the House and the Senate bills. The White House basically follows the Senate bill, except that in a handful of key instances it weighs in with a Solomonic compromise. "We view this as the opening bid for the health meeting" that will be televised live this Thursday, said Mr. Pfeiffer.

One day before the debut of Pierre Audi's much anticipated new production of Verdi's "Attila" at the Metropolitan Opera, the Met  announced a substitution in one of the key roles. Carlos Álvarez, the Spanish baritone who was to sing the role of Ezio, will not perform in Tuesday night's premiere because of illness, the Met said in a news release on Monday. Taking Mr. Álvarez's place will be Giovanni Meoni, who will be making his Met debut. Mr. Meoni has sung at the Teatro la Fenice in Venice and the Teatro dell'Opera in Rome and has sung the role of Ezio in Bari, Italy, the Met said. Riccardo Muti, the former music director and conductor of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan, will be making his own Met debut with this production, as will the opera itself.

We've had a lot of quite sophisticated mathematical puzzles recently, like last week's Case of the Carnival Cups, and the Toiling Antomatons and Stashing Llamas before that. Today we go on to something different, and far grander. I must announce that I have solved all the world's problems. I've found the secret of making unlimited money with a simple scheme, and I've also figured out how to generate unlimited energy with my new invention, the papaya battery. Both these are based on the successful application of one of the deepest human principles of all time - getting something for nothing! To understand the papaya battery requires some physics, so let's consider the money solution first.

The Baftas, a.k.a. the British Oscars, should provide some cold comfort to awards-season watchers. On the one hand, "The Hurt Locker," this year's hard-charging underdog, swept the prizes on Sunday, picking up six of its eight races, including best picture, best director and best original screenplay. On the other, the British cinephiles have predicted the eventual best picture Oscar winner only three times in the nine years since their little show has been held before the Academy Awards. So as Harvey Weinstein would like to remind you, it ain't over yet for "Inglourious Basterds" (no matter how seemingly unlikely).

TAMPA, Fla. - One of my favorite quotations from last season came from the player who is the newest Yankee. Pitching for the first time in a month, Chan Ho Park retired Manny Ramirez, Matt Kemp and Casey Blake in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series at Dodger Stadium. Asked afterward when the last time he pitched that well was, Park replied, "An hour and 20 minutes ago."

Before he was the creative director and founder of Acne, Jonny Johansson knocked around as a musician. So it's no surprise that the Swedish fashion label's first furniture collection takes its cues from the place where music and fashion meet: the remix. Take the Nya Berlin, a 1920s sofa designed for that city's Swedish embassy by the modernist Carl Malmsten. Johansson stretched and contorted the sofa's no-nonsense curves to arrive at five new variations, built in the south of Sweden and upholstered in cupcake shades of denim. Johansson says of his latest release: "I have all these architect and designer friends who are inspired by fashion. I thought, Why not look at it the other way around?"
For the newspapers of Phildelphia, Monday is a not-so-happy anniversary, one year after The Daily News, The Inquirer and philly.com all asked for bankruptcy protection.

In a previous post, and an article last year, The New York Times examined the question of how Taliban fighters obtain their small-arms ammunition. The limited data available - gleaned from captured Taliban weapons and magazines, or from spent casings collected from Taliban firing positions after firefights - pointed to Afghan security forces as a significant source.

A California Animal Abuser Registry | A proposal to create an online registry of animal abusers, complete with home addresses and places of work, was introduced last week in the State Senate by Dean Florez, the majority leader. It would be the first of its kind in the country. "We know there's a link between those who abuse animals and those who perform other forms of violence," said Stephan Otto, the director of legislative affairs of the Animal Legal Defense Fund, a group that helped to draft the bill. "Presumably if we're able to track animal abusers and be able to know where they live, there will be less opportunity where those vulnerable to them would be near them." [The New York Times]

The International Monetary Fund has long preached the virtues of keeping inflation low and allowing money to flow freely across international boundaries. But two recent research papers by economists at the fund have questioned the soundness of that advice, arguing that slightly higher inflation and restrictions on capital flows can sometimes help buffer countries from financial turmoil, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

New York City's freshly elected comptroller, John Liu, announced this week what he called major reforms in the way the city's pension fund works. He offered several good ideas, particularly his decision not to accept political contributions from anybody doing business with the city's $100 billion pension fund, The New York Times's editorial board says. DYMANT--Zofia, nee Benet, died on February 19, 2010, at age 86, in Rye, New York. She was born in Brzeziny, Poland on March 3, 1923, and was a teenager when the war began and she was forced to move to the ghetto in a nearby town. She was able to escape to Warsaw in 1942 with false identity papers that allowed her to pass as a Christian. She was an avid art and music lover, a lifelong learner, a supporter of many charities, and a cherished member of the Harrison Jewish Community Center for over 30 years. Her beloved husband Jan died in 1986. She is survived by her daughter Anita and son-in-law Richard Drooyan, of Sherman Oaks, California, son Michael of Briarcliff Manor, and four grandchildren. Funeral services at Harrison JCC on February 22, 2010 at 10am. Donations in her memory may be made to FIDV, 1133 Broadway, Suite 232, New York, NY 10010.

HEALTH care reform should have two critical goals: reducing costs and covering more people. To meet them, Democrats and Republicans must abandon simplistic, ideologically driven proposals that animate each party's base. Liberals cannot insist on Medicare for all, and conservatives cannot insist on markets for all, plus tort reform. Neither approach will work. Medicare is an inherently inflationary fee-for-service system that rewards volume, not value. Market-based strategies cannot cover the uninsured or prevent some insurance companies from covering only healthy Americans.

Watching and surfing, surfing and watching: a substantial number of viewers who tuned in to the opening ceremony for the Olympic Winter Games on Feb. 12 spent time on their computers, too. According to Nielsen, 13 percent of viewers went online during the four-hour event on NBC. Facebook had the largest share, followed by Google, Yahoo, AOL and MSN, obvious sources of search, e-mail and news. The broadcast viewers who went online each browsed for an average of 32 minutes. COOK--Joe, whose list of accomplishments include writing the original pilot scripts of the Flintstones, died Friday in Mineola, NY. He started in broadcasting as the 1st heart-throb teen disc jockey in mid-west for KDAL radio, Duluth, MN. Joined KSTP-TV, Minneapolis in 1948 and in 1954 moved to NBC in NYC where he wrote/produced NBC's Monitor with Bob and Ray and NBC Bandstand with Bert Parks, Skitch Henderson and Doc Severinsen. Co-wrote Perry Como Summer Show with Andy Rooney and Alan Sherman starring Tony Bennett. Wrote over 500 Reasoner Report essays for ABC anchor Harry Reasoner (Writer's Guild of America Award). Great Space Coaster (Peabody Award), and first two episodes of the The Flintstones, originally Flagstones, for Hanna-Barbera (Fred named for his father-in-law and Wilma, his local PTA president). Head writer on ABC's AM America (precursor for GMA), and NBC's Miss America Pageant (1980-1988), and stage version of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs at Radio City. In later years, wrote and produced "Two Minutes with Joe Cook" on News 12 Long Island and Christmas Tree Lighting at EAB Plaza (1987-2008). Resident of Floral Park, NY over 50 years and survived by three children, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral services, February 22 and 23, Thomas F. Dalton, Floral Park.

PRESIDENT OBAMA, Harry Reid and Nancy Pelosi have failed at health care reform. They have failed because they fundamentally don't believe in markets, incentives and the power of hundreds of millions of people to make smart choices about their health. It's just not in the Democratic leaders' DNA. Transforming health care to slow the growth of spending requires a radical restructuring of how health services are paid for. The most powerful way to reduce costs (and make room to expand coverage) is to shift away from ''volume-based'' reimbursement (the more you do, the more money you make) to ''value-based'' reimbursement.

WHEN Americans think about health care, they think first of health, not finance. They go to the doctor to get well, not to show off their government-issued insurance card. So President Obama's health care reform plan was doomed from the moment the American people figured out that his goal was to spend less on health care. While the president's idea of ''bending the curve'' on health care means cuts in Medicare, to the American people bending the curve means living better and longer. To the folks on Main Street, it means not appointing Kafkaesque committees to measure ''quality-adjusted life years'' but fostering a vibrant climate of scientific research and opening a wider pipeline for new medicines.

JACK ROSE ''Luck in the Valley'' (Thrill Jockey) A lot of people were blindsided when Jack Rose died in December, apparently of a heart attack, at 38. With his richly resonant acoustic guitar playing on an outpouring of small-batch recordings, Mr. Rose had spent the last decade refining a contemporary take on old-time traditions. He was often heralded as the John Fahey of his generation, and if that commendation felt the slightest bit premature, he seemed on his way to earning it.

Andre Lange of Germany became the most decorated bobsled pilot in Olympic history, winning his fourth gold medal in the two-man event Sunday at the Whistler Sliding Centre. Lange and his brakeman, Kevin Kuske, finished their four runs in 3 minutes 26.65 seconds, 0.22 of a second ahead of the bobsled steered by his countryman Thomas Florschuetz. The Russian Alexsandr Zubkov (3:27.51) won the bronze, capturing the country's first medal in the two-man event.

Magazine editor, remedial reading specialist. Ardent lover of the city. JOANNA NEWSOM ''Have One on Me'' (Drag City) Maybe it's preposterous to suggest that Joanna Newsom's three-CD, two-hour album, ''Have One on Me,'' is in any way stripped down. Along the way its songs deploy horns and strings, electric guitar and African and Balkan instruments alongside Ms. Newsom's own harp and piano. The title song, which muses on the international intrigues and inner desires of the 19th-century courtesan Lola Montez, runs 11 minutes. Yet there's good reason for both the length of the album and its occasional lavish moments. Ms. Newsom has discovered how to open up her music: to let it whisper and swell, to be swept into the purely musical pleasures of an ingenious arrangement or to let simplicity and silence speak for her.

BREEN--Marion I.,died on February 2, 2010 in New York City. She was 96. Marion was born in Chicago on November 14, 1913 to Cornelius and Kathryn (Vander Starr) Breen. Marion graduated from Northwestern University with honors in 1935. Following graduation she was employed by Bell and Zoller Coal Company working her way up to Advertising Manager. She moved to New York in 1947 to be the personal secretary of CV Starr who was the founder of American Underwriters Insurance a forerunner of AIG. After Mr. Starr's death in 1968 she was an officer of The Starr Foundation and an honorary director until the time of her death. She had a tremendous love of the arts and music frequenting the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic as a patron. Marion was a long-time and faithful member of Marble Collegiate Church. Through her generosity and kind spirit she touched the lives of many people and organizations. She was predeceased by her brother, Cornelius who died at birth, and sister, Janet and Janet's husband, Lester and their older son, The Rev. Brian Helge. She is survived by her nephew, The Rev. Mark P. Helge and his wife, Kathleen and their sons, Andrew and Joel. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, February 25 at 2pm at Marble Collegiate Church on Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Marble Collegiate Church or the Recording for the Blind and Dyslexic.

After years of performing and teaching she founded New York International Ballet Competition and served as its Executive Director and soul for 25 years. She is survived by her loving family: mother, Frieda Zucker; husband of 51 years, James A. Goldstein; son, Seth; daughter and son-in-law, Robin and Jeff Fontaine; and grandchildren, Ella, Noah, Paley, and Isaac. She also leaves behind a large extended family and abundant friends who will miss her greatly. Funeral services: Monday, February 22, at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to NYIBC, Inc.

COPEN--Ilona. The board, staff and volunteers of the New York International Ballet Competition mourn the death of our inspirational founding Executive Director, Ilona Copen. Over the past 25 years, Ms. Copen profoundly changed the lives of young ballet dancers from all over the world. Her guiding principle was to develop each dancer's potential through education and coaching. Ms. Copen's approach to the advancement of dance as an art form combined with her generous nature made her a moving force in the creation and operation of the World Dance Alliance and the International Dance Committee of the International Theater Institute-UNESCO. Always reaching out with an open heart and a helping hand she built life-long relationships in and out of the dance world. We celebrate her immense talent and capacity to galvanize people into action. Her passion, leadership, and warmth will be deeply missed.

REPUBLICANS can't and won't accept a simple combination of the Democratic health care bills that passed the House and Senate. But the country needs health care reform, and Republicans must engage in the process. They should insist on adding reforms that would do more to reduce costs, in order to avoid higher income, payroll or similar taxes. (These taxes are different from the proposed excise tax on high-cost health insurance, which would actually reduce health-care spending.) Further cost-saving reforms could include meaningful changes in medical liability law; better opportunities for people to save money when they take steps to lower their health care costs; and Medicare savings from greater use of competitive bidding.

The après-ski crowd clumps into the 19th Hole bar at Mad River Barn in Waitsfield, Vt., red-cheeked from afternoon runs and shedding all manner of performance plumage. Nearly everyone in the place is holding a beer glass. Behind the bar is a single tap. But if you're from the area, that tap speaks volumes. It is the Single Chair Ale, a locals-only secret that Magic Hat Brewery has been producing for 15 years, ever since Mad River Glen Ski Area became a nonprofit cooperative. People up here tend to do things their own way, and such is the case with both the ski co-op and the beer, which is addictively quaffable yet only selectively available - and only on tap. Due to the liaison, what could be just another quirky regional brew became a celebrated cause and has long since nestled comfortably into a niche as a destination beer.

The Eagles released running back Brian Westbrook on Tuesday. Westbrook, a versatile veteran, has battled injuries in recent years, including two concussions. John DeLucie, the executive chef and a partner at The Waverly Inn in Greenwich Village, will wear a second toque come spring, when he opens The Lion, a new restaurant in the space on West Ninth Street that was Village. Through his publicist, Mr. DeLucie said that he has no plans to leave The Waverly Inn, apart from a brief hiatus of several weeks while he gets The Lion up and running.

On Sunday evening, 16 people gathered in a cramped Lower East Side storefront for a class on making irrational decisions. One woman was between jobs and apartments and wanted help thinking things through; the artist sitting next to her wanted to shut off the part of her brain that impedes creative thinking. No money changed hands. Instead, the teacher asked everyone to "pay" for the class by bringing ideas -- an example of a good decision made in the last two weeks, and one made in the last five years.

TAMPA, Fla. -- There are usually so many ancillary issues surrounding the Yankees that one of General Manager Brian Cashman's favorite (and more optimistic) sayings -- "Camp Quiet" -- goes unspoken. What passes for noise around these parts (aside from Nick Swisher) is the contract status of Joe Girardi, Mariano Rivera and Derek Jeter, who on Wednesday morning will address the non-issue for the first and only time this season.

In its March issue, National Geographic Traveler ranks the most bike-friendly cities in the United States for visitors. Topping the list, predictably, is Portland, Ore., which boasts dozens of bike rental shops, 75 miles of bike paths and guided bike tours along its waterfront and nearby gorges.

The fashion world's favorite new parlor game - watching "The September Issue," R.J. Cutler's hilarious documentary about the making of Vogue's bumper 2007 issue - just got even more entertaining. You might think it would be hard to be an inflation hawk, demanding monetary tightening now now now, in the current environment. For one thing, there's no inflation. And there's also mass unemployment. Based on historic Fed behavior, the combination of these two factors should mean a Fed funds rate of around -6 percent; since the Fed can't do that, it ought at least to keep rates near zero for a long time, probably at least the next two years.

Overview | How does the way Congress was designed to function differ from how it actually operates? How do bills really become laws? What factors contribute to Congressional gridlock? In this lesson, students chart the basic process of how a bill becomes a law, and then consider Senator Evan Bayh's criticisms of the Senate. They then dig into a current piece of legislation and create a detailed flow chart showing the complexity of the real process. Finally, they create "political trees" for members of Congress, showing key relationships, connections and interests.

A fire broke out on Sunday morning at Philadelphia International Records, where Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff perfected the "Philadelphia sound" of smooth R&B for singers like Teddy Pendergrass and Patti LaBelle, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The fire swept through the label's office area, melting gold and platinum records and destroying much of its memorabilia, but it spared the historic studio and the label's tape library, according to the newspaper.

This month's decision by the Morgan Library & Museum to lift restrictions on a cache of letters, written by the reclusive author J.D. Salinger to his longtime friend, Mike Mitchell, has Salinger fans clamoring for a peek. (Mr. Salinger died in January.) When the choreographer Mark Morris is not rehearsing his company, the Mark Morris Dance Group, or creating works for ballet or opera houses, he can often be found eating, both at home and in restaurants around the world, including those of his fellow Washington State native, the celebrity chef Mario Batali. Since the two met 10 years ago, they have become fans of each other's work. Over a boozy dinner at Mr. Batali's Del Posto in Chelsea, they talked about art and ice skating, the work of their colleagues, Michelle Obama and much more, often in language too blue for a family newspaper. They will continue the conversation in a discussion at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday at 6 p.m. as part of the Morris company's engagement there, which will include the world premiere of "Socrates" tonight. In the year since we released the Congress API, we've learned a lot from how people have used it and from general reactions. We're proud that various developers have used it to help build Web sites and Facebook and mobile applications, while others have created libraries for Ruby, Python and R (among others) for interacting with the API. Virginia Grise, a writer, performer and teacher, has won the Yale Drama Series $10,000 playwriting prize for "blu,"  a work about how a Mexican-American family copes with the death of its eldest son, a soldier in Iraq. The English playwright David Hare, who chose Ms. Grise's drama out of 960 submissions, said in the announcement of the award that, "Virginia Grise's writing is blazingly talented and resonant and the play stays with you long after you've read it." The prize, which is  jointly sponsored by Yale University Press and Yale Repertory Theater and funded by the David C. Horn Foundation, also means that "blu" will be published and will have a reading at Yale. The runners-up are "Siona MacDuff" by Mary Hamilton and  "Nineteen Kinds of Peril" by Tom Lavignino.

Trent Kowalik, one of three actors to win the Tony Award for his performance as the title character in "Billy Elliot: The Musical," will leave the show after his March 7 performance, its publicists said on Tuesday. It's the literary showdown that readers have been clamoring for: in one corner, Barbara Kingsolver, author of "The Lacuna," the best-selling 2009 novel about art, McCarthyism, and post-World War II America; in the opposing corner, Lorrie Moore, author of last year's widely praised post-9/11 novel "A Gate at the Stairs." And in the three remaining corners of this five-cornered ring, the authors Sherman Alexie ("War Dances"); Colson Whitehead ("Sag Harbor"); and Lorraine M. López ("Homicide Survivors Picnic and Other Stories"). These are the five finalists for the 2010 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, its organizers announced on Tuesday. They were selected from nearly 350 submissions by more than 90 publishers. The winner, to be announced in a ceremony on March 23, will receive a $15,000 prize; the four runners-up receive $5,000 each.

A further note in the same vein as my last post on this subject: When Reihan Salam and I co-authored Grand New Party, our book about conservative domestic policy, we didn't spend a lot of time talking about entitlements. That's because we felt that the Republican Party had roughly the right ideas on Medicare and Social Security: Some combination of means-testing and raising the retirement age, presumably, to keep the programs from swallowing the budget in the short run, with a shift toward a voucherized system as the long-term (though possibly unachievable) goal for Medicare reform. Essentially, our view was that the G.O.P. needed to think much more creatively about discretionary spending, with a particular eye toward the challenges facing working class families, while continuing to take a pretty firm limited-government line on the question of how big we should allow our entitlement system to get.

But he signed a long-term deal with the Yankees, and for the first time in three years, Teixeira has continuity.

If fashion is all about performance, then Chantal Thomass is a master player. Anyone familiar with the French designer instantly associates her with blunt-cut jet fringed hair, crimsonlips and a strict black and white wardrobe with an enticing bit of lingerie coyly on display. There may or may not be a corset in the mix, and a satin whip or feathered tickler might be tucked away somewhere in a tufted boudoir. The look is equal parts dominatrix and "I can have it all" workingwoman.

"What day is today?" Mark Boal asked the Bagger in a late-night phone call from London. It was Monday, and Mr. Boal had arrived in London on Sunday, just in the nick of time to receive his Bafta award for best original screenplay for "The Hurt Locker," less than 24 hours after receiving an award in the same category from the Writers Guild of America in Los Angeles. We know: tough life.

I've been surprised at the blitheness with which liberal health care writers have greeted the White House's proposal to postpone the excise tax on high-value health care plans till 2018 - eight years and a political eternity away. "There's not a lot of policy news in the president's new health-care plan," writes Ezra Klein, adding that "the real story of the bill is as it's always been." Jonathan Cohn digs into the excise tax issue a bit more, but concludes that the change is cosmetic: "It doesn't mean sacrificing the tax's projected ability to control costs, which is what economists, including the ones who work at the Congressional Budget Office, care about."
Brad looks at John Cochrane asserting that fiscal expansion does nothing but shift money around, and tries to figure out Cochrane's model. It's a hopeless quest.

I've been scanning the London shows and reading the reviews before I head downtown this morning to watch Burberry's live stream in 3-D, and it's plain, as Sarah Mower noted in her review of the Central Saint Martins M.A. show, that the female silhouette is being revisualized. If some of the shapes in the Saint Martins show had not been so effective - one student's renderings of jackets and bottoms were so flat as to appear perfectly steamrolled - you might have been tempted to dismiss the work as fascinating experiments. But with computer programs reshaping design, with fabrics able to hold forms or seemingly mutate, the clothes don't elicit ordinary responses.

"I do this very old-fashioned thing," the choreographer Lar Lubovitch said in a recent interview. "I design the music visually." In honor of his company's two-week engagement at the Joyce Theater, beginning tonight, Mr. Lubovitch has returned to his roots with a premiere, "Coltrane's Favorite Things," the final dance in an all-jazz program. "For the Coltrane piece," Gia Kourlas writes, "Mr. Lubovitch found inspiration in a 1963 live recording from a Copenhagen performance of the saxophonist's effervescent interpretation of Richard Rodgers's 'My Favorite Things.' " "I've known the piece of music for a long time," Mr. Lubovitch said. "It was only recently that I felt I could manage it. I like to imagine that I am not doing anything that's exactly to the music. I'm trying to write the visual line of the score that capitulates to everything but doesn't copy it." Mr. Lubovitch never studied jazz dance, but jazz is where he feels at home; the sound, as he put it, "assaults my solar plexus and causes a response in the rest of my body."

You may have just missed the Berlin Film Festival, which ended Sunday, but you can still feel like a jet-setting movie star without leaving the city by paying a visit to Film Comment Select. The program, hosted by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and running through March 4, "offers a chance to sample a kind of tasting menu of the festival circuit," writes A.O. Scott. The series at the Walter Reade "seems committed above all to being interesting and to calling the attention of the cognoscenti and the merely curious to movies they might otherwise have missed." Tonight, go to see "Be Good," Juliette Garcias's directorial debut about a woman with a false identity married to a man in a rural French village.
